PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Senate to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn baby.
That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
That in 1989/90 alone Medicare subsidised 69,587 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to subsidise abortions through Medicare by passing the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill is intended to equip each House of Parliament to exercise more effectively its rights of control and supervision of delegated legislation.

With the proliferation of executive activity in the area of delegated legislation, legislative activity which binds the lives of all Australians in so many ways is becoming increasingly complex and having the potential for avoiding ready parliamentary scrutiny. In addition, the form in which delegated legislation is presented to the Parliament is often such that the Parliament must exercise only a take it or leave it choice. The measures in this Bill will overcome these problems.

The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has closely monitored the development of delegated legislation. The Committee is an acknowledged authority on the principles of delegated legislation. It is respected by all sides of this Chamber for its work relating to specific regulations and to principles of delegated legislation. In its reports, it has consistently reported on the need for the reform of certain aspects of delegated legislation.

In its March 1982 report, on the fiftieth anniversary of the Committee, it referred to the advantages of having delegated legislation examined in draft form before it is made. The Committee observed in that report that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) favoured the notion of issuing delegated legislation in draft. The Committee reported further on its discussions with the Attorney-General as follows:

The Government has frequently adopted on an ad hoc basis the practice of exposing new regulatory legislation to obtain public comment prior to enactment by Parliament . . . he concluded that, in principle, there are no reasons why a similar approach could not be pursued in relation to delegated legislation.

The important proviso which the Attorney-General made was that, naturally, procedures would be required to enable urgent measures to be dealt with. The Attorney-General concluded his comments on the matter by requesting that the Committee forward any suggestions which it might have in relation to the matter. The Committee went on to recommend that delegated legislation in draft form be made available for consideration and comment prior to its being made.
The Bill before the Senate will so provide.

I come now to the important principle of partial disallowance of delegated legislation. This matter has been considered at length and has often been reported on by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. In its Seventy-third Report of December 1982 the Committee referred to discussions in which the-

Attorney-General put forward a proposal that the power accorded to each House of Parliament under the Acts Interpretation Act to disallow regulations and other instruments be extended to include power to disallow part of a regulation or instrument rather than the entire regulation or instrument, as at present. The Committee warmly endorses the suggestion, and looks forward to an amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act . . .
The Chairman of the Committee, Senator Cooney, stated in this place in October 1986 that-

sometimes a single regulation contains many detailed sub-regulations. Part only of these provisions may infringe the Committee's principles. Indeed, a single clause only may be the sole objectionable part of the provisions. In these cases, a lack of a power to disallow part only of an instrument is an unacceptable flaw in the disallowance procedure. The Senate has to assess the merit of removing a number of good provisions in order to overcome a single bad provision. This flaw should be remedied as a matter of priority.
In its 1987 report, the Committee again raised the matter in the following terms-

With the increasing complexity of modern government a single amending regulation can often be long and detailed. Should one part of that amendment not meet with the approval of Parliament, a successful disallowance motion would obliterate the entire provision.

In this context, the Federal Court decision in Borthwick's Case in 1989 confirmed the power of each House to disallow discrete, individual regulations contained within a single, numbered paragraph of an instrument. Nevertheless, the power to disallow parts of an instrument is lacking.

The power of partial disallowance has been available since 1957 in relation to parts of ACT ordinances, yet the right to partially disallow a federal regulation is not yet available to the Federal Parliament. It is essential that this power be exercised by the Federal Parliament and this Bill will provide for that. Following acceptance of this Bill, the Parliament will be able to exercise a considered control and authority over delegated legislation rather than the take it or leave it choice with which it is presented at present.This Bill will overcome the problems arising from what the current Committee on Regulations and Ordinances described as an unacceptable flaw requiring remedy as a matter of priority.

I come now to the retrospective operation of regulations. The prohibition on the prejudicial retrospectivity of regulations contained in sub-section 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 was interpreted by the High Court in 1942 as applying only to express retrospectivity and not to retrospective effect. This reading down of the provision must now be corrected. The Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has expressed its concerns about this matter in its reports. In its Eightieth Report for example in 1987, the Committee again set out sound reasons why the retrospective operation of regulations should be avoided. It noted that-

because of the complexity of the modern regulatory environment, it is not realistic to outlaw all retrospectivity in delegated legislation. However, it should be possible, and it is certainly preferable, to legislate to prohibit regulatory retrospectivity which is prejudicial to the rights of individuals unless this is expressly authorised by statute.

The Committee then went on to again repeat its recommendations and urged the Attorney-General to amend sub-section 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act to remove the possibility of the retrospective operation of regulations.

The above measures will improve parliamentary and public scrutiny of delegated legislation and provide the Senate with greater authority to exercise its rights of control and supervision of delegated legislation and I therefore commend this Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES BILL 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 be referred immediately, that is, before the Bill is read a second time, to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, for inquiry and report on or before 13 August 1991.

The purpose of this motion is to allow the outrageous and draconian Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill to be properly considered by the Senate. In the House of Representatives we had the disgraceful experience of seeing this legislation guillotined through after less than four and a half hours of debate. Previously it was expected that this Bill would be debated in the Senate at this time. However, it has been postponed to the Budget Session. This would seem to me to be an opportunity for those hundreds of people who have written in, expressing outrage at this ban on political advertising, to come before a Senate committee to give their evidence so that a proper evaluation can be made.

For the benefit of all Australians, and this is not entirely recognised through the community, I should explain that this Bill would have the effect of banning from the air waves for all time advertisements containing any political reference whatever, to Federal, State or local government. It would also mean that politicians and interest groups would have no opportunity to present their messages or appeal for funds directly to the Australian public, but will have their messages filtered through the press gallery or current affairs programs.

I know that the Australian Democrats have taken a view that that part of the Bill will not survive because they support us. In fact, they do not support us. Our view is that we are totally opposed to the ban in any shape or form; the Democrats have taken the view that they are opposed to a total ban. There is a vast difference between those two views, because being opposed to a total ban means that the Democrats want some watered down provision with very stringent regulations.

If this Bill, which would implement an unprecedented denial of freedom of speech, is to have any proper scrutiny at all, then it is essential for an all-party committee to allow the people of Australia to be heard. The referral to the Standing Committee would give them this opportunity-an opportunity that they will not get unless we take advantage of the winter recess to refer the matter to a committee.

There has been a ground well of community outrage against the Government's proposal, and my office has been flooded with calls from groups and individuals protesting against the ban. I have not yet shown this to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), but I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of the people who have communicated with us.

TALK.START.PARA: —A referral of the Bill to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs would allow all its implications to be fully considered. Matters which call for investigation include the following. They would include the Bill's effect on freedom of expression, particularly freedom of political expression; the conflict between the Bill and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights; the constitutional power of the Commonwealth to prohibit the broadcast of advertisements containing references to State and/or local political issues. They would also include ensuring equitable treatment of all donors to any political party; and whether there is adequate protection from intimidation for those groups of individuals making donations. I do not mean just intimidation after a disclosure has been made, but the coercion that we have all heard about at WA Inc. in forcing people to make donations for political favours. Another matter that could be investigated is the question whether there are sufficient penalties provided to prevent political donations being extracted by coercion.

SPEECH.PARA: All these interests, including members of the general public, have a right to have their views considered by the Senate. Unless the Standing Committee is given a reference today, there may well be no time available for this process of consultation to occur. We trust that this reference will meet with support from all parties in the Senate, and we particularly hope that the Democrats will be willing to allow this degree of public participation in the law making process. If they agree with us that this legislation is not fit for passage by the Senate, then the most logical course is for the Standing Committee to be given the opportunity to properly scrutinise it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this motion. We do so because of a number of reasons, and I will take a few moments to explain them. It is quite apparent to us that this is a deferral action in the classic way that Liberal governments in this country have approached issues such as this. We are talking here not only about going very much to the core of our electoral process and the way in which parties are funded, but also as to how transparent that funding process is. This also goes to the question of the costs of campaigning.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some basic points that need to be taken into account when one considers what has been proposed by the Opposition. This matter has not been raised in a vacuum. It has been raised at the conclusion of a long and exhaustive process of discussion in this Parliament. We have had a parliamentary committee, namely the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which has looked at the twin problems of the costs of campaigning as well as disclosure provisions. In respect to the latter the Committee has come up with a whole series of proposals which evidence the fact that the disclosure provisions that are now in place are really a farce. That was the one conclusion that one can draw from that Committee's report. It came up with a series of proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you frightened of the Committee?

—Senator Parer can throw around whatever allegations he likes; I am not going to respond to him. I will treat him with the same contempt with which he handles truth in this place. I will concentrate on this issue.
—Order! Senator Parer was heard in silence and the Minister should also be heard in silence.
—The Government's proposal comes by way of a response to that Committee report.
—I raise a point of order.
—It had better be a point of order.
—I do not accept that instruction, Mr Deputy President. I am taking a point of order.
—What is your point of order?
—I ask you to withdraw that comment.
—I shall not. What is your point of order?

—My point of order is that it is improper to describe any member of the Opposition or indeed any member of this place as being someone who should be treated with contempt. I therefore ask the Minister to withdraw his comment.
—There is no point of order.

—The basic point is that the proposals embodied in this legislation are a response to that Committee's report. It is a committee which exhaustively assessed this issue and came up with recommendations in respect of both areas under contemplation. In respect of that most important area of disclosure, it made a number of specific recommendations. They are the recommendations which are in substantial part embodied in the Government's legislation. The matter has been exhaustively assessed in respect of that.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the other aspect of the legislation-the question of costs of campaigning and how we tackle that-the Government has responded in two ways. We have done so in respect of the level of public funding and in respect of the costs of electronic campaigning. Our response is different to that of the Committee. The issue was discussed by the Committee and the Committee has come up with a proposal for free time, to which the Government has spelt out why it has rejected it.

It is quite apparent-and we can read numbers-that the Government's total proposal will not get through the Senate. I still believe that it is the best and fairest way to go, and I will continue to believe that. The reality is that in respect of both legs of the Bill the matter has been exhaustively assessed and the Government is responding to a parliamentary committee report.

Opposition senators have asked that we go through another parliamentary committee process. They do so knowing that the path that they claim to object to-namely, the advertising ban-will not in its totality get through this place. They do so for another reason, which I believe is the most important reason-it is insidious and it is one that they will not admit to publicly because they know they have absolutely no right on their side in respect of that-and that is the proposal about deferring the introduction of disclosure provisions.

We have seen this procedure applied elsewhere. A number of years ago, Mr Greiner promised disclosure legislation in New South Wales. In doing so, he made it very clear that he would not send the proposal off to another parliamentary committee on the never-never. But that is precisely what he finally finished up doing. Why? Because the conservatives, the Liberal and National parties, in this place and in every other Parliament in this Commonwealth have consistently-and the record shows it very starkly-run away from full disclosure.

This Government's proposal is to make as transparent as possible the disclosure provisions in this country. No degree of misinformation or distortion from the Opposition about what the Government's proposal is all about will conceal that fact.

I do not need to speak much longer other than to say that we and the community are concerned to ensure that the funding of the political process in this country is both clean and transparent. We will not tolerate any further delay. We will not defer it and put it on the never-never, as the Opposition would love us to. We will not bow to pressures from the brown paper bag brigade from Queensland or those who run the Liberal Party. I will not go through the whole litany of quotes that I can put to the Senate in terms of Liberal Party opposition to disclosure.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a disgrace.

—From Senator O'Chee, that is a great reference. The basic point is that this legislation is in response to a parliamentary committee report. To send it off to another parliamentary committee would put it on the never-never, and we will not tolerate that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal of Senator Parer is to send the aspect of political broadcasts in the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for report back to the Senate when we reconvene for the Budget session. I thought that was necessary to say since the Senate has so recently been in some turmoil with the political parties, whose massive and questionable slush funds match each other, irrespective of whether it is the brown paper bags or black briefcases. That is what is we are debating.

SPEECH.PARA: The actual proposal is to send off to a committee legislation which we already know will not pass in anything like the form that it is in before this chamber. Since April this year, the Government has known that the proposal in the legislation for a blanket ban on political advertising in the electronic media that the Opposition says is its major concern is not on. Today we have the Opposition proposing that through the recess the resources of the parliamentary committee, the general public who might be called before it, and the politicians involved should be engaged in an exercise in absolute futility.

Certainly we agree with the Opposition, as we have said publicly, that the Government's proposal to eliminate electronic advertising of political matter is unacceptable. We agree with the Opposition. I do not know whether that constitutes doing a deal with the Opposition, but we agree with the Opposition. Those aspects of the Bill will not pass. Therefore, we will not send that significant part of the legislation off to a Senate committee. The Australian Democrats are quite clear on disclosure and have been since our formation in 1977. We support it and will support those aspects of the Bill with amendment to make it even tighter, if we believe that is necessary.

What the Democrats believe should be done during this parliamentary recess, and what is being done by us, is that amendments to address the questions which this Bill raises-the questions of political party funding, the costs and effectiveness of election campaigning, and amendments to bring a better piece of legislation out of the process in the Parliament-should be put together, circulated, discussed and negotiated. That is the work that should be done in the recess, not a mechanism which would hold up that process. It is work that will bring us to addressing those very real concerns which we share with the Government-the costs of campaigning and the process of political party funding in this country. Those are issues of concern to the Democrats. We welcome this legislation because it provides us with a vehicle, firstly, to call the political parties and their backers to account, which will happen through the disclosure provisions, and, secondly, to regulate in the area of political advertising.

Our priority is amendments which we have had before this place previously-most recently in May last year via former Senator Macklin-to introduce truth in advertising. At the moment, the Electoral Act is a licence to lie. We will put those amendments forward.

We have also announced publicly that we want to regulate in the area of advertising to insist that political advertisements are informative and not just ad agency hype, which not only gobbles up money but also does not give any information to the voters. Our amendments will require a talking heads process. We will get those amendments before the political parties, the public and the people who have written to us, and we will discuss them and make comment. When we return here in August, we will be ready to discuss and debate that legislation.

I am very happy if Senator Parer and his colleagues want to do a deal with the Democrats on this matter, just as we have done, for instance, on the Comcare legislation. Does he remember how we sat together and removed the age discrimination provisions from Comcare not two days ago? Was that a deal? No, we negotiated, we agreed and we voted together.

What about the wool tax? We have brought that down between us to 10 per cent. Was that a deal? No, we negotiated, we voted, we sat together and we improved that legislation. What about Telecom? The Opposition and the Democrats removed the Government's ability to charge $1m to Telecom. Was that a deal? As far as I am concerned, it was not. We did that because we disagreed about the legislation; nevertheless, we did it. If we sit together on our amendments to this legislation, I will be perfectly happy, and if we sit together on some of the Opposition's amendments to this legislation I will be perfectly happy. But we have to get on with the job. The Opposition it trying to whip up a public furore. Members of the Press Gallery could not be more bored when one tells them what this exercise is-an exercise in absolute futility and, even worse, an exercise in the waste of public money.

We will not support this motion. We will get on with the job and we will get this legislation passed in a form which will benefit the electoral process in this country as early as we possibly can in August. We regret that the Senate has dragged its heels for so long and that we have not had a chance to get it through before now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say in response to the comments of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) that when the Minister does not have an answer it is his style to become personal, abusive and intimidatory in his comments. That is what he did today. There was not a rebuttal of the motion put forward by Senator Parer. In addition to that, I say to the Minister that the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill has not been to a committee yet. That point ought to be made.

—Mr Deputy President, I seek your guidance on a point of order. I will not canvass what I said in my speech. Obviously, I refute the allegations of intimidation, but is the allegation of intimidation unparliamentary? If so, I ask for it to be withdrawn.

—I am sorry, Senator Bolkus; I was distracted because I was trying to follow up a matter that occurred earlier in the chamber. Can you indicate to me the words you are objecting to and are seeking a ruling on?
—The accusation was that I was trying to intimidate members of parliament. That sort of allegation may very well be unparliamentary, but I seek your guidance on that.

—I do not think it is the sort of allegation that should be made, but because I did not hear it clearly I will not take any action at this stage. I will listen as carefully as I can while trying to follow up this other matter.

—The point I want to make clearly is that this legislation has not been to a committee, despite the comments of the Minister. He is talking about a committee looking at the subject area of the past-not a committee looking at the legislation currently before the Senate chamber. In relation to Senator Powell's suggestion that this is an exercise in futility, is it an exercise in futility to give the public the opportunity to express a point of view about legislation that is crucial? It will not hold up the Bill by a day. That is the other point that ought to be made. This process will not hold up this legislation at all.

SPEECH.PARA: All we ask is that the voice of the people be able to be heard on this legislation. Each of us in this chamber, by our vote, will be indicating to all Australians the worth of their right to express an opinion on a piece of controversial legislation-not just any piece of legislation, but legislation which, more than any other legislation that has been introduced in an Australian Parliament, in effect makes a mockery of the value that we ought to be placing on democracy. Some might say that that is an emotive term, but how else do we describe legislation which has been reviled by the Human Rights Commissioner; which breaches the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights; which is authoritarian and which acts as a restriction on the right of free speech; and which leaves more than one million illiterate with no way of exercising their right to informed political choice? That is what we are talking about in the legislation currently before this chamber.

Given that, I believe that there is no choice at all. If we believe in democracy, if we believe in free speech-which is the first and vital component of democracy-then we can only say yes to the resolution put forward by Senator Parer. We can only say yes to allowing debate which will, I hope, ultimately have this legislation referred a committee so that concerned groups and individuals can express a point of view. To refuse that right, that option, is to vote against democratic rights, freedom of speech and democratic government. How else would one describe refusing the right of the Law Council of Australia to put a point of view? And should it not be putting that point of view at this stage of the process, not at the end of the process when the Bill has passed through this chamber?

We want the opportunity for community groups to look at the original Bill so that the amendments that Senator Powell talks about can be considered by this chamber through a process by which the legislation passes before the chamber. We send far less controversial and far less contentious legislation off to committees and the public for scrutiny on almost a daily basis-and so it should be, so that the public and interest groups have an opportunity to put a point of view on the legislative direction of this country.

Why in this instance, on such an important piece of legislation, should we deny the right for that opportunity to be passed on to various groups within the community? Some have said that this would place an extra burden on a committee in the recess, that some people have perhaps made other arrangements for the recess. There is the other point of view, which was expressed in no uncertain terms, that proposed amendments will suffice and listening to the people is seemingly a waste of time. That is what Senator Powell said in her speech just a moment ago. Oh, for the civil libertarians in our community to be privy to such evidence of cynicism and opportunism-that Senator Powell is the wisdom of all amendments for this legislation and is not prepared to put them to the Human Rights Commissioner! Perhaps it is the Human Rights Commissioner who has written in reply to Senator Powell about the Democrats' talking heads proposals, with which he does not agree, which Senator Powell does not want to put on the public record during a committee hearing. Perhaps the Democrats do not want that explained to the public.

Why is the Government not proceeding with this legislation in this last week of the sittings? Is it because the New South Wales Labor Party is so strapped for funds as a result of the last New South Wales State election campaign that it does not want the disclosure measures brought in until it gets the debt fixed up? Is that the reason why we are not debating this matter this week-so that there is an extra couple of months to get the cash in to repay the debt of the last election campaign? Why has the Government gutted its legislation? In the early hours of the legislation being considered in the House of Representatives an amendment was moved by the Government that effectively guts the disclosure provisions of this legislation-an outrageous amendment proposed by the Government. Should that not be open to public scrutiny, debate and comment by interest groups in the community?

All I say to the Senate is this: what is there to hide by opening this legislation up? What is there to hide by not allowing the Human Rights Commissioner to put his evidence on the public record? What is there to hide by restricting the Law Council's putting a point of view publicly on this legislation? Any amendments that we consider in due course have the benefit of input from sections of the community which have a rightful place to express a point of view to influence the legislative direction of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised at the contribution made this morning by Senator Powell. Senator Powell comes from the Party that used to say that it wanted to keep everyone else here honest. She comes from the Party that says, `Legislation should be properly scrutinised', and from the Party that advocates very strongly the referral of contentious Bills, and Bills that have any complicated legislative framework, whether they are contentious or not, off to committees for proper consideration. What she now says about the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, one of the most contentious Bills that has been attempted to be carried through this place, is that she has had a look at the Bill and decided what she wants, so there is no need for a parliamentary committee to look at it-thereby removing the right of a whole range of people to put their views to the Parliament about the impact of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Olsen has mentioned some of these people: the Law Council of Australia, the Human Rights Commissioner and many others. Senator Olsen has ably put the point that referring this Bill to a committee will not delay by one day the passage of the legislation in whatever form it ends up in. Senator Powell's argument is that, because she has had a look at the Bill and knows what amendments she wants to move, she will talk about it with the Government and that will be okay.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Opposition.

—And the Opposition. She will talk about it with a number of other people. On that basis, Senator Powell, why do you ever bother referring anything to a committee? That is what you should have told the chamber.
—Order! Senator Vanstone, please direct your remarks through the Chair.

—Through you, Mr Deputy President, if Senator Powell's argument is sustainable in relation to this Bill, it is sustainable in relation to any other Bill that is far less controversial and far less complicated.

SPEECH.PARA: I look forward to seeing Senator Powell and her cohorts follow through with that and never ask for a Bill or any section of a Bill to go to a committee. She will have plenty of time to look at the problems; she will be able to discuss Bills with whom she chooses-Government, Opposition, various interest groups-and she will be totally satisfied that we will come to the best solution through that process. This morning she has basically made a case for saying there is no need for referral of Bills to select committees or particular committees of this Parliament. I think that is a pretty disgraceful exercise.

Let me turn to what the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) wants to say. He wants to say that we need a complete ban on advertising. He admits that he will not get that. Some arrangement has to be made with the Australian Democrats. He says he wants a complete ban so that public order can be maintained. The aspect of public order that he thinks is under threat is the free and proper conduct of elections. He says elections are under threat because of corruption. He puts forward no evidence that corruption goes on because of the high cost of advertising.

If he turned his mind to the matter he would see where corruption takes place. We would be kidding ourselves if we said it never took place; Western Australia is a classic example of just how strongly corruption occurs amongst some Labor governments of this country. Where corruption does take place, it is, by and large, in my view, not because the parties or politicians have a need for funds for advertising but because some evil rich people want to buy governments; they want to buy policies.

If a government has no need of advertising money or a lesser need of advertising money, what will be offered is something different-cash for oneself as opposed to cash to run one's party. In other words, removing a party's need for funds for electronic advertising does not remove any incentive for corruption, because we still have corrupt people in the community who want to buy governments off and we still have, as we see in Western Australia, governments which can be bought off. If they are not bought off by money for advertising, they will be bought off by something else.

I want to make a point that Senator Alston also made: public order maintained through free and proper conduct of elections cannot be maintained unless we have freedom of speech. That is an essential requirement of the free and proper conduct of elections. In relation to this, the Government purports to say, `That is all right; people will hear on the television news, radio news and current affairs programs what is happening'.

But, if we turn our attention to press reporting, what this Government thinks of the press gallery and the media in general is quite instructive. In only the last couple of days, Mr Deputy President, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the leader of your Party, has said that the people in the gallery here, and the media around Australia, lack integrity; but in the next breath he says Australians should trust the media for information about what the parties think and what the policies are.

On a number of occasions Mr Keating has said that we just cannot trust people in the gallery. He says that they are intellectually deficient, that he has to tone his arguments down to get them to understand. During the Gulf war, the media told us that one of our ships had been involved in a collision, when no such thing had happened.

I for one am not happy to say in this place that the information about what the Government wants to do or what the Opposition wants to do, or information about Democrat policies, should be passed on to the public through the electronic media. This is a massive attack on the maintenance of public order; it is an attack on the free and proper conduct of elections because it is an attack on the parties and candidates freely putting their views, unedited, in those elections. This Bill should be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill continues to be about freedom of speech, which is the point that all speakers from the Opposition ranks have made. But this particular debate concerns the reference of the Bills to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to investigate, as we do with other Bills, just how parts of it will operate. During the period of debate, prior to the Bill being introduced, again and again we on this side of the House asked questions of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), and the Minister would simply reply, `Wait until the Bill comes down and you will see'. We waited until the Bill came down and now we see arising many questions that have been of concern to other Australian citizens and organisations; quite clearly there is a case to have these matters looked at and interpreted by a committee hearing evidence and making determinations.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the sorts of things that it would be eminently reasonable to have investigated. In looking at the explanatory memorandum accompanying the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, the first thing that leaps out from the page is that there is no definition of `advertisement' per se. I refer honourable senators to page 5 of the explanatory memorandum, where it says:

While the Bill defines `political advertisement', it does not define the concept of `advertisement' itself. `Advertisement' is intended to be given the widest possible interpretation, consistent with what is ordinarily understood to be an advertisement.

Is that to be interpreted by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT)? Do we believe that there is sufficient power or that that is the proper course of action? What is to be the proper modus operandi of the Bill and what will be its effect on things such as talkback radio? I read on from page 5 of the explanatory memorandum:
It is intended-
and I stress the use of the word `intended', a word which in no way conveys the impression that this matter is settled, and therefore it should be investigated-
that `advertisement' will not include for example bona fide reports of news or current affairs, including documentaries, talk back programmes or editorial comment by broadcasters.

That is a proper area that ought to be investigated to see what is meant by the terms `bona fide' and `news or current affairs'. What is the status of a person who goes onto talkback radio and makes a political statement-that is, a statement containing political matter as defined within the Act? Does it constitute an advertisement; would that matter be determined by the ABT; and are we satisfied that justice is not only done but appears to be done by that body? As I said in a press release that I put out very early in this debate, it is like giving Dracula the keys to the blood bank.

The ABT is headed by a man who, although he may-and will-strive to carry out his duties in a correct way, is known to be an Australian Labor Party aficionado, somebody who has been a paid employee of the ALP and a Senate candidate of the ALP. As I have said before, it is important that justice is not only done but seen to be done.

There are other things that we can look at. What is a political advertisement on one's own behalf? The Bill specifically outlaws advertisements which are put to air by broadcasters themselves. It says that they may not put to air a political advertisement on their own behalf. What is that meant to encompass? We need to hear evidence on how that will work. Is the penalty reasonable? Prior to the introduction of the Bill, we asked questions. We asked whether, if someone breached the Act, they would be fined, and whether, if they refused to pay the fine, they would be imprisoned. Thereby we would have imprisonment for exercising freedom of speech.

The Government has attempted to get around this dilemma by saying, `No, we will not do it that way; we will cancel the licence of the broadcaster'. How does that affect the rights of shareholders and employees? Is that a fair and equitable remedy? We need to hear evidence as to whether that is so.

How broad is the right of Government departments to advertise in the period other than the period after which the writs are issued? People should bear in mind that only the Government of the day will know that date. Right up until the issue of the writs, it will be able to tell its departments what time they can book space. They can run advertisements right up to the day of the issue of the writs. How broad is that right and what fetter is upon it? We need to hear evidence on that?

We need to hear how wide the powers of the ABT are. Not only is the ABT to have its present powers, but also it is to get extended powers. It is to get the right to apply for injunction-like remedies. It will have a wide range of powers to be able to interpret. How reasonable and how defined are those powers? What are the rights of appeal from decisions made by the ABT?

Another question that needs to be examined is the meaning of the amendment that the Government itself has moved, whereby the government of the day will be given power by regulation-not under legislation debated in this chamber but by regulation-to determine who shall be required to file a return showing disclosure of donations received.

It would be open to the Government, for instance, to exempt a State union or a particular solicitor's trust fund and say that it need not disclose. It may, by regulation, say that it need not be disclosed. It also has the power by regulation to set the limit above which disclosure must be made. So, we need to see whether those particular regulations would constitute a Henry VIII clause-that is, that the intent of the legislation or the legislation itself may be altered by regulation. The use of Henry VIII clauses is, within the Westminster system, absolutely and utterly disdained, and a recent conference in Perth on this question resolved that there should be no acceptance that there is any legitimate use of regular Henry VIII clauses at all.

Another point that needs to be made is that we need to hear from those who have made points of view on the public record, such as Brian Burdekin, the Law Council of Australia, the Business Council of Australia, the Brotherhood of St Laurence, the National Freedom of Blind Citizens, and the Australian Council of Social Service. Our Committee needs to hear from each of them. Finally, if honourable senators want to know someone else's opinion, the editorial in this morning's Australian states that the ad ban Bill is `a piece of chicanery' and that the `self-interest is breathtaking' on the part of the Government. Full disclosure is what we require. As I have said before, in terms of full disclosure, we need to see the deal that has been done between the Government and the Democrats such that the Democrats will not support this motion to refer this legislation to a committee this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Baume, I will make some comment about the advice I gave Senator Baume when he stood earlier today on a point of order. There have been many spurious points of order coming from the Opposition. Because the matter was heated, I thought it was possible that we might see another one. I have tried to recollect the points of order that Senator Baume has raised in this chamber, and I would point out at this stage that I have never known Senator Baume to raise a spurious point of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I want to speak very briefly to this legislation because, quite frankly, the Government's approach to this whole matter, and the matter of the rights of the public and the democratic rights of voters, is summed up in that very comment on which I took a point of order-the comment by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) in which he said, `I intend to treat you with the contempt you deserve' when he was speaking to--
—No, he did not.
—The honourable Senator can refer to the Hansard.
—No, that is not what he said. He used that word, but in a different context. You misheard.

—If that was not the context, and if I have one or two words out of place, I can assure the honourable Senator that that was the thrust and intent of the Minister's comment, because it was in response to an interjection by Senator Parer along the lines of, `Why do you fear the public's view; what have you got to hide?' Why the Minister would regard someone expressing that view with contempt is, I imagine, simply because it is a summation of the Government's view of this matter. As Senator Bishop has just quoted, the editorial in the Australian, which describes the ad ban as a piece of chicanery, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government's legislation to ban political advertising reaches new heights of political cunning.

The Government has connived to overcome opposition to a proposal to reduce the public's right of free expression by unnaturally combining it with more widely supported legislation calling for full disclosure of all political donations.

The ad ban is the result of exactly the kind of corrupt pandering to vested interests that Senator Bolkus claims to be seeking to prevent. It is just that the particular vested interest happens to be broke; Labor is financially strapped and is trying to lower the stakes before the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Financially and morally.
—I accept that interjection-and morally, as Senator Macdonald says. The article concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: So the fate of Senator Bolkus's Bill will rest with the Democrats. They should reject it in its present form. The legislation was never any more than an attempt by the Government to duchess the Democrats into passing the media ban in return for Labor support for full disclosure.

On today's form, the Democrats have been successfully duchessed. I congratulate the Government on its piece of chicanery; I congratulate it on its political cunning; and I congratulate it for its ability to treat with contempt the people who are expressing the rights of individuals, the rights of Australian citizens to complain, to approach or to discuss with a committee the undemocratic details of this Bill. I congratulate the Government on all those matters and I must say that, in return, I treat the Government and its Bill with the contempt it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am the only senator currently in the chamber who was a member of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters which discussed this whole question at length. I was somewhat intrigued, to put it mildly, to hear what the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) said, that the Bill currently before the Parliament is an attempt to address the matters raised in that report. In fact, we on that Committee spent days and days considering heaps of submissions and examining many witnesses, and a report was presented to the Parliament. That report dealt with the questions of political broadcasting and disclosure, to the extent that the legislation currently before the chamber deals with questions of disclosure raised by that Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: It can possibly be argued that the Minister was correct in saying that that was a response to this Committee's report. To the extent that the Bill deals with political broadcasting or advertising, it does not reflect the views even of the majority of that Committee and the majority's recommendations. I happened to have disagreed with the majority recommendations even at that time because, as honourable senators will see in my dissenting report, I concluded that the recommendations were unlikely to achieve their stated objective of ensuring that voters who followed the electronic media would be adequately informed of the issues at stake in any election and of releasing political parties from an implied reliance on major donors.

I did not think that even those recommendations would achieve those objectives, and certainly I do not think that the current proposals-nor, from what I have heard, the Australian Democrats' amendments or proposals-would achieve that objective either. I have heard senators here, including Senator Powell, say across the chamber, `All right, we can do a deal with senators around the chamber' or `with the Opposition and the Government', and I presume that that applies to me as well. I am not actually interested in making arrangements between ourselves on a question which strikes at the very heart of democracy and the integrity of the political process. All those issues should be right out in the open because we, as parliamentarians, quite frankly cannot be trusted in matters where our self-interest is involved.

I do not mean that as a reflection on the honourable intentions of any senator, including myself. I say, `cannot be trusted', but `trusted' is probably not the correct word. I am not capable of being so disinterested in these particular matters as to come up with a proper conclusion which would ensure the integrity of the political process unless the people-that is, the voters and other groups within society-know what we are on about.

In my view, the way to do that is to ensure that this Bill-which is different, as I have said, to the recommendations that came from that Committee-goes to a committee so that members of the voting public can come before that committee to express their views directly. Whether that be the Committee suggested by Senator Parer, or the usual process adopted in relation to complicated Bills or Bills which contain major policy issues of sending them off to a standing committee, I do not know. All we have before us today is that this measure be referred to a committee. Because that will give the opportunity to the voting public to have their say about what we as politicians should do to ensure the integrity of the political process, I agree with this motion and I hope that it is carried.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Parer's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

upon which Senator Olsen had moved by way of amendment:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991 and allied Bills was interrupted last night, we were discussing the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill and in particular the conclusions and recommendations of a Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) review of the existing bounty on machine tools and robots. A further sensible amendment which has arisen from the BIE report is the proposal to make eligible for bounty all equipment produced in the bountiable categories, whether sold in the domestic market or overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a proposal to introduce a minimum annual production threshold before any bounty may be claimed. I will deal with that later when discussing all the minimum annual thresholds which are proposed in the Bill. The computer bounty is also to be expanded to include local manufacture of printed circuit boards from 1 July 1991. This measure is supported by the Australian Democrats. The consequent removal of the current tariff will assist local industry in many sectors such as telecommunications, computers and aerospace.

The primary matter of contention in this Bill is the proposal to limit various bounty payments by creating minimum annual thresholds which firms must exceed to qualify for assistance. We have heard that Senator Olsen will be moving an amendment on behalf of the Opposition to stop this. The second reading speech of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) states:

The primary objective of the threshold is to encourage efficient manufacturing in those sectors by eliminating from the schemes peripheral production by firms not significantly committed to bountiable production in the respective industries.
That is, marginal producers, as determined purely by production levels and not by unit costs or any efficiency measure, are to be denied bounty assistance.

These proposals mean that manufacturers may not be entitled to receive bounty unless they have produced a quantity of bountiable equipment under the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984, the Bounty (Printed Fabrics) Act 1981 or the Bounty and Capitalisation Grants (Textiles Yarns) Act 1981 which entitles them to a bounty of $10,000 for a year of production-that is, only if a small business produces enough of any of the bountiable items stated above to qualify for that bounty. No bounty would be payable if the entitlement is less than $10,000.

The inequity of this proposal is obvious. What about the firm that would have been entitled to $9,900? Will it produce extra useless product just to qualify for that bounty? Will it be tempted to fiddle the books in order to qualify? What of the small business which would only qualify for a bounty of $1,000? Why should that be denied to it? The minimum bounty proposed for the Bounty (Bed Sheeting) Act 1977 is even more extreme. The Bill sets the lower limit at $100,000, which is a huge threshold to exceed for a small business.

The final matter dealt with in the Opposition amendments is the proposed introduction of a minimum annual threshold of $200,000 of value added for eligibility for payment under the Bounty (Metal Working Machines and Robots) Act 1985. It is not clear why the criterion was minimum bounty payments for some of the bounty thresholds and in the case of the robotic bounty a minimum value added criterion was accepted by the Government. What will these minimum threshold measures yield in savings? According to the Minister's second reading speech, they have no financial implications.

Why, in a period of falling national production and rapidly escalating unemployment, are we debating a measure which is specifically designed to cut small-scale production? Surely, the few people who are employed in that production have to be protected, at least until the employment outlook has improved. It is for these reasons, and the fact that any figure which could be adopted would be totally arbitrary anyway, that the Australian Democrats will be supporting the Opposition's amendments which seek to remove the minimum threshold provisions from the Bill. In relation to the Opposition's second reading amendment, it will probably come as no surprise to the Opposition that the Democrats are ideologically opposed to almost all of it, except for the last piece. We will be moving our own second reading amendment later in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate today is debating the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991 and the Customs Amendment Bill 1991. These Bills are a by-product of the Government's industry statement delivered on 12 March. The Government stated that its measures were to improve the product capacity of the Australian economy to make it more competitive and its most powerful spur was tariff reductions. The tariff reductions proposed were that general assistance be reduced from 10 and 15 per cent in 1992 to 5 per cent by 1996; passenger motor vehicle tariffs be phased down from 35 per cent in 1992 to 15 per cent in the year 2000; textile, clothing and footwear tariffs be reduced to 25 per cent by the year 2000; and general agricultural tariffs be reduced in line with general tariffs-in other words, down to 5 per cent by 1996. These reductions would bring Australia's nominal tariff rates down to approximately 3 per cent-an average effective rate of assistance down by 5 per cent in the year 2000.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, I would like to address my remarks particularly to the effect that these tariff cuts will have on agricultural products. Rural producers sometimes wonder why they have to have more a rapid pace of reform than any other industry. They accept top down tariff reductions, but these cuts seem to come from the bottom up. They feel that the costs of the imported products will benefit by these tariff cuts because they become the market price indicators. This applies particularly to farmers that grow processed vegetables who come under increased pressure to accept lower prices because of the presence of subsidised imports.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his 12 March statement referred to the European Economic Community, United States of America (USA) and Japanese farm subsidies, which average more than $300 billion a year, and to the heavy burden placed on the farmers by corrupted world agricultural trade. The solution proposed in the March statement was to maintain our vigorous campaign for substantial reform of agricultural trade in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) Uruguay Round of negotiations.

If we look at Australia's tariff cuts since 1988, the GATT secretariat estimates that they involve an average trade weighted cut of up to 44 per cent. However, the difference between these other countries and Australia is as reported in the March publication of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade:

The March industry statement cuts will bring us into line with those of other industrialised countries, most of which-still also use a battery of non tariff measures such as quotas and subsidies to restrict imports.
Further:

At the current Uruguay Round of trade negotiations, most participants have so far failed to reach the agreed target of an average tariff reduction of a third-a level exceeded in Australia's initial offer based on the 1988 reductions.
It goes on to explain:

While no other country has yet matched the comprehensive liberalisation that Australia has announced since the Round began in 1986, we remain optimistic that other countries will move in Australia's direction and we will certainly continue to press for this.
I am becoming disappointed at the actions of other countries in the world. It seems that Australia is the only country that is progressing down the free trade route.

We are trying to lead the world in this campaign for free trade; we are out there with the drum and the banner but no-one is following. The farmers have just about had a gutful of it. In today's newspapers, we find that the USA has sold Kuwait many hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of wheat that is heavily subsidised through trade subsidies. The report, to which I have referred, describes the present world trade situation in which Australian producers have to work. The desired free world trade situation at the moment is not a reality. So it is no wonder that many rural industries subjected to corrupt world markets are struggling and struggling badly.

This is what the Government is not acknowledging, by further reducing tariffs now, and particularly without simultaneously introducing other reforms to reduce industry input costs. I ask the Minister at the table, Senator Tate, who I believe is a realistic person, how his Government can reduce tariffs while pursuing accord mark VI. How on earth can we increase the cost of products in Australia, whether they be manufactured products, grown products or processed products, pushing up the price on the one hand, while reducing tariff levels on the other? It is a complete impossibility. All the Government is doing-and I hope that Senator Tate takes this back to Cabinet-is increasing the length of the line of unemployed people. It is not possible to do both things: we cannot push up costs on the one hand and decrease tariff levels on the other. This should be obvious to everyone, and needs no more than a grade 4 level of understanding.

By means of this Bill vegetable tariffs are to be reduced in July, to 10 per cent, and then to 5 per cent by 1996. A 5 per cent tariff will also apply to produce from developing countries. Furthermore, by this legislation, some vegetable tariffs are to be bound under GATT. This means that Australia is giving a binding commitment to our competitors that our vegetable tariff levels will never be raised. It does not matter what happens with regard to imports, production subsidies and export subsidies-we can have subsidised producers products flooding into this nation-this Government has said, `We are going to lead the world. We will bind our tariffs. We will bind our farmers, and we will not give them any assistance at all'.

By binding vegetable tariffs, it seems that vegetables are the token produce exposed to greater threat from imports in order to win more international praise for the Government. This is being done without regard by the Government for the consequences to the horticultural industry, which last year sustained imports of $2.1 billion of food products. At the same time, no corresponding benefits seem to have been obtained for Australian products in overseas markets. The consequences of reduced and bound vegetable tariffs will be devastating for the horticultural industry.

In my home State of Queensland, over the past five years the efficient pineapple industry has lost 22 per cent of the domestic market to imports. Yet the pineapple industry is suffering badly from such factors as the effects of cheap subsidised imports, reduced tariff levels and an increase in multi-national companies sourcing their pineapples from developing countries. Most of this product has some sort of subsidy or is countervailed in some way. It is the same with citrus growers, where tariff levels will be reduced to 3 per cent by 1996. Brazilian orange juice concentrate comes into Australia at a 5 per cent tariff level, as Brazil is classified as a developing country, despite its massive 36 per cent share of the world market. Surely in these economic times there is a need for the Government to remove preferred national concession in relation to some products where the country involved is able to influence world trade.

In relation to tomatoes, imports went up by 103 per cent last year, while at the same time Australian tomato and potato farmers were ploughing their crops back into the ground. It is well known that some European countries massively subsidise tomato production, encouraging overproduction. The subsidy level for tomatoes in the European Community (EC) is $425 per tonne, equivalent to 19c per can, while the Australian price is only $120 per tonne. The subsidy is three times the actual Australian price. Last year, 28,750 tonnes of EC tomatoes were imported to Australia, yet Australian canned tomato production was only 18,991 tonnes.

Subsidised vegetables are making inroads into Australian canned food sales. Yesterday it was reported that Queensland pea growers have had to accept a cut of 12.5 per cent for their vegetables going to the processors, as otherwise Edgell would be unable to compete against imported products, and it would have pulled out of the Queensland market if the price cuts were not accepted. I have sympathy for Edgell and I have great sympathy for the Australian farmers, because Edgell cannot compete against the products that are being imported, mainly under generic brands by Coles, Woolworths and the other chains.

Last year the amount of imported frozen peas rose by 5.42 per cent; frozen corn by 11.62 per cent; frozen potatoes by a massive 72.2 per cent, when the Australian potato crop was being ploughed back into the ground; and canned asparagus by 22.32 per cent. I am not suggesting for one moment that there should be some form of protectionism, some sort of tariff barrier, but I am saying that Australian farmers are the most efficient in the world. They can compete against anyone. They can compete against low-cost countries and against low wages and still win, but they can never compete against the treasuries of the United States of America or the European Community. They just cannot do it. The EC uses other subsidy devices such as minimum farm prices, production aids, regional employment programs, government aid to set up food manufacturing plants, and export rebate schemes. Our farmers are left defenceless and naked against these subsidies.

The United States is the largest importer of tomato products and has a 100 tariff rate for EC tomato imports. The European Community dominates 85 per cent of the world's export markets and is excluded from the US market. It then has to seek alternative markets for its cheap subsidised tomatoes, with Australia being the target. It is less well known that Australian processors are reaching the point where imports are making them almost unviable. This means that the whole fabric of food production in Australia is threatened because of the effect of highly subsidised food imports. This situation is repeated in relation to many rural products.

I now turn to a major Queensland primary and manufacturing industry, the sugar industry. The March industry statement, without any warning, changed the tariff regime for sugar. Fellow senators will remember the comprehensive Senate inquiry in 1988 which I moved to establish to set up a tariff regime until 1992 following the lifting of the embargo on sugar. The lifting of the embargo was a measure used by the Government as a bargaining tool in the Uruguay GATT negotiations. The sugar industry made this contribution and in turn expected to be able to rely on the tariff regime which was established by the Government and which, in the words of the Minister, was to be reviewed in 1992 by the Industries Assistance Commission, as it then was. The Government then put into place a specific tariff on both white and raw sugar imports of $115 a tonne until 1 July 1991, $95 a tonne until 1 July 1992 and $70 a tonne after 1 July 1992, with an Industry Commission inquiry to determine the tariff levels thereafter. Suddenly, without any consultation with the industry, the Government unilaterally ended this agreement-with a stroke of the pen, not even advising the industry what it intended to do.

Accordingly, the specific tariff rates were reduced from $95 to $76 a tonne as at 1 July 1991, and from $70 to $55 a tonne as at 1 July 1992. This means an immediate loss to the Queensland sugar industry of $13.1m in the next year and $10.3m in the following year. It also means a loss to the New South Wales industry of $3.8m-and it sustains a more severe loss than the Queensland industry on a pro rata basis. The Australian sugar industry is one of the most efficient in the world and it is recognised as a very low cost producer. Last year, it gave more than $1 billion in export earnings. This season, the Australian industry has endured massive fuel increases at harvesting times due to the Gulf war, droughts and floods, with a decrease of $300m in industry earnings this year.

What cannot be avoided is the fact that the Government broke a firm promise to the industry-that was, that the tariffs were as agreed until July 1992. That commitment was given by every party in this Parliament. The drop in world prices from US14.6c a pound last May to 8c a pound today places a heavy burden on sugar farmers when their costs are going up and their returns are going down. The only assistance the sugar industry has had was the tariff level for 20 per cent of its product sold on the domestic market. There is no assistance for the 80 per cent of its product on the export market sold at world prices. There is no level playing field out there for the sugar industry. It is kicking against a 40-knot breeze and it does not even get a change of end at quarter time.

The world prices are kept artificially low by subsidies. I think we should compare the subsidy levels of the major sugar producing countries. The European Economic Community subsidy is $551 per tonne, or 214 per cent of the world price; in Thailand, it is $447 a tonne, or 173 per cent; in the United States of America, it is $357, or 138 per cent of the world price; whereas in Australia, it is $76 for 20 per cent of the crop, or 28 per cent reducing to 21 per cent.

The broken promise on tariff levels is a disgraceful and disrespectful way to treat the Australian sugar industry. I cannot support the reduction in tariff levels and I will support an amendment. I had one drafted, but it is exactly the same as the Australian Democrats' amendment, which I will be supporting in the committee stage.

I want to take up a point about the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice). When this Bill was debated in the House of Representatives, it was disgraceful to hear the honourable member for Hinkler defend his Government's actions in breaking its promises to his constituents. The honourable member claimed to be the only sugar producer in the House of Representatives, and then went on to say that the Government's action gave the end users of sugar an opportunity to get on the front foot and become competitive.

Mr Courtice is not a sugar producer. He was left a sugar cane farm, but he could not hack it. He walked out, became a union representative and leased his farm. To say that he is a sugar producer is wrong: he is misleading the Parliament. He could not stay in there. But what Mr Courtice always does is drag this Parliament down and use it as a cess-pit to tackle anyone who has a disagreement with his Party. He has attacked every local government chairman in his area. He has attacked a number of other prominent citizens around the Bundaberg area; but when it comes to defending his constituents in this Parliament-and that is what he is sent down here to do-he is about as useless as an ashtray on a motor bike.

He did not mention the breaking of the Government's promise. He did not mention the loss to the individual farmers of $2,500 per farm and he did not mention the severe effect that the loss of income will have as it flows through the sugar communities. He represents one of the largest sugar communities-Bundaberg. Surely, he must care about the jobs that will be lost, about the income that will be lost by farmers in his constituency, and the rural towns already severely hit by his Government's engineered recession. He will see unemployment soar and businesses close down.

The honourable member does not seem to be concerned about that. He seems more concerned about toeing the Government line and promoting his chances to get into Cabinet. I can say to him that it would be the greatest insult to farmers in Australia if he were ever elevated above his present position as a back bench member of the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the next two years only.
—Yes; he will be lucky to hold his seat after this disgraceful performance. The honourable member, and I say that with some--
—Liberality.

—Yes, with some liberality. He was also silent on the threat to his area of Bundaberg Sugar Co. being taken over by the British conglomerate, Tate and Lyle, until last week when he said that foreign investment should be allowed so that Australian companies can invest overseas. Bundaberg Sugar is not a company in need of foreign investment. It is a highly successful Australian company. In this interview he did not once mention the effect on his electorate or on the people of Bundaberg.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, the canegrowers are not satisfied with Tate and Lyle's assurances. They received absolute assurance from Tate and Lyle about the continuation of a single seller in the market, acquisition and the canegrowers' equity in any refinery. Yet the canegrower is not satisfied with an overseas owner who is heavily involved in the beet and corn syrup market in direct conflict with Australia's raw sugar industry. This poses a threat to the canegrowers' years of hard work and equity. It is undeniable that the effect of the Federal Government's economic policies has been to see the selling off of the Australian farm. As Australian firms have floundered, buyers have moved in from overseas for the bargains. This is not so in the case of Bundaberg Sugar; it is a prime takeover target simply because it has been so successful.

Mr Kerin and the Government have inflicted a further possible blow on the canegrowers and the future of the sugar industry with their approval of the Tate and Lyle foreign takeover bid for Bundaberg Sugar. The Queensland State Government-a Labor government-which is much closer to the scene, decided that it could not find a sufficient level of potential benefit which would flow from the proposal put forward by Tate and Lyle. The major concern was the potential effect on Bundaberg district canegrowers and domestic sugar industries flowing from Tate and Lyle's leading position in the international sweetener market.

Under the Foreign Takeovers Act, the main criterion is that such a takeover is not judged contrary to the national interest. Mr Kerin has sadly let down the Bundaberg and Australian sugar growers by allowing in a foreign player with a proven conflicting interest to our industry. Let us hope that the decision was not made, as the newspapers suggest, to prove that Mr Kerin could be a decisive Treasurer.

A further Bill being considered cognately today is the Customs Amendment Bill. This Bill puts into effect the Government's announcement in the March industry statement that anti-dumping measures should be speeded up so the first preliminary stage could be reduced to 135 days, to be implemented by regulation. Also, it provides that farmers affected by dumping can bring actions as processors if their raw goods are closely related to the processed product and that anti-dumping duties stay in effect for the full three years.

The coalition policy is that this first stage should be speeded up to 55 days with a further 120 days until the final investigation. Accordingly, I support the amendment of the coalition. As anti-dumping is the only means that the Government has left available to the Australian producers under the free trade stance, these amendments have been desperately needed. The Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, of which I am a member, investigated the anti-dumping legislation and I believe it will bring down its report tomorrow. It is hoped that the Government will take action on the recommendations in implementing any further reforms suggested by that Senate Committee.

Primary industry should not be bearing the brunt of further tariff cuts without accompanying reforms that cut its costs. Australian primary producers are efficient by international standards. They can and do compete well in international markets, but they find it difficult and almost impossible to compete against the massive subsidies provided by the rest of the world. It is difficult to say that now is the time that agricultural tariffs should be reduced when the rest of the world is heavily subsidising-and increasingly subsidising-its industry. All other countries in the world are increasing subsidies and Australia is going one-out in decreasing tariffs.

We have done just about everything possible to lead world trade. We have given away just about every bargaining chip that we had in the interests of getting world trade to take place. We have removed the sugar embargo. We are lowering the tariffs in this Bill, and we did it before in the 1988 economic statement. We have disbanded the domestic price for wheat and the binding of some vegetable tariffs. We are even harmonising our food standards with the international Codex standard. No-one can accuse Australia of not playing the world trade game. It is about time some other nations got in behind us.

The coalition's policy is for tariff reductions, but with simultaneous micro-economic reform. To do one without the other, as this Government is doing, is to jeopardise the survival not only of primary industry but also all industries in Australia. To pursue an increased wages policy and the Mark VI accord, which will increase wages by $12 a week, and another 6 per cent productivity increase with another 3 per cent on top of that, is quite wrong. It is jeopardising not only our primary industry, but also our secondary industry.

Already we have seen a reduction from 30 per cent to around 13 per cent in our manufacturing industries. Whilst I can support the reduction of tariffs, I find it very difficult to support when the Government is increasing costs to manufacturers while trying to reduce protection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to lead the Opposition in this debate on the Customs Amendment Bill 1991 and the allied Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991. With respect to the Customs Amendment Bill 1991, I move:
