SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate, while it is prepared to give the bill a second reading, is of the opinion that, in conjunction with the amendments to anti-dumping and countervailing procedures contained in the bill, the Government should further streamline these procedures so that Australian producers have adequate defence against dumped and subsidised imports, by condensing the entire preliminary investigation period to 55 days, after which provisional measures can be implemented, followed by a final investigation period of 120 days''.

The purpose of the Customs Amendment Bill is to implement changes announced in the March industry statement relating to dumping and countervailing procedures. The Bill provides me with an opportunity to focus on the free trade messages inherent in the so-called dumping of produce. I am particularly concerned that to soften the message of protection reductions, which was the ostensible aim of the industry statement, the Government made a commitment to faster and more effective anti-dumping action.

Anti-dumping measures can be used as a protectionist measure. A deceptive belief is held by some that, for instance, when the subsidised Australian automotive industry sells goods on foreign markets at prices below that at which they are sold domestically, it is called an export success story-and I would cite the Capri. But when a subsidised American wheat farmer sells his produce in traditional Australian markets, he is an unfair trader who has dumped his produce. Clearly, we need more consistency.

Dumping should be seen for what it is-competition. Anti-dumping action can, if not properly used, lead to further yet less visible protection as it allows businesses to stand out from the cold winds of competition. More and more, as we see an international commitment to the reduction of overall tariffs, I find that the increase in non-tariff barriers by way of not only anti-dumping and countervailing mechanisms but also, of course, the ubiquitous health and safety regulations, can effectively take over the role where tariffs have been diminished. The coalition is strongly of the view that an anti-dumping mechanism must not be used as an alternative form of industry protection to shield industries from genuine international competition. Mr Acting Deputy President, I wonder if we could have a little less conversation?

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that the conversation on the right of the Chair is distracting the speaking senator. I ask all honourable senators not to disturb the speaker.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I will have a conversation in this chamber in my correct chair, with the person in his correct chair next to me, as I wish.

—I remind Senator Tate and all senators that this chamber must obey Standing Orders. Where a senator is distracted by too audible a conversation in the chamber, the Chair brings that to the attention of the chamber. I ask Senator Bishop to continue her remarks.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, tell me what the Standing Order is.
—I will look up the Standing Order and at the conclusion of Senator Bishop's speech I will bring that to the attention of Senator Tate and the chamber. I ask Senator Bishop to resume her speech.
—Thank you very much, Mr Acting Deputy President. Thank you, Senator Tate and Senator Collins for your courtesy.
—Thank you for your sarcasm, Senator Bishop.

—My thanks for the quietening of the conversation was meant as an act of courtesy on my part. The coalition is strongly of the view that an anti-dumping mechanism must not be used as an alternative form of industry protection to shield industries from genuine international competition, and I repeat that statement because it is an important one.

SPEECH.PARA: Having made the most important point, it is worth considering how the coalition government would approach reductions in industry protection. We have made it quite plain that our program to expose Australian industry to international competition will occur in conjunction with a systematic program of micro-economic reform. The coalition has consistently prescribed that cuts in protection should be accompanied by genuine micro-economic reform and that both the ball and the chain should be removed from import substitutions and potential and current exporters. Implementing these reforms together ensures that the benefits of both arms of reform are maximised.

The Industry Commission has estimated that the benefit to the Australian economy of reducing protection alone will be to the tune of $4 billion. To reduce protection and make genuine micro-economic reform will see the economy realising $43 billion of additional growth. That is a most important aspect in an economy which is suffering from the recession that was planned by this Government-the one that the former Treasurer said we had to have. It is in this context that the opportunity for genuine reform of anti-dumping and countervailing regimes becomes available.

In the meantime, we have the most unsatisfactory situation of intellectual dishonesty where the Government maintains that it has a genuine anti-dumping mechanism but, in reality, it is so drawn out and inefficient as to be largely ineffective. Some may argue that this is perversely in the interest of free traders such as myself, but I do not wish to be part of this deception. If the Government is going to do away with anti-dumping mechanisms, it should be explicit in doing so. What I would not do is have a lengthy, drawn out investigation period creating significant costs, knowing that local firms may be dissuaded from making anti-dumping applications. The interests of free trade may very well be served by such a course of action, but what a fraud would be served on Australian industry, and it is simply not acceptable.

This is the logic which justifies the position that we take on this Bill and, indeed, the second reading amendment which I have just moved. The logic is quite simple: for a country to have an anti-dumping mechanism, the only honest course of action is for that mechanism to be both efficient and effective. Because of the danger of the mechanism yielding arbitrary protection for certain industries, the procedure must be balanced and thorough.

In the current economic climate, it has been argued by my colleague Mr McLachlan, in the other place, that the current mechanism and, indeed, the proposed new shortened mechanism, take so long that local industry, for all practical purposes, can be destroyed before the provisional measures can be imposed.

My amendment calls on the Government to reduce the current three-tier investigation process to two-that is, a 55-day preliminary investigation period, after which provisional measures can be imposed, followed by a single 12-day final investigation stage. Honourable senators should turn their minds back to 1988 when the current arrangements were debated. At that time the coalition successfully moved amendments to shorten the first two stages of the Government's proposal of 70 days and 180 days to 55 days and 120 days. In 1988 Senator Button said that it could not be done. Perhaps he was thinking of the relative incompetence of the Customs Service in reaching quality findings. Not only has he proved to be wrong, but he is now himself reducing the times for the establishment of a prima facie case and preliminary investigation. Even this is not enough. An industry suffering material injury may have to wait four and a half months for relief by means of the provisional measure, and another four months for the Anti-Dumping Authority to undertake the final investigation.

The effect of my amendment would be to urge the Government to remove one layer of investigation and condense the primary investigation period to 55 days. In the 1986 review of the anti-dumping system by Professor Fred Gruen it was recommended that the Customs Service should make substantial efforts to meet targets of 55 days for preliminary findings and 120 days for findings in normal cases. That was the recommendation in 1986. It is surely a long time to have to wait to 1991 to move in this direction.

The Customs Amendment Bill makes other changes to anti-dumping and countervailing measures by increasing access of primary producers to the mechanism. This was recommended by Professor Gruen and was at the heart of the coalition's decision to require a Senate committee to investigate this matter. Upstream producers will now be able to claim relief from dumping and processed agricultural goods, provided that the goods are closely related to the raw agricultural material. The Bill also provides the calculation of a full dumping margin at the preliminary finding stage of a dumping inquiry to help speed up investigations. The condition supports this change. However, may I add that it is important to monitor the new provisions in light of changing international trading arrangements and General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade requirements.

A further change in this Bill relates to the sunsetting of countervailing measures so as to remove an anomaly whereby sunset provisions are dated from the first notice relating to subsidised product and not to the current notice. Finally, the Bill alters some Customs search procedures, extending the pool of judges for appointment as Division 1B judges under the Customs Act 1901. We do not oppose these changes, but I seriously commend our amendment as it would make the effectiveness of anti-dumping and countervailing measures effective and efficient, and thereby enhance the international trading capabilities of our potential and existing exporters and assist those who are engaged in substitution manufactures.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Bjelke-Petersen, I did undertake to refer to the Standing Orders at the conclusion of Senator Bishop's speech. I draw attention to standing order 184(1):

INTERJECT.PARA: Order shall be maintained in the Senate by the President.

In a case where a senator speaking feels interrupted by a conversation, however usual it is for there to be side conversations in the chamber, it is appropriate for the Chair to acknowledge the senator who is speaking feeling that he or she is being interrupted and to draw that to the attention of the chamber. That is what I did. I could refer to Odgers Senate Practice on page 153 relating to interjections, or I could refer the Senate to other standing orders such as 203 or 197. But I rest the case on standing order 184. I think that the matter is understood, and certainly we are not seeking any prohibition in this chamber of useful side conversations taking place while a senator is speaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity Senator Tate is not here to hear that.
—I hear the interjection from Senator Macdonald, and I assure him and the chamber that Senator Tate did have a conversation with me, as he had to leave. He understands the Standing Orders now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, which we are now debating, the Government is addressing how it will set what it calls a level playing field for the motor vehicle industry, the textiles, clothing and footwear-TCF-industries, the vegetable industry and the sugar industry. What concerns me greatly is that the Government is doing this without regard to the impact of its policies on the competitive conditions within which producers in each of those industries work. In particular, I would like to address my comments to the effects of this legislation on one of Australia's most efficient industries, the sugar industry. Senator Boswell in his speech has dealt thoroughly with the effects that this legislation will have on other primary industries, such as tomato growing, and the growing of pineapples, peas, corn and potatoes.

SPEECH.PARA: Many argue about the merits of free trade and the abolition of tariffs, but they fail to address the real issue under discussion. It is not about whether we believe in free trade. It is simply whether we are prepared to give the nod to and turn a blind eye to a deliberate `breach of promise' by the Government. That promise to sugar growers was that the tariff regime for sugar would be $95 a tonne from 1 July 1990 to 1 July 1991, and then $75 a tonne after that until the Industry Commission inquiry guidelines were released. That promise was made to growers back in 1989 and, naturally, many subsequently made financial commitments based on that assurance. With industry policy, it is not just the policies that count; it is the consistency of those policies. When the ground rules are changed in the middle of the game, it is diabolical. The President of the Queensland Farmers Federation stated:

. . . the reduction in the tariffs flies in the face of the transitional arrangements agreed to by the Senate Committee of Inquiry in 1988. These arrangements were developed through extensive consultation . . . as a transitional measure prior to the establishment of the long term position in the Industry Commission Inquiry scheduled for later this year. The proposed action makes a mockery of both the Senate Inquiry and the Industry Commission Inquiry. Indeed, it is a breach of the commitment provided to the sugar industry in 1988. It was a commitment by the Parliament, made after extensive consultation with all sectors of the industry and it included an appropriate review mechanism in the form of the Industry Commission Inquiry.

Sugar growers have watched with trepidation the collapse of the wheat, wool and other rural industries. Forecasts for the sugar industry indicate a capitulation of prices during the next two years similar to that of wheat in the past two years, with growers expected to bear the brunt of the industry's problems.

Sugar prices have already fallen 45 per cent from last year. They fell from US$14.6c a pound in may last year to US$0.8c a pound. Growers have been aware of the price drop. Political and economic changes in the Soviet Union and eastern Europe, and trade sanctions against Iraq have created a slump in overseas demand. Australian growers have prepared for the downturn by becoming more efficient. But they were taken by surprise when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in the industry policy statement in March, announced that tariffs were to be decreased faster than expected.
I will quote from a newspaper article of 13 March which carried the by-line, `Canegrowers King Hit'. That report quoted the Queensland Cane Growers Council Chairman, Mr Harry Bonanno, who said:
The March industry statement king hits the raw sugar industry at a time when it is already reeling from low sugar prices.
He went on to say:
The industry statement was also a breach of the Government's promise not to change industry tariffs until after this year's Industry Commission inquiry.

What good on earth is it having an inquiry if Government members have already changed their minds? That decision is expected to wipe on average $2,500, or almost 10 per cent, from sugar growers' incomes in one fell swoop. It represents a loss of $13.1m in Queensland and $3.8m in New South Wales this year alone, a total of $16.9m-a substantial amount to lose in anyone's language.

In 1989, when the Australian sugar industry was deregulated with embargoes and set domestic prices replaced by import tariffs, growers were told to prepare for competition on the domestic market from overseas producers. The decision was grudgingly accepted by growers because, by losing the set domestic price, they were to benefit when world export prices rose. By coincidence, sugar prices reached record levels during 1989 and the industry prospered. A slump in world stocks was combined with strong Asian demand. However, when the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, deregulated the domestic market in 1989, he gave the industry an assurance-I repeat, he gave an assurance-on a set tariff level to 1992 when an Industry Commission inquiry was expected to release new proposals. Mr Kerin said that the tariff regime for imported sugar would be $115 a tonne for 1989, $95 a tonne from 1 July 1990 to 1 July 1991 and then $75 a tonne after that until the Industry Commission inquiry guidelines were released.

I regret to say that Mr Hawke's 12 March industry statement broke that agreement. In line with the Government's 1988 agreement of general tariff reductions, it cut sugar tariffs more than 20 per cent. The 1991 rate was cut from $95 a tonne to $76, with 1992 tariffs reduced from $75 a tonne to $55. Growers in the only two States producing sugar-Queensland and New South Wales-are expected on average to lose $2,500 per grower over the next two years. For many, the lower tariffs could be the last straw.

Sugar cane requires a five-year plan. Sugar growers have to establish goals and commit their finance to them. In doing so, they have to believe that commitments given by the Government will enable them to aim for those goals. Many marginal growers have been planning to diversify into other areas in anticipation of the lower tariffs and world prices, but the Government's move has brought many problems forward. However, in this amendment, the Government has moved unilaterally and without consultation with the industry. It has told the industry that there is no consultation to reduce the specific duty and that it will reduce the tariff from $95 to $70 in 1991 and from $70 to $55 in 1992.

Regrettably, we are placing a number of our major industries in a position where there will be even more unemployed, where there will be an even larger number of those engaged in the textiles, clothing and footwear industry who will be shutting up plant and moving offshore and where, in the sugar and vegetable industries, we will find that imports will take over their market share. Reductions of tariffs in these areas, as some sort of grand gesture while they are not being matched by our trading competitors, is warm inner-glow nonsense. Indeed, regrettably, most competitors provide enormous subsidies to their producers. What makes it worse in the case of the sugar industry is that the Industry Commission has already started its inquiry into the protection that is to apply to the industry post-1 July 1992. So we are in a situation where, by adopting this tariff reduction, we are telling producers, `Do not take us at our word. Do not budget with your life savings according to our promises'.

I can understand those who are sceptical of the promises of the Government. We all know that its record on broken promises is long. How many times have we recalled the promises-no capital gains tax; no increase in the Medicare levy; no child will live in poverty; no sales tax or excise on wine; inflation will keep below 5 per cent; home ownership will be within the reach of ordinary Australians; no need for any devaluation of the dollar; and Labor will reduce the price of petrol? The latest broken promise by the Prime Minister is that he would resign well before the next election. However, I do believe that we in the Opposition should not condone the deliberate breaking of promises by the Government. What makes it even more criminal is that we are doing so after people have committed their life savings in what has been an economically difficult time and thus their continued economic viability is threatened.

Currently, sugar trade takes place in what is probably the most corrupt market in the world for any commodity. Domestic subsidies are often several hundred per cent. Many countries have total import bans. Others, like the United States of America, have quotas guaranteeing that the world market is anything but free and fair. This means that there are enormous local subsidies applying in all the major sugar producing countries of the world.

Nor is any real progress being made in effecting any kind of liberalisation in world sugar trade. The major exporting nations have increased their concentration of total exports, with five countries now accounting for 77 per cent of the world trade in sugar. Australia ranks with Thailand, behind Cuba, and the European Economic Community (EEC). Australia has been building its tariff policy around its commitment to the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). We are told that it is necessary for Australia to reduce its tariff barriers to demonstrate our good faith at GATT and to encourage the larger, more powerful nations to demonstrate that they will follow our lead.

However, it is quite clear that this philosophy is not working. The EEC and other countries have failed to respond to any of the initiatives taken by Australia and other trading nations. The Australian sugar industry, which is more completely exposed to the chills of international competition than probably any other sugar industry in the world, is now exposed even further without any concessions having been won from our trading competitors. As Harry Bonanno said in an interview on Brisbane radio, no government is prepared to assist any industry at the moment. The major problem we have is the international scene where we are not getting a fair go in trade. Australia is proving to be lilywhite in the area of trade tariffs and no other country seems to be following along the same avenue.

It worries me that, in supporting this legislation, we are not meeting the assurances we have already made to the industry. As I said earlier, the issue here is not whether we believe in free trade but simply whether we give the nod and turn a blind eye to a deliberate breach of promise by this Government. The Government has changed the ground rules midstream.

I remind honourable senators that the total eastern coast of Australia from Cairns down to Grafton, or indeed Coffs Harbour, is to a very great degree dependent upon the sugar industry. This is the industry which is getting hurt and these are the people who are getting hurt. I cannot support further hardship for those in the sugar industry by condoning this about-face with other people's finances by the Government.

The Australian Labor Party has shown that it is quite willing to callously break its promises. But we should not assist it by condoning its actions. I intend to join with my National Party Leader in the Senate, Senator Boswell, to support an amendment to be moved in the committee stage by the Australian Democrats which will meet my concerns about what the Government proposed increased reductions of tariffs contained in the March statement will do to rural industries in Australia and, in particular, to the very important sugar industry in the State of Queensland, which I represent in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991, the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill and the Customs Amendment Bill 1991 which are currently before the Senate set out this Government's policy on free trade. A question which I am frequently asked is: what is the difference between the coalition's policy on free trade and the Government's policy on free trade?
—What is it?

—If Senator Collins just waits, he will find out. It might be the first thing that he learns this year, but he will find out. As we sit here and look at the crisis currently facing Australian primary industry, it is appropriate to address the differences between the policy of the discredited Government which sits opposite us on the Senate benches and those of us on this side of the Parliament. The differences are four.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, we do not believe that it is appropriate to have an increasing rate of reduction on tariffs while the Government fails to deregulate the labour market. This Government is very good at deregulating other people's industries, other people's interests, but it is no good at taking the hard decisions about deregulation of the labour market-and that, if anything, is the one decision which will return productivity and employment to the Australian economy. But this Government will not do it. While it parades itself around the world and takes the credit for deregulating one primary industry after another, it will not deregulate the labour market-and that is the primary reason why this country is in recession at the moment.

The second difference between the policies of those on this side of the chamber and the policies of those on the opposite side is that, unlike the Government, we believe in effective and efficient regulations and legislation to cover dumping and countervailing. This Government likes to make lots of soothing noises about taking action to prevent dumping and countervailing, but it does not have the courage to do so. It was only as a result of the actions of Senator Boswell and my National Party colleagues that we got an effective inquiry into dumping and countervailing, but this Government still dismantles our trade barriers while doing nothing to ensure that goods that are subsidised from overseas are not allowed to flood these markets and destroy unprotected Australian industries. This will be the crux of one of the points I will be making today in respect of the sugar industry.

The third matter, which does not significantly affect the Bills before the Senate today, is quarantine restrictions. I will, however, flag the fact that this Government, though it has been warned by those of us in the National Party time and time again, refuses to take the necessary steps to protect Australian primary industry from the threat of disease coming in from overseas, disease that runs the risk of devastating one primary industry after another. It was some six or eight months ago that I asked Senator Cook, as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, whether anything was going to be done about the threat of disease importation from bananas from overseas. Senator Cook replied to the effect that it was just another National Party form of protection. It does not take long before the wheel turns. It brings me no great sense of satisfaction to say that, within six to eight months of Senator Cook on behalf of the Government refusing to take adequate steps to prevent disease coming into this country, we have seen the devastation of the Australian pawpaw industry through the introduction of cucurbits to this country that brought with it ringspot infestation.

The fourth and equally significant difference between this Government's policies and the policies of those on this side of the chamber relates to the exchange rate. It is a fact that this exchange rate is still artificially high. It is artificially high because of the artificially high interest rates created by the discredited former Treasurer, Paul Keating, which have been maintained by his successor, Mr Kerin. That exchange rate costs Australian primary producers, Australian manufacturers and, most importantly, Australian workers billions and billions of dollars every year. But this Government has done nothing to change its policies.

Therefore, in addressing the three Bills before the Senate today, we have to face the prospect that one day world trade will become more liberal, but the question we must decide today is what we are going to do in the interim. It is a fact that a tide of change is lapping the shores of this nation, just as a tide of change is lapping the shores of every continent around this world-a change in political circumstances, a change in economic circumstances and, hopefully, a change in trade. But at the moment the change in trade is still a long way off. We still have international competitors in South East Asia, in the Americas and in Europe that insist on subsidising inefficient farmers for political ends; yet this Government is allowing the produce of those subsidised nations to flood these shores and to destroy the livelihoods of Australian farmers, Australian small businessmen and Australian towns.

I wish to direct many comments today to the sugar industry in my home State of Queensland, because the sugar industry in this country-and most of it is contained within Queensland-has earnings of some $1 billion. Every year 80 per cent of the crop of the Australian sugar industry is exported. This Government talks about creating an export mentality, yet it is single-handedly undermining one of Australia's great export earnings. Some 20 per cent of the crop in Queensland is committed on long term contracts, but those long term contracts are soon to expire. The question is: are we going to undermine a critical Australian export industry at a time when it struggles to get new export contracts in a corrupt world market, or are we going to say, as we on this side of the chamber do, that what this Government has done in breaking not only its promise to the sugar industry but the Parliament's promise to that industry is unsatisfactory?

The 1990 season has seen severe crop losses in Queensland as a result of the wet weather. It is expected that the new crop will be in the vicinity of 23.93 million tonnes. That, combined with lower world prices, has led to a reduction in the income of the sugar industry of some $200m-a 20 per cent reduction. That reduction in income would have been greater were it not for the fact that the sugar industry has embarked upon a process of rapid and aggressive expansion in the level of production. But there is a problem because in the process of expansion the industry has necessarily incurred costs-long term costs which it will be able to pay off if it is not undermined by deliberate changes in government policy. That is what we are facing. If this Government is to have any credibility in talking about how we need to encourage an export industry, it is necessary for it to have a sympathetic attitude to Australian sugar farmers who are trying to expand their industry and meet the Government's calls for increasing levels of export, yet the Government does nothing of the sort. It has decided, without consultation with the sugar industry, in breach of its promise and, most importantly, in breach of the Parliament's promise, to cut the level of tariffs on sugar.

One of the reasons that Senator Button gave for this cut in the level of tariffs on sugar was that it would improve the processing costs of downstream industries, but the fact is that the price of sugar is but a small component of the costs of processing industries in this nation. I take as an example SPC Ltd, a cannery which uses a large amount of sugar in the preservation of the fruit which it cans for Australia's markets and for export markets around the world. As a result of improvements in industrial relations, SPC had an improvement in productivity of some 48 per cent. Those sorts of productivity gains are available to not hundreds but thousands of businesses around this country, big and small, if this Government has the courage to deregulate the labour market, if it has the courage to allow a change in industrial relations that will create millions of jobs around this country.

This Government does not have the courage to do it. In sitting back on its hands, it has allowed the jobs of hundreds of thousands of Australians to be sacrificed upon the alter of its failed economic policies. It has allowed the job prospects of hundreds of thousands of young Australians to be destroyed for years because it will not make the right decisions, because it is too far in bed with its union mates to see the importance of the necessary economic changes in areas such as industrial relations. If Senator Button really is interested in improving the productivity and the profitability of the Australian preserving and processing industries, why does he not start where the rot is worst-with our industrial relations policies, which do not improve the productivity of Australian industry but take jobs away from Australian workers?

One of the things that we must consider in the reduction of tariffs in the sugar industry is the rate of tariffs in other countries. Senator Button in March tried to tell this Senate that the Australian sugar industry-this is a great one!-is highly protected compared with our international rivals. That, of course, is not the case.

Under the tariff schedule that was first put in place in 1988, I understand that the ad valorem rate of tariff-and the ad valorem rate is a big deception-was something in the vicinity of 35 per cent from 1989-90 and 28 per cent from 1990-91. At the same time, the European Community and France had an effective subsidy on sugar production of $551 a tonne, compared with the rate until July this year of $115 a tonne in Australia. In effect, the European Community is giving a subsidy of 214 per cent of the world price. Thailand, one of our South East Asian competitors, has an effective subsidy of $446 a tonne, or 173 per cent of the world price, and the United States has an effective subsidy of $357, 138 per cent of the world price.

This Government has the audacity to say that a subsidy rate of $95 a tonne is excessive. This Government, in the face of subsidies as high as $551 a tonne, has the audacity to come into this Parliament and say that an Australian industry which has a tariff of $95 a tonne is highly protected in international markets. This Australian sugar industry is one of the least protected sugar industries in the world. It is a sign that this Government, in its headlong charge to implement its policies, will do anything to sacrifice the truth. But these policies will bring nothing but ruin and despair to the Australian sugar industry and will without doubt show the Australian sugar industry that this Government is corrupt, morally, financially and in every other sense, because the Government is failing to do the right thing by Australian industries that are earning export dollars for this nation.

The great lie in the arguments that have been put forward by the Government is that this is an ad valorem tariff. Nothing could be further from the truth. In 1988, when this regime was put into place, it was intended that this would be a set rate tariff specifically because of the high volatility in international sugar prices. What happens? The international sugar price goes down and this Government says, `Goodness gracious, the ad valorem tariff rate is too high; we will have to cut the tariff as well'. The set rates of tariffs were put in place to allow the Australian sugar industry to become deregulated, to expand and to become competitive in international terms-to assist it over the hard times. What has this Government done when the hard times have come along? It has kicked away the props. It has kicked away any possibility that the Australian sugar industry might have had to get through those hard times.

We have heard this Government talking about ad valorem tariffs when the tariffs were never meant to be ad valorem rates at all. This Government is very good with other people's money. It has been good with Mr Connell's money, Dallas Dempster's money, Mr Bond's money-and the money of goodness knows what other people. But I am concerned with what it is doing with canegrowers money.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many of your Party are in gaol in Queensland for that reason?

—It is amusing that Senator Button should interject like that. He comes from the Australian Labor Party, the party of the big black briefcase, the party where Brian Burke can send his secretary down to the local bank and withdraw $300,000 in cash. The only problem was that the $300,000 did not come from his account. It certainly went into his account but we do not know what happened to it after that. Senator Button should not forget that there is a commission of inquiry into the malpractice of the Labor Party and its government in Western Australia, the Royal Commission into an Attempt to Bribe a Member of the House of Assembly and Other Matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I appreciate the humour of Senator Button-and obviously he has to be humorous to make a comment like that-I do not believe that his interjection has much relevance to this debate and I do not believe that it shows that he understands what is going on. We have seen a discredited Labor Government that is looking to attack one primary industry after another in an attempt to undermine the economic fortunes of this nation, in an attempt to divide the very people who are providing the basis of this country's potential economic recovery. That is why we are seeing this Government do what it is doing.

But there is a very specific case to show how this Government's policies have made primary industry sick. That is, of course, Bundaberg Sugar Co. Ltd. In May 1990, Bundaberg Sugar traded at $4.50 a share. At that time the price of sugar was approximately 15c to 16c a pound. Now the price is some 8c to 8 1/2c a pound. Prior to the Tate and Lyle bid for Bundaberg sugar, Bundaberg Sugar shares were trading at below $3.70 each. In other words, the reduction in world prices and the Government's announcement that it was going to reduce the tariff on the sugar industry have eroded the profitability of Bundaberg Sugar and the entire Australian sugar industry so much that we have seen incredible reductions in the value of the share price of Bundaberg Sugar, reductions of something like 20 per cent in its share price.

It is no coincidence that Tate and Lyle made its bid for Bundaberg Sugar shortly after this Government's much vaunted industry statement, an industry statement which this Government said would assist Australian industry and which instead has driven it into the arms of a foreign predator. Worse still, this foreign predator which is launching this hostile bid for an Australian controlled company makes its profits from European Community export restitution payments. Here we see a so-called Australian government ripping away the tariff on the sugar industry-a tariff which it asked this Parliament to promise to the Australian sugar industry. It is driving down the profitability of an Australian industry, driving down the share price of one of Queensland's best companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of Australia's best companies.

—One of Australia's best companies, as Senator Boswell says. Then the Government encourages this foreign competitor to come in with its European subsidies to gobble an Australian company. That is what Senator Button and the Government are doing-allowing a subsidised predator to come in and gobble an Australian company. Mr Kerin, as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, sat by and allowed these changes, these reductions in the tariff. Then, as Treasurer, having delivered the first cut as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin delivered the unkindest cut of all: he refused to say that this bid by a subsidised foreign predator was contrary to the national interest. He has given approval for this bid to go ahead. He has given approval for yet another Australian industry to fall into the hands of foreigners.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have anything against foreign investment per se, but it is very dubious whether anything good will come out of this bid. It is certainly the case that the profitability of Tate and Lyle comes from subsidies which are not available to Australian industry. That is why the moves and the actions of this Government are thoroughly reprehensible and that is why I do not believe it can have any credibility.

We have seen the tortuous and unfortunate saga of the Australian sugar industry. It is yet another primary industry which this Government, through its deliberate actions, has managed to destroy. It is yet another industry where the hand of Mr Kerin has blackened the prospects of its members. The question is: should we as senators allow the promises of this Parliament to be broken? I do not care what promises those opposite may want to break as a government, but should we allow to be broken the promises of this Parliament that came out of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology inquiry into assistance for the sugar industry?

We have a major problem in Queensland with our sugar industry as a result of this Government's policies. I do not believe in good conscience that I can allow the promises of a Parliament to be broken for the vested interests of the Government, especially when the Government fails to do the other four things that are required to make liberalisation of international trade a reasonable prospect for this nation. I do not believe that this Government has any credibility when it talks about international trade, primary industry or manufacturing industry, or any industry of that kind. For these reasons, I will be supporting the amendments to be moved in the Senate today.

Finally, as I said, I welcome the tide of change that laps the shores of every nation around this world today. However, I am concerned about the tidal wave of subsidised goods, the tidal wave of dumped and countervailed goods which is coming towards Australia at a great rate of knots. I do not believe in the face of this tidal wave of subsidy that we should take down the storm walls and allow Australian primary industry to be flooded with subsidised goods. For this reason, I have great pleasure in standing behind my National Party colleagues, Senator Boswell and Senator Bjelke-Petersen, in their stance on these Bills today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the restricted time today, I intend to confine my remarks on the three Bills before us-the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, the Bounty Legislation Bill and the Customs Amendment Bill-primarily to the Government's contemptuous disregard for the sugar industry and the effect that the Government's decision, announced in the March economic statement which is being put into effect by these Bills, will have on the sugar industry, an industry which I might add has directly provided my livelihood all my working life.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of this legislation will mean a loss to the sugar industry conservatively estimated to be worth $16m in the 1991-92 year and $11m in the 1992-93 year. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has a record of broken promises, and Senator Bjelke-Petersen has listed them. I will just mention a few: there will be no capital gains tax; no child will live in poverty; and `I will serve my full three-year term as Prime Minister'. However, one might have expected that, when a government, as opposed to Labor politicians, makes a decision and a promise, it can be relied upon to honour those decisions and agreements. The whole fabric of government, business and, in fact, society falls down if a government makes decisions and commitments and then, after a very short period, unilaterally breaks those promises and commitments. This is what has happened in relation to the sugar industry.

In 1989, following the lifting of the embargo on sugar imports, it was recommended that a specific duty which would be triggered when world prices were less than 12c per pound would apply. There was some hesitation that such a recommendation might be illegal under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, but the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, implemented a compromise solution whereby he directed that the tariff would be $115 per tonne from July 1989 up to 1 July 1991; $95 per tonne from 1 July this year; and $70 per tonne from 1 July 1992. In that three year period, the Industry Commission was to review the rate of protection that would apply to the sugar industry.

However, without any warning or notice to the industry at all, this legislation reduces the tariff from the beginning of next month from $95 per tonne to $76 per tonne, and next year from $70 per tonne to $55 per tonne. Sugar farmers plant in April and May of one year and harvest in the September to December period of the next year. Their decisions on acreages, fertiliser, forward planning and budgeting therefore must be done 18 months in advance. For a government to allow an industry to proceed on the basis that it was receiving a guaranteed price of a certain amount, and then, without any consultation with the industry, unilaterally to change that overnight is incredible and shows the Government's complete lack of integrity when it comes to having any sort of feeling or sympathy with the small businessmen and farmers who are the backbone of this country.

Why the rural industries continue to go around lauding and having some fascination for the efforts of the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, is a mystery to me. All these anti-rural, anti-farmer pieces of legislation were initiated in his term as Minister. The Government's complete lack of feeling for those whose income depends upon their ability to produce is understandable when one considers that the country is run by a Prime Minister and a would-be Prime Minister who have never had to worry about a weekly income at any time in their life except to go around and pick up a fixed amount pay cheque from the pay office at the end of every week.

Tariffs were scheduled to come down in an ordered fashion, and I suspect that the rural industries believed that the Industry Commission would apply further reductions at the end of the agreed period. However, the industry had a chance not only to adjust and work out what was happening, but also to learn to live with the lower prices.

We agree with the general thrust of the Government's direction, but the Government seems incapable of understanding the other things that have to be done to benefit Australia. The Government has squandered the opportunity it had with the 12 March statement to create an environment which would allow real revitalisation of Australian industry, and we will be moving amendments condemning the Government for missing these opportunities. Our amendments call upon the Government for comprehensive labour market reform, genuine enterprise agreements, voluntary unionism, the abolition of security of tenure on the waterfront, the removal of cabotage on Australian coastal waters, and the introduction of a comprehensive goods and services tax which will abolish the current ramshackle wholesale sales tax and allow business inputs to be exempted and so boost export.

The rorts on the waterfront generally are legend in this country and bring about a situation where, because the Government has failed to do anything about real reform of the waterfront and coastal shipping or about domestic transfer costs, sugar can be landed in Sydney from Bangkok at the same freight rate as applies to sugar from Bundaberg. There have been spectacular successes where the labour market has been deregulated. One only has to look at Mudginberri, Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd, the 48 per cent improvement in productivity at SPC Ltd over the past three months after an agreement with the employers, the Powers Brewing experiment, and the 400 per cent increase in productivity at Robe River.

The Labor Government has slashed protection to all Australian industries but, at the same time, it has not given Australian industries the chance to compete with overseas competitors on the same terms as to transport, labour and telecommunications costs. The Customs Amendment Bill 1991 also gives effect to reform of Australia's anti-dumping mechanisms. Of particular interest to our primary producers is clause 7 of the legislation which amends the principal Act by facilitating the use of anti-dumping or countervailing arrangements by agricultural or horticultural industries affected by the dumping of processed agricultural goods.

However, the coalition will be moving an amendment calling on the Government to reduce the current three-tier investigation process to a two-tier one-that is, a 55-day preliminary investigation period after which provisional measures can be imposed, followed by a single 120-day investigation stage. It is clear from the feedback that I get from all over my State that the rural producers are again suffering because of the corrupt world trading regime, sugar being perhaps one of the most notorious cases.

The Australian sugar industry is the most efficient sugar industry in the world, but how can it possibly compete with producers from other parts of the world who are very highly subsidised? France subsidises its domestic price for sugar to the extent of $551 per metric tonne; Thailand, $446 per tonne; and the United States of America, $356 per tonne. This might be compared with the subsidy that the reduced tariffs will give to the Australian sugar industry of $55 per tonne.

It is worse when we consider that Thailand, which is one of our principal competitors, also enjoys developing country preferential trade status in Australia. Put another way, the Australian subsidy is about 28 per cent; the United States subsidy about 138 per cent; Thailand, 173 per cent; and France, 214 per cent. How can Australian industries possibly compete in that sort of a market? When addressing the Queensland canegrowers conference earlier this year, Mr Lindsay Hall, the Chairman of the Queensland Farmers Federation, said:
Farmers have no problems with the lowering of tariffs and freeing of trade. What they don't think is reasonable is for this to be undertaken in isolation from the rest of the world.

It should be made clear to the rural community that it is the current Australian Labor Party Government and Mr Kerin who have reneged on their promises regarding the fixed rate of tariffs to apply from 1 July this year, and have refused to deliver the corresponding micro-economic reforms that would, to a certain extent, have made the tariff reductions much more bearable.

I will be doing all that I can to ensure that the best interests of the sugar industry are enhanced and that we keep industry requirements under review. Solutions will have to be found to provide safeguards for the Australian sugar industry when world market prices are cripplingly low because of the corrupt practices of governments in countries which compete directly with us on world markets. There is no sense in wiping off the map an efficient Australian industry if governments in the European Community, the United States and Thailand do not respond to Australia's lead in attempting to make the world sugar market free and more competitive.

If nothing is done overseas to rationalise world sugar markets, and subsidies and protection that other countries give to their industries, there may come a day when Australia will have to look again at the whole question. I intend to maintain my close connection with the sugar industry so that that industry can have a credible voice in the next government. Short term political actions that only provide ammunition for the Australian Labor Party to cling desperately to power do not interest me.

The duplicity of the Australian Democrats' actions in this debate is shown by their continuing anti-rural stand. I mention the wool debate, where the Democrats held the line for a little while and made sure for a few days at least that farmers in rural Australia would have a low tax. However, I understand from reading the newspaper that they are about to be bought off, that they are not going to hold the line and that they are going to tax the rural community more and more.

While speaking of the wool debate, I should pay tribute to and congratulate the eight Liberal and four National Party senators who supported that debate and very skilfully achieved the result that woolgrowers wanted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that comment, Senator Macdonald. I am not sure of its relevance, but we note it.
—You had better read your speech. It doesn't have a bit in there about an interjection from the Chair.

—I do not need to worry about your interjections, Senator Button. Why not go and look after Coronation Hill and try to do something decent for Australia, rather than sitting there babbling like a little boy. Go and do something productive for Australia.
—Order! Senator Macdonald, address your remarks through the Chair.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am always interrupted when what I say gets a bit close to the bone. Senator Button does not like it to be pointed out to the world at large that the Democrats are being bought off all the time by his Government so that it can get through its grubby little pieces of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I was pointing out the Democrats' anti-rural bias. I certainly hope that the sugar industry does not want to advertise on the electronic airwaves at the next election its anger at the Government's action because, as the Democrats have been bought off yet again by this Government, the sugar industry and anyone else in Australia will not be able to advertise on the electronic media at the next election. That is the sort of anti-rural bias that the Democrats have. How can anyone support any action of a party that is so blatantly anti-farmer and trying desperately to hide its anti-rural bias.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order I now call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw to the attention of the Senate a number of matters relating to the wool industry and the debate that occurred the other night. I also wish to acknowledge and put on the public record a number of faxed petitions that I have received from growers around Australia, particularly from my State of Western Australia. Because of the difficulty of distance, particularly in our pastoral areas, these petitions have travelled from property to property by fax, so they are not in the prescribed form and cannot be presented in this place as such. Nonetheless, I have received some 2,000 signatures that have been recorded on faxes throughout the State of Western Australia. They represent approximately 25 per cent of all woolgrowers in my State. I want to put that on the public record and to thank those people for the interest they have shown in the current debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I will read a number of the messages I have received from them. Obviously, one cannot read all the messages, but it is worth looking at some of them. A fax from Ethel Creek in Newman says:
For the future of the wool industry, we, the undersigned, demand the House of Representatives levy the woolgrower no more than 10 per cent wool tax.
One from the Gindalbie Pastoral Company in Kalgoorlie says:

For woolgrowing to survive in the semi-arid pastoral country, it is critical that the wool tax be no higher than 10 per cent. We have no alternative source of income, so earnestly request that you use your influence on our behalf.
And one from Carnarvon says:
In the future interests of a viable wool industry and its survival, we, the undersigned, demand that the House of Representatives levy woolgrowers no more than a 10 per cent wool tax.

There is a host of these messages. I want to put some of them on the public record so as to acknowledge the position and, hopefully, have the Government recognise the importance of the level of tax to the survival of many people in the wool industry in my State.

I also want to take the opportunity to refer to a couple of things which were said the other night in the heat of the debate and which, in all fairness, need to be put correctly on the table. In doing so I am not intending to have a shot at anybody, but I think the record should be absolutely correct.

I refer particularly to my having been misrepresented by Senator Bolkus, regarding figures I presented to this chamber, when he claimed that I was averaging figures out and started to quote me. I interjected and he pulled off it. I want to make it quite clear that the figures I gave to this chamber the other night in terms of the saving to growers were that for every 1,000 sheep the difference between a 15 per cent and a 10 per cent tax was $750. I also stated that producers, or anybody, could do their own figures from that aspect of it. I was not trying to present a case in terms of the average, because there is no such thing as an average woolgrower or an average producer-it just does not work like that. But when you start looking at the bone fide wool producers-I am talking about those people who receive more than 70 per cent of their income from wool-then the figures go up quite significantly.

I raise another point in order to put the record absolutely straight. Here one has to be critical of the Department in terms of what was done here the other night, when I asked Senator Bolkus whether he would put on the table the figures that had been used or how the calculations of the government figures had been reached, and there was tabled in this place the ACIL submission of May, from which it was said the figures that were worked from had come. It was quoted, against the claim of a number of us on this side of the chamber, when we said that the latest ACIL figures showed that a tax of 9.25 per cent was sufficient in the first year. That ACIL submission of May was not the latest submission. In fact, the submission from which we were quoting was dated June 1991. I request the Government to update its information.

I re-emphasise this point. The situation has changed very significantly since the Vines report was brought down. I refer in particular to the fact that the price of wool has been significantly better than anticipated. In fact, it went over 600c just yesterday. As a comparison, the Government, which I have no doubt has been using Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) figures as well, was predicting at the time the reserve price scheme was abolished that the price for wool would be 300c a kilo. So the current market price is double the Government's prediction back in about January of this year. I note that very recently ABARE has adjusted its figures back up to 475c, which once again changes the scenario very significantly.

Once again, I draw the attention of this chamber to the fact that I have received petitions from approximately 25 per cent of the wool growers in Western Australia and to acknowledge the fact that they are taking a very keen interest in this debate. It is imperative that the Government examines our figures very closely, looks carefully at the latest ACIL report, and accepts the decision of the Senate the other night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On numerous occasions I have risen in this place to expose the human and other faces of banking and of the rural crisis in Australia. I rise today to alert the Senate to the tragic circumstances of the Wilson family of Hopetoun in Victoria. The circumstances of the Wilson family are a classic case of Australian battlers and honest, hardworking Australian farmers. Today they bury their two-year-old son, Mathew. There is widespread anger at the Wilsons' experience of the last few months, particularly of the last few weeks, but in many respects, excepting for its tragic culmination last Monday and today, it is typical of what is happening across Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I will briefly outline the Wilsons' circumstances now and I will seek leave to table a fuller description which has been provided to me in the last 24 hours on their behalf by their legal representatives with supporting evidence. I am advised that there are no matters currently before the court in relation to what is contained in these documents. Matters have been before the court previously and judgments have been made, and those judgments are referred to in the documents that I will seek to table. I have previously circulated copies of the relevant documents to both sides of the chamber.

The Wilsons' case goes back over a period of 20-odd years, but probably the most significant events have been in recent weeks. Mr Wilson was evicted from his farm by action of the Sheriff's Office on 29 May. That was only a few weeks ago. A party of 30 officers from the Sheriff's Office arrived on Wednesday, 29 May, and physically carried Mrs Wilson from her dwelling and placed her on the roadway, and they did likewise with all the Wilsons' possessions. Mr Wilson was not at home at the time. On Monday, 17 June, after the eviction, Barry's son Mathew, aged two, was with Barry on his tractor on the farm. The tractor was of a cabin variety. I understand the child leant against the door, which had not been properly closed, and fell out under the wheel of the moving tractor. Mathew was killed and his funeral is today.
The letter from the legal solicitor says:

The second event is a direct consequence of the first. Wilson's life was thrown into turmoil by the eviction. He has been terribly stressed, both psychologically and emotionally. I could not imagine this tragedy occurring in his life if his life had been running normally.

I am advised that the door had been damaged during the process of eviction and that Mr Wilson was not aware of the fact that the door was not functioning correctly when he placed young Mathew in the tractor before the tragedy occurred.

I was approached by the Wilson family several weeks ago to intervene on their behalf in a last-ditch attempt to avoid the eviction from the property, so I was aware of the circumstances that had been building up. The Wilson's case is one of several hundred cases from the rural sector that I have been dealing with over the last two years or so. Indeed, it is one of about 600 cases that I have on my files.

The build-up to this set of circumstances is not untypical of what has occurred in rural Australia in recent times. Of course, I think we are all aware of the fact that farmers are financially vulnerable by virtue of the nature of what they are doing, the susceptibility to seasonal change and the like. There is an acknowledged financial vulnerability. That was accommodated for by what used to be called a rural bank. But rural banks sold out to the general banking process and the pursuit of profits. Nevertheless, the financial requirements of people in rural circumstances are peculiar to those circumstances.

Over a period of years the Wilsons had made necessary financial arrangements through Westpac and the Rural Finance Corporation. They gave rise to financial difficulties in the mid-1980s. There was an attempt on the part of Mr Wilson himself to restructure those financial circumstances with the assistance of the Rural Finance Corporation of Victoria, whose function specifically is to assist in those processes.

Westpac became involved in this process of restructuring. It is not unreasonable to say that eventually the financial difficulties became such that the bank walked away from him and left him in the hands of the Rural Finance Corporation. Mr Wilson put a series of restructuring propositions before the Corporation. They were all bluntly rejected, but no alternative strategies were devised for them.

The long and short of it is that, slowly but inexorably, as we have seen with so many rural families, the Wilsons found themselves moving towards financial disaster. As is so typical of the rural sector, the financial disaster often is, I believe and have argued in this place, of the making of their financiers. The obligation of those financiers to assist in the management of the financial circumstances is often abandoned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean, I may shortly be replaced in the chair, and it might assist the Senate if I were to ask you whether you wish to seek leave to table those documents now, or whether you are going to do that later.
—I was intending to do that at the end, but I will do it now. I acknowledge the point you are making.
—Is leave granted to table the documents?

—Not at this stage. I would like to give further consideration to this matter. I must say that, while I understand Senator McLean's good intentions, I find this whole issue somewhat distasteful in terms of debate in the Senate. I would like to have the opportunity to look at the documents before I reach a decision.

—Thank you, Minister. Senator McLean, I understand that means that you could, at least at the end of your speech, seek leave again to table the documents, by which stage the Minister may have a different view. Is it acceptable to defer leave at this time?
—That was my intention, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—I am sorry. Thank you, Senator.

—I find it disconcerting that Senator Button has used the word `distasteful' when referring to the process in which I am now involved. I would have thought, since I am acting at the request of the family and its legal advisers and, I believe, in the public interest, that it was by no means a distasteful process. It could certainly be described as uncomfortable and distressing; I find it so. If I eventually seek and am given leave to table the documents, they will be a case history in themselves. I plead with those honourable senators who are now considering the documents to see them in their totality, because that is where their impact lies.

SPEECH.PARA: It might assist Senator Button if I were to now move to the matter of why I brought this to the attention of the Senate, rather than to a consideration of the details of the case. Injustice at the hands of financiers and so-called financial advisers is, as I say, quite widespread throughout rural Australia at the moment. It has given rise to enormous frustration and anger, and I would suggest to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) and to the Leader of the Government (Senator Button), that it has given rise to a potential for violence. I also suggest that we have a responsibility to adopt all possible measures to avert those violent outcomes.

I have not brought this matter before the Senate lightly; nor have I previously brought these matters before the Senate lightly. About two months ago, a woman in Sydney advised me that she was going to take up arms and resist eviction from her property at the direction of a court order on behalf of a bank. I intervened on that occasion, spoke to the sheriff's office involved, and the woman was persuaded not to use arms in resisting eviction.

I am really building up to make the point that, as a result of visits to rural South Australia and New South Wales and soon to rural Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia, I am convinced, on the one hand, that there is a need to build up pressure for action in resolving situations. I have previously raised with the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs the fact that people are not getting satisfaction through court and judicial processes. Often the outcome is to be evicted after having spent thousands or hundreds of thousands of dollars in what are the due processes. Often the outcome is eviction by force. People who are experiencing and witnessing these processes are becoming frustrated, very angry and potentially violent.

I can assure honourable senators that the results of these tragic circumstances experienced by the Wilsons are such that intervention was required on the part of authorities to, hopefully, achieve just outcomes through more prudent, just, calm and compassionate approaches to resolving the problems that these people are experiencing. The problems are widespread and the frustration is absolutely enormous. In attempting to resolve this building frustration, I have appealed to those in authority over and over again in the best ways possible to me. That is the challenge with which we are confronted.

I am advised by this family that they will be seeking to place this matter before the public, for it to be a high profile matter and so that the public share their experience. I do not believe it is unreasonable of them, in view of the 20 years' experience they have had, to seek our cooperation in order to avoid recurrences of excessive use of force in evictions associated with actions resulting from court directions achieved by banks and other financiers.

Often it is impossible for people to fight these processes otherwise. I can tell the Senate that they are now going to do it increasingly in ways which are likely to be most unfortunate. I am simply putting out a plea to those who are responsible, to assist in avoiding what may be further tragic circumstances. My intention in raising this matter in this place at the request of the Wilson family and their legal representatives is no more than to alert those in authority, and the Australian community at large, that we have a huge challenge on our hands. It is one that we have to attend to very quickly and very compassionately.

In closing, I seek leave of the Senate to table the documents which I have previously circulated, admittedly only within the last few hours because I have only had them for that period. I seek leave to table them as a case study, as a substantiation of what I have been saying before the Senate and with the best assurances I can give that they do not bring into the Senate matters which are currently before courts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted, Senator Tate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not grant leave. I seek leave to give a very brief explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the wish of any senator to deny to Senator McLean the opportunity to present documents for consideration by the Senate and for tabling. Indeed, in so far as he seeks to table a series of letters which give some idea of the history of the matter as handled by Rural Finance in relation to the farming operations of Barry Robert Wilson, even though I have not had time to read all those documents and letters I imagine that they themselves are not the subject of a current matter before a court and possibly could be tabled. I would in any case have sought more time to have them examined.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why really I do not grant leave is that on the first page of the letter sent by solicitors to Senator McLean there is an allegation about the circumstances-and indeed an allegation about almost the cause-of the tragic death of this young boy, Mathew, aged two. There is an allegation that the death was, in the terms of the letter, a `direct consequence of the eviction'. The circumstances surrounding that tragic death could well be the subject of a coronial inquiry. I think that it would be improper to table in the Senate documents which make allegations about the circumstances surrounding a death which might be the subject of some sort of coroner's inquiry.
It is only on that basis that I am being cautious at the moment and refusing leave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about a matter that I raised in Question Time two days ago: Austrade and its reconstitution, the position that its current Chairman and Board hold and the need for the appointment of a new general manager. I want to relate my remarks today particularly to that part of Austrade which is to be split from Austrade as and from 1 September: that is, EFIC, the Export Finance Insurance Corporation. It is the part of Austrade which acts as an insurance company for overseas exports and also is in the business of making loans.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the Senate to the debate that took place on 28 May last, in the committee stages of the Appropriations Bills. I was dealing with the question of a loan of $8m that had been made to one Mr Cantor, a gentleman who was found to have links with the Mafia and to have been charged in the United States with a serious offence concerning fraud.

I asked the Minister on a number of occasions to give me an undertaking that the Australian Government, through EFIC, would not continue to risk millions of dollars of taxpayers' money through loans that were being made by lending money to the likes of Mr Cantor. In other words, I was saying that I did not believe that their scrutiny process was good enough. I also pointed out that the $8m concerning the loan to Mr Cantor to build a boat worth $25m, which he presently has, was also the subject of another allocation of $8m through the Department of Industry, Trade and Commerce. So through other methods of assistance the total amount paid to build Mr Cantor's boat was $16m.

The particular aspect that I raise is the assertion by Senator Button, in answer to my question about wasting taxpayers' money, that EFIC does not deal with taxpayers' money. He said, as reported at page 3693 of Hansard:
First of all, the fundamental premise in this allegation is that we are talking about taxpayers' money. We are not.

It is important that the Senate and those who are interested in these matters become aware of the methods of funding Austrade and, in particular, EFIC. First of all, the amount of money that Austrade has to lend to individuals or corporations is money that it first raises on the ordinary market at certain rates and then it makes loans at particular rates which are very often below market rates. The Government subsidises those interest rates by giving an interest subsidy, that is, a payment straight out of Consolidated Revenue. It is very interesting to look at the figures as they were available as at 30 June 1990, and the sorts of amounts of money that Austrade, through EFIC, has in fact been dealing with.

Current export finance loans, which are ones where the capital is required to be repaid as well as interest, amount to $62.9m as at 30 June. Accounts which are non-current, that is, where there are only interest payments being made presently-such as the loan to Mr Cantor-stand at $639m. Of that $62.9m, $12.3m comes from the Commonwealth account, that is, taxpayers' money out of Consolidated Revenue. Of the $639m outstanding by way of non-current loans, $280m is by way of taxpayers' money by way of the Commonwealth account.

The borrowings that EFIC itself has managed to raise are $130m current and $1.108 billion non-current. Of this, EFIC itself borrowed $82.7m current and $820m non-current. Thus the Commonwealth, or the taxpayer, provided $55m current and $282m non-current.

Clearly all these operations of Austrade, through this borrowing program, involve very much taxpayers' money at every turn. And, of course, there is the question of salaries and wages and office space that are all part of the public sector.

Equally, on that occasion, Senator Button referred to the amount of money that was provided for the insurance of our wheat which is exported to Iraq and became particularly relevant at the time of the Gulf war. Indeed, when we passed Appropriation Bill No. 3 we had to provide moneys from Consolidated Revenue to meet payments to farmers for wheat which was not paid for by the purchaser.
Again there was a statement that this was part of a commercial exercise when that is clearly not so, that this risk was carried in the national interest and therefore on Consolidated Revenue.

Now it is important to understand the mechanism by which EFIC makes a decision to accept or not accept a risk, that is, it judges it to be a commercial risk, and the way in which the risk is carried in the national interest on the Commonwealth account. The decision is simply made by the board. In this case that is the board of Austrade because EFIC and Austrade have been one and the same entity and have had the same board. So the board members make the decision as to whether or not they will accept a risk.

If they decide they cannot accept the risk they make a recommendation and the Minister then makes a decision. I cannot ascertain whether or not that decision is subject to a Cabinet decision, or whether the Minister has the power to make it himself. But that recommendation, if it is approved, is then dealt with in this way: a premium is paid which is the equal of the normal commercial premium, plus 25 per cent. The risk is then carried by the taxpayer on the Commonwealth account. The EFIC annual report of 1989-90 showed that the contingent risk on the Commonwealth account was $507m. So we can see that the risk that is carried by Consolidated Revenue, or in the national interest, is really quite considerable.

The reason I have raised these matters is that at a time of review and a time of restructuring of Austrade I think we have to pay particular attention to whether or not the splitting of EFIC away from Austrade is a sensible decision. Bear in mind that EFIC will remain with Senator Button as part of DITAC-the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce-and that Austrade will go to, I think, the man I call `that cool customer', Senator Evans, as part of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. But, more particularly, it will be under the control of Dr Blewett.

I think there are many questions that need to be asked about the restructuring. There are many questions that need to be asked about the delay that has been in existence in the appointing of a General Manager. I understand that Mr Ferris has made it known in the last 48 hours that he will not under any circumstances be an applicant for the position of General Manager. And I believe it is not acceptable in the whole sorry mess of Austrade to make Mr Lindsay MacAlister, the previous Managing Director of that operation, a scapegoat for an organisation which was at all times overseen by the board of Austrade.

I think there are serious questions that need to be examined and I hope that my raising these matters today will begin a more timely process of asking questions so that we can effectively get a much more efficient Austrade body or assistance to our would be exporters and current exporters.

The second point I wanted to raise relates to the question that I asked in the chamber yesterday about the meeting of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) with Mr Nelson Mandela. I asked whether the payment of the $83,000 to the African National Congress, a political organisation in a foreign country, was indeed a condition precedent upon Mr Mandela receiving Senator Evans. Senator Evans gave a lengthy reply concerning how the money was to be paid and went on to detail how the $2m was to be paid. He tabled a news release that he had put out on 11 June 1991. I attempted to move that the Senate take note of Senator Evans's answer, but I was not granted leave to do so. I did, however, manage to put one or two comments on the record by drawing to the Senate's attention the fact that Senator Evans had indeed misrepresented me in the course of his answer. I was able to address one or two points, but I think it is important today to draw the Senate's attention to that news release in some degree of detail.

The most important thing that comes from it is that the Minister purports to rely upon Professor Ross Garnaut's report to justify, in the way which is set out at the back of the news release, his payment of the $2m, that is, $83,000 in kind directly to the African National Congress and a further amount of $US188,000 for an institute of economic research at a selected university, to be established in consultation and by way of negotiation with the African National Congress. Clearly, this again is money which is tied to this political organisation in a foreign nation.

In reading in detail the comments that Senator Evans made, one is drawn to the conclusion that the Minister is equating the African National Congress with the democratic movement in South Africa. It was the democratic movement that Professor Garnaut was concerned to uphold.
