It was in general terms to all participants in that democratic movement that Professor Garnaut, according to the release itself, wished to see assistance given. At no time did he recommend it solely for the African National Congress, which the Government, by way of Senator Evans, seems to have picked as the body which will become the subsequent government in South Africa. It is abhorrent that we have a Foreign Minister who believes that he has the right to choose who will be the elected government after a democratic process in a foreign nation. But, as we heard yesterday, his record shows that he wishes to intervene in other people's democratic processes in places like India and in other nations and make judgments on them. If the world disagrees with him he abuses them, just as he abused the African nationals in South Africa. Indeed, he went to the extent of even using obscene language and throwing things at them.

We on this side of the House condemned Senator Evans in this place only a few days ago for his inability to choose the correct priorities for foreign policy and for his inability to conduct himself in a way which is suitable for a Foreign Minister. All I can say after reading this material further is that the things that we had to say in that debate the other day have been borne out. Indeed, if he had any decency at all he would clearly resign as the Minister.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Warrama Living History Centre Pty Ltd

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Senate has a number of Bills to consider before two o'clock, so I intend to make my comments as brief as possible. I wish to raise the matter of the Warrama Living History Centre-a failed government exercise, or failed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) exercise, in the private sector. The Warrama Living History Centre was intended to be an Aboriginal tourist attraction on the northern beaches just north of the centre of Cairns. Unfortunately, the Warrama Living History Centre from day one has been an unfortunate exercise which has resulted in the loss of several hundred thousand dollars and potential losses far in excess of that.

SPEECH.PARA: At this point I seek leave to table the report of the receivers and managers of the Warrama Living History Centre Pty Ltd as at 8 November 1990. I also seek leave to table the report of the liquidators of that company dated 4 June 1991. I note that these documents were shown to Senator Button previously when he was the Minister at the table.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I open my remarks by quoting one of the comments in the report of the receivers and managers:

SPEECH.PARA: Another aspect of the commentaries and studies we query is the attempt to create a large scale tourist attraction with resultant high wages and overheads from day one. A more prudent approach may have been to commence with a more modest operation providing an opportunity to expand as the market was developed.

How large was this business operation? At the height of its operation, which lasted for some three months only, Warrama Living History Centre employed 78 staff. The details are contained in the report, but I hasten to highlight some of the areas where people were employed. There were 20 people employed in entertainment and performing, 23 kitchen and bar staff and 12 gardeners. That is not necessarily a high level of staff, but one has to consider it by comparison with the number of people who went through the centre. For example, in the six days of November 1990 in which the Warrama Living History Centre was operating, it had total visitor numbers of 42 people. It had three visitors on 1 November, 29 on the second, none on the third, two on the fourth, none on the fifth and 10 on the sixth. The report gives details of the number of people who visited. At no stage did the visitor numbers at the centre ever exceed 215 in a day. There are many days, of course, when nobody attended, but there were still 78 people who were employed there. The receivers point out in the report that, as a result of this, to a very large extent the purposes of the restaurant and bar were to provide food and drink for staff at subsidised prices.

The company was put into receivership as a result of a court order in November last year. I understand, although I am not able to confirm this, that the court order was sought by ATSIC. It must be understood that in this matter ATSIC is a shareholder of the company; ATSIC holds 1,500 preference shares at a face value of $1,000 each. So ATSIC stands in there as a shareholder of the company. It also gave guarantees to various banks which lent money to the enterprise. It is my understanding that the total value of those guaranteed loans is about $596,555. So a lot of taxpayers' money has already gone to support this enterprise. ATSIC, however, decided that it was time to put it into receivership. The one problem is that $310,577 is owed to unsecured creditors in the Cairns area. Those creditors are listed in the report prepared by the receivers and managers.

We find, however, that there is a major problem. ATSIC signed a contract under seal to transfer title to the land, which had been bought by ATSIC's predecessor, to the company. In other words, the land on which the company was operating is owned by ATSIC, but ATSIC had signed a contract to hand this land over to the company. ATSIC, according to the report of the liquidators, now refuses to do so. The consequence is that this land will no longer be available to meet the claims of unsecured creditors. That means, of course, that the unsecured creditors are going to dip out in a fairly substantial way. It is suggested in this report that the amount paid to unsecured creditors may be as little as 4c in the dollar. It is said that if ATSIC waives its priority claim for the guarantee money that it has to cough up, that will rise to only 11c in the dollar. The key, therefore, is whether ATSIC in fact hands over the land, which it agreed under contract that it would do.

The report of the liquidator says that ATSIC is now suggesting that the sale contract is invalid-for what reason I am unsure-and therefore it is not bound to transfer title to the company or its liquidator. The liquidator, according to this report, has sought independent legal advice in order to clarify the extent to which assets rightly belong to the company and are available to meet claims of the creditors. It says:
Messrs Seymour Nulty advise that whilst the matter is complex, the company may have a valid claim in order to enforce the contract of sale, thereby obtaining the title to the land.

Now, there is one little problem. In the State of Queensland, when a matter of this nature is brought before the Supreme Court and the plaintiff is a company which is in liquidation, the defendant is entitled to claim that the plaintiff provides what is called security for costs. In other words, if the liquidator and the creditors are going to sue ATSIC to get the land, to get their money back, they have to cough up their money in advance. The report of the liquidator shows that the legal costs are expected to be in the vicinity of $70,000. In other words, these people are going to have to cough up almost 25 per cent of what they are already owed just to try to get some of their money back.

That is fine for ATSIC because ATSIC is having its legal expenses paid by the Commonwealth, from the taxpayers' money, but here are these poor people who have lost a total of $310,000 and they are trying to ensure that they get the assets to which the company is entitled; ATSIC is relying upon some sort of technicality in the law and is saying, `You can sue us, but we are going to fight you all the way. We are going to use the taxpayers' money to fight you'; and there is a very real prospect that ATSIC will insist on the creditors coughing up the legal expenses before they even get into court, by insisting on the creditors providing security for costs. If that is the case, it will be a classic example of bloody-mindedness by a government entity.

The situation is rather ironic, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Senate is currently conducting an inquiry into the cost of justice, into the high cost of legal fees, yet we find a government entity using the cost of justice to prevent the unsecured creditors of the company from having access to the land which ATSIC had freely agreed to transfer to the company.

I do not wish to go much further in delving into the matter because it could be the subject of legal action, but what I do say is that, if ATSIC is going to be bloody-minded about this solely on a technicality, it is highly unsatisfactory. It shows that entities such as ATSIC have run out of control. They have no sense of reasonableness or accountability. The $70,000, or however much it cost ATSIC to run this legal action, is money that it could be better spending elsewhere. The $1 1/2m of share money was money that could have been spent elsewhere.

While we have a high rate of Aborigines suffering from nutritional disease, while we have Aborigines who suffer from having poor educational and living standards, to see money spent like this is an absolute disgrace. The fact that in three months of operation this enterprise had total receipts of only $48,890 yet losses of $287,000 just on its operations shows that there is no reality in the way ATSIC has invested in this. I am gravely concerned, Mr Acting Deputy President, that an injustice will be done if ATSIC uses its superior position in the courts because it is funded by the Government to bludgeon the unsecured creditors into submission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to discuss Australia's industrial relations future, with particular reference to the policies of the Australian Democrats. Honourable senators will recall that some three or four weeks ago in Question Time Senator Sherry drew our attention to the continuing pressure by Senator McLean to force the Government to legislate for what he calls the right to strike. An examination of what Senator McLean is proposing shows that it has little to do with the right to strike. Australians already have a right to strike, which is exercised far too regularly, to which any observer of our industrial relations scene will attest.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator McLean is about is entrenching union power and privilege. Make no mistake: what Senator McLean wants to do is to remove restraints on militant actions by union leaders. The effect of Senator McLean's policies is to enable unions to call strikes, often at minimal cost and risk to themselves, which can inflict massive costs on employers, their employees and the wider community.

I wish to examine today the reasons why Senator McLean has put forward his astonishing proposal to remove effective barriers to the wrecking behaviour of militant union bosses. Why has Senator McLean reversed the traditional approach of the Australian Democrats, which has been to support the rights of small business against powerful unions?

Honourable senators should recall that the Australian Democrats have traditionally been bitterly critical of the links between trade unions and the ALP. The Democrats' policy speech in 1983, for example, included this reference:

The Labor Party and the trade union movement are by definition, inseparable. With these intractable vested interests there's no way either of these parties can `bring Australia together' . . . would you feel contented to have that power transferred to Bob Hawke, knowing the extravagancies of the trade union movement could be ruthlessly impacted on him.

How right, Senator Sherry, former Senator Don Chipp was-how right he was! The Hawke Government has probably kept one of its major promises, I certainly concede that. That promise was to the trade union movement. That promise was to protect and promote the power of trade unions through legislation, government administrative action and government grants. There is no question that Bob Hawke kept that promise.

In 1984, I remind the Senate, the Democrats joined with the coalition to prevent the Government from repealing sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act. Some of our newer Democrats senators may not recall this, but as recently as 1986 enterprise bargaining formed an important part of the Democrats' industrial relations policy. In 1986 Senator Siddons, the then industrial relations spokesperson for the Democrats, introduced a private member's Bill which, to quote from the second reading speech:

. . . offers a practical alternative to centralised wage fixing. It puts in place a voluntary collective bargaining mechanism alongside the present conciliation . . . framework. It gives a clear alternative to wage fixing while keeping in place the centralised wage fixing system.
The civil courts would have a central role in this industrial relations system in enforcing contracts.

Prior to the advent of Senator McLean, the Australian Democrats were strong supporters of voluntary trade unionism, enterprise agreements outside the centralised wage fixing system, the use of common law torts in industrial disputes and the banning of secondary boycotts.

In recent years the Democrats' commitment to each of these policies has been significantly weakened. Senator McLean, as far as I can see-and I have gone through quite a number of the statements that Senator McLean has made on this issue-has stated five reasons for proposing this major shift in Australian Democrats policy. I wish to examine briefly each of these reasons.

The first reason offered by Senator McLean for a change in the Democrats' industrial relations policy is that 45D `must be set in the contemporary situation' rather than `the environment in which it was framed in the 1980s by the Fraser Government'. He went on to say:
Its drafting was a fairly frantic action by the Fraser Government with the intention of emasculating the unions.
Those are strong words. He continued:
It projected the impression, and was built upon the assumption, that all industrial action is irresponsible.

This statement alone has three errors. Firstly, section 45D was not framed in the 1980s. It was inserted in May 1977. Secondly, the clause was the result of considered recommendations of the Swanson committee, not, as Senator McLean says, an invention by the Fraser Government. Thirdly, Senator McLean assumes that the section was introduced with the intention of emasculating the unions. The intention was to protect independent business men and women from capricious union action. As John Howard pointed out at the time, secondary boycotts had been used by some trade unions to dictate business arrangements which, among other things, had resulted in higher prices for consumers. The need for section 45E, I remind Senator McLean, arose when the Transport Workers Union combined with Amoco to cut off petrol supplies to Leon Laidley, a wholesale petrol distributor.

The second reason put forward by Senator McLean, and this time it was in December 1989, was that the right to strike Bill was in response `to the growing unease and confusion that is being felt within the Australian community following the recent common law decisions on the right to strike'. No evidence was put forward to support Senator McLean's contention about `the growing unease and confusion'. I have not received even one letter from a constituent complaining about sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act. I suspect that you have not received any complaints, Mr Acting Deputy President.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had plenty.

—I suspect that Senator Sherry has not received any complaints from a genuine constituent. I am not talking about one of the union boss mates of Senator Sherry, but a genuine constituent complaining about sections 45d and 45e. I dare say that no-one in this chamber can easily recall one letter that he has received from a rank and file unionist complaining about these sections. I concede that there is considerable unease-indeed outright opposition-among trade union leaders over the effectiveness of common law and the actions of the Trade Practices Act in tackling capricious union actions. There is no question about that great unease amongst the union leadership.

SPEECH.PARA: Attitudes to trade union power by those who describe themselves as Australian Democrats seem to contradict Senator McLean's industrial relations initiatives. A recent survey undertaken by the School of Social Sciences at the Australian National University, amongst other things, asked: do you think that trade unions in this country have too much or too little power? Only 4 per cent of Australian Democrats voters thought that Australian trade unions had too little power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good to see they are taking an interest!

—In contrast, 96 per cent of Australian Democrats voters felt that trade unions had either the right amount of power or too much power. It is worth noting that this poll was taken under the current industrial arrangements where common law actions and the use of section 45d and 45e form part of our industrial relations environment.
—What do the samples show?

—Significantly, Australian Democrats voters want stronger protection against militant unions, not the weaker protection of the type proposed by Senator McLean. Let me say that it was a far larger sample than the example that was quoted by Senator Gareth Evans in Question Time two days ago about the support for the African National Congress. I make that point to Senator McMullan.

SPEECH.PARA: The third reason stated by Senator McLean, this time in a recent Bulletin article, was that legislation had to recognise that industrial action can be responsible. He argued that common law torts in section 45d had been what he described as a `big gun held to the head of unionists'. Again, no evidence was put forward by Senator McLean to sustain his argument that there is a new community move towards strikers.

Unions which behave responsibly do not send businesses to the wall. They do not deny essential services to the community. They do not destroy the businesses of suppliers and others associated with the target of a strike. That is what I would have thought responsible unionism was about. Of course, unions that do not act in this way, as I will show, are most unlikely to attract common law actions and the use of 45d and 45e. Let us face it, if these actions have been a big gun held at the head of trade union leaders or anybody else who wants to take industrial action, this has in no way cowed the union bosses.

Despite the protections afforded in common law, Australia has a comparatively high rate of industrial disputes. This is a curse-Senator McMullan looks curious-in an environment where trade unions are, to quote the immortal words of President Ferguson of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, `part and parcel of the government' and common law actions have been available to employers. It is worth recording the fact that the most significant common law actions have been taken by small businesses facing large, radical unions. The fourth reason stated by Senator McLean is that there is a moral imperative in certain circumstances for people to withdraw their labour. He said:

They can be morally obliged to do so because of circumstances. Now, in doing so, they must be free of an automatic liability under common law or torts because it happens to affect somebody else down the line.

That is a somewhat callous statement. In this statement Senator McLean is misstating how the law operates. Employers are free to withdraw their labour, employees are free to withdraw their labour on proper notice without any liability.

Senator McLean fails to point out the vital fact that no rank and file trade union member in Australia-and this is an important point-has been sued, gaoled or fined for striking, not one. In fact, the number of cases in which unions have had to pay damages during the 1980s can probably be counted on my fingers.

Union leaders and their organisations, however, are liable if they induce people to break contracts. As Peter Costello, our distinguished shadow Minister for corporate law reform and consumer affairs, has pointed out--

TALK.START.PARA: —Extinguished-not distinguished.
—Excellent. I am sure that Peter Costello will enjoy that comment from you. I quote him:

SPEECH.PARA: Unions which induce employees to withdraw their labour (if they would not otherwise freely choose to do so) run the risk of civil liability. This liability is rarely incurred. The individual has freedom to strike. Others are not free to induce the individual to act in a way which he or she would not voluntarily choose. Other citizens, businesses, employers, are subject to the same limitation. They may not induce others to breach contracts. The law protects freedom of contract and the right to have a contract performed.

Do unionists feel they have the right to strike? Over 1,000 strikes have occurred during 1990 and very few have occasioned common law actions. Senator McLean does not understand that even where it would be possible to bring unions before civil courts, employers typically prefer to negotiate rather than to sue. Certainly sections 45d and 45e and industrial torts have been useful in bringing about a resolution of some conflicts. By weakening or abolishing these actions Senator McLean will encourage more industrial disputes.

The final reason stated by Senator McLean is what he calls the `spreading incidence of actions taken under section 45d outside the trade union context'. He cited actions between footballers and football administrators and others relating to school closures and conservation groups.

It is not correct to say that section 45d has been used in football club disputes and school closures. In view of the claims by Senator McLean, I have had this statement carefully checked and there do not appear to be any such cases. There was a case relating to football clubs taken under section 46 of the Trade Practices Act.

In the BHP case, the action under 45d related to threats to life and property taken by the Greenpeace boat. Interestingly, this type of action would still be liable under the McLean right to strike Bill. BHP did not proceed with the action. The company argued:
. . . Greenpeace has a right to highlight environmental concerns but it has no right to endanger lives and damage property.

The five reasons put forward by Senator McLean to justify his right to strike Bill are shown on closer analysis either to have been factually incorrect or misleading, or to distort historical and recent experiences. Not once in all the statements Senator McLean has made recently on this issue has he ever shown the slightest bit of concern for the rights of men and women who suffer as a result of capricious union action.

What of the employees of a company who do not want to strike? What about the supplier companies and their employees who are damaged by unions closing down a firm? What of the sometimes tens of thousands of people, men and women and children, who can be hugely inconvenienced by a major strike? Senator McLean has not said one word about their rights. Nothing in the numerous statements of Senator McLean indicates one little bit of concern about the costs of capricious strike actions in the community.

Senator McLean has brought into this chamber what he calls a right to strike Bill. He has urged the Government to take action. The Bill brought forward by Senator McLean and the sorts of actions he is proposing to the Government do not involve the right to strike-they are an invitation to strike, and on that basis I believe they will be rejected by the Australian community.
