DEBATE.TITLE: FOREIGN JUDGMENTS BILL 1991PROCEEDS OF CRIME LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991COURTS (MEDIATION AND ARBITRATION) BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 June, on motion by Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put the Opposition's position in relation to each of these three Bills. The first is the Foreign Judgments Bill 1991. The coalition is not opposing this Bill which provides for the enforcement of foreign civil judgments in Australia. It is becoming more and more common for economic activity to reach beyond national borders. A corresponding need has arisen for nation states to pursue agreements with each other in order to provide for the enforcement of each other's civil judgments. Such agreements have recently been reached between Australia and the United Kingdom for the enforcement of inferior court money judgments and between Australia and New Zealand for the enforcement of non-money judgments and judgments for revenue debts. The agreement with the United Kingdom represents an interim measure designed to protect Australian interests in the United Kingdom from any harsh consequences that may flow from the operation of the common market convention on jurisdiction and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia currently has a uniform scheme of State and Territory legislation, the basis of which is reciprocity, for the registration and enforcement of foreign civil money judgments. The uniform scheme is largely based on the United Kingdom's Foreign Judgments (Reciprocal Enforcement) Act of 1933 and modelled on the Foreign Judgments (Reciprocal Enforcement) Ordinance 1954 of the Australian Capital Territory. It provides for the direct execution of foreign civil money judgments. It does not depart greatly from the common law rules relating to the recognition and enforcement of foreign judgments.

Under the existing scheme, the countries and courts whose judgments may be registered are specified by way of regulation. In order to be registered the judgment must be that of a superior court, it must be final and conclusive between the parties, it must be for a sum of money and, at the date of the application, the judgment must be enforceable by execution in the foreign country and not wholly satisfied.

This Bill replaces the existing State and Territory legislation. The basis of the scheme is reciprocity of treatment. The new legislation will be applied with respect to judgments of courts of a particular country specified by regulations where the Governor-General is satisfied that substantial reciprocity of treatment will be assured in relation to the enforcement in that country of Australian money judgments.

As with the existing scheme, this Bill provides for the enforcement of civil money judgments of foreign superior courts. This Bill differs from the uniform scheme in that it also provides for the enforcement of judgments of foreign inferior courts where the foreign country provides reciprocal treatment for Australian judgments. In addition, it provides for the enforcement of foreign non-money judgments where there is reciprocity of treatment. As a result of the recent agreement with New Zealand reached in the context of the closer economic relations process, New Zealand revenue judgments will be able to be enforced in the same way as civil money judgments.

Although the Opposition is not opposing this Bill, we have a concern about the fact that the proposed legislation will operate to the exclusion of State and Territory law. The Opposition is usually wary of moves by the Commonwealth to enter a field in which it is the States which hitherto have had the power to legislate. I understand that you might be particularly of that view, Mr Deputy President. In this case, there is clearly an advantage in having one single piece of Federal legislation in that it will be easier to negotiate and implement arrangements with other countries for the enforcement of judgments on a reciprocal basis.

The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) said during the second reading debate on this Bill in the other place that the introduction of Commonwealth legislation in this area has received general support from State and Territory Ministers. The Opposition is concerned that this seems somewhat equivocal. The Commonwealth has also undertaken to consult with the States and Territories before entering into any arrangements with another country for the enforcement of civil judgments.

The shadow Attorney-General asked the Attorney-General during the second reading debate in the other place to explain the precise nature of the types of consultations the Government will carry out. The Attorney-General in reply assured the shadow Attorney that the Government had consulted with the States, although this does not address our concerns about the nature of future consultations. But, despite these concerns, the Opposition is not opposing this Bill as it will facilitate the process of negotiating and implementing arrangements with other countries for the reciprocal enforcement of civil judgments.

The Opposition also does not oppose the Proceeds of Crime Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 which amends the Crimes Act 1914, the Customs Act 1901, and the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987. The principal change introduced in this Bill is the establishment of a confiscated assets trust fund into which will be put funds recovered under the Proceeds of Crime Act, the drug trafficking provisions of the Customs Act and section 9 of the Crimes Act 1914.

The Bill further provides that the money collected in the Trust Fund is to be distributed equally to law enforcement agencies and to drug education and rehabilitation programs. The official trustee is to administer the Trust Fund. The Trust Fund is to be a trust account for the purposes of the Audit Act and the reporting provisions set out in the Act will therefore apply.

Clause 19 of the Bill inserts new Part IIA in the Proceeds of Crime Act. In this new part the provisions relating to the Confiscated Assets Trust Fund are set out. New section 34A provides for the establishment of the Fund. New section 34B provides for payments into the Fund. New section 34C relates to payments out of the Trust Fund. Proposed section 34D provides for the distribution of funds.

Under proposed section 34D(2) half of the net proceeds from the Trust Fund is to be distributed at the Attorney-General's discretion to law enforcement projects which are thought to enhance the detection, investigation or prosecution of major criminal activities. The other half of the distributable funds is to be distributed to drug education and drug rehabilitation programs at the discretion of the Minister for Health.

Although the Opposition agrees that this concept of putting ill-gotten gains to productive use for the benefit of society as a whole is a worthy one, we have significant difficulty with one aspect of the proposal. These funds, because they are being paid into a trust fund and not into Consolidated Revenue, are not within the direct control of the Parliament. There is no specific accountability to the Parliament. There is a significant amount of money involved. It is expected that approximately $9m will be distributed through the Trust Fund in the next 3 years.

The Bill will confer very wide discretions on the Attorney and the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) who will decide exactly how the funds will be expended. However, the Bill specifies no means by which those Ministers should or could inform the Parliament of these spending decisions. In other words, the discretions are basically unfettered.

The Opposition takes the view that those Ministers should be accountable for these expenditure decisions. It is proper, in our estimation, that the Parliament should have a greater role in monitoring the operation of the Act. For example, the Opposition has suggested that such decisions on the allocation of trust funds could be set out in written instruments which could be gazetted or tabled in both Houses of the Parliament, or even subject to disallowance or variation. The Opposition had previously given serious consideration to referring this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for detailed examination. The shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peacock, raised this problem during the second reading debate in the other place. As a result, discussions ensued between Mr Peacock and the Attorney-General.

I understand that the outcome of those discussions is that Senator Tate-or someone on his behalf-will today be undertaking on behalf of both Ministers, the Attorney-General and the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe), that the Government will inform the Parliament of decisions made regarding the allocation of funds under section 34D by tabling a statement detailing all the agencies or programs selected to receive funding within 15 days of the decision being made. The Opposition is satisfied that this commitment will meet our concerns and that a referral to the Committee I mentioned would therefore not be necessary.

The Government is moving amendments to this Bill to add a definition of `prescribed officer' in relation to clauses 9, 15 and 17. These clauses make reference to certain obligations of the Attorney-General or a person authorised by the Attorney, including a power to direct that narcotic goods be disposed of. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee expressed the view that it might be appropriate to limit the persons or classes of person whom the Attorney could authorise. The Government's amendments add a definition of `prescribed officer' as `an officer in the Senior Executive Service'. This is a sensible solution and the Opposition supports these further amendments.

While it is true the Opposition has, from time to time, expressed misgivings about some aspects of the Proceeds of Crime legislation, I would, on this occasion, like to emphasise that we support its aims and we support the measures introduced by this Bill today.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the information that he provided in answer to my question on Tuesday concerning the audit of assistance provided to the projects nominated by the African National Congress (ANC). I now ask the Minister: is the upshot of the carefully crafted words provided by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau in the Minister's answer that none of the projects has ever actually been audited by AIDAB auditors or the Australian National Audit Office?

—The words in my answer will have to speak for themselves. I am not in a position to draw any inference from them of the kind that Senator Kemp does. I will seek some further information responding specifically to that question and give him an early reply.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is extraordinary that the Minister does not seem to know of or have read the words which he incorporated in the Senate yesterday. I point out to the Minister--
—Ask your question.

—I point out to the Minister, Senator Ray, that nowhere in that answer is there an indication that these projects have been independently audited. I have had discussions with Australian People for Health, Education and Development Abroad (APHEDA) officers and they have indicated--
—Order! Senator Kemp, would you ask the supplementary question. This is not a debate.

—Thank you, Mr President. APHEDA officers have indicated to me that the ANC carries out its own audits of these projects. My question is: is it correct that none of these projects has been independently audited by AIDAB or the Australian National Audit Office?

—As my answer yesterday said, these voluntary organisations are responsible for audits of funds they are administering and for the submission of reports to AIDAB. It is competent for AIDAB to subsequently investigate an organisation in question in respect of the auditing of any project that AIDAB wants to do so or has grounds for doing so. I do not know, on the basis of the information supplied to me, whether there has been such a follow-up in respect of any of those specific projects which were the subject of the honourable senator's specific question. I said that I will find out, and I will.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to reports of a speech by the United Nations Secretary-General in which he urged member nations to adopt next year an international convention on climate change. Is it correct that this convention aims to avoid the deleterious effects of global warming, possibly by stabilising and reducing harmful gas emissions, increasing energy efficiency and conserving forests? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the Government has yet considered this convention and, if so, has any decision been made about whether or not the convention's adoption will have Australian support?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Negotiations for the framework convention on climate change, to which Senator Colston refers, which convention would contain appropriate commitments for actions to combat climate change and its adverse effects, began in Washington DC in February this year. The aim is to finalise the treaty for signature at the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, which is to be held in Brazil in June 1992. The second session of the negotiations have just commenced in Geneva, on 19 June, and they will continue until 28 June.

ANSWER.PARA: Agreement that the ultimate global objectives should be to stabilise greenhouse gas concentrations at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate was reached at the second world climate conference in November 1990 by Australia, along with 136 other countries. Energy efficiency was recognised as the most cost-effective immediate measure for reducing energy related carbon dioxide emissions and the reduction of deforestation and the protection and management of forests were seen as important measures to achieve this objective.

The Government considers that the negotiations for a climate change convention are one of the highest priorities for international action to address global environmental problems. We put that sort of position on record as early as the Hague conference in March 1989, which I addressed. The Prime Minister also had some things to say in early 1990 to the effect that there is no greater global environmental concern than the greenhouse effect and the depletion of the ozone layer. So we do strongly support this whole exercise.

We are working in the negotiations for international agreement to the Toronto target, so-called, on carbon dioxide emissions and that involves stabilisation of emissions by 2000 and a 20 per cent reduction by 2005 based on 1988 emission levels. We are also working on reductions of other greenhouse gases which are not controlled by the Montreal protocol as a global target.

A decision on whether or not the Government will adopt the convention-this is the final point, in response to the honourable senator's question-will depend on the outcome of these negotiations and the form and content of the text which emerges. At this stage, it is simply not possible to predict the final outcome. But it is obviously our hope that a substantive convention will emerge which meets our objectives and which can command broad international support.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to his decision to donate Australian taxpayers' money to the African National Congress (ANC). I ask the Minister: did the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) recommend that this money not be given directly to the ANC? If so, why did the Government proceed contrary to the advice of its aid agency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the honourable senator referring to the $2m for the economic planning assistance project?
—Do you want to table the recommendations? Then we will all know.

—Look, the Special Assistance Program for South Africans (SAPSA), formerly the Special Assistance Program for South Africans and Namibians (SAPSAN), has never been directed specifically to the ANC. In that context, AIDAB has had a clear view, as the Government has had, that in the context of development assistance moneys generally-and, indeed, for that matter, any other form of government money-it is not appropriate that money go to a political organisation. It is for that reason that the whole of the $15m over three years that was targeted for projects identified in consultation with the ANC did not involve money going directly to the ANC. I would not be at all surprised if, in that context, there were not some formal recommendation on the books somewhere suggesting as much. There has been no argument about that policy.

ANSWER.PARA: The $2m that has recently been the subject of an announced grant or an announced program over the next two years involves as to one small part of it, namely $83,000, an exception to what hitherto has been the generally adopted and agreed rule. This was not a program that was initiated from AIDAB. It is a program which, as I said yesterday, was initiated essentially by the Prime Minister, arising out of his conversations with Nelson Mandela and others and his view, which I share and the Government shares, that Australia can and should make a useful contribution to the capacity for economic analysis and planning of the opposition movement so as to put South Africa in a much better position so far as economic management strategies are concerned to cope with the new democracy.

It still has a development assistance rationale but it has got quite a different rationale from any previous, specific program that has been adopted under the SAPSA umbrella. As such, we considered carefully whether it was appropriate that one particular dimension of that particular program could legitimately, or should legitimately, involve, for the first time, some direct funds going to the ANC. We decided that in the particular context I have just mentioned, it was appropriate-namely, to establish the ANC department of economic planning.

The funds, as I think I said yesterday, are not being given by way of a blank cheque. They are being in fact given in the form of specific equipment. It is equipment that will be handed over in the form of a library, computers and office equipment of that kind. So I would be surprised if there were any recommendation in existence or comment in existence from AIDAB bearing specifically upon that particular component of that particular project money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you have a look and check?
—Yes, but I would be very surprised because this is not something which has been generated from AIDAB as part of the AIDAB-SAPSAN program.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review by Michael Lynch which states that exports by the Australian automotive industry are expected to top the $1 billion mark through 1991 and the United States has displaced New Zealand as the biggest overseas sales market for Australian car and component manufacturers. Can the Minister inform the House of the export prospects in the remaining life of the current car plan and the likely impact on exports of the new industry arrangements which will replace the current plan when it expires in 1992?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the press report by Michael Lynch and others about exports from the automotive industry. The figures which the honourable senator refers to are based on a press release from the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries. It is noted by the Chamber that automotive exports are now moving towards parity with imports of automotive products, which is something fairly new in the Australian context. This is something which the industry and its work force can be justifiably proud of.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1985, when the car plan began, the value of automotive exports was $442m. The Automotive Industry Authority reported that in 1990 exports reached $938.7m, which is a 112 per cent increase since 1985. Between 1989 and 1990 alone the increase was 44.7 per cent. The industry predicts that automotive exports will exceed $1 billion by the end of calendar year 1991, which puts the industry on track for a targeted export figure of $1.2 billion by the end of the current car plan in 1992.

Senator Jones in his question referred to the United States replacing New Zealand as the major destination for Australian exports. That is largely because of one manufactured vehicle. On the other hand, exports to Japan have grown very extensively in the form of automotive components. Those are the two major developing markets for the industry in respect of those two segments of it.

As I have said, this growth in exports will continue under the arrangements announced in the 12 March industry statement. The point to be made about all that is that these increasing exports are a sign of the growing integration of the Australian motor vehicle industry into the world strategies of major automotive companies. That is something which has to take place. The small size of the Australian domestic car market and the way in which the international industry works make it imperative that Australia get into exports. It is an industry very dependent on volume of production both in terms of quality and costs, and exports become essential in that situation. All political parties should be concerned about those volume implications of the industry.

We have to work, and we have worked, to get our industry integrated into the international one. If we had not done that we would not have had the promising outlook that exists for the industry at present. That fact was recognised in the original car plan. The export figures are a sign of that success and I am confident that exports by the motor vehicle industry will continue to rise.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. I refer to changes in last year's Budget which introduced a penalty deduction of two weeks payment of Austudy, in addition to non-payment of Austudy, for unexplained absences of more than five days in one term. Is the Minister aware that homeless students, for whom Austudy is the only source of income, are having payments reduced without warning or explanation? Does the Minister realise that homeless students have no parent or guardian available to write a note explaining their absence, or to take them to a doctor for a medical certificate? Does the Minister regard the two weeks penalty as particularly harsh in relation to homeless students who at least are making an effort to stay at school? Does the Minister realise that the unsupported lifestyle of homeless students often leads to the odd day away from school-to find a place to live, for instance, when living arrangements break down, or to collect emergency food vouchers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Coincidentally, I have a brief on the issue raised by Senator Bell. I am informed that students are satisfied that the Austudy homeless provisions are treated with special consideration due to their circumstances and that social workers are commonly used to assist departmental staff in processing them. I am informed that where the Department receives allegations concerning a homeless student the facts are ascertained very carefully before any action is taken to suspend payments. For example, a person may allege that a student is no longer at school and should not receive Austudy. This claim would be investigated thoroughly by contacting the school and the student.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department conducts regular enrolment and attendance checks of students on Austudy. These checks have the wide support of school systems. The attendance checks are primarily an incentive for students to remain at school rather than a punitive measure. If from these checks a school advises that a student has discontinued and there is no suggestion that the student is at another school, the allowance may be suspended to minimise the student's debt. In some cases a social worker is consulted. The school is responsible for advising whether it has approved a student's absence. The Department adjusts the Austudy payments based on this advice. If the student has good reasons for the absence from school, this is taken up directly with the school.

I am also informed that occasionally a student may have transferred to another school and failed to tell the Department. In these cases payments would be reinstated as soon as the client confirmed that he or she is still a student. If in these circumstances a homeless student is in financial difficulties, an emergency payment can be approved. I am informed that there are occasions where payments may be suspended without reference to the student or the school, as may happen when correspondence to the student is returned `addressee unknown'. It should be emphasised that this action would result from a student failing to meet his obligation to inform the Department of a change of address. I am asked to stress that the few homeless students whose payments are suspended, usually resulting from their own failure to advise of a new school or a new address, are treated very sympathetically by the Department and payments are reinstated urgently if they continue to be eligible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In light of the Minister's answer that special consideration is given and that social workers are involved, will the Minister be challenging the allegation in the Age newspaper of 20 June this year which claimed that up to 30 students from one Victorian school had recently had their Austudy allowances cut without warning or explanation?

—The article in the Age needs to be tested in accordance with the advice that I have. I do not have any further information. I have not seen the article. However, I will refer the question to Mr Baldwin, the relevant Minister, to see whether his Department can provide further information on the instance referred to in the Melbourne Age article.

—I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether his attention has been drawn to reports of a statement by the Premier of New South Wales to the effect that `the market' is paying corporate executives less today than it was 12 months ago. Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether it is the market or the executives themselves that determine executive remuneration? Finally, can he advise what the current situation is with levels of executive remuneration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the reports by the-as the question has termed it-Premier-by-the-skin-of-his-teeth, Mr Greiner--
—He only got 52.4 per cent of the vote.
—Let us compare the Opposition's predictions with the outcome--
—Order! It is an interesting debate but it means there will be less questions.

—I have seen those reports. The question asked of me is whether it is the market or the executives themselves which determine executive remuneration. In many cases, directors certainly vote themselves their own increases. For there to be a viable market, there needs to be a change between senior executive positions at a great rate. There is some shedding of executive positions, but in the present climate one cannot say that there is much turnover in the major companies.

ANSWER.PARA: Executive remuneration continues to rise in this country and it is certainly above the increases experienced by ordinary workers. In the year to February 1991, average weekly earnings rose by 6.9 per cent compared with a rise of 6.3 per cent in the year to February 1990. The average remuneration for directors of the top 23 companies continued to outstrip the rise in average weekly earnings by ordinary workers, although the increase was not as steep as experienced in 1989. Average remuneration for directors rose by 12 per cent in 1990 compared with 23.5 per cent in 1989.

The figures I have for comparison are of the 23 largest companies. The 25 largest companies, as determined by the Australian Stock Exchange based on their market capitalisation, includes two New Zealand companies whose reporting requirements are different from the Australian companies. Looking at the 23 largest companies in 1990 with Australian reporting requirements, despite the last two quarters experiencing negative economic growth, increases in executive remuneration bear little resemblance to the financial performance of our top companies.

In 1990, in the 23 largest Australian companies with the highest paid directors, 18 directors increased their remuneration by more than average weekly earnings. The largest rise in remuneration for the highest paid director was for the Managing Director of Adelaide Steamship Co., whose remuneration rose by $430,000, or 56 per cent, in 1990 to reach $1.2m. I point out that the group that this Managing Director presided over is now in debt of around $4 billion.

Other large increases occurred for the highest paid directors of the following companies: National Australia Bank Ltd, a rise of $200,000 or 32 per cent; Pacific Dunlop Ltd, up $190,000 or 49 per cent; and Goodman Fielder Wattie Ltd, up $190,000 or 37 per cent. News Corporation Ltd continued to have the highest paid director. His remuneration actually did fall from $12.9m in 1989 to $12.7m in 1990. Average remuneration for each of the 10 highest paid executives in the largest 23 companies rose by 14.6 per cent in 1990, compared with a rise of 16.2 per cent in 1989.

I have commissioned a research project which will look at the determinants of executive remuneration in Australia so that there can be a better understanding of how their rates are set and so the Government can be better positioned and advised as to whether it should take action and, if so, what action it can take about it.

I conclude my answer by saying that it is instructive that the Opposition should feel constrained to interject in the course of my answer and try to distract me from it. The importance of the interjection will not be lost on workers in this country who are being asked to bear the brunt of restraint and often are being prosecuted by the Opposition about their wage claims. It seems that the Opposition feels constrained to simply defend executive remuneration. The Government's position is that, where restraint is called for, it should be equitable across-the-board and no group of employees, directors or managers is exempt from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia, who must have had a lot of difficulty having his hand in the air and not being seen by the Prime Minister on the subject of Coronation Hill the other day. I refer to the Prime Minister's so-called highly principled stand on the alleged--
—I will repeat the question in view of the interruptions, Mr President.
—Order! You will ask the question.
—I refer to the Prime Minister's so-called highly principled stand on the alleged wishes of--
—Order! Senator Tambling, ask the question.

—I ask the Minister about the Prime Minister's highly principled stand on the alleged wishes of the Jawoyn people in locking up Coronation Hill, which is worth $500m. Will the Government give the same unequivocal commitment and understanding to the application that has been made by Aboriginal people in Western Australia under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act-the same one that has been used for the consideration of the Jawoyn-to prevent the development of Dominion Mining's $350m nickel project at Yakabindie?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is called reading with expression. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided me with the following information. In May 1990, the Western Australian Minister for Aboriginal Affairs--
—Read it with enthusiasm.

—Does the honourable senator want Senator Tambling to hear the answer or not? In May 1990, the Western Australian Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Dr Judyth Watson, gave consent under section 18(3) of the Western Australian Aboriginal Heritage Act for Dominion Mining to develop a mine at Yakabindie. This decision was based on recommendations of the Western Australian Museum's Aboriginal cultural materials committee which had studied the report of a survey for Aboriginal sites undertaken on behalf of Dominion Mining.

ANSWER.PARA: This original survey of the area around the proposed development found a number of archaeological sites of low significance. It also identified two nearby known significant cultural sites which were avoided in the development planning. In October 1990, Ngalia Heritage Research Council, representing local Aboriginals, made it known that it was not happy with the original survey as it was felt that there had been limited consultation. The Council requested a supplementary survey. This was eventually agreed to by Dominion Mining and was recently carried out. Dominion Mining suspended further work in the area pending the result of the survey. The findings of this survey, which appears to have consulted a wide range of Aboriginal people, are that the whole area of intended mining development at Yakabindie contains a number of significant sites, particularly Joans Creek which runs through the middle of the project.

The Minister has recently received an application made under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 for protection of Aboriginal sites in the area of the proposed project. The Minister has written to the Western Australian Minister for Aboriginal Affairs requesting advice on what action, if any, the Western Australian Government proposes to take to ensure that these sites are protected. He now awaits that advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Carmen Lawrence say about it?

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the interjection from Senator Panizza. Can I refer the Minister to a statement made in the last day or two by the Western Australian Premier, Dr Lawrence, at a meeting with the mining industry where she said that it was `totally unacceptable' to the Western Australian Government that important new projects representing hundreds of millions of dollars and thousands of jobs were being delayed, sometimes by `vexatious claims' made on behalf of Aboriginal groups. In light of this opposition by Dr Lawrence, does the Minister now anticipate complicated constitutional High Court challenges from the Western Australian Government? Does he anticipate that there will be a necessity for Special Premiers Conferences to be called to adjust the financial arrangements that will be at stake between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory, particularly for Coronation Hill? Will the Minister and Cabinet continue to be the toadies and sycophants of a Prime Minister who is preoccupied with his own vanity and superstition?

—I am sure that there is a question buried in there somewhere. As I said when I responded with the advice given to me by the Minister, consultation clearly has commenced between the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and his colleague in the Western Australian Government. I imagine those matters will be addressed during those consultations.

—Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce advise what role the Federal Government is playing in relation to the proposal by the consortium of British Aerospace Australia Ltd, Auspace Pty Ltd and Hawker de Havilland Ltd to use the Woomera rocket range in South Australia for launching commercial satellites? In view of the strong level of support offered by the South Australian Government for this project and the economic and employment advantages it will offer to South Australia, can the Minister indicate whether the Federal Government is in a position to assist the consortium and the State Government in getting this worthwhile project off the ground?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of a series of thoughtful questions I have had from South Australian senators recently. I must say that I am very proud of the team that we have in the Senate from South Australia-they are certainly better than their football team!
—They should be first in the rocket.

—Yes, that is right. They take a very keen interest in the affairs of their own State. It is true, as Senator Schacht pointed out-and this shows almost a degree of prescience on his behalf-that a consortium of Australian companies announced at the Paris Air Show their intention to cooperate in the development program with a view to establishing an Australian satellite launching facility at Woomera. The consortium is headed by British Aerospace Australia, and includes Auspace and Hawker de Havilland.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposed facility would be capable of launching light satellites-that is, up to 1,000 kilograms-into low Earth orbit. It would be complementary to the proposed Cape York spaceport but, indeed, performing a very different function. A proposal submitted by the consortium to the Australian Space Board seeking financial support for the initial design studies was considered favourably by the Board yesterday. The Space Board sees merit in the proposal and will talk with the consortium about the extended financial support which might be provided through the Australian Space Office. This project was originally referred to as the Australian launch vehicle program. That program was developed in the light of the so-called Motorola iridium project and was considered a serious contender. However, Motorola has deferred the choice of a maintenance launch supplier for a period of some two years.

There is evidence to support the proposition that there exists a growing market for such a space vehicle, quite apart from the Motorola business. An important development arising from the project is the fact that a team of Australian companies which normally have been rivals in various areas of space and aerospace technology has come together, welding an Australian industry competence into an internationally competitive entity. That is, of course, a very desirable target in an industry of this kind. I welcome the honourable senator's question, and I have no doubt that he will keep monitoring the success or otherwise of this venture.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of the extreme concern being expressed by the Australian farming community regarding his statement to the Australian Woman's Day magazine that the live sheep trade `is a rotten trade and it would be good if we could phase it out'? Is he aware of the extent of the importance of this trade to Australian farmers and its benefit to the wider community, to the tune of $250m in export earnings? Is it Government policy to phase out the live sheep trade, or is the Minister out of step with Government policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, at least this is a change from South Africa.
—It is about North Africa.

—North Africa, as Senator Button reminds me. Views about the live sheep trade are quite strongly held in the community, including by a number of people with whom I have spoken within the meat and livestock industry. It is a very commonly shared view throughout the industry that it would be better if over time it were possible to phase out the live sheep trade in favour of killing in Australia and sending the meat abroad in refrigerated form-not only because of the humanitarian, or animal rights, if you like, dimension to the matter but, of course, because of the employment implications and the value added factor involved.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not Government policy in any way to inhibit the operation of that trade at the moment, although a number of events in recent times in the Middle East, and in particular in the trade as it relates to Saudi Arabia, have operated in practice as such an inhibition, and efforts have been made to seek alternative ways of getting the same export volume and value, but by other means.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is rotten about that?

—I do not think I need to go into details for Senator Alston. If he is insensitive enough not to appreciate what the down side associated with the live sheep trade is, I do not think I can help him in this place.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In light of the Minister's answer, I ask him whether his attitude has caused only half-hearted attempts by the Government to seek the full restoration of the trade.
—One of the rotten down sides is that we get more money if we process the meat.

—As Senator Collins just said, repeating what I said in my opening burst, it has not had anything to do with any sort of inadequate attempt to recapture the trade that was lost as a result of quarantine and other related restrictions imposed by Saudi Arabia. In fact, we have been trying very hard to overcome those problems as they have arisen each time. But, I repeat, in the longer term it is a very widely held view within the industry and elsewhere that here, as elsewhere, it makes more sense to value add, if you like, by doing the killing in Australia and creating additional employment in Australia, quite apart from avoiding all the rather nasty humanitarian implications that are associated very often with the long sea voyage for these animals.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer the Minister to press reports today that an Ansett A320 jet was forced to land at Perth Airport yesterday on one engine. Can the Minister provide the Senate with any details of this incident and indicate whether the safety of those on board this aircraft was seriously threatened?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noticed Senator Panizza becoming suddenly alert when that question was asked. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has provided me with the following information. The aircraft was operating as Ansett Australia flight 161 from Sydney to Perth. At 1056 hours the pilot reported that the right engine thrust reversing system warning light had illuminated. The right engine was reduced to idle power and the descent of the aircraft was commenced, the aircraft being unable to maintain a cruising altitude of 35,000 feet on one engine. The aircraft was stabilised at lower altitude and the flight continued to Perth. Normal landing was carried out at 1210 hours local time. The nature of the fault has not yet been determined. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation is investigating the incident.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be noted that the Ansett airbus fleet is equipped with different engines from those on the Lauda 767 which crashed in Thailand; that is, they are equipped with General Electric Snecma CFM56-type aircraft engines, compared with the Pratt and Whitney 4,000-series engines on the Lauda aircraft. The aircraft has since been flown back from Perth to Melbourne without passengers on board. The aircraft is effectively grounded while the problem is investigated by Ansett. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation is continuing its investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. It follows his answer to a question asked by Senator Schacht about Australian companies involved in the proposed new satellite launching facility, and I congratulate those Australian companies involved. I ask the Minister: why have all Australian companies, including those that the Minister mentioned, been excluded by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) from the tender list for the proposed new systems to control Australian airspace?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That question would probably be more appropriately directed to the Minister responsible for the Civil Aviation Authority. However, let me say that I have had some interest and involvement in this question. From my own knowledge I can say that, after the tenders were called for the dual system, as I think it is called, proposed by the CAA, a number of international companies responded. Efforts were certainly made to put together an Australian consortium, which would be a prime tenderer for the work to be done, which involves a very large contract.

ANSWER.PARA: Subsequent to that, I have been involved in arranging meetings between the CAA and Australian companies interested in participating in the contracts. Those meetings and discussions are ongoing. My own view about these matters is that Australian instrumentalities-government or semi-government-should have very high in their priorities the giving of work or contracts as far as possible to Australian companies which can provide the quality of service and product required. I am not in a position to judge whether that was so in this case, but let me simply say that I have been endeavouring, through my Department, to get Australian companies involved in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen press reports that China is seriously considering signing the Treaty for the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and could agree to join the Missile Technology Control Regime? What is the Australian Government's response to that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen those reports and Australia would very warmly welcome such decisions being made by China. We have long urged that country to adhere to the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty. During my recent visit to Beijing, I again encouraged the Chinese to join the Treaty. I also urged that, with the experiences of the Gulf war in mind, serious consideration be given to China's seeking membership of the Missile Technology Control Regime and certainly the Australian Government remains very keen that China takes action in these areas at an early date.

ANSWER.PARA: Were China to join the NPT, this would be really a very significant contribution to the international community's efforts to strengthen the barriers against nuclear proliferation. With France's recent decision to adhere to the NPT, the situation is that China will remain the only nuclear weapon state outside the scope of that particular treaty. Obviously, its accession to it will give it a major boost, which is important at a time when the review for the whole future of the Treaty is coming up in the mid-1990s.

China is a major producer and exporter of missiles and missile technology and its membership of the Missile Technology Control Regime would again obviously be a major step forward for the effectiveness of controls on missile proliferation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the United States sale of 100,000 tonnes of subsidised wheat to Kuwait. In the light of the undertakings given to Australia by the United States Government earlier this year that our traditional markets would not be targeted, and our Prime Minister's various statements that no one section of Australia would carry the Gulf war burden, I ask: what will the Minister and the Government do about the situation, apart from expressing strong concern, as Dr Blewett has done?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can do at this stage is repeat that very strong expression of concern and refer to the fact that Dr Blewett has today written a personal protest to the US Secretary of Agriculture stressing Australia's concerns at the initiative. The obvious ground for concern is the manifest way in which-as Senator Panizza says-this particular initiative does, on the face of it, run headlong into the terms of the assurance given by the United States President himself to Prime Minister Hawke in a letter of 25 March when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: All possible care will be taken to avoid disruption to traditional markets where Australia as a non-subsidising exporter has significant interests. This includes Middle East markets in the post-war period.

The concerns obviously stem from the price depressing effect that this carries with it for Australian sales to the Middle East region, particularly the Gulf, which is the major market for Australian wheat exports.

How the Government will proceed, if and when it proves to be the case that protests currently being made and the concerns currently being expressed are not heeded, is something for the Government to consider in the light of all the circumstances. But I do not think that anyone should be in any doubt as to how seriously we take this latest effort in subsidised market penetration by the United States and how much at odds with both its commitments to Australia and its purported commitments to more liberalised international trade regime we regard this as being.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his reply to date; I know that 100,000 tonnes is not a big sale as a one-off, but the lower price can flow into a general lower price over the whole wheat crop. Does the Minister not think the situation is serious enough to immediately send away a higher delegation than that which went last time, namely, himself?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted by that expression of confidence on the part of Senator Panizza and I am glad to hear that it is shared by all those opposite! I will take that suggestion very seriously indeed, because I think it is an entirely helpful and positive one.

ANSWER.PARA: The short point is that whatever the order of magnitude of this particular sale, it is, as Senator Panizza says, something which can have, even in its own terms, an impact on pricing in that particular market. But more importantly, it raises the question of future policy for larger sales in the Middle East and it also raises the question of the value of assurances to us from the United States. We take it very seriously and we will take every possible sensible action available to us to correct it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface my question by referring to superannuation industry estimates of a current inflow of net investable funds of the order of $15 billion annually, rising within 10 years to net investable funds of $60 billion per year. I ask the Minister: will the Government consider measures to ensure that this welcome increase in domestic savings is used to redress Australia's catastrophic level of unemployment, including directing a substantial proportion of superannuation funds into government guaranteed loans to public utilities for urgently needed infrastructure investment and limiting offshore investment by superannuation funds? Both measures would be a recognition that these funds are savings which belong to Australians and which should be used to provide jobs for Australians, provided that adequate security and return on investment are assured, which they are in this case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I am not sure that investment behaviour should be dictated by total assurance of no risk in respect of return on capital. Having said that, let me say that the question is an important one. It is a sensitive issue at the present time in terms of the considerable debate taking place within the superannuation industry-
—They won't have a bar of it, including your proposal.

—The poor old know-all; he knows everything, this bloke! Senator Alston has no idea about the debate taking place within the industry about these issues. It is very significant and substantial. Part of the reason is that in the 1970s and the 1980s, large funds were devoted to office buildings in Australia's cities, tourist resorts and things of this kind.
—A lot of that was due to the levels of inflation.

—I am not arguing the reason; I am saying that this happened. As a result of taxation changes and over-investment in these areas, the pattern of investment for some of these institutions will change. The question is what it is likely to change to. If one looks at both the infrastructure demands and the industry demands in the Australian economy, I think it is important that this debate be progressed with much more sympathy, if I can put it that way, to the demands of infrastructure and productive industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Various estimates are given of the aggregation of superannuation investment funds and so on; they differ from time to time. There is no doubt that there is a very significant aggregation of investable funds in the superannuation industry. On the question of whether a government should prescribe the provision of guaranteeing loans to public facilities, as Senator Spindler put it, or limiting offshore investment, it is not my view that government should prescribe these things.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope it is not the Government's view, either.

—Well, Senator Spindler asked for my view, and that is what I am responding to. These questions are always facilitated by interjections. It is only this Opposition that will amend a question. One can amend an answer, but I am sure that Senator Spindler does not want his question amended by the Opposition. That is my view of these matters. The points that Senator Spindler raises are important and have to be dealt with in the context of the behaviour of institutions in the next few years.

—Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support aware that 45 ships were held up in yesterday's stoppage called by the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia as a result of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission decision on Tuesday? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the daily cost of this stoppage and the value of any export cargo that was held up? Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister that Australian waterfront reform is still on track after yesterday's disastrous stoppage and the threat of more to come?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the significant problems caused by yesterday's stoppage, and I am confident in respect of the negotiations that have been continuing since then by the Prime Minister and me that there will be no need for any further industrial action. There is no question that the progress of waterfront reform has been significantly impeded by the problems associated with the recent national wage case decision.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts are that we and the parties are concerned that the Commission in its most recent decision appears to have misunderstood the agreement that was reached between the parties at the negotiations in Sydney. We are consulting with the parties, both unions and employers, and we will be seeking to have those matters placed again before the Commission. I am confident, in the light of the negotiations which are proceeding, that so far as the unions are concerned no further industrial action will be necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs and it relates to the Government's position on a consumption tax. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the impact on consumers of a consumption tax set at 15 per cent, especially the impact upon the disposable incomes of lower and middle income earners? Can the Minister identify any advantages for consumers in such a tax, or is it simply a case of nothing but an added impost accompanying every retail purchase?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very difficult to see any advantages to be gained by consumers in the Australian marketplace by the imposition of a consumption tax. Certainly the Government cannot identify any, and is firmly opposed to the introduction of such a consumption tax. As Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, I am very concerned about the effect of a possible consumption tax on shoppers and consumers out in the shopping malls and marketplaces of Australia particularly, as Senator Loosley has indicated, those on a low income or on a fixed income.
—Are you concerned about the taxes they are paying now?
—Senator Vanstone should be very worried about this, too, because retirees who have put money away will find in relation to their savings--
—There would be a compensation package for them.

—Senator Watson is now putting forward parts of a possible Opposition policy on consumption tax. I am not referring to that policy; I am being very careful not to. I am simply saying that if there were a consumption tax, then those who have retired and squirreled away some savings to provide for their own upkeep during their retirement rather than depend on a pension will immediately find those savings devalued by the imposition of a consumption tax. It is not very clear at all that there will be any form of compensation offered in a way that will compensate those retirees as opposed to those who are on a particular income from social security.
—They will be looked after.

—Senator Watson says that they will be looked after, but the fact is that there has been no identification of how they might be looked after. I am sorry, Mr President, that I have been drawn into responding to an interjection and should not have done so. The fact is that those on low and fixed incomes will be in a perilous situation out in the marketplace with the imposition of a tax, whether it is 15 per cent, 12.5 per cent or whatever. Senator Loosley referred to the retail sector, and to have 12.5 per cent added to the purchase of food and beverages, medicines or drugs, would put an intolerable burden-a regressively imposed burden-on people which would require some sort of compensation. But certain costings have been done that show that the cost of compensating such people would amount to billions more than the additional indirect revenue raised.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to services, too, not merely goods out in the marketplace, when one looks at visits to the doctor, dentist or lawyer, or to the purchase of child care services, tourism and so on, one discovers that if a consumption tax is added to those services, quite clearly there will be a grave impact on the household expenditure patterns of people, particularly those on low incomes or on those who have retired on fixed incomes. I find it impossible to identify any advantages but, instead, see terrible disadvantages. Therefore, the Government is reinforced in its view that there should be no consumption tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It follows Senator Panizza's question regarding the sale of 100,000 tonnes of wheat to Kuwait. When will Australia get some dividend from leading the world in its free trade attitude? We have given away the sugar embargo, there has been a destabilisation of the domestic wheat price, the abandoning of vegetable tariffs, the harmonisation of our food standards and reducing them and so on. When will the rest of the world come into line with us, or will we continue to lead the world in trade and get no return?

—Australia makes no apology for taking the robust attitude that we have towards free trade principles in so far as agricultural trade, and indeed trade generally, is concerned. Every sophisticated analysis-and I am not talking about a National Party analysis-that has been done of the costs and benefits to this country of adopting this policy strategy has manifestly demonstrated beyond any possible colour of sensible qualification that that is the way for us to go. The conspicuous context in which we are finding that out is the Uruguay Round. Obviously the agricultural dimension of the Uruguay Round is crucial to the future health of our export economy. If Senator Boswell has not appreciated that basic fact, I wonder why he is occupying the exalted position that he is.

—Has the Minister for Social Security seen an article in the Sun-Herald of 16 June in which it was suggested that older widows, who have little or no chance of getting a job, are being forced by the Government to take up unemployment benefits and enter the job market? Who is now eligible for a class B widows pension and why is this pension being phased out?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The surprising thing about the article in the Sun-Herald to which Senator Zakharov has referred is that the phasing out of the class B widows pension has been going on since July 1987; it is hardly a new issue. In the last 12 months I do not think I have had a question on it, so I am surprised that it could suddenly be seen as anything new. The decision taken in July 1987 was an attempt to reflect a changed community attitude. It must be remembered that that widows pension was first introduced in 1942. I think the attitude towards the role of women in our society has changed pretty dramatically during the course of the last half a century. The Government recognised that in 1987 and set out to encourage women who finally had more time on their hands, as their children had moved on, to enter the work force.

ANSWER.PARA: The truth has been that most of the women so affected have welcomed those initiatives. Specifically, those who are eligible for that pension now are widows aged 45 at 1 July 1987 who received a class A widows pension or supporting parent benefit, or who subsequently became eligible for one of those payments; women aged 50 or more on 1 July 1987; and women who, before 1 July 1987, were receiving a class B widows pension.

In fact, the numbers have gradually been going down. There were 83,500 women on that pension in June 1989, the number went down to 78,700 in June 1990 and to 74,700 this year. So the numbers have continued to decline. We all need to show some concern for women who have been out of the work force for often 30 years; they will find the transition difficult. I think, therefore, that we have to attempt even more to give them priority in the Newstart program. We shall certainly be doing that. During the recession there may well be a special case for them regarding the amount of reporting requirements there are for activity testing. That is something else we will be looking at.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—On 3 June Senator Macdonald asked me a question about the effects of the pilots strike on small business in north Queensland-I think that was the point of the question. I undertook to get him some information about the impact of the pilots strike on businesses in north Queensland. I have obtained that information and I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 June (Hansard, page 4083) Senator MacDonald asked me as the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question without notice about the number of businesses, particularly in North Queensland, that went into liquidation as a result of the Government's actions during the pilots' strike. I undertook to try to find out the extent of small business failures due to the pilots strike.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.
Unfortunately, no statistics are available that indicate the number of business failures that were attributed by the owners to the effects of the pilots' strike.

A survey on the impact of the pilots' strike on Queensland conducted by the National Centre for Studies in Travel and Tourism and commissioned by the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation concluded that the pilots' strike had an extremely negative impact on Queensland's tourism industry. The estimated loss in direct visitor expenditure during the first 13 weeks of the pilots' strike was nearly $200m. Mackay, the Whitsundays, Townsville and Cairns were the most severely affected. Forward bookings in hotels/motels for December 1989 and January 1990 were down considerably compared with the previous year. The Australian Bureau of Statistics' figures for occupancy rates (the proportion of available room nights sold) for licensed hotels and motels etc confirm that Northern Queensland tourist centres recorded large falls in occupancy rates over this period.

Anecdotal evidence suggests that the pilots' strike was one of a number of factors to have had a detrimental impact on the North Queensland economy during 1989 and 1990. Other factors were the downturn in the building industry, cyclones and the earlier switch in tourism demand away from North Queensland to Brisbane as a result of Expo.''

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary answer to a supplementary question asked on 18 June by Senator Coulter concerning nuclear power reactors for Indonesia. I said yesterday that Australian uranium exports are enriched in the United States, France and the United Kingdom. These three countries are major enrichers of uranium. Further to that answer, I wish to add that I have now been advised by my Department that Australian uranium is also enriched in The Netherlands, Germany and Japan, countries which are also covered by Australian bilateral safeguards agreements. I put that on the record for the sake of completeness.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Knowles yesterday, I undertook to supply her with further information relating to three specific grants made through the Australian Embassy in Pretoria in 1989-90. I had assumed from her reference in the question to the grants being made through the embassy that the funds probably came from the direct assistance program-which is the small project aid fund administered by ambassadors generally around the world-rather than from the specific Special Assistance Program for South Africans and Namibians (SAPSAN). My checking has established that the grants were made under the SAPSAN program. The three projects mentioned by Senator Knowles primarily involve support for specific training activities and skills upgrading, predominantly for unemployed union members.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the grant to the South African Black Hawkers and Informal Business Association-SABHIBA-this project involved the training of young blacks in basic business skills and technical training in the shoe repair business, and had a strong developmental focus, especially in view of the size and importance of the informal sector in the South African economy.

The grant to the Building Industry Workers Union of South Africa supported training courses for shop stewards in legal and human rights issues. The grant to the National Union of Steel and Allied Workers project provided panel beating and spray painting equipment for a training workshop to upgrade the skills of unemployed union members and school leavers.

The proposals for these projects were carefully appraised by staff at the Australian Embassy in Pretoria and were judged to fully meet SAPSAN program guidelines. Those guidelines were set out in full in my answer to question No. 639 from Mr Cobb in the House of Representatives. They require that grants meet program objectives including, for example, that they meet humanitarian needs caused by apartheid and help prepare disadvantaged South African inhabitants and refugees for the post-apartheid era.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question was whether they were properly audited.

—I am getting to that. Approval for each of these activities was given by the Australian Ambassador on the basis of a recommendation from staff. The Australian Embassy monitored the progress of individual projects through visits and regular meetings with officials and through the assessment of project reports. As noted in the SAPSAN review report, the post has been particularly conscious of the need for proper attention to financial management. Despite staffing constraints, the embassy has been assiduous in monitoring projects which provide good opportunities for projecting Australia's development in human rights concerns to ordinary South Africans. On the basis of reports available, I am advised that none of these grants have been allocated to purposes other than development assistance properly so defined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of Senator Button, I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the timeliness and quality of annual reports. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION THE TIMELINESS AND QUALITY OF ANNUAL REPORTS
JUNE 1989
SCHEDULE OF RECOMMENDATIONS AND RESPONSES

1. The Departments of Finance and Prime Minister and Cabinet (PM&), together should identify and remove any areas of unnecessary overlap between the requirements for departmental annual reports and explanatory notes. This review should not lead to any loss in public access to any item of information currently available in either annual reports or explanatory notes. Any removal of overlapping requirements should not involve a reduction in the scope of annual reports.

Revised guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports were issued in early 1991 and include (at page 14) a section on Portfolio Program Performance Statements (formerly called Explanatory Notes) and annual reports, which was prepared after extensive consultation with departments and other agencies and which sets out the functions of Program Performance Statements and annual reports. There should be very little overlap between the two kinds of document, but the amount of information made available either in one kind or the other has not been reduced and the requirement that annual reports be prepared in such a way that they can be understood on their own has been retained.
2. The annual reporting guidelines for both departments and statutory authorities should be renamed `annual reporting requirements'.

The Government notes the recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts (JCPA) that `when it is procedurally convenient to do so, the Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports be renamed as Departmental Annual Reporting Requirements, or an equivalent title' (recommendation 4, Report 304, Guidelines for Departmental Annual Reports).

Subsection 25(7) of the Public Service Act 1922 requires that departmental annual reports be prepared in accordance with `guidelines' from time to time presented to the Parliament. The Government expects to introduce in the 1991 Budget sittings an amendment substituting for the reference to guidelines a reference to requirements. Once amended legislation comes into effect, the guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports will be renamed accordingly. Departments will continue to be reminded in letters from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (PM&) each year that subsection 25(7) makes compliance mandatory.

When the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced, consideration will be given to issuing the new document under the heading Requirements.

3. Urgent action should be taken by the Departments of Finance and Prime Minister and Cabinet to develop new draft annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities. The accountability role of annual reports should be the principal focus of the review.

The Government notes that this recommendation has been supported by the Senate Standing Committee (SSC) on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its Report on Annual Reports Referred to the Committee (May 1990, p.6). It notes, too, that the JCPA has recently reported following its inquiry into annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities. The task of co-ordinating work on the drafting of new requirements in relation to the annual reports of statutory authorities will involve consultation with a wide range of agencies, taking into account issues raised in submissions to the JCPA on the subject by PM&, the Department of Finance and other agencies, the recommendations of the JCPA, and issues raised by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration (SSCFPA) in paragraph 3.36 of its own report.

The Government agrees that the primary purpose of authorities in producing their annual reports should be to meet requirements in relation to accountability. The Government will continue its practice of considering recommendations and comments by parliamentary committees.
4. The Government grant to RAIPA should be increased to something in the range of $12 000 to $15 000 per year.

The Government notes that the Committee made its recommendation `Having regard to the value of the [annual reports awards] scheme' conducted by the ACT Division of RAIPA. The Government made a grant-in-aid of $5000 to the ACT Division for 1990-91. The grant was for the purpose of providing supplementary assistance towards general administrative costs, including costs associated with its annual reports awards scheme. The Government does not consider that a grant of $12 000 to $15 000 would have been warranted.
The ACT Division will have an opportunity to apply for another grant next year.
5. The Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet should maintain a register of non-statutory bodies (NSBs) containing specified data on all such bodies as proposed in the Committee's 1986 report.

Since the Government's response of 8 December 1987 to the report on NSBs referred to in the recommendation, information about NSBs has been required in annual reports either of NSBs themselves or of their parent bodies, as the respective Ministers decide. There is also a requirement that parent bodies, in their annual reports, list any NSBs which produce their own annual reports, showing to whom those reports are presented and whether they are tabled in the Parliament or made public in some other way. The result of these requirements has been that information about NSBs is made available but that there is recognition of the possibility it may be available in reports not presented to the Parliament.

Provided annual reports containing information about NSBs are tabled, the Parliament has easy access to all the information in them. To ensure this, the Government will now require information about NSBs to be provided in annual reports (their own or their parent bodies') which are presented to Ministers and the Parliament. This requirement should close off any possibility that information might not be readily available to the Parliament.

It also underlines the accountability of NSBs to Ministers, in line with the Government's response of 8 December 1987 referred to above. However, while it is appropriate that Ministers and the Parliament should have information about NSBs, PM& has no such monitoring role as would be implicit in a decision that it should maintain a central register.

As pointed out by the Prime Minister in a letter of 11 February 1988 to the Committee on the subject of a proposed central register, committees wishing to examine NSBs would need to consult a collection of annual reports anyway, whether or not a register existed. It is sensible to make annual reports the comprehensive source of information about NSBs.

It may, however, become possible for the Government to offer committees further assistance. PM& is at present looking into ways of implementing the Government's announcement in its National Agenda for a Multicultural Australia (June 1989) that appointments of people in the EEO target groups to statutory and other government bodies would be monitored and that PM& would introduce a computerised system to record the findings. It may be found that this computerised system will facilitate the production of lists of bodies, including NSBs, to which appointments are made.

If that should prove to be the case, the Government would consider making such lists available for committees to use for their own purposes. In the meantime, agencies will continue to be required to provide in their annual reports lists of all NSBs of which they are the parent bodies and to show in relation to each listed NSB whether information about it appears in the tabled annual report of the NSB itself or in that of its parent body.
6. A review of the scope and content of the annual reporting guidelines for departments should be undertaken by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in conjunction with the JCPA.

The guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports have been reviewed, taking into account comments and recommendations of the JCPA and other parliamentary committees. Revised guidelines were presented to the Parliament in early 1991 after approval by the JCPA.
7. The current [departmental annual report] guidelines should be fully adhered to until they are revised after that review.
PM& wrote to all departments in 1989 and 1990 about the need to comply with the 1987 guidelines as amended. Compliance is a requirement under the Public Service Act 1922.

8. Procedures for future amendment of the guidelines should be adopted that involve, as a minimum: consultation before amendments are promulgated, and public hearings by the JCPA where such consultation reveals significant objections to the amendment.

The Government notes that the JCPA has recommended that `PM& establish procedures to receive and consider proposals for amendments to the Guidelines for the [Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports]' (recommendation 5 of Report 304, Guidelines for Departmental Annual Reports).

Revised departmental annual report guidelines were issued in 1987 and 1991 after consultation involving PM&, the Department of Finance, other departments and certain agencies. When the 1991 guidelines were prepared, the Government had available to it the views and recommendations of the SSCFPA and other Senate committees and the JCPA, as set out in a number of reports. These views and recommendations were taken into account. The JCPA approved the guidelines issued in 1987 and 1991 before they were presented to Parliament as required by the Public Service Act 1922.
