Procedures for amending the guidelines in future are set out in the preamble to the revised guidelines at page 7 and will be as follows: PM& will write early in the second half of each financial year to all departments about the guidelines to be followed in the preparation of that year's reports; at the same time it will invite departments to pass on in due course any comments or suggestions that may occur to them as a result of using that year's guidelines, and will draw attention to any changes made in the guidelines for the current year, including any changes made as a result of departments' suggestions the previous year.

The handling of suggestions will depend on their nature. In some cases more elaborate consultation procedures will be necessary than in others, but in all cases changes will need to be presented to the Parliament by the Prime Minister after approval by the JCPA. It will be for the JCPA to consider whether or not to hold public hearings. In some cases when new requirements are introduced departments may need time to establish data bases and procedures before they will be able to comply with the new requirements in preparing their annual reports.

9. Responsibility for the guidelines should remain with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet but the Department must adopt a broader, more dynamic and proactive role as coordinator and, more importantly, custodian of the guidelines on annual reports.

The Government notes that the JCPA has recommended that `PM& continue in the role of co-ordinator of the Guidelines [for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports] and become more active in providing clarification of the Guidelines and coordinating proposals for change' (recommendation 7 of Report 304, Guidelines for Departmental Annual Reports).

PM& has co-ordinated work on revised guidelines for departmental annual reports issued in 1987 and 1991. It has written to departments in the past about their reporting obligations and in future will write to them each year as outlined in the response to recommendation 8. In this way, PM& fosters compliance with the guidelines; it does not have the additional role of monitoring departments' annual reports.
The Government will assign to the appropriate agency the task of co-ordinating work on the preparation of new guidelines on statutory authorities' annual reports.
10. A Handbook of External Reporting should be developed and maintained by PM& to consolidate annual reporting requirements currently scattered in various pieces of legislation and other documents.

The Government notes that the JCPA has recommended that `PM& compile and disseminate an Annual Reporting Handbook which consolidates all documents specifying requirements for departmental annual reports' (recommendation 48 of Report 304, Guidelines for Departmental Annual Reports).

The guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports and material associated with them are to be included in the Managers' Toolbox maintained by the Department of Finance. PM& will remind agencies responsible for the associated material of the need to ensure that the latest versions are available in the Toolbox (see the preamble to the revised guidelines, paragraph 5.3).
11. The Handbook of External Reporting should also incorporate the guidelines for explanatory notes.

The guidelines issued for the preparation of Program Performance Statements (formerly called Explanatory Notes) for the Budget Estimates are available in the Managers' Toolbox. Revised guidelines are expected to be available in the Toolbox later in 1991, as are the guidelines issued for the preparation of Explanatory Notes for the Additional Estimates.
12. The title `Explanatory Notes' should be replaced by `Program Performance Statement'.

The Government has agreed to a similar recommendation which was made by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in its review of the Financial Management Improvement Program, Not Dollars Alone. The name change will more accurately reflect the actual role and function of the document.

13. All annual reports should include a comprehensive index and should also contain, just before the index, a section that cross references the requirements of the guidelines of the contents of the report.
The Government notes:
* the SSCFPA's comment in its Report on Annual Reports: Reports Tabled July-December 1989 that a quality index is a useful adjunct to a report of more than 50 pages (p.6);

* the SSC on Industry, Science and Technology's comment in its Report on Annual Reports: Reports Tabled July-December 1989 that, while hesitating to nominate a report size below which an index is not required, and while considering a detailed contents page to suffice for reports under 20 pages, it considered an index essential for substantial reports, for example reports over 20 pages; and the Committee's recommendation that agencies include in their reports a checklist of reporting requirements which indicates whether or not in the agency's view each guideline or part thereof has been covered and if it has where in the report and if not why it has not been covered (p.6);

* the SSC on Employment, Education and Training's comment in its Report on Annual Reports (May 1990) that a checklist or summary of reporting requirements `would help the Committee locate within the report the particular issues which the guidelines identify as topics on which information should be provided' (p.2);

* the SSC on Legal and Constitutional Affairs' recommendation in its Report on Annual Reports Referred to the Committee (May 1990) that the guidelines for both departments' and statutory authorities' annual reports be amended so as to require each report to contain a section showing which pages of the report relate to each requirement of the relevant guidelines (p.ll);

* the JCPA's recommendation in its Report 299, Compliance with Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports, that all departmental annual reports contain, in addition to any other form of index, a section that cross references the requirements of the Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports to the contents of the report (p.14); and

* the JCPA's recommendation in its Report 304, Guidelines for Departmental Annual Reports, that the revised Guidelines require each report to contain a table of contents, index to contents required by the guidelines and alphabetical index (recommendation 29).

The 1991 revised guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports include a section at page 8 on aids to access. This section requires that each departmental annual report contain a table of contents, an alphabetical index (optional if the report is less than 50 pages long) and an index of requirements showing where in the report the content relating to each requirement numbered in the guidelines is located. If any requirement was not applicable to the department during the year, the index of reporting requirements is to show this, and, if any requirement was not met for any other reason, the reason is to be shown.

When the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced, consideration will be given to including similar requirements in any new document.
14. The forthcoming review of annual report guidelines should produce specific standards for the presentation of some classes of information in annual reports.
The Government notes the Committee's concern that any detailed prescriptions on standardised presentation of information should leave scope for departmental innovation (paragraph 4.40).
It notes the JCPA's recommendations (Nos 36-39, Report 304), that:

Under the co-ordination of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, consideration be given to the scope for development of standard contents and or presentation requirements for the various topics which the guidelines require that annual reports address (36);

Under the co-ordination of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, consideration be given to which organisations would be best placed to draft standard content or presentation requirements for each topic (37);
If standard content or presentation requirements are to be prepared for any topics, they be prepared for adoption with effect from the 1990-91 annual reports (38); and

Consideration be given to standard reporting formats being compulsory at the broad level, for example, a specific topic in a specific appendix, but optional at detailed levels, for example, layout of tables to show staffing information (39).

The Government notes, too, the comments of the JCPA that `The Committee had not considered it necessary for the Guidelines to address [the extent to which it is acceptable to provide information in a standard format in appendixes] as it anticipated that, given a requirement to report, departments would provide the required information in the form which best suited their circumstances. The Committee can see considerable advantage in much of the detailed information being presented in appendices, but is [reluctant] to prescribe that or any other form of presentation' (p.53); and that `With regard to presentation requirements, such as standard formats for personnel information, the Committee foresees departments having concerns at being required to report in inappropriate formats' (p.57).

The preamble to the revised guidelines provides at paragraph 2.11 that, except to the extent prescribed in the guidelines, the content and format of annual reports are to be determined by Secretaries. The Government places considerable importance on the principle that Secretaries should have as much freedom as possible to determine the nature of their annual reports and should be responsible for the results. This principle is consistent with measures taken by the Government to devolve management responsibilities to individual departments, and it recognises the need to allow each department the scope to tailor its reports to the particular nature of its operations, which may differ in significant ways from those of other departments.

The Government considers that an appropriate balance between prescription and freedom has been struck in the revised guidelines. Detailed minimum requirements have been set in relation to a number of matters.
Particular areas where, in the Committee's view, presentation standards could be introduced have been examined in the revision of the departmental annual report guidelines, with results as follows:

* use of a table of contents and an index-the revised guidelines require annual reports to contain these, but do not attempt to lay down standardised formats for them (see response to recommendation 13, and revised guidelines, page 8);

* use of standard appendices for required items, for example Appendix 1 should always have the same contents in reports that use appendices the Government considers that the aids to access now required in departmental annual reports will obviate any need for this level of prescription;
* specified minimum levels and types of staffing information-the section on staffing information in the revised guidelines (page 16) has been made clearer and more specific;

* reports to be structured in program format-the section on program reporting in the guidelines (page 14) has been revised. Information is required about each of the department's programs and the annual report will identify the operational approaches adopted and issues confronted in the implementation or maintenance of each program over the past year. There may be some parts of the report's contents, however, which cannot be addressed clearly in strict program format. Each departmental Secretary has discretion to determine which topics might best be consolidated to form separate sections of the report;

* information in standard form on the use of consultants, business regulations, post-separation employment cases, NSBs and reviews by the Auditor-General-the relevant sections of the guidelines (pages 23, 30, 20,10, 26) have been made clearer and more specific; and

* FOI information-the current arrangements appear to be satisfactory. Agencies may obtain advice from the FOI and Human Rights Branch of the Attorney-General's Department on such matters as information required and format in section 8 statements .

When the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced, consideration will be given to following similar principles, as appropriate.

15. The review of the guidelines should also give weight to concerns that the scope of performance information required in annual reports is unclear and that inadequate recognition is given to the contributions made by people to the performance of government programs.

The revised guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports (page 14) encourage departments where relevant to report progress at the operational level against published corporate or strategic plans and portfolio evaluation plans, in sections of their annual reports which deal with programs. When the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced, consideration will be given to including a similar requirement in any new document, as appropriate.

The Government notes that by its reference to `recognition of the contributions of people', the Committee intends that reports should show `the kind of attention and leadership given to people', and, in reporting on the achievement of objectives, should describe `other important, people- related management issues such as staff development, staff mobility, recognition and reward, appraisal schemes, staff facilities and the impact of restructures and how they were handled' (p.25).

The revised guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports require departments to report on some of the issues identified by the Committee. It is for departmental managers to decide how this material may best be incorporated in the report, though the Government agrees that the connection between `people-related management issues' and the achievement of objectives should be drawn out.

The Committee's comments are drawn to the attention of departments in an appendix to the revised guidelines, and will be taken into account when the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced.
16. All annual reports for the 1989-90 financial year should be tabled on or before 30 November 1990.
17. All annual reports for the 1990-91 and subsequent financial years should be tabled on or before 31 October.

All departments and most other agencies are currently required to report on a financial year basis. Subsection 34c(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 provides that periodic reports must be furnished `as soon as practicable after the end of the particular period to which the report relates and, in any event, within 6 months after the end of that particular period'. In the case of agencies reporting on a financial year basis, the deadline for furnishing reports is thus 31 December. The Government expects agencies to make their annual reports available as soon as practicable, as the Act requires. The responses to recommendations 18 and 20-21 below indicate that agencies should if possible complete their annual reports in time for Ministers to table them before the Senate estimates hearings or, if that target cannot be met, before the end of the Budget Sittings. These requirements are taken up in the preamble to the guidelines on the preparation of departmental annual reports (p.5).

The Australian National Audit Office has advised that, because of the number of agencies whose financial statements it must audit, it may not be able to complete audits in time to allow all agencies to table their annual reports on or before 30 November or 31 October. It considers that fewer difficulties may be experienced when agencies have had time to adapt their accounting systems to cope with requirements now in the Audit Act 1901.

New requirements have also been added to the guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports. The addition of new reporting requirements may add to the time needed for the preparation of annual reports. This aspect of the situation will be monitored and taken into account when future decisions are made on reporting deadlines.

The Government notes the SSCFPA's comment, in its report, Departmental Annual Reports for 1988-89, that in 1989 almost all departments would have met the tighter deadline recommended by the Committee for 1989-90 reports (p.4).
The Government has decided, however, that for the time being the 6-month deadline will remain, but that the following action is to be taken to promote timely reporting:

* Secretaries of departments and heads of agencies, in the statements or letters of transmittal prepared in relation to their annual reports, are to include a statement of the terms of subsection 34c(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act (and, if applicable, those of subsection 34c(4) or 34c(7)); and

* PM& is to inquire of the Audit Office, and to advise the Committee by the end of 1992, what scope the Audit Office then sees for shortening the 6-month deadline. PM& will also seek advice on the likelihood of printing bottlenecks, and will consult departments about pressures they have experienced in preparing their reports.
18. The present requirement for draft annual reports to be available to Senate Estimates Committees should be removed from the guidelines.

The 1987 guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports required that reports be available for the estimates hearings or, if reports were not available, that `interim statements' (not explicitly drafts of reports) be provided. The current guidelines for statutory authorities' annual reports require that reports be provided if possible in time for the estimates hearings.

The Government notes that the SSCFPA's recommendation was made in conjunction with a recommendation (no. 27) intended to provide for parliamentary scrutiny of annual reports outside the estimates hearings; and that the recommendation that tabling deadlines be brought forward to 31 October (no. 17) was made as an `alternative' to the present requirement for interim statements (Departmental Annual Reports for 1988-89, p.4). If these recommendations were taken up (and if Program Performance Statements are self-contained, as they should be) there would be little point in retaining the requirement for interim statements for use by Estimates Committees. Recommendation 27 was taken up by the Senate in a Resolution of 14 December 1989, and parliamentary scrutiny will be extended with implementation of the JCPA's recommendation (no. 2 of Report 304) that standing committees of the House of Representatives be assigned the ongoing role of conducting reviews of departmental operations based upon the annual reports of departments. However, at this stage it has not seemed feasible to take up recommendation 17.

The Government notes, too, that the JCPA has recommended retention of the requirement for interim statements (recommendation 25, Report 304), and that some Senate Estimates Committees have also expressed support for its retention.

In these circumstances, it would be reasonable to retain the requirement, provided that any interim statements made available could be of real use to the Parliament. The SSCFPA has commented that unfinalised documents are not a satisfactory basis for parliamentary scrutiny and that reports or drafts cannot be used by Estimates Committees unless provided in good time (paragraphs 5.9-10).

The Government has decided that agencies' annual reports or material to be included in them should, unless there is a specific reason, be made available to Senate Estimates Committees prior to hearings involving the respective agencies. It may be inappropriate for agencies to make available content that has not yet been settled, though material submitted to Senate Estimates Committee Secretariats may be accompanied by unaudited financial statements.

Portfolios will continue to be required to lodge their Program Performance Statements (formerly called Explanatory Notes) with the Senate Table Office soon after the Budget, as part of the series of Budget and Budget-related papers. Subsequently, but prior to the conduct of hearings of the Senate Estimates Committees, portfolios will also submit to Committee Secretariats tabled annual reports of portfolio agencies and, in relation to agencies whose reports have not been tabled, interim statements. These interim statements need not be drafts of annual reports (or drafts of parts of them) but should indicate what material could be made available should Committees wish to request it.

These requirements are set out in the preamble to the revised guidelines for departmental annual reports (paragraph 3.9), and will be taken into account when the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced.
19. Copies of current corporate plans, where they exist, should be provided to Senate Estimates Committees with the explanatory notes.

Some agencies have made a practice of letting Estimates Committees have copies of their corporate plans. The Government, while having no wish to discourage this practice, is unwilling to make a requirement that all agencies adopt it, feeling rather that it is for the management of an agency to decide the nature of any corporate plan it produces. Any accountability features of a corporate plan should be made available in some form to the Minister and the Parliament, and agencies may well feel that the most convenient way to make them available is to provide a copy of the plan.

Annual reports and Portfolio Program Performance Statements (formerly called Explanatory Notes) form the chief accountability documents for agencies. The Program Performance Statements, as previously was the case with Portfolio Explanatory Notes, are the Minister's document provided to Parliament to demonstrate the effectiveness of programs by detailing the resource requirements and related performance targets which have been set for achievement over the period of the Budget.

Annual reports, on the other hand, focus below the portfolio level as a means of bringing together information on an agency's activities. In effect, the annual report provides the major avenue by which an agency head can account to the Minister for the administrative efficiency of that agency. The Minister, in turn, tables the annual report in Parliament as a statement of the agency's efficiency.

Program Performance Statements and annual reports, therefore, serve quite distinct purposes, but are complementary in their nature. Portfolios are encouraged to take advantage of this complementarity so that, in submitting documents (or interim statements) to the Senate Estimates Committees, unnecessary overlap and duplication between the two documents is avoided or minimised. This can be achieved through effective cross-referencing between the documents, as well as to other sources of more detailed information relating to program performance, such as corporate plans. All the documents referred to, however, must be made available to the Estimates Committees at the same time as the Program Performance Statements and annual reports (or interim statements).

20. The Acts Interpretation Act should be amended to provide for ministers to table annual reports within seven calendar days of receiving them but, in any event, no later than 30 November 1990 for the 1989-90 report and 31 October each year for all subsequent reports.

21. The Acts Interpretation Act should be amended to explicitly provide for the tabling of annual reports to the Presiding Officers of the Parliament when neither the Senate or the House of Representatives is sitting between the date of receipt of any annual report by a minister and seven days later or the reporting date.

The Government recognises that the earlier annual reports are publicly available the more useful they may be, and it considers therefore that reports should be tabled as soon as practical after being received by Ministers. Subsection 25(8) of the Public Service Act 1922 and subsection 34c(3) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 require a Minister to have an annual report tabled in both Houses of Parliament within 15 sitting days after the day on which the Minister receives the report. Sitting patterns are currently such that in normal circumstances this gives a maximum period of between five and seven weeks.

As the Committee recognises, any attempt to shorten this period by converting it to a number of calendar days would entail providing somehow for reports to be tabled on non-sitting days. There are arrangements currently in place for papers to be circulated out of session and so made publicly available. Such circulation, however, does not amount to tabling. Papers circulated out of session still need to be formally tabled when the Parliament next sits. The Government understands that the view is taken in some quarters of the Parliament that it is not normally appropriate to circulate and make public papers required to be presented to the Parliament, before those papers have in fact been so presented. On the other hand, the view is taken that papers should be made available as early as possible.

Resolution of these views is a matter for the Presiding Officers and the Parliament, which may wish to inquire what scope there may be, either for the use of resolutions along the lines of those adopted from time to time (chiefly by the Senate) that in the event of the respective Presiding Officer's receiving a particular paper (or a paper of a particular kind) out of session the paper shall be deemed to have been presented to the respective House; or for suitable amendments to Standing Orders. The Government would be prepared to consider the introduction of a 21 calendar day tabling period if provision existed for tabling out of session.

In the meantime, in an effort to reduce delay, the Government is willing to undertake that a Minister, if 21 calendar days have elapsed since he or she received an annual report, will endeavour to table the report within the next 3 sitting days. If the statutory 15 sitting day period should expire before those 3 sitting days have elapsed, the Minister will of course be bound to meet the statutory obligation.

As indicated in the response to recommendation 18, there is a requirement that annual reports be furnished to Ministers if possible in time for tabling prior to the estimates hearings. If that target cannot be met, departments and Ministers will in any event endeavour to make annual reports available before the end of the Budget Sittings.

The preamble to the revised guidelines on the preparation of departmental annual reports (pages 5-6) refers to the tabling arrangements set out above. The Government will assess the operation of the new arrangements, and will take the findings into account when the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced.
The issue of tabling by the end of October or November is addressed in the response to recommendations 16 and 17.

22. The letter of transmittal to the minister from the departmental secretary or chief executive of an organisation, which is currently printed within the report, should be replaced by a separate covering letter not printed in the report. A copy of this letter should be sent to the Clerk of each House.

The Government notes the difficulty which the Committee has had in trying to ascertain when reports were furnished to Ministers. It notes, too, the SSCFPA's reference to this recommendation in its Report on Annual Reports: Reports Tabled July-December 1989 (p.ll), and the support for the recommendation expressed by:
* the President of the Senate, in his August 1990 President's Report on Annual Reports (p.2);

* the SSC on Employment, Education and Training, in its May 1990 Report on Annual Reports (the Committee also expressed the view that any letter of transmittal within annual reports should be undated);
* the SSC on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, in its May 1990 report, Examination of Annual Reports (p.4); and
* the SSC on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, in its May 1990 Report on Annual Reports Referred to the Committee (p.8).

The Government agrees that agencies and Ministers should be able to demonstrate their compliance with the statutory requirement that reports be furnish to Ministers by a certain date (Acts Interpretation Act subsection 34c(2)) and tabled within a certain period after the date on which reports are received by Ministers (Public Service Act subsection 25(8), Acts Interpretation Act subsection 34c(3)).

An agency cannot accurately predict how long the interval will be between the date when the text of its report (including any letter of transmittal incorporated in it) is finalised and the date when printed copies are available to be furnished to the Minister. Nor can it be assumed that the date of furnishing will be the same as the date on which the Minister receives a report.

Whether or not reports are furnished to Ministers with separate covering letters, there remains a need for each report to incorporate a statement by the agency head certifying its compliance with (e.g.) section 25 of the Public Service Act. That statement should be signed and dated.

The revised guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports include a requirement (no. 01) that the annual report of a department contain a statement by the Secretary, dated when the Secretary gives the text final clearance to be printed. When the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced, consideration will be give to including a similar requirement in any new document.

Agencies, in furnishing reports to Ministers, may if they wish do so under cover of separate (dated) letters. To meet the concerns expressed by parliamentary committees, Ministers, in tabling reports, will advise the Parliament on what date or dates the reports were furnished to and received by them.

23. It should be mandatory for departmental secretaries or chief executives of other agencies to lodge an explanation of late tabling, on a standard form, before the tabling deadline expires. If there are further delays an additional explanation of late tabling form should be submitted before the expiry of the extended tabling date.
24. All explanations of late tabling should be forwarded to the Clerks of both Houses who should table the forms as they are received.

The Acts Interpretation Act 1901 provides that when a report will not be ready in time, the person responsible for furnishing it to the Minister may (not must) apply in advance for additional time to complete the report, and that the person must, if application is made, furnish an explanation of the delay. The Minister may grant additional time and must table the application/explanation and his or her response within 3 sitting days. The Act also provides that, when a report has not been furnished on time, the person responsible for the report must furnish an explanation to the Minister within 14 days and the Minister must table the explanation within 3 sitting days of receipt.
The Act provides that further extensions of time may be sought in advance and that further explanations must be provided when deadlines already extended are not met.

The Government considers that there may be cases when a person responsible for a report may reasonably expect up until very close to the deadline to be able to meet that deadline. For that reason, the Government has decided not to make action in advance of a breach of a deadline mandatory. The Government agrees, however, that advance notice is preferable to retrospective notice, and that, when an explanation of a late report is given retrospectively, the agency head may reasonably be expected to explain why advance notice was not given. The guidelines for departmental annual reports (preamble, paragraph 3.6) have been amended accordingly, and when the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced, consideration will be given to including a similar requirement in any new document.

The Government agrees that explanations should include information in relation to the headings in the standard form proposed by the Committee, but it considers it is enough for agencies to be advised the information is required, without having standard forms supplied. It is not appropriate, moreover, for agencies to submit explanations of late reporting direct to the Presiding Officers. If their reports are furnished late, they owe explanations to Ministers, who table those explanations in the Parliament.

25. Ministers, when tabling annual reports, should draw the attention of the House or the Senate to any annual reports which are being tabled later than the tabling deadline for the year to which the report relates.

The Government agrees that when a report is furnished late, the Minister in tabling the report should advise the Parliament by what date the report had originally been due. The revised guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports include a requirement along these lines (preamble, paragraph 3.8), and when the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced, consideration will be given to including a similar requirement in any new document.

26. Depending on the nature of the reason for late tabling, this Committee or the JCPA should consider requiring the departmental secretary or chief executive of any other agency to attend a public hearing to further explain the delay.

This is a matter for the two committees. Secretaries and heads of agencies are required to follow principles set out in the Government Guidelines for Official Witnesses before Parliamentary Committees and Related matters.
27. A regular program of scrutiny should be adopted by legislative and general purpose committees of the Senate based on annual reports.
28. The President of the Senate should provide each year a report listing the dates of tabling of all annual reports, the dates the reports were sent to ministers and the reasons for late tabling.

The Government notes that the Senate passed a resolution in relation to recommendations 27 and 28 on 14 December 1989, and that reports by the President and the legislative and general purpose committees of the Senate have been tabled pursuant to that resolution.
Difficulties associated with determining the dates on which annual reports were furnished to Ministers are addressed in the Government's response to recommendation 22.
29. Legislative and general purpose committees of the Senate should use the RAIPA annual report awards judges' report as input to hearings with representatives of executive agencies.
This is a matter for the committees.
30. Parliamentary departments should be required to report under the same guidelines as executive departments and should be subject to the same processes of committee scrutiny.

The Government notes that the President of the Senate and Speaker of the House of Representatives have agreed that the parliamentary departments should comply with the guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports.

PM& has now included the parliamentary departments on its mailing list for circular letters about the guidelines, and, subject to consideration of any advice received regarding difficulties experienced by those departments in complying with the guidelines, subsection 25(9) of the Public Service Act 1922 will be amended to require their reports to be prepared in accordance with the guidelines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a few remarks about this Government response, which in general terms I welcome. Most of the recommendations of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration have been agreed to, though I regret that some of them are a bit too hidebound by the fairly religious adherence to the devolution theory that is around these days.

SPEECH.PARA: I also regret that it has taken two years for this response to come to us. I do not think that such a delay is good enough. I realise that it has been partly caused by the fact that other committees in the meantime have made similar recommendations, but I am not sure that that can seriously be accepted as a reason for delay. It is just an indication that, because of the delay, there has been a re-emphasis by other committees of the sorts of things proposed by the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

In passing, on the question of delays in tabling, we are still waiting for the Government response to the Committee's report on government companies. The time delay is of a similar order in that case, and unfortunately many of the recommendations are therefore becoming outdated merely because of the passage of time. I think that is a matter to be seriously regretted.

I will not comment on the Government's responses to every one of the many recommendations in the report of the Committee entitled The Timeliness and Quality of Annual Reports, but I look first at recommendation No. 6 and the Government's response to it. This recommendation concerned the continuing suggestion of the Committee that the Government should maintain a register of non-statutory bodies so that the list is continually available rather than having to rely only on annual reports.

I note that in the response, this matter having been mentioned again in our report, the Government has indicated that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet may in fact be introducing a computerised system to record the appointment of people in the equal employment opportunity target groups to statutory and other government bodies and that, therefore, the Government might find it useful to effectively have a register, as has been recommended in the past by the Committee. I welcome this belated recognition that it is useful to the Government to have a continuous register of those bodies, and I am glad to see that it may well come about by this indirect route.

In recommendation No. 17, the Committee recommended that all annual reports for 1989-90 should be tabled on or before 30 November 1990 and that all annual reports for 1991 and subsequent financial years should be tabled on or before 31 October to improve the time taken for annual reports to be tabled after the end of the period being reported on. The response from the Government is for the Australian National Audit Office to advise the Committee by the end of 1992 on the scope the Audit Office sees for shortening the six-month deadline that currently exists. I think that response is rather on the weak side. I would have preferred a stronger commitment to abbreviating the required time for tabling of annual reports. Most departments have satisfied well and truly the shorter time period, but my view is that to make it a formal requirement would have been preferable.

Another matter I would like to comment on is recommendation No. 20, which was our suggestion that the Acts Interpretation Act should be amended to provide for Ministers to table annual reports within seven calendar days of receiving them, as well as complying with the overall time requirement. In this case, the Government has said that it would be prepared to consider the introduction of a 21 calendar day tabling period if provision existed for tabling out of session.

I should mention that this issue requires an acknowledgment that providing an annual report to the Presiding Officers under the procedures of the Senate could involve that report being deemed to have been tabled and therefore avoiding long delays due to the Parliament not perhaps being in session at the time a report becomes available. Even given that, I suggest that the 21 calendar day period is still longer than is necessary. I cannot understand why seven days is not reasonable enough. There is no particular need for a Minister to sit on a report once it has been received. I do not see any reason why within a very short period after a report's reception it ought not to be tabled. We acknowledge that the main delay is the time it takes for a department or an agency to prepare a report, to have it audited and to have it printed, but once it is finally provided to the Minister there should be no reason for any further delay in the tabling by the Minister.

Another issue that we dealt with was the question of keeping track of compliance with the timing requirements. There was the problem of the letter of transmittal of a report being incorporated in a report before it was printed and, therefore, the date of actual receipt by the Minister not being easily ascertained. The Government has agreed that agencies and Ministers should be able to demonstrate their compliance with the statutory requirement. The response has been that to meet the concerns expressed by parliamentary committees Ministers, in the tabling of reports, will advise the Parliament on what date or dates the reports were furnished to and received by them. That is not exactly the way in which the Committee recommended it should happen, but at least it will be an improvement in that people can see the exact dates involved and there will not then need to be a wild goose chase trying to clear up any apparent delays that might appear on the surface.

Recommendation No. 23 talked about it being mandatory for departmental secretaries or chief executives to lodge an explanation about any late tabling. The Government has agreed that explanations should be provided and should include information in relation to the headings and the standard form proposed by the Committee. The Government considers that it is enough for agencies to be advised of the information without having standard forms supplied.

The response makes the point that it is not appropriate for agencies to submit explanations of late reporting direct to the Presiding Officers. If their reports are furnished late, they owe explanations to Ministers, who table those explanations in the Parliament. I acknowledge that point of protocol, but I emphasise that the suggestion of the Committee was an attempt to streamline the process. The intention was to treat such explanations in a formula way, as routine, so that they were therefore able to be tabled amongst the papers tabled by the Clerk rather than such a relatively simple matter having to be tabled by a Minister, who has to go through all the formalities, which are almost equivalent to the tabling of the report itself. Recommendation No. 25 reads:

Ministers, when tabling annual reports, should draw the attention of the House or the Senate to any annual reports which are being tabled later than the tabling deadline for the year to which the report relates.

The Government has agreed that when that happens the Minister should advise the Parliament in that way. There are many other comments on this matter I would like to make but, in order to abbreviate the proceedings, I conclude my remarks there. Despite the long delay in this response coming, I welcome it. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Button, I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology on People and Technology-New Management Techniques in Manufacturing Industry. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion relating to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
TO
THE REPORT
OF
THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE
ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND
TECHNOLOGY:
PEOPLE AND TECHNOLOGY
NEW MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES IN MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY
presented by
The Minister
for
Industry, Technology and Commerce
Background

On 29 May 1990, the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology tabled its Report ``People and Technology: New Management Techniques in Manufacturing Industry''. This Report stemmed from the Committee's earlier Report of September 1988, titled ``Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation: Making it Together''.

In that 1988 Report, the Committee reviewed a number of unproductive attitudes which it considered could be changed, to revitalise the manufacturing sector. This 1990 Report has examined in greater depth the following key recommendations from the Committee's earlier review:
* that new management techniques be introduced where practicable;
* that labour improve its situation, for example, by taking the lead in negotiating removal of restrictive work and management practices;
* that management become committed to the ideal of industrial democracy and encourage greater involvement of the workforce in productivity, quality and safety matters.
Main Considerations of this Report

The Committee noted the economic imperative for improvement in Australia's manufacturing performance and that a key feature of successfully developed economies is a strong manufacturing sector with a skilled and committed workforce. To increase productivity and restore Australian industry's international competitiveness, the Committee considered that manufacturers needed to assess whether their company's performance measured up to a ``successful enterprise'' and whether the company had appropriate human resource policies and practices in place.

As examined in this Report, the term ``New Management Techniques'' was used in two ways. First, it referred to a range of advanced management technologies and systems, such as Value-Added-Management (VAM), Just-inTime (JIT), and Computer-aided Design/Manufacturing (CAD/CAM). Second, it covered the more general management/workforce relationship, with an emphasis on decisions made on the basis of employee involvement.

While there had been some take up of these best management practices by many businesses, the Committee concluded that there had been limited and insufficient implementation of these new technologies. The reasons included a general short-term emphasis on increased sales that outweighed the strategic investment in technology needed to gain a longer-term competitive advantage.

A wider attitudinal change was seen to be necessary, so that decisions could be driven by a strategic vision that was communicated to all levels of staff and employees and guided day-to-day decisions about resources and production. The TAFE educational system was considered to be a vital ingredient in the skills formation necessary for the advanced technologies and new management techniques, in order to be able to apply this strategic vision. More interaction between industry and TAFE was considered by the Committee to be desirable, particularly concerning curriculum development that incorporated these manufacturing and management philosophies.

Inherent in the successful outcome from adopting these philosophies and practices would be a greater feeling of common purpose amongst employers and employees. However, the Committee suggested that many factors work against such a common purpose being developed, including mistrust between management and the workforce, educational difficulties, and demarcation disputes.

The Committee believed that there was high recognition in industry of the need to adopt the measures it had been reviewing, but that this would not necessarily lead to action. It suggested that national and state governments should use their coordinating powers to bring together the various groups involved with improving manufacturing sector productivity.

In relation to current government activity, the Committee acknowledged the central role of the National Industry Extension Service (NIES) in providing information about the services available to manufacturing industry. It did note, however, that for the NIES programs to be effective there would need to be greater awareness of the new management techniques and their relevance to a firm.

This awareness would be raised in three ways. First, by industry knowing about the support services available not only from government but also from peak bodies such as the Australian Institute of Management. Second, by unions continuing award restructuring and encouraging multi-skilling. Third, tertiary education should be better known, more accessible and more responsive to industry training needs.

As the first step for action, the Committee recommended that an Australian model for new management techniques was required. The model was to take account of uniquely Australian factors, while drawing on the best of world experience and adapting it to Australian experience. The Committee then made a number of recommendations about developing the model through a series of national conferences and then using the draft model as a basis for separate industry models.

In all, the Committee made eighteen recommendations. Three of these are specifically directed at firms in the manufacturing sector, as means to assist them in becoming internationally competitive. A further four are directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, in relation to his responsibilities for the technical and further education system and its interaction with the manufacturing sector.

An additional four are addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, including the principal one of developing the proposed Australian model of new management techniques. The balance of seven recommendations relates to the series of national conferences that are suggested as the means of discussing, developing and refining the model.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Introduction

Firstly, I would like to indicate that I am making this response jointly on behalf of my portfolio and my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The Committee is to be congratulated for the breadth of its examination of this vital topic, as may be seen by the cross-portfolio issues it has raised for consideration.

In considering the Government's response to the Committee's report, I put some thought into firstly reviewing the problems identified by the Committee and then secondly looking at the solutions proposed through the series of recommendations. I share the concerns of the Committee about the rate of take-up by the manufacturing sector of new management techniques and the slow development of internationally competitive Australian enterprises.

With this in mind, I believe that the Committee has correctly identified the two main management issues hindering the development of internationally competitive Australian enterprises. As outlined in the Report, the two issues are the slow take-up of new management techniques and, even more important, the lack of awareness of the services already available. This almost inevitably leads to the short-term emphasis on sales, without a long-term strategy to drive the development of appropriate products for markets in Australia and overseas.

By contrast, this Government believes that an internationally competitive Australian firm needs to know exactly what it is good at doing, how it will win against its competitors, and also that it should have an excellent business plan as a road map for achieving its goals. A successful Australian business is a partnership: between the firm and its customers, and most important, between everyone working in the company.
Current Government Programs

This Government believes that its current programs are designed to achieve these results and are successfully contributing to the development of such firms. In this regard, I was pleased to read the positive and supportive references to the National Industry Extension Service (NIES) and the importance of its catalytic role as a change agent in providing information about best manufacturing and management practices.

Since it started in 1986, NIES has developed into a highly successful mechanism for enhancing the efficiency and competitiveness of companies throughout Australia. NIES has also demonstrated that Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments can work together effectively on this important mission.

NIES offers a range of programs that can assist firms realise their competitive advantage through products that can sell in Australian and overseas markets. These programs include diagnostic assessment, strategic planning, business planning, advanced manufacturing technologies, human resources, product innovation, cost management, quality and export strategies.
Other Government Initiatives of 1990
(1) The New Workplace Culture

I am pleased now also to be able to give an outline of other developments in 1990 that were highly relevant to the Committee's deliberations, involving my colleagues the Ministers for Employment, Education and Training and for Industrial Relations. These developments are mentioned here to show the scope of this Government's current action on the very real problems associated with developing internationally competitive Australian industry.

Shortly after the Committee presented its Report ``People and Technology'', the Government also received the Pappas Carter Evans and Koop (PCEK) Report titled ``The Global Challenge'', dealing with Australian manufacturing in the 1990s. That Report has since received wide public debate, in the context of the direction of Australian manufacturing industry policy and what Government action may be appropriate. I would here like briefly to describe the Government's action so far, in relation to the New Workplace Culture aspects of the Report.

As ``The Global Challenge'' has noted, the culture that commonly exists in Australian workplaces presents a major handicap for the international competitiveness of our industry and typically results in work that falls short of international standards of quality and productivity. The PCEK Report considered that profound changes in attitude were needed by management, unions and training institutions, which it summarised as the requirement for a New Workplace Culture.
The key elements of the New Workplace Culture include:
- flatter organisational structures;
- continuous improvements in productivity and quality, by incorporating the ideas of workers at all levels;
- team-based approaches to problem-solving;
- technologies based on people and hardware;
- flexible production relying on multi-skilled workers;
- suppliers involved in product design, quality improvement and productivity efforts;
- human resource policies that encourage workers to be stakeholders in the corporation;
- support for skills upgrading and retraining across the firm's workforce.

This Government was keen to quickly identify the factors which are contributing to the development of a new workplace culture. The Government formed a task-force involving the three portfolios mentioned previously, so that a comprehensive analysis could be made of these factors and any impediments to the adoption of a new workplace culture.

In recent months, the task-force engaged in intensive discussions with employer groups and unions, and with individual enterprises, to gather information on current progress in workplace reform and provide recommendations on appropriate government policy and programs. The Task Force presented its Report in the first week in February and its outcomes were the subject of Cabinet consideration in the context of the Industry Statement.

Stemming from this consideration, an Australian Best Practice Demonstration Program was announced in the Government Statement ``Building a Competitive Australia'' on 12 March. The program is to be administered by the Department of Industrial Relations in conjunction with the Australian Manufacturing Council. It will consist of two elements:
* assistance to individual enterprises that wish to demonstrate their commitment to workplace reform and want to make substantial progress in achieving reform; and
* an integrated information campaign.
(2) Developments in Training

Against the background of the economic imperative to improve Australia's international competitiveness, the last two or three years have been characterised by significant changes in the environment in which the industry training system is operating. I would here like to outline two of these changes, which are very relevant to the Committee's considerations and which are set out in more detail in the attached replies to Recommendations 3, 4 and 5.
- Reforms to the Training system

In its micro-economic reform agenda, this Government has placed a high priority on making reforms in the Vocational Education and Training system, so as to increase the skills of the workforce and thereby improve enterprise productivity and competitiveness. Some significant achievements have been made, particularly during 1990, as the results of several years of review and consultation came to fruition.

Last year the National Training Board was established by the Commonwealth and States to set, in co-operation with Industry, national skill standards. These will underpin reformation of quality national curricula and a nationally consistent system of competency based training, which in turn will form the basis of a more competitive and market relevant system.
- Training in support of Award Restructuring

Further during 1990, my colleague together with State Ministers, commissioned a report from a Committee which was directed by leaders in industry, on the training costs of Award Restructuring. The Report (known as the Deveson Report) was considered by a special meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible for Training on 2 November 1990, and was accepted as the basis for a more effective partnership between TAFE and Industry providers of training.

An historical consensus reached at this meeting was for the Commonwealth and States to work together to create the environment for an open and competitive training system which is market based and responsive to industry. This will see the development of industry and/or enterprise based training facilities which may be competitive with the public TAFE system, and which could also include joint ventures or other forms of inter-related training facilities in TAFE and Industry. Indeed some specific projects are already in train.

A further significant agreement by Ministers was the establishment of an Australian Committee for Training Curriculum, which will develop national core curricula for both on-and off-the-job training. It will also be able to produce training materials for both TAFE and private industry providers, taking into account industry priorities.

The preceding developments will build on the already improved links between TAFE and industry that were established following the 1989 document Commonwealth Priorities for TAFE. Developments have included joint/cooperative arrangements with firms and industry associations, involvement at the local level by industry representatives on College Councils and in course development and evaluation activities, and co-operation with industries in the establishment and expansion of industry skill centres in key sectors involved in the award restructuring process.
(3) Initiatives in Management Training
- Mission on Management Education

Another important initiative has recently been taken by my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, who has been reviewing his portfolio strategies for improving the quality of management training in Australia. This has been one consequence of the Report to him by the Employment and Skills Formation Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET), entitled Industry Training in Australia: the need for change.

The Minister established a Mission on Management Education, which has undertaken a study on overseas trends in management education, training and development. In 1990, the Mission visited Japan, the USA and Europe to report on best practice management skills formation and key strategic initiatives that can be taken at enterprise, industry, state and national levels to enhance management skills formation in Australia.

This enhancement will be critical in helping to instil management practices that place Australian industry on an internationally competitive footing. The Mission's report is expected to be available through NBEET for public debate and consultation in mid 1991.
-National Management Skills Formation Strategy

In his March 12 Industry Statement, the Prime Minister outlined the Government's commitment to the development of a National Management Skills Formation Strategy to strengthen management skills. The Strategy will involve research and policy measures that can identify the need and growth in demand for management skills. It will also ensure that the supply and quality of education, training and advisory services are adequate and responsive to the needs of management.

The Strategy will also seek to strengthen the links between training providers and employer and encourage business to develop more effective management skills programs. Input from a wide range of interested parties will be important in developing appropriate measures under the Strategy. Funding worth $2.3 million will be provided in 1991-92.
- Training Needs of Small Business

A study of the training needs of small business has been undertaken by the Bureau of Industry Economics on behalf of DEET and DITAC. The study assesses the training needs of workers and management in a number of small businesses in key sectors (motels, metal fabrication, mechanical and electrical engineering, automotive components and information technology). Due for release in mid 1991, the study will underpin efforts to increase awareness by small business of the benefits of training, improve the quality of training provided by small businesses and facilitate access to it so that small business can participate more fully.
- National TAFE Curriculum: Export Practices &Procedures

I note also that the Queensland Government Bureau of Employment, Vocational and Further Education and Training has proposed a national strategy to address problems identified in the NBEET report ``Benchmark Study of Management Development''. One of those problems was the low involvement of Australian organisations in international business and the strategy proposed is a national core curriculum for the TAFE system on Export Practices and Procedures.
Conclusions and intended Government action

Given the considerations I have detailed above and the initiatives already underway, I have some doubts about the need for yet another management model that would be in addition to those already available through NIES, other areas of the Government and the private sector. Similarly, I have reservations about the series of conferences recommended as the means of introducing and refining this model.

The proposals in the Report for the national conferences, formation of working groups and development of separate industry models represent extended processes that would not necessarily result in productive outcomes. I would also be concerned about the Federal Government being the sponsor of these processes, when there is the acknowledged need for the private sector to be more responsive in adopting the already existing best management practices.

However, I do acknowledge that the Government's existing programs are spread across several portfolios and may be difficult to access, from the perspective of an individual firm wishing to develop its strategies for international competitiveness. I agree with the Committee's comment on page 57 of its report about the need for a greater awareness of the new management techniques and their relevance to a firm.

Consequently, I have asked that the Bureau of Industry Economics include a segment on best management practice in its annual Industry Outlook Conference. Additionally, as a key issue is the awareness of the available management techniques, this Government intends to identify each of its current programs that are relevant to this theme and bring together this information into the one coordinated document, which would then be available to the manufacturing sector.

This information would principally bring together data about programs in the portfolios of Industry, Technology and Commerce, Employment, Education and Training, and Industrial Relations. Taken together, I suggest that they would outline an extensive Australian model of the current best manufacturing and management practices, being presently promoted by the Government, for developing an internationally competitive Australian enterprise.
The foregoing initial comments and background will therefore be the basis of the Government's responses to the Committee's recommendations, which are attached to this statement.
RESPONSES TO EACH OF THE RECOMMENDATIONS
RECOMMENDATION 1
That the following definition of a ``successful company'' be adopted by businesses as their goal:

A world competitive company produces the highest quality products or services which exactly meet customer needs at the lowest possible cost. To achieve this, the enterprise workforce, at all levels, will share a common purpose enhanced through consultative and problem solving mechanisms, a commitment to skills training, career structures and access to appropriate technologies.
Response

The Government endorses the definition and supports its adoption by businesses, noting that it is the basis of the NIES programs. Current Government actions to create an open training market which is responsive to industry needs, and in which skills acquired from structured training and relevant experience can be recognised, are designed to create the right environment for companies to take the initiative to develop the skills of their employees to the highest standards.
RECOMMENDATION 2

That companies ensure that their corporate plan includes goals about technology and skills acquisition which are developed and worked towards following consultation at all levels from the Board of Directors to the production workforce.
Response

The Government strongly supports this recommendation, while acknowledging that this is an issue for consideration by individual enterprises. The Government is concerned that a more fundamental issue is the very large number of manufacturing companies which do not have corporate or strategic plans.
RECOMMENDATION 3

That the Minister for Employment, Education and Training initiate, as a matter of urgency, the development and implementation of a core curriculum for institutions of technical and further education. This core curriculum should include a compulsory component of management education.
Response

It is important to note that the Commonwealth Government has no constitutional powers to direct specific changes in the TAFE sector. These matters are the responsibility of State and Territory Governments. The Commonwealth, however, works co-operatively with those Governments to influence the common adoption of policies and practices in the national interest.
Against this background, in 1989 the Commonwealth recognised
* the need to integrate and co-ordinate education and training policies and
* the need for close consultation between TAFE and relevant industries;
* the need for nationally agreed basis for the establishment curricula; and
* the need for a continuing commitment to interstate co-operative effort in TAFE.

The Commonwealth and State/Territory Ministers have now formally agreed that emphasis will be placed on the development of national industry skill standards, which in turn will form the basis for implementation of national core curricula and the expansion of competency-based trade training.

Appropriate staff development activities, particularly for teachers, are also necessary and are being actively encouraged. Priority for the major curriculum development activities will go to those arising from award restructuring.

In 1990, the Commonwealth and the States and Territories established The National Training Board (NTB), to determine in consultation with industry, national skill and competence standards which all Governments have agreed to implement through the curricula and courses recognised in their State.

The Commonwealth, through DEET, also provides significant financial support for the Industry Training Advisory Boards (ITABs-formerly known as Industry Training Committees). These are industry owned and operated bodies which provide a formal two-way conduit for exchanging views and information between industry parties and Government on the needs for industry training.

These Boards work closely with the TAFE system to establish curricula for training courses across most industries. There are currently 121 of these Boards, organised into a National/State network to cover most industries; there were 21 new Committees established with Commonwealth funding during 1989/90.
Proposed Action

In 1991, these national co-operative ventures will continue to be a high priority, using Commonwealth recurrent funding to the States for TAFE. This will enable each State and Territory to access funds for projects which are then made available freely through all TAFE systems.

The Government is also considering ways to enhance the network of ITABs so that they can continue to promote and develop systematic training in their industries and advise State and Commonwealth governments on training matters affecting their industries. This follows a comprehensive review conducted by the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) during 1990.
RECOMMENDATION 4

That the Minister for Employment, Education and Training initiate processes which will allow transferable accreditation of training between levels of courses and states as well as examining in-house training programs and determining levels of accreditation for such programs.
Response

Both Commonwealth and State Governments have recognised for some time that improved arrangements for recognising skills held by individuals and for the integration of on- and off-the-job training would lead to greater effectiveness of training outcomes and greater efficiency and equity in the workplace. They have been devoting considerable resources to developing appropriate means for addressing the issues in consultation with union and employer representatives, which includes considerable negotiation necessary to obtain consensus from all parties.

These issues are also integral to the industrial interests of the parties, and have been the subject of the negotiations involved in the award restructuring process. In particular, these negotiations have been working to establish agreement on mechanisms to allow for:
* greater reliability and flexibility in skills recognition arrangements;
* appropriate placement of people in the skills hierarchies established under restructured awards following initial translation;
* industry and geographic mobility;
* the recognition of skills gained informally; and
* incentives for workers to increase their skills and reskill in new areas.

The Commonwealth is pursuing these arrangements through the Commonwealth-State consultative forum. This is now represented by the newly formed Vocational Education and Training Advisory Committee (VEETAC), which has arisen from a merger of five former consultative fora.
Through joint Commonwealth and State co-operation two significant reports relevant to these issues have recently been released:
* the Report,
A Strategic Framework for the Implementation of a Competency based Training; and
* the Discussion paper,
Official Accreditation/Registration Arrangements for Vocational Courses/Training Programs.

Both of these documents have been developed through extensive consultation with key peak industrial parties over the past year, and the recommendations of the Report on competency based training were formally endorsed by Commonwealth and State/Territory Ministers at a special meeting on 2 November 1990.

Following this agreement all Governments agreed to work to having substantial progress towards the development of competency based courses by the end of 1990. Ministers agreed to the establishment of a framework for national consistency in recognition of skills, accreditation and recognition of training providers and promotion of credit transfer arrangements. State authorities will continue to exercise their statutory functions within this agreed framework and lateral reciprocal agreements. This will streamline industry access to these regulatory services.

The development of national skill and competency standards through the National Training Board, and the shifting of the training system to a competency basis will provide the necessary underpinning for a nationally consistent set of recognition, accreditation and articulation arrangements. This will allow for real portability of skills and qualifications across State borders and in some cases between parts of some industries.
RECOMMENDATION 5

That the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, as a matter of urgency, develop the interaction between TAFE and industry through an effective interchange program and equipment sharing for training.
Response

An increased importance of direct TAFE/Industry links has been a part of the reform of the industry training system which has been under review since 1989. It was overtly recognised in the 1989 document Commonwealth Priorities in TAFE, which set out a partnership in which human and capital resources of both TAFE institutions and industrial enterprises are used co-operatively to expand the provision of the quality of on-the-job and off-the-job training.

Since then, considerable achievements have been made in various States and Territories to make the TAFE systems more responsive to industry through joint ventures, business development units and special training of consultants to industry. The Commonwealth encourages the development of these initiatives through the annual resource agreements negotiated for the use of Commonwealth recurrent funding support which is provided to the State TAFE systems.
These specifically provide for, amongst other matters:
* involvement at the local level by industry representatives on TAFE College Councils and in course development and evaluation activities;
* continued provision for joint venture purchases; and
* co-operation with industry in the establishment and expansion of industry skill centres in key sectors.

Training provided through skill centres complements training available on-the-job, and through TAFE and other providers. Some centres are located in enterprises and some are stand alone facilities or are part of shared TAFE facilities. Since 1989 the Commonwealth has contributed directly to the establishment of twenty-four industry skill centres.
To build on these achievements, in 1991 the Commonwealth and States will introduce some new elements to increase the flexibility of programs to strengthen TAFE/industry links. These will include:
* provisions to fund TAFE projects constructed on industry owned land so that TAFE facilities can be close to industry; and
* provisions to expand joint venture proposals within general equipment allocations.
RECOMMENDATION 6

That the development of an Australian model for new management techniques be a principal outcome of a series of national conferences which would serve to raise awareness of new management techniques. The model should be developed over successive conferences as experience and knowledge of relevant factors increases.
PLUS
RECOMMENDATION 7

That the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce use the recommendations and comments in this Report as the basis for developing a draft model for consideration at the proposed conferences. Development of that draft model should take place following consultation with bodies such as the AMC and NIES. The draft model should form the basis for separate industry models which would clarify the terminology, specify the performance indicators and enable the identification of businesses able to meet the standards of the model. National and state conferences will provide the opportunity to discuss both the Australian and individual industry models and allow refinements to be made to assist Australian manufacturing to international competitiveness.
PLUS
RECOMMENDATION 8

That national and state governments provide financial and secretariat support for the conferences which should be convened under the auspices of the Australian manufacturing industries' peak body, the AMC, because of its tripartite nature and comprehensive representation of manufacturing industry groups.
PLUS
RECOMMENDATION 9
That initially a series of five national annual conferences be held along with complementary state conferences, the first of which should be held in early 1991.
PLUS
RECOMMENDATION 10
That the first national conference cover matters such as:
- development of an Australian model for new management techniques as set out in paragraph 4.21 (of Report);
- development of working groups to discuss experiences with new management techniques, the education system's ability to train the workforce, etc;
- reports by consultants including case studies;
- international industry experience, including guest speakers and case studies;
- industry sector forecasts and trends;
- national and international economic forecasts;
- keynote addresses by relevant Ministers outlining government action;
- reports by peak bodies; and
- strategies for developing overseas markets, in conjunction with AUSTRADE.
PLUS
RECOMMENDATION 11

That attendance at national conferences should be primarily for management/employee representatives of enterprises involved in implementing new management techniques, together with a smaller number of representatives of peak bodies, relevant academics and government officials. Organisations such as TQMI, AIM, TTC etc., which have expertise in running seminars and providing consultancy services for implementing new management techniques should also play a key role. Government and industry assistance should also be provided to enterprises or individuals able to prepare case studies or other relevant work for presentation at the conferences.
PLUS
RECOMMENDATION 12

That state conferences build on matters raised at the national conferences with an emphasis on providing information about new management techniques to manufacturers at the enterprise level. These conferences should allow a two way flow of information to ensure that manufacturers are aware of developments and their relevance. At such conferences there should be representatives from the education systems as well as industry and government so that manufacturers can put their concerns to them.
Responses to Recommendations 6-12
