As outlined in the covering introduction, the Government agrees with the problems that the Committee identified and considers that current Government programs and services already provide adequate access to the array of new management techniques. The importance of ``access'' is emphasised, as the main conclusions of the Committee related to the low use and, indeed, knowledge of the existing techniques and technologies in Australia.

The Government considers that it is more appropriate for industry to be made more aware of the range of Government and private sector services which are already available and which are acknowledged to be assisting the development of internationally competitive Australian enterprises. It would be preferable for industry to make better and more extensive use of those services already existing and available, than to introduce an additional model.

The Committee did note the potential confusion possible when industry is considering the array of support services currently available. To address this potential, the Government will ensure that the services currently available in and through the portfolios of Industry, Technology and Commerce, Employment, Education and Training, and Industrial Relations, will be brought together into the one document. This will then provide a comprehensive overview of the Government's present programs, in a short and handy format.

The Commonwealth and State Government partners in the NIES network have from time to time considered whether to develop standard packages (or models) of programs for separate industries. The consensus has been that there are too many differences between firms, even within the same industry, for such a broad approach to be worthwhile pursuing. The idea that there is a single ``model'' which can be employed to solve industry's problems is highly seductive. Regrettably, the reality is that a ``model'' in one industry or country is seldom directly transferable to another.

A better measure of performance and guide to implementing change in an enterprise is what its best international competitors are doing. In order to further advance this notion, the Australian Manufacturing Council is undertaking a study into how Australian enterprises can use detailed comparisons with overseas ``sister'' plants as a way of implementing change.

These comparisons need to delve into all the relevant factors underlying competitiveness, such as management practices, human resource policies, technology and work organisation. The Global Challenge noted that the most successful firms in implementing change had used these comparisons as a means to build an understanding of both the need for change and its feasibility among employees at all levels.

The mechanisms of national conferences proposed by the Committee for developing the model are also not considered the most effective means of introducing the changes identified by the Committee as necessary. The Government believes that better and more appropriate ways include one-to-one working with firms and selective networking, and suggests that the key focus for introducing change should thus be on individual enterprises or groups of enterprises.
RECOMMENDATION 13

That the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, in conjunction with peak industry and union organisations, institute a program of overseas visits by representative manufacturing industry groups to study developments in the implementation of new management techniques. These industry delegates should report their findings back to the national/state conferences. Assistance should also be provided to bring experts to Australia to attend the conferences or to address industry directly as appropriate.
Response

The Government acknowledges that overseas visits of the type proposed can be very useful. It has already, through the Department of Industrial Relations, part-funded a number of tripartite overseas missions between 1988 and 1990 in the industry sectors of metals, vehicles, textiles, clothing and footwear, timber, meat and food processing.

While these missions were undertaken in the context of the award restructuring and workplace reform processes, they also examined the operations of internationally competitive best practice firms, technological change, new management techniques and emerging trends in their sectors. The missions were very successful in the impetus and direction they provided to the restructuring process and in developing a common purpose among the key industry partners. It is considered that they have gone a large part of the way towards meeting the objectives incorporated within this Recommendation.

As referred to in the previous answers to Recommendations 6-12, the study by the Australian Manufacturing Council proposes a more focused approach to undertaking overseas missions on international ``best practice''. The AMC study aims to provide enterprises with an incentive to examine and develop ongoing contacts with similar overseas plants.

There is also an existing NIES program which provides an additional cost effective method of assessing developments in new management techniques. The Integrated Manufacturing Program brings together user groups of non-competing companies to share information on how to introduce best world practice management techniques.

The issue of Management Education is under active consideration within the Employment, Education and Training portfolio and by the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. A preliminary survey of attitudes to time spent on management education amongst senior management across all industries has been completed. A Mission on Management Education in mid-November 1990 visited the USA, Europe and Japan and a report will be available through NBEET in mid 1991.

NIES is also currently providing assistance to further the dissemination of manufacturing technologies and enhance international industry-academic linkages, with the Fraunhofer Institute for Production, Engineering and Automation in Germany. Since 1989, there have been a series of secondments of Institute staff to the South Australian Centre for Manufacturing, to present seminars and undertake specific company consulting assignments. These secondments are continuing and are expected to enhance Australia's current level of manufacturing technology in the areas of software development, automation systems and advanced manufacturing concepts.
RECOMMENDATION 14

That the Minister for Employment, Education and Training prepare for presentation and discussion at the first national conference a paper setting out education assistance for manufacturing industry and proposals to ensure its relevance, given the emerging technologies and multiskilling now required for Australian manufacturing to be internationally competitive.
Response

There are many types of funding for vocational education and training provided by the Commonwealth though DEET and through the State/Territory TAFE systems. The manufacturing sector is a major beneficiary of the various funding allocations. Information in the responses to Recommendations 3,4,and 5 indicates efforts to ensure relevance to industry needs and to promote multi-skilling.

The Minister is, however, aware of the need for better information, and new resource materials explaining the intent and extent of training reform are being prepared; they are expected to be available in the second quarter of 1991.
See also the response to Recommendations 6-12.
RECOMMENDATION 15

That the first national conference be held in Melbourne, as a major centre for manufacturing industry in Australia. The second conference should be held in Sydney and subsequent conferences alternate between these major centres of manufacturing.
Response
See the overall response to Recommendations 6-12.
RECOMMENDATION 16

That NIES streamline and promote the accessibility of NIES offices through the establishment of a well advertised one-stop hotline service which, by having instant access to a wide range of information and databases, will be able to provide immediate and appropriate advice, information and referrals to enterprises seeking assistance.
Response

For initial contacts by callers, the NIES Business Office in each State or Territory has a one-stop telephone number, which is also supplemented by 008 numbers for country callers in Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. In view of the problems encountered by the Committee in contacting these numbers, there will be a review made of how these numbers are answered.
RECOMMENDATION 17
That NIES augment its role as a national coordinating agency by using data from their evaluation program as a means of determining future directions and operating principles.
Response

The data to be gathered by the NIES evaluation program will be used in determining NIES's future priorities. As NIES is also half-way through its intended operational life, it is presently reviewing its current directions and whether it is meeting the needs of the market. During February, there were a series of seminars in each state, comprising NIES client companies (both successful and unsuccessful), consultants, interested Departments and other interested parties which provided feedback on NIES future directions.
RECOMMENDATION 18

That firms assess their operations by conducting a diagnostic review, which may indicate a need to develop and implement enterprise improvement plans to improve performance and lead to world competitiveness within an agreed time frame.
Response

The Government strongly endorses the need for Australian companies to utilise professional diagnostic review as a precursor to adopting best management techniques. In this context, a free diagnostic is a critical first stage in the provision of most NIES services to companies.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Tate, I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on annual reports referred to the Committee. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Government Response to the Report of the Senate Standing
Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs
Report on Annual Reports Referred to the Committee
May 1990
Schedule of Recommendations and Responses

1. The Committee endorses the conclusion of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration [SSCFPA] in its report on The Timeliness and Quality of Annual Reports that the guidelines for reporting by statutory authorities are in need of revision.
The Government's response to recommendation 3 of the report of the SSCFPA is as follows:

The Government notes that this recommendation has been supported by the Senate Standing Committee (SSC) on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its Report on Annual Reports Referred to the Committee (May 1990, p.6). It notes, too, that the JCPA has recently reported following its inquiry into annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities.

The task of co-ordinating work on the drafting of new requirements in relation to the annual reports of statutory authorities will involve consultation with a wide range of agencies, taking into account issues raised in submissions to the JCPA on the subject by PM&, the Department of Finance and other agencies, the recommendations of the JCPA, and issues raised by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration (SSCFPA) in paragraph 3.36 of its own report.

The Government agrees that the primary purpose of authorities in producing their annual reports should be to meet requirements in relation to accountability. The Government will continue its practice of considering recommendations and comments by parliamentary committees.

2. Recommendation: The Government examine the current procedures relating to transmittal of annual reports to Ministers with a view to amending them in such a way as to indicate for the benefit of Parliament the actual date of transmittal. In making this recommendation, the Committee endorses the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration contained in its report entitled The Timeliness and Quality of Annual Reports, namely that the letter of transmittal to the Minister be produced separately to the report. A copy of the letter, dated with the date that the report is actually passed to the Minister, should be sent to the Clerks of each House at the same time as it is sent to the Minister. The Clerks should then table these letters when they are received.
The Government's response to recommendation 22 of the SSCFPA's report is as follows:

The Government notes the difficulty which the Committee has had in trying to ascertain when reports were furnished to Ministers. It notes, too, the SSCFPA's reference to this recommendation in its Report on Annual Reports: Reports Tabled July-December 1989 (p.11), and the support for the recommendation expressed by:
* the President of the Senate, in his August 1990 President's Report on Annual Reports (p. 2);

* the SSC on Employment, Education and Training, in its May 1990 Report on Annual Reports (the Committee also expressed the view that any letter of transmittal within annual reports should be undated);
* the SSC on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, in its May 1990 report, Examination of Annual Reports (p. 4); and
* the SSC on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, in its May 1990 Report on Annual Reports Referred to the Committee (p. 8).

The Government agrees that agencies and Ministers should be able to demonstrate their compliance with the statutory requirement that reports be furnished to Ministers by a certain date (Acts Interpretation Act subsection 34C(2)) and tabled within a certain period after the date on which reports are received by Ministers (Public Service Act subsection 25(8), Acts Interpretation Act subsection 34C(3)).

An agency cannot accurately predict how long the interval will be between the date when the text of its report (including any letter of transmittal incorporated in it) is finalised and the date when printed copies are available to be furnished to the Minister. Nor can it be assumed that the date of furnishing will be the same as the date on which the Minister receives a report.

Whether or not reports are furnished to Ministers with separate covering letters, there remains a need for each report to incorporate a statement by the agency head certifying its compliance with (e.g.) section 25 of the Public Service Act. That statement should be signed and dated.

The revised guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports include a requirement (no. 01) that the annual report of a department contain a statement by the Secretary, dated when the Secretary gives the text final clearance to be printed. When the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced, consideration will be given to including a similar requirement in any new document.

Agencies, in furnishing reports to Ministers, may if they wish do so under cover of separate (dated) letters. To meet the concerns expressed by parliamentary committees, Ministers, in tabling reports, will advise the Parliament on what date or dates the reports were furnished to and received by them.
3. Recommendation: Consideration be given to developing separate sets of reporting guidelines for budget dependent authorities and Government Business Enterprises.

The issue of providing guidelines relevant to the range of agencies was among the considerations which were raised in submissions by PM& and the Department of Finance to the JCPA on annual reporting requirements for statutory authorities, and which will be taken into account when the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced. The JCPA has now reported and work is commencing on the drafting of new requirements in relation to the annual reports of statutory authorities.

4. Recommendation: The guidelines for both departmental and statutory authority annual reports be amended so as specifically to require reporting on the progress of Equal Employment Opportunity programs (even if such a report merely sets out reasons for not pursuing an EEO program).

The revised guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports include the following requirements: that departments report on the operation of their EEO plans in accordance with detailed guidelines issued by the office of the Public Service Commissioner (PSC) (page 19); that if any reporting requirement was not applicable to a department during the year this be shown in an index of requirements in its annual report; and that if any requirement was not met for any other reason the reason be shown (page 8).

The PSC guidelines referred to above are included in the Personnel Management Guidelines booklet, EEO Programs Guidelines 1 and 2 Updated, issued by the PSC in January 1990. These guidelines apply also to a large number of statutory authorities. Certain other authorities are covered by the EEO (Commonwealth Authorities) Act 1987. The situation is summarised at pages 66-68 of the PSC's booklet. When the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced, consideration will be given to ways of including appropriate EEO reporting requirements in any new document.

5. Recommendation: The guidelines for both departmental and statutory authority annual reports be amended so as to require each report to contain a section showing which pages of the report relate to each requirement of the relevant guidelines.
The revised guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports include a requirement (page 8) that annual reports contain an index of reporting requirements.

When the current Guidelines for the Content, Preparation and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities are revised or replaced, consideration will be given to including a similar requirement in any new document.
6. Recommendation: Appropriate guidelines be developed to govern the preparation of annual reports on the operation of Acts.

The Government agrees that the suggestions for reporting on the operation of Acts put forward by the Committee are generally appropriate, and it has drawn up the following guidelines based (with slight modifications) on the committee's remarks. The guidelines will be effective in relation to reports for 1991-92 and subsequent years.
Where an Act requires annual reports on the operation of the Act or part of it, those reports should contain:
* table of contents;
* a reference to the relevant legislation;
* descriptive and statistical material on the operation of the Act during the year, including:
- an outline of the objects of the Act;
- information which assists in determining whether the Act is promoting the achievement of those objects;
- a summary of any relevant legislative amendments;
- a summary of any relevant judicial decisions;
- an indication of the level of activity under the Act (for example, the number of cases dealt with);
- information which shows the resources devoted to administration of the Act and assists assessment of the efficiency and effectiveness of the deployment of those resources;
- information which assists assessment of the social and economic effects of the Act and its effects on individual citizens; and
- if appropriate, a summary of expected or proposed future developments, including any proposed amendments to the Act.

In the preparation of annual reports on the operation of Acts, attention is to be given to clarity of layout. Indexes are to be included if they would make the contents of reports significantly more accessible.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Richardson, I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on the Canberra leasehold system. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE
REPORT ON THE CANBERRA LEASEHOLD SYSTEM
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO RECOMMENDATIONS
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories is pleased to announce the Government's response to the Recommendations contained in the Report on the Canberra Leasehold System tabled in November 1988 by the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. With the introduction of self-government in the ACT in 1989 and the confirmation by the Commonwealth that it would retain both the ownership of land in the ACT and the leasehold system of land tenure, the relevance of the Report to the Commonwealth's interests has diminished.
Four recommendations remain of continuing relevance:

* Recommendations 3 and 4, which recommend fixed term leases 99 years renewable without further premium for residential leases, and 99 years or shorter terms as appropriate with negotiated renewal and further premiums for non-residential. The ACT (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988 provides for leases to be for specific periods rather than in perpetuity. Acceptance of these recommendations is considered highly desirable in the interests of avoiding undue speculation and achieving orderly development and redevelopment.

* Recommendation 6 which proposes that lease administrators should take the initiative in relation to redevelopment in the Territory, rather than be reactive. It is important that Territory legislation does not impede the Commonwealth initiating redevelopment proposals in areas of Territory Land formally designated by the National Capital Plan as being of national significance.

* Recommendation 11, which seeks active enforcement of lease purpose clauses. Within Designated Areas of the National Capital Plan, such enforcement is considered critical to the effectiveness of the Plan.

A similar Report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure has been referred to the Chief Minister for the ACT with the Commonwealth's views for consideration by her Government and the ACT Assembly as appropriate.
Recommendation
Comment
Response
1. The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth retain ownership of land in the ACT.
The Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988 confirms the continued ownership of ACT land by the Commonwealth.
Accept. Substance of this recommendation already given legislative force.
2. The Committee affirms the view that the leasehold system of property tenure provides an appropriate basis for land planning and management in the ACT and that it should be retained.
The above legislation confirms the continued application of the leasehold system.
Accept. Substance of this recommendation already given legislative force.

3. The Committee recommends leases should be for a term of years rather than in perpetuity. Residential leases should be for 99 years. Non-residential leases should be for 99 years or for shorter periods and their renewal should be at the discretion of, and on terms negotiated with, the ground landlord, and will include the payment of a further premium.

Continuation of a fixed term lease system is provided for by the above legislation and is considered appropriate. This is the best method of avoiding undue speculation by land-holders and achieving orderly development and redevelopment. Leases in perpetuity would effectively be little different to freehold, and would give rise to an altered level of expectation on the part of the lessees.
A fixed term leasing system is provided for by the ACT (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988. This system is considered a basic essential to Canberra's orderly development.
4. The Committee recommends that the City Area Leases Ordinance be amended to provide for the renewal of residential leases at the end of 99 years without further charge.
The principle is supported. Lessees of residential leases should on expiry of their leases, be able to continue in occupancy without significant cost implications.
A matter for the ACT Government.

5. The Committee recommends that lease purpose clauses in leases under the Ordinances be treated as both instruments of land use control and parts of an agreement. Administration and planning should be closely related to one another and coordinated.

The Commonwealth's interest in land use in the Australian Capital Territory will in future be safeguarded through the National Capital Plan and the provisions of the ACT (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988. It is considered appropriate that the ACT Government should decide whether to continue utilising Lease Purpose clauses as the means of controlling land use or whether to tie the purposes to which a lease may be put to the uses permitted (for the time being) by the Territory Plan, or within Designated Areas, the National Capital Plan.
Except with regard to the National Capital Plan, It is agreed that lease administration and planning should be carried out by a single authority.
A matter for the ACT Government.

6. The Committee recommends that the authority responsible for lease administration, in close cooperation with the proposed Territorial Planning Authority, should take the initiative, rather than being reactive in relation to redevelopment.

Within Designated Areas of the National Capital Plan, the Commonwealth via the National Capital Planning Authority may well wish to initiate redevelopment rather than await action and react to private sector initiatives. It is important therefore that the ACT Government does not enact legislation which would threaten this capability.
Accept. However action by the ACT Government should not impede the Commonwealth initiating redevelopment in Designated Areas of the National Capital Plan.
7. The Committee recommends that approved policy plans and development plans should be binding on the planning and development authority.

Under the Transitional Provisions of the ACT (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988, this recommendation is given effect to. This is an interim situation only. The NCPA (and all authorities and bodies of both governments) are bound not to act in any way inconsistent with the National Capital Plan. There is currently no legislation binding Territory Authorities or bodies to the Territory Plan. The stature of the Plan and the credibility of the legislature and its servants would be enhanced if such a provision was made.
The Commonwealth and Territory are bound by the National Capital Plan. The ACT Government might consider the extent of binding of the Territory Plan.
8. The Committee recommends that implementation of land development by the private sector must be closely monitored and its effects carefully assessed by the ACT Administration.
No comment.
A matter for the ACT Government.

9. The Committee believes that the current methods of amendment of lease purpose clauses under section 11a of the City Area Leases Ordinance are unsatisfactory and recommends that they should be replaced by surrender of the existing lease and the grant of a new lease for the new purpose.

Lease surrender and the granting of a new lease are considered to be appropriate techniques to replace the current method of varying lease purposes, provided opportunities for public objection are not curtailed.
This recommendation is properly one for the ACT.
A matter for the ACT Government.

10. The Committee recommends the current 50 per cent betterment levy should be replaced by compensation to the lessee for the value of the lease that is surrendered, including improvements, and a charge of the full premium value for the grant of a new lease together with the cost of any necessary off-site services.

Arguments advanced by the for this recommendation are compelling and are supported. Revenue from the administration and management of Territory land is however a matter which can only properly be considered by the ACT Government.
A matter for the ACT Government.
11. The Committee recommends that the lease administration section of ACT Administration should take action against lessees who breach the purpose clauses of their leases.

This is clearly a matter which should be addressed by the ACT Government. Within the Designated Areas of the National Capital Plan, the Commonwealth (through the Designated Areas of NCPA) will require prompt and effective action in relation to breaches of purpose clauses where this would result in any inconsistency with a provision of the National Capital Plan.
Accept. The Commonwealth will require prompt action in relation to breaches of lease purpose clauses in respect of Designated land in the National Capital Plan.
12. The Committee recognises that there are benefits in simplifying leases. However, the Committee recommends that in the process there should be no weakening of safeguards.
Territory Government's proposed planning legislation includes appropriate safeguards.
A matter for the ACT Government.
13. The Committee recommends that the development rights of some of the older existing leases need to be defined more precisely.

14. The Committee believes there should be opportunities for public participation in planning decisions not only when draft policy and development plans are being prepared but also when specific decisions are being made to change lease purposes or to grant leases on unleased land in established areas.

Section 25 of the ACT (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988 sets out requirements for Territory Planning legislation which include procedures for ascertaining and considering the views of the public. Within the constraints of the Section, and also s. 29 which deals with administration of Territory land, this recommendation is properly a matter for the ACT Government to consider. The principle of public participation in planning matters is well established. Care should however be exercised to prevent successive and repetitive `bites of the same cherry' and to ensure that conflict can be resolved with some expedition.
A matter for the ACT Government within the requirements set down in the ACT (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988.

15. The Committee recommends there be a legislative requirement for proposals for surrender and a new grant to be publicly notified (Section 11a CALO). They would be considered in the first instance by the planning and leasing authority. Its decisions would be subject to objection or appeal through the AAT. This procedure would apply to leases under any of the four lease ordinances.

Whatever method of land use change is adopted, it is important that appropriate public processes are adopted. As for Recommendation 9, it is for the ACT Government to establish appropriate procedures to apply to Territory land.
A matter for the ACT Government.

16. The Committee recommends that the financial terms and other conditions of leases granted under Section 17 of the City Area Leases Ordinance or under Section 72a of the Real Property Ordinance should be on the public record.
This is strictly a matter for the ACT Government. Making such matters part of the public record would clearly be in the interest of open Government.
A matter for the ACT Government.

17. The Committee recommends that the ACT Administration publish a booklet which sets out the features of the leasehold system, explains the rights and responsibilities of lessees and provides an introduction to the areas of the department responsible for the various aspects of leasehold administration. This booklet should be made freely available.
The ACT Government now has responsibility for the management of Territory Land. Recommendations 17 and 18 are therefore no longer relevant to the Commonwealth's interests.
A matter for the ACT Government.

18. The Committee, therefore, recommends that within one year the ACT Administration report to both the Senate and House of Representatives Standing Committees on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on how these recommendations are operating.
See above.
A matter for the ACT Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to this document, it not being the time of the year when people are encouraged to go into in depth analyses of Government responses to reports.
