TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Collins, I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on aspects of the proposal for a very fast train-final report. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE
REPORT ON:
ASPECTS OF THE PROPOSAL FOR A VERY FAST TRAIN
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Government welcomes the Report prepared by the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on Aspects of the Proposal For a Very Fast Train, released on 13 March 1991.

The Federal Government believes that the rail industry has an important role to play in the development of a more efficient and competitive land transport sector; one in which road and rail perform efficiently the tasks to which they are best suited. This approach enhances the efficiency of our transport system and the quality of service it provides, as well as minimises the environmental impacts of transport activities.
The proposal for a Very Fast Train, representing a major, privately-financed venture in the rail industry, is viewed by the Government as an exciting initiative in the development of land transport.

Against this background, the Federal Government has worked closely with the Governments of New South Wales, Victoria and the ACT in an inter-governmental Task Force to evaluate the VFT proposal. The principal requests made of the Governments by the VFT Joint Venture would involve government acceptance of the justification for the project, of an inland, rather than coastal route, of various performance criteria and of particular processes for the assessment of the environmental impacts of the VFT.

However, before Governments decide on these issues, there is a more fundamental threshold issue and this concerns the taxation treatment of the VFT. The VFT Joint Venture has proposed that there be changes to the tax system to assist the financing of the VFT and to remove a perceived tax bias against infrastructure projects, such as the VFT, which involve large construction costs and a deferred flow of revenue. A Committee of Ministers, of which I am a member, has been formed to examine the taxation issues and will shortly be finalising its considerations.

The Report on Aspects of the Proposal For a Very Fast Train emphasises that while the Committee views the development of the project favourably, in a very general sense, it has not been called on to examine the economic or financial viability of the project, nor to comment on the taxation issues which are fundamental to the project proceeding.

While the discussion on the VFT in the media has focused on taxation and financing issues, the concerns of the community have been wider. Indeed, there can be few projects which have engendered such public interest and debate as the VFT. The Committee's Report examines many issues which are of great interest and importance in this debate. The Committee's considerations contribute significantly to the understanding of complex matters such as noise levels and noise standards, energy use and atmospheric pollution, land acquisition, alternative high speed rail technologies, the impacts of a VFT on land use and the possible effects on regional development.
The Committee has made several recommendations on which I would like to comment:
Recommendation (Chapter 1 paragraph 1.26)
The Committee recommends that the guidelines governing the content of the Joint Venture's environmental impact statement be exposed in draft form for public comment for a period of six weeks.
Response

The Government agrees that the environmental impact statement (EIS) guidelines should be exposed for public comment before they are finalised. A period of six weeks would be appropriate given the magnitude and complexity of the project and the degree of public interest. The public review period would, however, need to be agreed between the four relevant Governments-the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and the ACT.
Recommendation (Chapter 1 paragraph 1.38)

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth give priority in its negotiations with the Joint Venture to establishing what protection for the Commonwealth is feasible should the project fail in the construction phase. In addition, the Committee recommends that the Commonwealth ensure that wide publicity is given to its position that there will be no Commonwealth subsidy to, or rescue of, the project if it runs into financial difficulties.
Response

The Commonwealth considers that a formal agreement between the four governments and the Joint Venture would be required to suitably limit governments' financial exposure and the degree of government liability for the project. Such an agreement has already been considered by the inter-governmental VFT Task Force. The Government agrees with the Committee that one possible means of minimising the risk to taxpayers funds would be to insert in such an agreement a clause similar to that in the English Channel Tunnel Act 1987.
Recommendation (Chapter 2 paragraph 2.59)

The Committee recommends that the economic and technical feasibility of a fast freight train sharing part or all of the VFT alignments should be examined as a matter of urgency in the context of the overall proposals for an FFT. The economics of governments paying for the cost of reducing gradients to levels acceptable to the FFT should be considered if it proves impractical to have the FFT use VFT gradients.
Response

The Government appreciates the detailed discussion by the Committee regarding the possibility of a shared alignment for the VFT and a fast freight train (FFT) between Sydney and Melbourne. However, any future upgrading of the Sydney-Melbourne line, including reducing gradients to levels appropriate to an FFT, would be a matter of commercial consideration by the future board of the National Rail Freight Corporation, and the Victorian and NSW rail systems.
Recommendation (Chapter 3 paragraph 3.113)

The Committee recommends that the governments responsible for setting and enforcing VFT safety standards be required to approve, on safety grounds, any proposal to use the VFT corridor for pipelines, communication cables, electricity transmissions lines, or similar utilities. The power should exist to permit sharing only on condition that specified safety precautions and procedures are observed.
Response

It would be desirable to ensure that any proposal to share the VFT corridor is examined and evaluated according to international rail safety standards by an independent party-further comment, relevant to this issue is provided below in response to the recommendations in Chapter 6.
Recommendation (Chapter 5 paragraph 5.58)

The Committee recommends that the basis, reasonableness and adequacy of the noise standards proposed by the Joint Venture for the VFT project, and not merely the question of the VFT's compliance with those standards, should be open to public scrutiny either prior to, or as part of, the EIS assessment process.
Response

The VFT Joint Venture's proposed noise standards are outlined in its VFT Project Evaluation report (November 1990), with supporting documentation in a consultancy report provided in February 1991. There has been no agreement given to the proposed standards which are at present under consideration by the four governments. The Government agrees that noise standards applying to the VFT should be exposed to full public scrutiny either prior to, or as part of, the EIS assessment process.
Recommendation (Chapter 6 paragraph 6.11)
The Committee recommends that:
- there be uniform safety standards governing the design and operation of the VFT;
- there be provision for uniform enforcement of these standards;
- the standards and their enforcement be no less vigorous than those applicable to very fast trains operating overseas; and

- a cooperative approach to setting and enforcing VFT safety standards be adopted by the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victorian and Australian Capital Territory Governments, but the Commonwealth be prepared to use the powers available to it to act unilaterally if the cooperative approach does not succeed.
Response

The Government agrees that the design and operation of the VFT should be subject to rigorous safety standards, applied and enforced in a uniform manner. Such safety standards would also need to comprehend any shared use of the VFT corridor for pipelines, communications purposes and other uses. All relevant models for the development, application and enforcement of safety standards for the VFT will be examined.
The Federal Government has been, and is, working with the NSW, Victorian and ACT Governments on a range of issues including safety standards.
Conclusion

The Government acknowledges the valuable contribution made by the Senate Standing Committee to the evaluation of the VFT project. The findings of the Committee are being taken into account by the Government in its consideration of the VFT Joint Venture's proposals which the Federal Government is assessing jointly with the New South Wales, Victorian and Australian Capital Territory Governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, of which I am a member, relates to an important project for Australia and the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). I commend the Committee's report to anyone who has not read it. The Government's response is a somewhat more bland document than I would have hoped, although perhaps it goes as far as it can. It refers to the fact that the threshold question still remains: that of taxation treatment for the very fast train project. It also refers to the relationship between the four governments involved and the Committee which has been established to look at those issues. I hope that they are working diligently and will give a high priority to the issues which are relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has responded to the recommendations of the Committee. Again, to an extent, one might say that its responses are bland but hopefully the conclusion, which indicates that the Government acknowledges the contribution made by the Committee in the evaluation and which refers to the relationship between the governments, indicates that priority is being given to that aspect of the matter.

On the question of the issue of taxation, which the Committee did not have before it pursuant to its terms of reference, I refer to the update document dated June 1991 of the joint venture in which the first paragraph, under `The Challenge to Government' states:

`Get on' with assessment: The VFT Joint Venture has strongly urged the Federal Government to get on with the assessment of the Sydney/Canberra/Melbourne high speed rail project. Proposals put forward by the VFT have now been with the Government for more than six months and it is now more than two months since a Ministerial Cabinet Sub-Committee was formed to urgently consider a range of key VFT issues.

I know that the Cabinet has had other matters on its mind, but these sorts of projects must be pursued at the same time. I, too, would urge with the joint venturer that these proposals be looked at, and I am disappointed that the Government has not been able, at the same time as responding to the Committee's report, to respond to these other issues as well. The second paragraph of the VFT update to which I have referred is headed `Australia's Largest Project'. It refers to the fact that it is commercially viable but suffers from discrimination in the tax law. It states, in part:

The VFT Joint Venture has demonstrated that a large start-up project such as the VFT is discriminated against relative to other investments. The Joint Venture has proposed changes to the taxation law to remove that discrimination. Recent studies by the Government's own Bureau of Industry Economics support the VFT position.

I hope that the Government will be imaginative. It is not being asked to contribute money but to look at the tax system in both the short and the longer term as to the benefits to taxpayers from this project and the benefit to Australia as a whole. Initially it was hoped to have the train running by 1995. As we are now into 1991 and still very much at the investigation stage, it would seem that that may not be achievable. It would be a pity if the project were delayed or lost altogether merely because four governments were not able to give it sufficient priority to ensure that what is an imaginative project is able to proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to address the Government's response on aspects of proposals for a very fast train (VFT). There have been some interesting articles on the VFT in the Australian in the past week, and I commend the Murdoch press for giving space to both sides of the debate for a change. Obviously, the VFT is still a very contentious proposal, but the current argument is really over the consortium's plea on taxation treatment. As the response indicates on page 2, the concerns of the community have been wider than the tax issue, which is a legitimate concern in its own right.

SPEECH.PARA: Recent media reports have again questioned the financial viability of the project in light of the reduction in air fares, and again I stress the real question of the financial viability of the VFT given that what we really need is a cheap, efficient interstate rail service designed to serve passengers as well as freight, and the somewhat quicker but more expensive back-up air service between urban centres in the south-east corridor of this country. Australia simply does not need this project because we can cope with transport between Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne by reducing road traffic, improving the current rail system and maintaining cheap air fares with appropriate discounts.

I do not need to repeat the arguments advanced for all this position because they have been made on several occasions previously. However, I stress the urgent need for an improved rail service in the south-east corridor for both passengers and freight. We do not need this white elephant mega-project, which is dubious on both environmental and financial grounds. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I rise to speak to this report to draw attention to the problems of small restricted health funds; in particular, the Mount Isa Mines health fund. Reinsurance was introduced by the Fraser Government in 1976 to ensure that no health fund would run into difficulties because of the sudden run on hospital costs. All bed day costs for private health fund contributors who spent more than 35 days in hospital in a year were put into a pool with a government subsidy-$150m at one time-and funds that had a large run on hospital costs received moneys from the pool; those that did not had to pay into the pool.

This scheme worked fairly well until June 1989 when the Government enlarged the pool by allowing funds to include costs for all hospital bed days of insured people aged 65 and over and some ancillary private hospital accommodation costs. Their reasoning for this was to spread the cost of the health of the insured aged across all health funds.

This decision has proved disastrous for small restricted membership employee based regional health funds, such as the MIM Employees Health Society. The MIM Employees Health Society estimates the cost to its fund for the year 1991-92 will be in excess of $2.5m or 8.15c per family member per week. This money goes directly to subsidise the larger open membership health funds.

What has been done to counter this increased cost to restricted membership employee based health funds? Individual funds, through their national body, the Health Insurance Restricted Membership Association of Australia, have fought the introduction of the latest changes to the reinsurance concept. HIRMAA continues to lobby for change to the restricted membership employee based private funds and has encouraged its membership to lobby their local parliamentary member for changes to occur.

Initially, legislative changes were delayed by three months and the Government was forced to pay a $20m subsidy from June 1989 to December 1990, but these moves have saved the MIM Employees Health Society $1.52m over that period. However, representations need to be pursued for further changes to occur. With the withdrawal of government subsidy from 1 January this year, payments to the reinsurance pool will increase from about $150,000 to $220,000 per quarter to about $540,000 per quarter. Costs for the financial year 1990-91 are estimated at $1.9m, and for the financial year 1991-92 at $2.5m.

It is obvious from these figures that attention needs to be drawn to this particular problem with the small insurance funds which operate on a restricted basis and which cannot cope with the problems associated with the larger unrestricted funds.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL BOARD OF EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Paper No. 3 on today's list refers to a set of guidelines set out by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) for the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, its councils and committees in the performance of their functions. The guidelines set out in the paper have three sets of priorities: economic, social and budgetary, and I will speak very briefly on each one.

The economic priorities include guidelines that are at variance with the legislation which the Minister is rushing through the Parliament. They call for the removal of unnecessary regulations and other impediments remaining central to the Government's approach; yet, we have just finished debating one Bill and are about to debate another, both of which over-regulate and create difficulties for the education industry. I refer to the renamed Education Services (Export Regulations) Bill and the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill.

The board is urged by the Minister to be mindful of certain economic priorities: increasing participation in education and increasing opportunities for upgrading skills and retraining. Perhaps this augurs well for the future, but the inquiry into adult and community education by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training has found that there are huge problems related to re-entry into education and training courses. It has also found that there is insufficient expenditure on migrant education and a deplorable lack of literacy in this country, which is an indictment on the whole education system.

The board is urged also to be mindful of improving the efficiency, effectiveness and flexibility of education and training, including training offered by private providers. Yet, later today or tomorrow we will debate a Bill which demands a national unified system of training. So, far from allowing training to be flexible, it confines it to a very narrow definition.

The board is urged further to help reduce institutional barriers between different educational and training systems. Again, I feel that that is a pious hope rather than a reality. The reality is that there is very poor articulation between different courses let alone between different institutions. Under the heading `social priorities' the Minister states that the Government's fundamental objective is to develop a fair, more prosperous and just society. One of the key elements of a just society, says the Minister, is equity in the distribution of economic resources, but their actual achievement is exactly the opposite: the gap has widened under the Hawke Labor Government.

Another element of a just society is fair and equal access to essential services, such as education; yet, the Senate Committee inquiry into adult and community education showed that there were still impenetrable barriers for some people to education: barriers such as distance, sex, ethnicity, language and ability.

The Minister reminds the board in this document that the Government has substantially expanded the number of places in higher education, but it has done so with disastrous results. The Government has expanded places but without providing sufficient additional resources, so we have universities that are bulging at the seams. Students are accommodated in overcrowded conditions and staff workloads have become impossible.

The board is reminded that a particular priority for this Government has been to ensure income support arrangements for young people in education, but the recent debate on the Student Assistance Amendment Bill in the Senate gives the lie to this. Students are finding it more difficult to get assistance to pursue further studies.

The Minister reminds the board of the Government's priority to improve literacy in this country, but we are way behind. When the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training held hearings recently around Australia, there was overwhelming evidence that not enough resources had been devoted to the literacy problem.

I want to make two final comments in relation to this document. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) urges Australia to become a clever country, but his Minister for Employment, Education and Training includes not one word in this document about the encouragement of gifted children. Much of the document refers to young people and new programs of assistance for those who are unemployed. It is a sad situation when the Government has to devise guidelines for a national board to cater for a massive high unemployment rate: 27 per cent of our young people are out of work and this document does little to solve their problem.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: report No. 33 1990-91-Departmental Administrative Activities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Initially, I would like to congratulate the Auditor-General on his normal excellent report. I think one of the points of which we should be cognisant and which comes out of the report is the Auditor-General's remark that limited conclusions could be drawn from the audits because of the small number of agencies reviewed. I know that a matter of great concern to a number of senators on this side of the chamber is the limited facilities available to the Auditor-General. Hence, his limited coverage of what is a massive department.

The report is an absolute indictment of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) who, in his administration of this portfolio, has quite clearly shown that he is neither very interested nor capable of handling something which is management oriented. He has shown this in a number of ways. He showed it in his improper interference with a contractor. The Minister came in after a tender had been let and reinstated the tenderer simply on the basis of the fact that the tenderer approached him and said that he had quoted too high a price. This destroyed the credibility of the purchasing function of the Commonwealth, which is of paramount importance, and the probity of contracts.

As the events of recent days have shown, the Minister used his Department to engage media monitoring consultants for his own political purposes. This is an improper use of such an activity. In fact, I would be somewhat surprised if the Auditor-General, when he has another look at this Department, does not look into this issue itself. Departmental consultants should be used for departmental work, not for political work. Quite clearly, the use of Croll Communications (Australia) Pty Ltd at a cost of some $17,000 or $18,000 a month over the last month just to track media in regard to both the interference in the contract, the advertisement ban and the disclosure provisions, was nothing to do with the Department but simply a political matter.

The Minister has indicated that he has no understanding or much interest in the information technology purchase area. There is an issue at stake, which has been going on for some 12 months now, in regard to the unlimited liability of purchase requirements and the consequential damages requirements. Again, that has not been resolved, although I understand that Senator Button has taken an interest in it in terms of his portfolio. So there might be some hope that this matter will be resolved.

Looking at the report itself, I would like to cover quickly some of the matters that the Auditor-General has drawn to the attention of this Parliament. In regard to motor vehicle use and disposal, the Auditor-General pointed out:

The ANAO found inadequacies in the maintenance of records of trips made in Commonwealth vehicles in almost all agencies despite the issue of instructions requiring records of usage to be kept. These problems mainly related to the records not being kept, being incomplete or missing. There were also instances where there was no check of these records to enable the validity of travel to be monitored.
One cannot run an organisation like that, particularly when taxpayers' money is involved and there is already a suspicion in the community about the probity of expenditure of taxpayers' money.

The Auditor-General went on to make an incredible statement which covers a whole range of subjects. In fact, I would go so far as to say that, even on this issue, if this sort of report were made about a company in the private sector there would be a good chance that the directors would be sacked and that the shareholders would have a case against their directors. The report also stated:
The ANAO found weaknesses in security over vehicles, vehicle keys-
the keys of Commonwealth owned cars-
and credit cards used for the purchase of petrol.

This raises a big question mark in respect of the extent to which this activity may be being abused. As I mentioned earlier, the Auditor-General has pointed out that he does not have the facilities at his disposal to pursue these matters at great length. The report continued:

The ANAO found little evidence that the exchange of an existing vehicle or hire of a new vehicle was supported by a needs assessment. The ANAO recommended that the decision to exchange an existing vehicle or to hire a new vehicle be made on the basis of demonstrated need.

I was greatly concerned about what the Auditor-General had to say in respect of asset recording, control and disposal. These are large ticket items. We are concerned here with taxpayers' money. The report states:
With one exception-
with one exception only-
all asset registers examined were incomplete in one way or another. The most common problem identified was the failure to include details of costs and acquisition dates in the register.

So we have a register which does not record costs or acquisition dates. What sort of business is this? As I have indicated on a number of occasions, Administrative Services is a management portfolio. This Department is responsible for purchasing, selling and maintaining a large quantity of assets of the Commonwealth. Yet, there is no record of costs and acquisition dates.

On 29 May I wrote to the Minister for Administrative Services asking him for details of an asset register. I have had no response. I have not even had an acknowledgment of that letter. The report continues:
Failure to do so-
that is, to keep a register with costs and acquisition dates-
make it difficult to report accurately the value of assets in financial statements and to monitor the ages of assets for disposal programs.

The Auditor-General has used kind words. It is not difficult-it is impossible. The quasi-commercial units in the Department of Administrative Services are moving to accrual accounting. But it is absolutely impossible to set up an accrual accounting system if one does not know the purchase date and the cost of a particular asset.

The Auditor-General's report is an absolute indictment of the Minister who seems to be more interested in playing party politics than getting on with managing what is probably the most critical department in the Commonwealth in terms of the ownership of assets. The report continued:
Common to all agencies-
not just one or two-
were the following shortcomings:
* assets being moved between locations without advising the area responsible for the maintenance of the asset register
* poor asset descriptions-
another kind phrase which means that they are not there and they cannot be recognised-
and location descriptions which made it difficult to locate/identify assets
So all of these Commonwealth government assets cannot be located; they cannot be described; they have no value on them; and no-one knows when they were purchased. The report continued:
* assets being disposed of without being retired from the asset register-
assets which are sold and which are thought to be still on the books-

* assets being purchased without being entered into the asset register. This situation appeared to arise because of the greater devolution of payment functions to program areas, the increasing use of corporate credit cards to purchase assets and the failure to maintain an audit trail between purchasing and receipt of assets, and
* asset registers containing a high proportion of items below agencies' minimum value for assets, which ranged from $250 up to $2,000. While some of the items were portable and attractive-
his word-
the inclusion of other low value items in the asset register created unnecessary work in maintaining the register and accounting for items in stocktakes.
The Auditor-General then went on to talk about stocktakes. He said:
Other problems with stocktaking were as follows-
and I will not go through the lot-
* often, the only personnel available to do stocktakes were the same people who maintained the asset register . . .

An asset register which he described earlier as being totally flawed. He points out, quite correctly, that stocktakes should be carried out by personnel other than those responsible for maintaining the asset records.

Another aspect of concern relates to time recording and leave records. Of course, the Auditor-General mentioned the vexed question of flexitime which is described by many people-and I know that this was the view of Senate Walsh when he was Minister for Finance-as being one of the great rackets of the last two decades. I think this point was brought out by the Auditor-General when he said:
In addition, the ANAO found in some agencies instances where provisions of both the Award and local agreements were not being adhered to. In particular:
* flex credits in excess of ten hours had been carried over to the following period without evidence of appropriate authorisation
* core time absence had occurred when officers had not accumulated sufficient flex time, and
* flex debits were carried out over two or more settlement periods.
He also pointed out:

The Personal Management Manual states that those officers not subject to flexitime arrangements (i.e. those above ASO 6 not subject to a local agreement) are not required to formally record attendance times . . .
One does not know whether they are there or not: they are not required to record attendance times. He stated:
for compensation purposes they should record attendance times in a personal diary.

The Auditor-General indicates that the officers falling within that category were generally not aware of this requirement. He spoke at great length about employee rehabilitation and compensation. He drew attention to the fact that there was an incorrect application of the provisions of subsections 19(2) and 19(3) of the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act for compensation for injuries resulting in incapacity, which caused over and underpayments of entitlements, and where calculations of normal weekly earnings were incorrect, resulting in over and under-reimbursements of payments by Comcare. In some agencies, the maintenance of history and leave records were inadequate. Manual history cards and leave records maintained by some agencies were recorded in pencil. When one sees such records in pencil a red light starts flashing. People record things in pencil so they can rub them out, for goodness sake.

Because of time constraints, I will not go into this in great detail, but I would like to come back to it later. I reiterate that if this were a business in the private sector it would almost certainly have not survived the recession. Also, with an audit report such as this, the directors would be fired. The chief in all of this is the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus: that is where the buck stops. He is totally responsible and has to accept the blame for this. If this were a company there would be a good chance of the shareholders suing their directors for not managing it properly.

The proper management of an operation is more important in the public sector than it is in the private sector, because in the public sector taxpayers' money is being used. We are taking money off taxpayers. Just as an anecdote, a small businessman who spoke to me only last week was subject to a tax audit. He said to the tax auditor, `I do not mind you coming in here and learning all about my business. You know more about it than I do. But I would like to know what you are doing with my money. If I can satisfy myself that you are using my money in a proper way, that will be okay'.

Here we have a quite curious situation of the Government taking a consuming interest in the affairs of everyone in the private sector, including honourable senators, in regard to the proper return to the Government of tax revenue, and an abuse of that money in its expenditure. It is my view that the Minister has a lot to answer for. Maybe he would be better off going to a department which he would prefer-as we understand from talk in the corridors-such as the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories or the Department of Social Security.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

INTERJECT.PARA: Report No. 34 of 1990-91-Department of Administrative Services-Services Provided to Members of Parliament and their Staff.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I will speak very briefly to the Auditor-General's report entitled Department of Administrative Services-Services Provided to Members of Parliament and their Staff. It is a report into the Parliamentary and Ministerial Services Branch of the Department of Administrative Services, which is responsible for the payment of ministerial salaries and allowances. It also provides resource support and services to members of parliament outside Parliament House and to their electorate staff.

The range of services provided includes office accommodation and related services, personnel services for staff employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act and travel services within Australia and overseas. The total expenditure on these services was $112m last year and approximately $123m is estimated for the current financial year. The estimated expenditure for the current financial year for salaries and related costs of ministerial and electorate office staff is about $49m, and $74m for associated administrative expenses, transport and travel costs of parliamentarians and their staff. The amount is considerable, and that is why it is important that the Auditor-General's conclusions be examined very closely by parliamentarians, who are affected by them. The key findings of the Audit report are:

the existing legislative and administrative framework makes it impracticable for Certifying Officers to establish that expenditure on certain entitlements is in accordance with legislative requirements . . .
That is a fairly basic problem. The report also found:
alternative administrative arrangements should be introduced to ensure that the test of `efficient and effective use of public moneys' is applied to parliamentarians' expenditure
there is a case for enhanced public reporting arrangements to provide more information on the level and type of expenditures by parliamentarians
guidelines should be developed to define more clearly the conditions for payments of entitlements
improved procedures are needed to ensure that supplies and services have been received
the provision of information to parliamentarians should be improved to assist them to manage their resources
controls over electorate staff travel should be strengthened, and
procedures for the recovery of expenditure from parliamentarians should be formalised.

In other words, this suggests that a fair range of improvement could take place in this area. Nonetheless, the AuditorGeneral finds that there are sound reasons for some limitations on the extent of intrusive examination into payments by and to parliamentarians; although the Australian National Audit Office is concerned-and quite rightly so-that:
. . . the terms `parliamentary' and `electorate' and `official business' are not defined in the determinations of the Remuneration Tribunal or in the Parliamentary Entitlements Act.
Nonetheless, the Remuneration Tribunal has given some indication by commenting that, having regard to the broad nature of the activities of parliamentarians:

. . . the scope of the `duties' of parliamentarians would include those activities associated with parliamentary and electorate work but not those which arise solely from a member's personal or social activities, or in the course of activities which are related exclusively to the member's party political matters.
The Auditor continues:

It would seem apparent from the above that the use of entitlements that are for electorate, parliamentary or official duties should not be permitted for activities related solely to social, party political or personal activities.
He continues:

Nevertheless, it is difficult to distinguish clearly or systematically those activities which are not related solely to social, political and personal activities. For example, what proportion of the expenditure must be for purposes related to official, parliamentary, or electorate business and not party business before it qualifies for an entitlement? In addition, it is likely that different people have different perceptions about what constitutes parliamentary and electorate business. Recognising that precision is impossible and that commonsense and that good judgment is required, the ANAO considers that there is a need for guidelines to be developed which assist in defining these terms.
The Audit Office also recommends:

. . . that monthly reports of all expenditure, together with the supporting documentation where appropriate, be forwarded to parliamentarians for the purpose of their certifying that expenditure has been used in accordance with legal entitlements and that efficient and effective use has been made of public moneys.

It seems to me that this would certainly dramatise to all members of parliament the fact that they are required to follow the requirements which the Audit Office seeks to have more clearly stated in terms of guidelines. This is the response from the Department to the Auditor-General's comments:

The Department accepts the recommendations of the ANAO and recognises that, in the absence of the application of the provisions of the Audit Act which deal with the use of public moneys when applying to members of Parliament, monthly accountability statements are desirable. The statements will enable the Department to satisfy its obligations in ensuring that expenditure is utilised in accordance with legal entitlements and that efficient and effective use has been made of public moneys.

I point out that one of those uses is postage. For example, there is a clear statement that postage must be used for electorate or parliamentary purposes but not for party business. It would be salutary for some members of parliament that I could think of to be required to certify monthly that all postage from their offices had, in fact, been for electorate or parliamentary business but not for party business.

On that topic, I hope that the Department, because of its agreement with the thrust of the Auditor-General's report, will promptly respond to the questions which were put on notice by Senator Parer on 28 May. A response is needed fairly soon to be within the guidelines. In particular, these questions go to the heart of some of the problems that seem to exist because of the lack of guidelines and because some members of parliament are, frankly, failing to face up to what should be their proper standards of behaviour. Some of Senator Parer's questions were as follows:

(1) Is it a permitted use of official postage entitlements for a Member and/or office holder of the Parliament to distribute: (a) letters soliciting financial donations for his/her political party or its endorsed candidates; (b) letters recruiting workers and assistants for his/her political party or its endorsed candidates; (c) notices of meetings of his/her political party; (d) minutes of meetings of his/her political party; (e) political party promotion material; or (f) how-to-vote material for himself/herself or candidates of his/her political party.
(2) Is it permissible for a Member to give stamps provided under an official allowance to an endorsed candidate of his/her political party or to a third party.
(3) Is it permissible for a Member to allow the use by another Member of Parliament of his/her bulk postage entitlement.

These things have become very important in view of the Government's attempt last year to increase the postage allowance to $30,000 for members of the House of Representatives but not members of the Senate, and also the proposed increase in the postage allowance to $20,000-odd by the latest Remuneration Tribunal recommendation. Senator Parer's questions continue as follows:
(4) Is it permissible for a Member to mail another Member's mail or the mail of a candidate of his/her political party on his/her bulk postage entitlement.

(5) Is it permissible for a Member to use his/her stationery allowance to produce: (a) fund raising letters or campaign worker recruiting letters for his/her political party or its endorsed candidates; or (b) how-to-vote material for him or herself or candidates of his/her political party.
(6) What are the guidelines for the use of departmental postage, including stamps, franking machines and bulk postage facilities, including Australia Post credit cards, by Ministers.
(7) Can an assurance be given that these guidelines have not been broken by any Minister of the Hawke Governments.
(8) Can an undertaking be given to investigate any possible breach of a prima facie case.

In view of the Australian Labor Party's increasing use of direct mail facilities-which seem to be part of the campaign to have the $30,000 allocated to lower House members of parliament-there is a clear and dramatic need, as the Auditor-General says, for clear guidelines to be stated and for the Department to require a regular certification by members that these guidelines, where they exist, are being met. Other matters raised by Senator Parer in his questions on notice are as follows:
(9) What have been the guidelines for the allocation of Ministerial offices since the election of the Hawke Labor Government.
(10) Which Ministers have located ministerial offices in their electorates.

(11) Is it permissible for Ministers to use departmental resources and facilities for: (a) parliamentary purposes; (b) electorate purposes; or (c) support of political parties and their endorsed candidates.
(12) In the last Parliament, which Ministers located ministerial offices in their electorates.

(13) What resources, in terms of staff and office equipment, and specifically, postage facilities, including stamps, franking machines and Australia Post credit cards, were provided for use in those offices.
(14) What were the identifying numbers of any franking machines issued to those offices.
(15) What telephone facilities are provided to Members and for what purposes are these facilities provided.

(16) Is it permitted to connect equipment to officially provided telephone equipment that has not been officially supplied to the Member, such as modems, direct dialling equipment and equipment associated with tele-marketing and telephone opinion research.
That is a very important question raised by Senator Parer because of the concerted campaign that has been undertaken by Government members in this area. The questions continue as follows:

(17) Are Members permitted to allow members of the public or political party workers to use or charge to a Member's official telephone, costs associated with tele-marketing or telephone opinion research.

(18) Has the Department of Administrative Services identified any over-expenditure of entitlements provided either by the Remuneration Tribunal, the Department of Administrative Services, the Parliament or its departments or a Government, to Members and Senators during the last Parliament; if so, for each case, please provide full and complete details of the over-expenditure, including: (a) details of the entitlement; (b) the nature and amount of the over-expenditure; (c) the name of the Member or Senator and, if applicable, the electoral division involved; (d) any action initiated to recover the over-expenditure and the result of the action initiated; and (e) the status of the recovery action or an explanation as to why no action has been taken.

Because, in general terms, I welcome the Department's support for the propositions of the Auditor-General about the requirement for certification and the need for guidelines, I hope that the Department will speedily provide an answer to the Minister for Administrative Services to these questions on notice, and that the Minister will then speedily convey that answer to the Parliament rather than delay or defer it or, as we have seen in the past, seek to cross out those bits which happen to embarrass him. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning Senator Michael Baume raised a point of order in relation to a remark made by Senator Bolkus. Senator Baume stated:

INTERJECT.PARA: My point of order is that it is improper to describe any member of the Opposition or indeed any member of this place as being someone who should be treated with contempt. I therefore ask the Minister to withdraw his comment.

On the basis of the point of order raised by Senator Baume, I ruled that there was no point of order. Although many honourable senators would not refer to other honourable senators as being deserving of contempt, I do not regard this as offensive in the context of standing order 193 (3). There is often a fine line between what a person in political life should be able to accept as part of the cut and thrust of politics and what should be regarded as offensive in the chamber. While, for example, I would not regard the use of the word `contempt' in the context raised by Senator Baume to be objectionable, I would regard as objectionable a remark that an honourable senator is `contemptible'.

After ruling that there was no point of order this morning, I immediately called for a transcript of the incident because, due to a barrage of interjections, I was not exactly sure of what Senator Bolkus had said. After receiving and reading the transcript, I still hold that my ruling in relation to the point of order raised by Senator Baume was correct. Again, I mention that Senator Baume remarked:

My point of order is that it is improper to describe any member of the Opposition or indeed any member of this place as being someone who should be treated with contempt. I therefore ask the Minister to withdraw his comment.
Senator Bolkus's comment, however, went further than this. He said:
Senator Parer can throw around whatever allegations he likes; I am not going to respond to him. I will treat him with the same contempt with which he handles truth in this place.

I have no hesitation in remarking that Senator Bolkus's comment linking `contempt' with `truth' was a personal reflection on Senator Parer. This part of Senator Bolkus's remarks was definitely in breach of standing order 193 (3).

I cannot see any useful purpose in pursuing the matter further, but I consider it is a matter I should bring to the attention of the chamber, especially as someone reading Hansard may gain the incorrect impression that I regarded that there was no point of order in relation to those words which linked `contempt' with `truth'.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

As the Bill is scheduled for debate later this afternoon, the letter may be of interest to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1991BOUNTY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991CUSTOMS AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill and allied Bills was adjourned for the matters of public interest discussion, I was pointing out to the Senate the duplicity of the Australian Democrats in relation to matters rural. I had mentioned their general anti-rural stand, the stand on which they were now vacillating in relation to wool, and I had mentioned the matter of political broadcasts. The Democrats, in their anti-rural bias, are proposing such things as a wealth tax, an inheritance tax, an extension of the capital gains tax, increased excises on petrol and diesel fuel, a levying on all domestic road freight movements, changes in the pay as you earn deduction procedures which would impose further burdens on employers, increases in company taxes, and the taxing of trusts as companies.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to their attitude to the rural and farming people, the Democrats have introduced a private members' Bill, which I suspect should properly be called `the invitation to strike Bill'. That Bill will take away any remedies that rural people might have against the likes of, say, Wally Curran, who has closed down meatworks in Victoria. It makes something of a mockery, I suggest, of the Question Time exchange on the live sheep export matter when the Democrats are agreeing and saying `hear, hear' to the fact that we should kill and abattoir the sheep within Australia and get the value added component of that. Of course, the Democrats want to take away any legislation that exists that will stop the sorts of strikes and actions that Wally Curran has instituted in Victoria to prevent rural people from slaughtering and abattoiring sheep in this country. The Democrats generally have this anti-rural, anti-farming bias. As I said this morning, how can anyone support the actions of a party which is so blatantly anti-farmer and which is so desperately trying to hide its anti-rural base?

I pointed out earlier that the short-term political actions which only provide ammunition for the Australian Labor Party (ALP) to cling desperately to power do not interest me at all. I, together with my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties, believe that it is in the best interests of Australians generally, and of canegrowers in particular, that the Liberal and National parties be united in their determination to defeat this Government that has done so much harm to rural industries in general and to the sugar industry in particular. In this regard, I congratulate and support the speeches given by my Queensland colleagues in the other place, namely, Mr Bruce Scott, Mr Braithwaite and Mr Truss, and I join with them in their attitude towards these Bills before us.

I believe that it is essential that we have a credible voice in the next Government which will ensure that the real interests of canegrowers and the industry that supports so much of Queensland, particularly north Queensland, are encouraged and enhanced. I intend to continue to support the sugar industry against the attacks on rural people and farmers that the Democrats are renowned for.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are watching how you vote very carefully, Senator Macdonald.

—We will see, over a period of time, whether Senator Kernot acts properly in the interests of rural industries. I understand from the former and now discredited Treasurer, Mr Keating, that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) jumps whenever the American President picks up the phone. I suppose it would be too much to expect the Prime Minister to consider Australian producers rather than American interests when jumping to the American phone calls. I wonder whether the Prime Minister has ever seriously done any tough bargaining with the Americans and the Europeans on the huge subsidies that they pay to their sugar growers. If he were as good at getting deals out of the Americans as he is at getting deals out of the ALP Left and the Democrats, then rural exporters would be prospering. I wonder whether the Prime Minister has ever proposed any joint action with the Cairns Group against the Americans and the Europeans which might lead to some fairer world practices.

SPEECH.PARA: Access to European markets for our sugar in a free, open and competitive system would mean that Australia could always sell at very good prices as much sugar as it could ever produce. Australia essentially is a trading nation. Whereas the United States exports about 15 per cent of its produce, Australia exports 65 per cent. With only a minuscule population by world standards, we must export to survive. It is essential that we redouble our efforts to achieve freer world trade. Because of our reliance on our exports to survive, a freer trading regime is much more critical to us than it is to most other countries. The changes contained in this legislation go some way to addressing that and they will send a message to our trading partners that we are serious about stopping unfair trading arrangements.

I have lived in a sugar town for most of my life, and whilst I am not a cane farmer I am the only one in this chamber whose livelihood has depended upon the returns gained by the sugar industry. I know of the calibre, energy and efficiency of the people who are involved in the sugar industry. I know all the cane farmers, the contractors, the mill workers, the field workers, the sugar chemists and the mill engineers. I know their commitment to the industry they serve. It is operated by a group of people who have proved over the years their resilience, their ability to adapt to new procedures and new practices and their innate ability to work and create wealth for Australia. There is no nine to five existence for these people or any handout for overtime, whenever a few extra hours are worked.

Principally, sugar cane is grown by people who came to this land from another country with not a penny to their name, often without friends and without experience of the harsh and difficult environment in which they found themselves. Often, they were not familiar with the language of the country. However, they had a complete and absolute willingness to work to better themselves and their families in a new land-a land which they saw as a land of opportunity. These people will adapt and progress, despite the lies and broken promises of this Government. They will cope because that is the sort of people they are.

The sugar industry in Queensland has been the most important continuing industry of coastal Queensland and has led its development and progress this century. As time goes by, it is my view that the major sugar growing areas of Queensland will contract to three parts of the State-the Ingham area, the Burdekin area and the Mackay district. Both State and Federal governments have a massive investment in the Burdekin area, with their inputs into the Burdekin dam and the infrastructure that supports it.

Individual families and the CSR company have invested a great deal of money in that area as well. The climate is ideal for the growing of sugar, a guaranteed water supply is there, the land is plentiful and available, and the complete infrastructure to produce the world's best and highest yielding sugar is also available. The tonnages per hectare grown in the Burdekin area are amongst the highest in the world. Mackay, further to the south, is also a very rich growing district. It has the climate and the infrastructure, but it does suffer from the lack of a guaranteed water supply- relying mainly on rainfall, which is cheap and nutritious but not always there when it is wanted.

For example, because of the floods and then droughts earlier this year in the region, the crop in the Plane Creek Mill area could be as low as 500,000 tonnes compared with 1.3 million tonnes in a good season-a yield of 46 tonnes per hectare or some 55 per cent only of the normal average. The full potential of the Mackay district will be reached only if a permanent water supply can be provided to that area. The Herbert River district also has been hard hit by natural calamities. The floods earlier this year will mean a loss in sugar production of an estimated $30m to the Ingham area. Yields in part of the Hinchinbrook district will be the lowest for 40 years.

I call upon the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia (Senator Collins) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) to initiate talks with the Mackay Regional Water Resources Committee and the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries in an effort to speed up planning and assessment of appraisal studies for future water storage in the Pioneer Valley of the Mackay district. I also call upon them to consider some contribution to financing a total catchment management project in the Herbert River area to enable some relief from the flooding and drainage problems that that area experiences. The Commonwealth Government must extend its support to projects which will enable the Mackay and Ingham regions to continue to enhance their role as major producers of export dollars. Some support by the Australian Democrats for these initiatives would be a far more genuine and telling indication of their support for the sugar industry than the transparent actions they often go on with.

A secure water supply to Mackay, drainage and flooding relief in Ingham and the expansion of the industry in the new areas served by the Burdekin Dam will enable the Australian sugar industry to continue its role as one of Australia's biggest and best export earners. But, more importantly, when this Government has had the courage to tackle reforms of the labour market and transport industries and has purified the world sugar markets, it can reduce tariffs as much as it likes, because in that situation the Australian industry will not need any protection; it can and will compete with and dominate any other sugar industry anywhere else in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it three Bills: the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991, the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 and the Customs Amendment Bill 1991. Time is short, as it usually is at this time of the session, given the Government's inability to manage things properly. If it cannot run a country, it certainly cannot run a Senate chamber. I see the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who is on duty, acknowledging the correctness of that statement. Since time is short, I will deal only briefly with the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill and then say a few words on the other Bill before us. The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill has eight schedules in it amending rates of tariff, and the Bill amending the Customs Act deals mainly with anti-dumping procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: I make a general point first in relation to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. It has to be seen as part of the Government's headlong rush to zero tariffs. There is quite a revolution going on in Australia with the Labor Government busy stripping tariffs off everything. That is causing a very high price to be paid by Australian manufacturing industry. Many people are going out of business because of the rate of change and the lack of coherent policies associated with those changes.

My concern is jobs for Australians within a sustainable industrial operation. By that I do not mean the potentiation or perpetuation of the tariff regime we had in the past, because it was clearly wrong and something had to be done. Tariffs started to increase in this country in the 1950s and the 1960s. When I came to the Senate 13 years ago, the average level of tariff protection across industry was 30 per cent. I spoke quite strongly about levels of tariff protection 13 years ago in the Senate chamber in the other Parliament House at a time when it was very unfashionable to talk about tariff protection and the need to reduce it. The problem with the tariff protection that we had in those days was that it was extreme. Residual elements still exist in Australian industry. The textile, clothing and footwear section of the manufacturing industry enjoys a tariff protection of between 80 and 120 per cent-it is hard to define. The motor industry has tariff protection levels between 60 and 80 per cent. Those levels reflect the great imbalance in the policy of 30 years ago.

We paid a very high price for that unbalanced tariff protection because industries became inefficient. It did not matter how bad management was; they could get away with bad management practices, secure in the belief that they had only to apply for an increase in tariff protection to shut competitors out of Australia. We saw the most outrageous moves on demarcation and union practices, all paid for by the tariff barrier. At the end of the day, we had a totally inequitable distribution of resources. Resources went into those industries which could attract the highest tariff protection, irrespective of the value to Australia in terms of employment and in terms of export earnings. The situation became so bad that the whole thing collapsed.

Remedial action has been taken during the time of this Labor Government. But it has adopted a very unthinking knee-jerk reaction to the situation. It has taken the point of view that, since tariffs are wrong, we must get rid of them. A much more analytical response than that is required. A little intelligence needs to be applied. As well as asking what is wrong, we have to ask why it went wrong. The solution to the tariff problem in Australia requires far more elegant and sophisticated approaches than we have seen from this Government, which has just been blindly winding back tariffs as fast as it can.

What was wrong with the old system was the extreme level that it went to, and the correction of it quite properly is the reduction and, hopefully, the elimination of tariffs, but we cannot make those corrections in isolation and still maintain industries in Australia. We need to develop an effective, efficient and, above all, competitive Australian industrial base producing goods that we can sell on world markets. The first thing that has to be done is not to chop the tariffs off but to fix the great inefficiencies in the Australian community that the industrial world has to cope with and to clean up those inefficiencies before we start going to zero tariffs. The Government has done nothing effective at all to reform Australian work practices in this regard. It has certainly talked a lot about it but, as we see from the debacle on the waterfront, it has done nothing to lead to a more efficient Australian community.

Only today in the Australian we see an article headed `Industrial action brings Newcastle company ``to its knees'' '. It is an article about a dockyard in Newcastle which is $465,000 in debt for damages because it is 32 days over its contract time for the refit of a Royal Australian Navy ship. In the past week at Bundaberg, one of the towns in my own State, two engineering companies gave evidence to the Industrial Relations Commission that they had export orders of $3.5m and over 100 jobs in jeopardy because of union warfare against them. The union there is the same union that is causing trouble in the dockyards in Newcastle. It is the old metal trades group of unions. They are as greedy and as intransigent and lawless a bunch as we would get outside the painters and dockers. This Government will not do anything to clean up the union movement, to bring it under the rule of law and say, `You have a national responsibility to the people of Australia. You have fair terms and conditions to work under. Abide by those'.

Until the work practices in Australia, not only at the dockside but across the wharves, through the transport industry and all the rest of it, are cleaned up, we simply cannot go to zero tariffs, because we leave Australian industry labouring under enormous penalties which make them uncompetitive, resulting in their going out of work. We have to maintain the life raft in some way until we get the people on the raft onto dry land. We will not get them to dry land until we clean up all the union featherbedding and union malpractices that this Government is paralysed to act against.

It is interesting that the Industry Commission looked at the effect of work practices within Australia and estimated that a figure of some $2,300 a year per family in increased spending was to be gained in the short term if we just cleaned up the inefficiencies within the society. That means around 50,000 extra jobs, and in aggregate around $22 billion a year, if we start to run the country efficiently. That is very much a function of the government of the day, standing up to the pressure groups and the special interest groups which deny the workers and the ordinary people of this country the standard of living that they are entitled to just by having an efficient society. Until that is done, a lot of this business of reducing tariffs only means that more and more Australians are put out of work. When the Liberal-National Party comes into government, whenever the election is held, that will be our top priority. We will fix up the inefficiencies and get rid of people like Mr Kelty and all the other people to whom Senator Cook, who has just come into the chamber, kowtows. Those people have no place in a modern Australia.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill in schedule 8, by amendments 7 to 12 which amend schedule 3 of the original Bill, deals with the sugar industry. It is a matter on which I wish to speak because it has occasioned quite a lot of comment within this chamber. Once more it is an example of a broken promise by this Government. It gave a solemn promise to implement the findings of a Senate committee on the levels of tariff protection for the sugar industry over a number of years as a consequence of the removal of the embargo. The Government, without any warning at all, has gone and broken those undertakings. As Senator Macdonald in an excellent speech pointed out, one needs lead time and warning because it is a cycle of about 18 months in which a grower can make his decisions as to when he will plant, what he will plant and finally reap the crop. To make a spontaneous decision in the way the Government did here to change the rules of the game has a profound impact on the growers and millers in the sugar industry.

I am pleased to have Senator Macdonald in the chamber with me. I have had a lifelong association in the sugar industry with growers, millers and marketeers. I would immodestly claim to have closer links with the industry than anyone in the Senate. I welcome Senator Macdonald, even if he was only a solicitor in a sugar town! But at least it puts him a long way ahead of some of the other people in this chamber today who have spoken on sugar. He has a far greater insight into the industry and its ramifications than, I suspect, do some of those who will follow me and some who have spoken earlier.

The sugar industry is interesting because it is very tightly controlled. I do not think there is any industry that has ever existed in Australia which has had a similar degree of regulation on every aspect. I refer to assignments as to where one can grow cane, the entitlement to the mills, the way the product is all bought by the Queensland Government and so on. It is all marketed in a certain way and, as I have said, it is a tightly structured industry. In the past it has had the ultimate in tariff protection. It did not just have high tariff barriers; it had a total prohibition on any sugar imports into Australia. If ever there were a formula for inefficiency in an industry, it would have to be the sugar industry. It is the exception that proves the rule in one sense because, despite the huge and inflexible degree of protection that it has enjoyed in the past, it is a world leader. It is an industry that sells 80 per cent of its product overseas on world markets at world prices, in good years and bad years, and it makes a profit.

There is a lesson here. The business of tariff protection is not to be seen in isolation, but in the context of the efficiencies within the industry. In 1989 the Government removed the embargo and agreed to a transition period in accordance with terms laid down by a Senate committee. It agreed to provide tariff protection of $115 a tonne up to July 1991, $95 to July 1992, and $70 from July 1992. Now, without warning, the figure has gone down to $76 a tonne to July this year, and $55 a tonne from July 1992. This is a clear break with the undertakings given by the Government to the industry. The decision will cost growers a great deal of money. It was entirely unnecessary. I believe that it is entirely unjustified, and it is an enormous injustice to the whole of the sugar industry, but the matter cannot be changed. We are dealing here with a taxation Bill under section 55 of the Constitution. All the protests from the Australian Democrats and the other people who will move amendments are cynical political exercises, because the Government will not change its mind on this matter and we will achieve nothing by voting against this Bill.

I say with some regret that the community will pay the price, but if the people vote a Labor government into power they have to pay the price of the economic mismanagement of the Government. The people who will pay the price in this instance will be the growers and millers in the sugar industry. Their real solution to the problem is to take action at the polls the next time they get the opportunity and vote out this Government lock, stock and barrel, as it deserves to be voted out.

There is another element of this Bill that is of relevance to this point, and that is the takeover bid that is now before the Australian financial world for Bundaberg Sugar Co. Ltd. Bundaberg Sugar is a very successful, very old, very well managed company, which I think is the largest company in Queensland, and one of the large companies in Australia. It is a grower, a miller, a refiner and a distiller. It is second only to CSR and produces about 22 per cent of the Australian crop.

I said that it was a very well managed company, and in times like this where everyone is feeling the pinch financially, as of 30 April 1991 Bundaberg Sugar had $40m in cash in its accounts. It is not a bankrupt company at all. It is extremely well managed. Yet it has been subjected to a very opportunistic bid from an English sugar company. I mentioned that Bundaberg Sugar was Australia's second largest sugar company; it is also Australia's largest sugar grower. It owns six raw sugar mills-Fairymead, Bingera, Millaquin, Mourilyan, Moreton, Babinda, and it also has a refinery at Millaquin. It has a half-share in the Bundaberg distillery which makes the famous Bundaberg rum, the only spirit of any international standing that is produced in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a bad drop either.

—An excellent drop. The fundamental problem that Bundaberg Sugar faces is that it operates in a deregulated market. It is being attacked in a predatory takeover by a company operating within a very protected market. When a company is working on the world market and is deeply involved in that market as Bundaberg Sugar is, when there is a surplus of the commodity the price comes down and therefore the profitability of the company falls, even though it is extremely sound and well managed. Conversely, when a company is operating within a highly protected market in which the price never falls-and the price of sugar in England where Tate and Lyle PLC operates is roughly three times what it is in Australia today-the company is completely insulated from any downturns in the market. It is very much stronger than a company that is exposed without any protection to the world market.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the problem Bundaberg Sugar faces at present. It is at a low point through world prices being low and it is exposed to an opportunistic bid from a predatory operator in Europe. Its correct defence should be to say to the Australian Government, `Look, we are important to Australia. We produce a commodity which we can sell and sell very readily overseas. Exports are crucially important to Australia's financial health, and we should be defended because we can contribute far more to the Australian economy by retaining the profits within Australia as an Australian owned company than being taken over by a foreign company.'.

There is a very valid and respectable argument to be made that Bundaberg Sugar is important strategically to Australia's financial health, but what happens? It gets referred by the Government to the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB), which is purely a toothless tiger, a political front put up by the Government to assuage or mislead the unthinking element in Australia that somehow or other this Government will protect Australia's vital interests. In reality, the FIRB has never taken on any takeover and denied it.

What is even worse, we had Mr Hawke and Mr Kerin prejudice the findings of the FIRB by going public with opinions before the FIRB report came down. Mr Hawke showed his great knowledge of the sugar industry by saying that Tate and Lyle would bring in some research to Australia. That is an absurd proposition because the Australian sugar industry is the world leader in research and applied technology.

One of the sad things about this takeover bid is that since every unit in the Australian industry contributes to research funding, the findings are distributed within the Australian sugar community. One object of Tate and Lyle in its takeover bid is to gain access to that world standard technology which is held within Australia; our technology is ahead of any other country in the world. Mr Kerin, who also knows as much about the sugar industry as Mr Hawke, then came in and said, `If we get Tate and Lyle in there, it will open up new markets for Australia.'.

The fact is that in good years and bad we sell 80 per cent of the Australian crop on world markets. Even in bad times we are not left with any sugar that carries over from year to year. Where will the markets come from that Tate and Lyle is promising or that Mr Kerin has promised us? It is a nonsense.

The real reason why the Government told the FIRB to approve the Tate and Lyle takeover is that it is desperately short of money. We are going into debt at a rate of something like $1.5 billion-$1,500m-a month on average. We have gone from a debt of about $30 billion to about $128 billion or $132 billion under the economic stewardship of this Government. The Government has to sell the farm. It has to sell everything it can in this country to get money coming in to try to balance the huge outflow. That is why it wants the $325m from Tate and Lyle. It takes the short term view.

It is certainly not in the national interest that Bundaberg Sugar should be sold to an overseas company. Even the Queensland Government recommended very strongly-as strongly as it could-that the bid not be proceeded with because there was no national advantage in it. We have it on the record that the company is a proven price rigger. It admits to having been involved in price fixing rackets in the United Kingdom for four years. Senator Button smiles; of course as a friend of the Prime Minister it would not affect his morality that someone was involved in dishonest practices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I object to that last comment. I do not think honourable senators should make references to a senator's morality. Senator MacGibbon can make references to my ideas, appearance and conduct-anything he likes-but not to my morality.
—I thought you were taking a point of order because he suggested you were the Prime Minister's friend.
—No, he referred to my morality.

—I withdraw that in an unqualified way; it was a slip. We have a proven price rigger in the company and we have a company that has a very poor investment record. According to a report in the Australian Financial Review, one of the directors who came out here as the bagman for Tate and Lyle, Mr Kerr Muir, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to remain competitive Bundaberg would need the most efficient technology, and Tate and Lyle could provide the necessary expertise and financial support.
``Anyone knows that we can all do better and can gain from introducing innovative world-leading technology, which costs money, which we're prepared to spend.''-

As I said earlier, this company has $40m in cash. Few companies in Australia today have $40m in cash in hard times. We can raise the money within Australia and the company can raise it within its own resources. But Tate and Lyle's record of investment is on the public record. According to Mr Brian Frith, writing in the Business Australian on Tuesday, 23 April 1991, one of the reports on Tate and Lyle indicates:
. . . that Tate &Lyle's capital expenditure in the UK over the past five years is only one third of British Sugar's-
which is a competitor of Tate and Lyle-
#57.8 million . . . to #187.9 million.
Moreover, Tate &Lyle admitted that its UK cane sugar refineries were run down, in need of capital expenditure of at least #100 million to bring them up to modern standards.
This is a very interesting point because Mr Frith then goes on to say:
Despite this, Tate &Lyle directors actually reduced budgeted expenditure this year-
