on capital equipment. So we have a company that has a pretty poor record of investment within its own industry and a company whose policies are inimical to the stated goals of the Australian Government.

One of the reasons why the Government is reducing tariffs is to free up trade around the world-to reduce barriers. Yet this same Tate and Lyle refused take any action in the recent past when it had the opportunity to free up the prohibition on the importation of sugar into the European common market. It refused to take any action against the stringent policies in the United States on the importation of sugar. Those two actions alone put it markedly at variance with the stated policies of this Government. If the company has anything to offer the sugar industry in Australia, it should come out and say so. There has been nothing on the public record yet that would encourage anyone to believe that there was anything beneficial in the Tate and Lyle bid for Bundaberg Sugar.

The people who will really suffer at the end of the day will be the growers. There has always been a traditional rift in the sugar industry between growers and millers; they are two sides of the one coin. There have been differences of opinion over the years between the Bundaberg millers and growers, but that is true throughout the whole industry. The growers will certainly find it much more difficult to deal with a board that is situated in London and oriented towards the European common market than some board that is situated in Bundaberg where they can physically walk in and discuss their differences.

In conclusion, I will deal very briefly with the other Bill, the Customs Amendment Bill 1991, which changes the legislation with respect to those who are entitled to carry out body searches and authorises Federal Court of Australia judges to be signatories to that warrant. That is something that, on this side of the chamber, we would support.

The other part of the Customs Amendment Bill concerns some minor changes to the anti-dumping legislation. Anti-dumping legislation becomes of less relevance the lower the tariff barriers in a country. In that sense, the importance and urgency of anti-dumping legislation is lessened with the shifts we have seen in recent years. Nevertheless, it is important that the country does have protection against dumping. It is an extraordinarily difficult field from a legislative point of view.

Basically, I spent quite a bit of time looking at this two years ago when I was shadow Minister for customs. I came to the conclusion that the principles we follow in this country are wrong. Here we require proof to be established within Australia that dumping has occurred. Dumping is defined as taking place when the products of one country are exported to another country at less than their normal value in the country of export.

The requirements in Australia are laid down in two stages. Suspicion of dumping has to be established over a period of a number of days first of all, and then we have to actually prove over, I think, 180 days that the goods were sold in Australia at a lower price than in the country of origin. The great difficulty with that is that, first of all, a lot of time is involved and in that time the company, companies or industry being affected by dumping can succumb. The other difficulty is that it costs a great deal of money, and that cost is borne by Australian taxpayers.

I think a preferable approach, where reasonable grounds exist to believe that dumping has taken place, is to require the importer to show that the goods are not being marketed in Australia at a value lower than in the country of origin, and put a prohibition on sales in the Australian community until that takes place. With those comments, I wish the Bills a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak particularly to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, which proposes to implement a number of alterations to the structure of tariffs in Australia. I want to focus on reductions of tariffs on primary products, in particular on sugar, and the ramifications of these reductions for the sugar industry in the State of Queensland, which I represent.

SPEECH.PARA: Other speakers, especially Senator Boswell, have adequately-indeed passionately-explained why we believe it is shameful that the sugar industry has been singled out for particularly harsh treatment. I say this because, along with others, I believe that the industry is entitled to operate in a climate of certainty. With respect to telecommunications, we are told repeatedly by this Government that the foreign second carrier is entitled to operate in a climate of certainty, and much of the legislation was arranged so that that could happen. Why can this not happen in our own sugar industry?

This industry previously had firm undertakings on tariff rates to apply in 1991-92 and 1992-93, pending an inquiry by the Industry Commission. The Government's actions in proposing this Bill presuppose the results of the inquiry and, I believe, are a slap in the face to the Commission. The readjusted rates, introduced without consultation, will cost an estimated $16m in 1991-92 and $11m in 1992-93. Such losses will have grave economic and social impacts on the Australian sugar industry and on Queensland in particular.

If we look at the state of the industry at the moment, we can see that raw sugar prices on the international market are currently at approximately US8.5c a pound, compared with a figure of US16c a pound 15 months ago. The world price of sugar has dropped by a larger percentage than the drop in the wheat price in the last 12 months. That is something that we have all expressed some concern about. The sugar industry suffered from severe crop losses for the 1990 season. Queensland canegrowers expect a further drop in income, conservatively estimated at $200m, from this season's weather-affected crop of 23.93 million tonnes and from lower world prices.

The industry is currently facing a further crisis of confidence from a major takeover bid by the overseas multinational company, Tate and Lyle, with no government guarantees. I, too, would like to speak about that for a moment. Canegrowers, the peak body representing the nation's 6,000 canegrowers, asked for assurances from Tate and Lyle about such things as the future structure of the industry as, indeed, I believe they should. As honourable senators know, under the terms of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act, the Treasurer must be satisfied that the foreign takeover is not contrary to the national interest.

Yet Tate and Lyle is a company with significant sweetener and sugar interests in the United States of America and Europe. It is the European Community in particular which is supporting its primary producers with substantial subsidies. I think it is reasonable to assume that Tate and Lyle's Australian operations would be less profitable than its European beet sugar industries. If Tate and Lyle were to prohibit or regulate competition between its various subsidiaries, this would certainly damage severely Australia's desperate efforts to increase exports. This is quite the opposite of what the Government claims it wants.
On Tuesday, in response to a question from Senator Spindler on this takeover, Senator Button, on behalf of the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), tabled the following answer:

To tighten foreign investment policy across the board would have an adverse effect on the long term direct foreign investment necessary for Australia's future growth and development, the creation of jobs, the restructuring of the economy to make Australia competitive internationally and improved living standards.

I ask, as previous speakers have also asked: how can it possibly be in the national interest to threaten the livelihood of Australia's 6,000 canegrowers and their families, and the provincial cities which rely on primary industries? That is real job creation for you! How can it be in the national interest to approve of a takeover which has the significant potential to decrease, not increase, exports?

This Government's large scale foreign investment, which translates into 40 per cent control of Australia's productive capacity, does not lead to improved living standards as the Government claims it does. Just ask the pensioners and families who can no longer afford to pay property rates on the Gold Coast because of the unfair escalation of property values there as a direct result of speculative foreign investment. Improved living standards for them means having to leave an area in which they chose to live.

The Queensland Labor Government, in another show of window dressing as I have referred to before, expressed its concerns over the proposed takeover, but when the crunch comes what can it do? I think it could more seriously argue with the Treasurer and the Foreign Investment Review Board instead of resorting to its standard response of feigned concern, knowing that in the end the Foreign Investment Review Board will make the ultimate decision. The Federal Treasurer should reverse his decision, as the takeover is quite clearly not in the national interest. But I guess when the Government is desperate because its policies have led to extraordinarily high current account deficits and foreign debt burdens, anything goes.

Senator Macdonald, who has special responsibility for northern Queensland and who lives in a sugar producing area, said in the debate that he will be doing all he can to ensure the best solutions for the sugar industry. He said that he would maintain his close association with the industry to give it a credible voice in the next coalition government. The Australian Democrats are offering Senator Macdonald the opportunity to do both-to ensure the best solution and to maintain his credibility, which I understand is very much at risk here.

The Democrats' solution, by way of request, is to make sure that the tariff arrangements which were set down prior to the industry statement are maintained, so that the industry can continue to operate in that environment of certainty. But Senator Macdonald has adopted the classic stance so loathed by the general public of speaking of his great concern and then refusing to vote to confirm that concern. That is why at all of the rural rallies we have been to in Queensland the rural community has invariably said, `The coalition offers us no hope either. It is just as bad as the Government'. Senator Macdonald's cowardly action in not supporting the Democrats amendment will simply confirm that view. At least the National Party puts its vote where its mouth is.

Senator Macdonald, in his usual Democrats bash, said that this Democrats amendment was a short term political action. He is right. We want to maintain an agreed level of tariff until 1993 so that the longer term process can continue in a way the sugar industry accepts.

Senator Macdonald also said that he could not support any action by such an anti-rural party as the Democrats. This is a weak excuse, and Senator Macdonald would know that. He knows that the canegrowers will not accept it. What is more, he is wrong about the Democrats rural policies, but the coalition continues to vexatiously misquote them.

Despite that, rural people are not believing the Liberals. Deputations to us from rural Australians about Austudy, assistance for isolated children and the level of foreign investment in the beef cattle industry confirm this. Last night, and today, the Democrats have received many telephone calls and faxes from woolgrowers. Let me quote from one or two of them to indicate to Senator Macdonald just how wrong he is. The first fax is from a wool growing family in Western Australia:

Congratulations Democrats. Please continue to `keep the bastards honest'. Rural Australia needs you like no-one has before . . . Rural Australia is crying out for decent representation and you can give it.
The next, received just before lunch, is from the New South Wales Farmers Association. It states in part:

The Association and many woolgrowers are aware that the Democrats, over the last two years, have been the wool industry's most consistent supporters . . . Over the last two years woolgrowers have been fortunate to have the support of the Democrats on a number of important issues. This we very much appreciate . . .
I suggest that it is time for some members of the coalition to change the rhetoric. It is not inconsistent that we should continue our support of primary industry by moving our amendment.

I acknowledge the cooperation of Senator Boswell in this respect. I know that he would like to have moved the amendment himself. Senator MacGibbon's comments regarding it being a lost cause to vote against the tariff changes in the sugar industry are misleading. The Senate may not amend the Bill but it may request the House of Representatives to amend it, and this is precisely what the Democrat amendment provides. The Senate can reject these changes. In this case, I believe that the Liberal Party needs to put the interests of the Australian sugar growers ahead of spurious selective arguments and Democrat bashing and vote to assist these growers by supporting our request.

We must oppose these accelerated reductions in tariffs for sugar because, while the international market remains corrupt and subject to massive interference by all the world's exporters, Australia must have a protection level sufficient to ensure the survival of an `efficient by world standards' regional sugar industry and, by extension, the communities reliant on those industries. Any substantial reduction of tariff levels, as foreshadowed by the March economic statement, will expose canegrowers further to these corrupt practices. At a time of relatively high unemployment, it could be said that other sugar exporting countries are, in effect, exporting unemployment to countries such as Australia.

The Federal Government should abide by its agreement with the industry of tariff levels at $95 from 1 July 1991 and $70 from 1 July 1992, and it should reconsider tariff levels on completion of the current Industry Commission hearing into the sugar industry. In closing, I quote from that interesting article from the Weekend Australian of 15 June headed `A road to recovery from our market-led malaise' by Mr C.D. Kemp, founder and former Director of the Institute of Public Affairs. He said:
Reductions in protection, if persisted with, should proceed cautiously, and the thoroughly absurd objective of eliminating all protection in the near future removed from the national agenda.
With this I concur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: -I thank Senator Kernot for her speech because it sums up much of this debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill and allied Bills. I do not want to talk in this debate at great length about the sugar industry, but let me say that it has been a magnificent example of politicians at work. Senator Kernot wants to do two things: she wants to establish her credentials as a virile Queensland senator and the Australian Democrats' credentials as people who are concerned, caring and beloved of those in the rural sector.

SPEECH.PARA: We see here an alliance-the first of its kind-between the National Party of Australia and the Democrats, provoked by two issues: the unholy Queensland alliance, which is a function of the Senate, if people take the view that it is a States' House, which I do not, as I share the views of Alfred Deakin; and, secondly, the desire of the Democrats to establish their foot in the door of being interested in rural issues as distinct from their normally narrow agenda. So, up in that corner of the chamber, we have the Democrats and the Nationals united together with a group of Queensland Liberal senators, also trying to prove their virility.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they won't vote.

—No, but they are trying also to prove their virility in the interests of the Queensland sugar industry. Senator O'Chee, who is the ideological and spiritual leader of the Democrats on this matter, made this point--
—Please!

—I am sorry, Senator, but you cannot avoid it. It may be uncomfortable, but Senator O'Chee, as a back bench senator for the Nationals-in fact, the back bench senator for the Nationals-made the point that the cost of the sugar industry to downstream industries, which is estimated at being $60m per year because of the price of sugar charged to those downstream industries, was not a matter of importance as this could all be fixed up by an SPC-type industrial relations agreement and we did not have to bother about these imposts and costs imposed on industries provided that we could provide an SPC magic wand.

SPEECH.PARA: All I can say to Senator O'Chee is go and tell SPC or any other food processor in this country that the cost of sugar is not a considerable impost on those industries. That is where the employment is. That is where the potential growth in employment is; it is not in the sugar industry. I understand the arguments that have been put and I understand the reasons. My plea is that this chamber does not sink too far into the pit of parochialism on the basis of the sorts of arguments that have been put here.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's nationalism.

—I am sorry, I do not wish to upset the honourable senator, but somebody once said that the human mind cannot bear too much reality, and I am asking her to bear a little bit. In the course of the 12 March statement, the Government took the view that we should reduce tariffs across the board, and we have done that. The new-found National Farmers Federation agenda in respect of tariff has been adopted by the Liberal Party: the graziers' agenda; the one dictated by the shadow spokesman, who is a very wealthy man and tells people, `I came into politics to fix a few things and if they do not like me or what I do I will go back, because I am a very rich man, thank you very much, to what I was doing before; politics can take me or leave me'. This graziers' agenda, dictated by people such as this for the Liberal Party, which is lacking totally in understanding of Australian industry, and imposed for the time being on the Liberal Party until it finds out a few political and industrial realities, is accepted at the present time by a significant group in the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: What did members of the Liberal Party say in the House of Representatives about the question of tariffs on sugar? They said absolutely nothing. Their spokesman was entirely silent on this issue. All he contributed in the course of debate about these Bills in the House of Representatives was this catchcry that the dumping mechanism should be speeded up.

I will come to that matter in the committee stage, because Senator Bishop parroted the Opposition's spokesman's words in this chamber and we will have to deal with that in the course of time. That is all he said: he talked about speeding up anti-dumping measures and the question of bounty thresholds. That was a great contribution to an industry debate in the House of Representatives from Mr `Squire' McLachlan, behind whom all of these people, such as Senator Olsen, Senator Durack and Senator Parer, follow like sheep, which is what Mr McLachlan has been used to all his life. They are sheep following Mr McLachlan down to the woolshed where he gets rid of all the problems by sacking a few shearers and then he goes back to his mansion.

That is what has happened to the Liberal Party. As we have seen over many years, in the Senate we have the glorious prospect of a coalition with the National Party tail seeking to wag the coalition dog. They have not sorted that problem out yet, and they will never sort it out while they are in coalition with people who say, `Get rid of tariffs, but not for our constituents, thank you'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cabinet ought to be the last sort of people talking about differences of opinion.

—I understand that Senator Olsen is sensitive about what I am saying. What has been said here is, `Get rid of tariffs for everyone except our little group, our constituents. Get rid of them for everyone else except them; protect them and look after them because the international marketplace is a bit tough and we must do something about looking after them'. That is the National Party agenda, and it always has been. If those opposite were ever to form a government they would go back to that agenda because that is what they did during the last seven years they were in government. There was not one per cent reduction in assistance to industry throughout the whole period of the Fraser Government.
—That was wrong.

—Senator Olsen says that it was wrong. When asked whether his Party would do these things if ever elected to government, Mr McLachlan said, `Read my lips', which is what was said by President Reagan. But will it have the guts to deliver that in government? This is the crisis of the coalition. The Liberals can easily mouth these things in opposition, but will they have the guts to do it? On their record in Australian politics to date the answer is no, because they have never done anything about it. When the Nationals start giving them a bit of stick, if they ever get into government, off they will go again with the Nationals to the watering hole. Today this coalition is added to by the Australian Democrats in pursuit of their own grubby little political motives.
—What about the Liberals? Oh, come on.

—That is a very nasty word to use about anyone. The honourable senator who comes from the `keep the bastards honest' Party does not like being described as grubby because that Party is so pure! The Democrats have no political motives at all in relation to any of these matters. It is all directed at purity. I understand that, but that is just not the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: A few matters were mentioned by honourable senators in the course of this debate, particularly amendments to be moved in the committee stage of this legislation, and I will refer to those. First, Senator Bourne of the Australian Democrats raised a couple of queries in relation to the import credit scheme for textile, clothing and footwear industries, which the Democrats have indicated they will support. If Senator Bourne is concerned about those matters, it is probably better for me to deal with them in committee. Senator Olsen, who was in the chamber for a brief time, raised a question about the consultation process that took place in relation to the import credit scheme. If required, that matter can be dealt with in the committee stage.

I should say something about the question of the anti-dumping changes made in the industry statement, because Senator Bishop addressed this question. She made the same speech as that made in the House of Representatives by Mr McLachlan, who said virtually nothing else in relation to these Bills. As for the Opposition's concern about the question of reducing time for dealing with anti-dumping complaints, let me say that the Government is not at all opposed to reducing the time for dealing with anti-dumping complaints. We would like to have them dealt with within a week, if possible, but of course the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) anti-dumping code, with which we comply, requires that after an application is received a decision must be taken to initiate the investigation.

Senator MacGibbon is right when he says that this dumping issue is very complex. I agree with him. When a prima facie case is made out, under the GATT code and in accordance with decisions of the GATT anti-dumping committee, the investigation period must provide all interested parties with at least 30 days to prepare and lodge a submission and they must also be given the right to consider and comment on a submission from any other party. That is what the GATT anti- dumping code requires. So the Opposition's suggestion about reducing that period to 55 days is just impractical. I do not disagree with the spirit of it; it is just impractical. It cannot be done consistently with the GATT anti-dumping code.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be interesting to read the Standing Committee's report tomorrow.

—I have been waiting breathlessly for months for the Senate Standing Committee report on this issue! In fact, the Government said that it would address any further issues required to be addressed following the publication of that report. Let me make the point at this stage that the timeframes in Australia for dealing with these complaints compare favourably with that of other major users of anti-dumping measures, such as the European Community, the United States and Canada. As I have said, I concede that this is an extraordinarily complex and difficult issue, but the spirit of the GATT code is to ensure that people, whether they be importers or producers, get a fair go in the process. The provision of a fair go is not always consistent with the greatest possible alacrity, which we all might desire.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally speaking, there has been a wide range of discussions in the course of this debate. I have listened avidly to everything that has been said, and I thank the Senate for its consideration of these Bills. During the committee stage there will be an opportunity to deal with these issues at greater length.

I now want to look at the second reading amendments. I read them once before and thought there was not much substance in them. However, I thought I should come back to them because some of them arrived as late as today. I have referred to the question of the time taken for dealing with dumping complaints. An amendment has been moved on behalf the Opposition about which I will say a couple of words. The woolshed agenda is tied up in the Opposition's amendment. It says that the Government has broken commitments by failing to promote full and effective competition in telecommunications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about your waterfront achievements.

—That means that the Opposition disagrees with us. I think the achievements at this stage must be described as modest. I make the point that coalition governments had none at all. They had no achievements at all in respect of the waterfront. The waterfront did not matter at all to coalition high tariff governments. The waterfront was not an issue; the labour market was not an issue. Malcolm Fraser and his merry men gave tariffs to anybody who asked for them.
—Get on to our agenda today.
—The honourable senator wants me to get on to the Opposition's agenda but he does not want me to get on to the Opposition's performance.
—Today and tomorrow, not yesterday.

—I understand the born-again Liberal Senator Olsen-born again with Ian McLachlan, who is his messiah. I understand that-the honourable senator comes from South Australia. They say in the honourable senator's State that one can always tell a McLachlan but that one cannot tell them anything.
—I thought he was a Victorian.
—Perhaps Senator Parer finds that a bit offensive. I do not think anybody would ever say that about him.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that the woolshed agenda is being put forward. That is fair enough-that is a matter for legitimate political debate. But this born-again party alleges that we are failing to reduce all protection to all industries. Put that in your pipe and smoke it, Senator Boswell. Senator Olsen will vote for a recommendation which accuses us of failing to reduce all protection for all industries. Think of the pineapples, think of the bananas, think of the sugar--

TALK.START.PARA: —Coupled with micro-economic reform.

—The other day I referred to my good friend, Jeff Kennett, as a boofhead. The honourable senator should not join him by making boofhead interjections about this issue. The honourable senator starts to bleat about micro-economic reform. For God's sake, Senator! I love the story that is told about the Kodak bounty. The Opposition spokesman went off to Kodak and said, `You don't need a bounty; what you need is micro-economic reform-you need better shipping, better waterfront reform'. The Kodak people said, `Really? That is a bit of a shock to us. We never use the waterfront. We have never used the waterfront since we have been in Australia. We fly all of our exports out of this country'.
—You said the only reason they got the money was because of the electorate.
—Come on-do not be silly. I decided that; it had nothing to do with it.
—You should be ashamed of yourself.

—I am not ashamed of myself. Why should I be ashamed of myself on the basis of an accusation from Senator Boswell-a person who comes in here day after day pork-barrelling with his brown paper bags in his pockets. Senator O'Chee came in here today and made a speech in which he accused Labor Party politicians of corruption when I think there are six politicians from his side of politics in gaol at present.
—It's only five.
—It is only five, is it-I am sorry; I beg your pardon. I apologise, Senator-maybe it will be six soon. It is ridiculous that Senator O'Chee should come in here and make those sorts of speeches.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment moved by the Australian Democrats says that the Government is obsessed with ideologically based commitment to deregulation and competition; that the legislation is contrary to the public interest; that the Government is pursuing a foreign investment policy against the long term interests of Australia et cetera. There are some figures which, however unpalatable to the Opposition or the Democrats, I want to give to the Senate again. Prior to the recession, for which this Government has to accept a high degree of responsibility-not the recession in the rural areas; not--

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got it; you wear it.
—I know, Senator.
—It's your recession. You wanted it. You got the recession; you worked for it. It is about the only successful thing you have done. You brought on a recession.

—I am not running away from that. The honourable senator always runs away from brown paper bags; I am not running away from that. Before Senator Boswell interrupted-and I know that he is more eloquent than I am and that perhaps he can put what I want to say better-I was saying that this is a recession for which this Government has to accept a high degree of responsibility, and does. But prior to the recession, in the March quarter of 1990, in spite of the commitments which the Democrats amendment refers to, this country produced more goods and services in the manufacturing and service sectors than ever before in our history. This also applied to the last quarter of 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no good coming in here and saying that the sort of environment created by the Government has led to all of the sorts of results which the Democrats like to list. Governments in this country presided for years over declining manufacturing employment. There were no exports from the manufacturing sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —It hasn't changed.
—Well, Senator, listen to the facts. By 1990 employment in manufacturing in this country had grown from 1985 by 88,000 people. That is not a huge number but it is the first time that it had grown.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make the further point that every year, year after year since 1985, exports of manufactured goods have increased by at least 10 per cent a year, and that is still happening. They are undeniable facts. It is all very well to have all of this spooky stuff about the Government not being concerned about these issues. We are. I am implicitly asked to acknowledge in Question Time day after day, `Aren't we doing the wrong thing by allowing foreign investors to come to Australia, a country which is very short on capital?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only on our terms. We need new investment on our terms. You don't have any criteria.

—We have to ask this question about foreign investors: who sells them what they buy? Australians sell them what they buy. The honourable senator can talk about foreign investors at Surfers Paradise, on the Gold Coast, and all that stuff. But who sells it to them? The answer is that Australians sell it to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Who can sell the Bundaberg Sugar Co. Ltd to Tate and Lyle? The shareholders of Bundaberg Sugar are the people who can make the decision to sell the company.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government had a role. You had a role in getting some guarantee.

—I think the honourable senator put a good argument for the shareholders of Bundaberg sugar not to make that sale. But I do not think she put a good argument in respect of foreign investment generally. I hold no brief for Tate and Lyle. My sister once used to work as a nanny for one of those Tates in London. She did not get a very good trot from them and I do not think anyone else might either.
—It is probably exactly the same as the sugarcane growers got-a pretty rough trot!

—I see, Senator. I say to Senator Boswell: keep up the good work. He has a big clash in his head with all the people who sit here and follow the woolshed agenda at the present time. They will change when they realise that it is not working as it ought to. I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate, silly as some of them have been. I commend the legislation to the Senate.

—by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. At the very beginning of Senator Button's summing up, he referred to me as `virile'. The Macquarie Dictionary defines virile as `having a marked degree of masculine strength' or `characterised by a vigorous masculine spirit'. I know that I may have failings, which do not include being grubby, but I am not virile; nor do I wish to be. I prefer to be considered something closer to the original Latin of, perhaps, `having life'.
—I apologise to Senator Kernot. I think she is a very attractive woman. I withdraw the word `virile'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I also claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Button claimed that I was the spiritual leader of the Australian Democrats. At times they may follow my ideology, but I doubt that even the Democrats could have the spirited concern for the rural industries that we in the National Party of Australia have.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Olsen's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill epitomises the Government's failure to deliver an economic environment which would allow a revitalisation of Australian industry, in particular because it:
(a) is obsessed with an ideologically based commitment to deregulation and competition in circumstances which are contrary to the public interest;
(b) is pursuing a foreign investment policy against the long-term interests of Australia; and

(c) fails to strengthen the existing anti-dumping procedures to allow Australian producers adequate defence against dumped and subsidised imports at a time when domestic protection is being phased out''.
I thank Senator Button for his eloquence. However, he has not swayed us from moving our amendment.
Amendment negatived.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill be now read a second time.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is that Senator Bishop's amendment to the Customs Amendment Bill be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question now is that the Customs Amendment Bill be read a second time.

INTERJECT.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question now is that the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 be read a second time.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1991
Clauses 1-12-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Schedules 1-7-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —During my speech in the second reading debate, I drew the Senate's attention to the guidelines for the various textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) programs, particularly the import credit scheme, and to the fact that the criteria for these guidelines had been circulated on a somewhat selective basis to certain companies. This had been drawn to our attention when some concern was expressed at this particular practice, which I would not have thought was normal government practice.

SPEECH.PARA: We are seeking an explanation from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) as to why, in this instance, the draft guidelines should be given to only selected companies to comment on, because that might create an advantage for those companies in due course. Those companies may have had the capacity to be able to influence the guidelines so that in due course they might be making some application to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce under the TCF import credit scheme. Therefore, I specifically ask the Minister: who was responsible for the decision that the draft guidelines should be selectively canvassed? Was that a direction from the Minister or was it taken solely by the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The assumptions underlying that question are not quite correct. The industry has a representative association which is the peak textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) industry association. The draft guidelines were sent to all the associations that represent the companies in their dealings with governments. They were sent to unions, general employer associations and some selected companies which are major exporters of TCF items. They were sent to the representative bodies of all companies and to the major companies which are, in fact, exporters as well.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an industry involving many small firms which are totally domestic in their orientation. The main intention of the distribution was to seek timely and quick comment from the industry and to facilitate the introduction of the scheme on 1 July 1991. That was the desired objective. We were trying to cover a cross-section of the information on value adding and export in the industry. During this consultation process not only were the draft guidelines sent out but also officers of the Authority, the Australian Customs Service and the Department were made available to discuss the proposed import credit scheme.

If Senator Olsen's question is based on a company saying that it did not get a copy of the guidelines, I can understand that that is a possibility, but the problem should have been rectified by the industry association of which that company is likely to be a member.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Government decided to abandon the convention of exposing administrative guidelines for public comment prior to implementation? Following up the answer just given by the Minister, I recognise that the various associations would have large and small firms as members, but did the number of companies that might have been selected to comment on the guidelines include large and small companies?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe so. They were export companies. There are some small export companies and some large export companies, but they were companies in the export business. Senator Olsen referred to abandoning the convention of publishing guidelines for public comment. With respect, there is no such convention in relation to guidelines of this kind.
—Will the guidelines eventually be gazetted as regulations and be subject to parliamentary scrutiny?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The guidelines will be published under the provisions of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority and they will be disallowable instruments.

SPEECH.PARA: Schedules agreed to.
Schedule 8.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Schedule 8, pages 60 and 61, proposed amendments of Schedule 3 of the principal Act, omit amendments 7 to 12.

The effect of this amendment is to maintain the level of tariffs at the pre-industry statement level. As I and other speakers have canvassed in our contributions to the debate, we think that it is imperative that the sugar industry be allowed to continue to operate in a climate of certainty. We think it is unfair to change the rules without consultation. We think it is discriminatory to single out the sugar industry in this way before the findings of the Industry Commission report into sugar are made known. As the Government persists with its dismantling of all tariffs I think, in all fairness, that it should do it in a way that the industry understands and accepts. I take this last opportunity to appeal especially to those Queensland Liberal senators who have spoken in this debate with some passion and concern, to put their vote where their mouths have been in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this amendment. In fact, it was my intention to move an amendment in exactly the same terms as this Democrat amendment. I support the amendment for the reason that a commitment was given by this Parliament that certain tariff levels would continue until 1992. The tariff agreed upon by this Parliament was $95 a tonne, reducing to $75 a tonne as from 1 July 1991, and then from $70 a tonne down to $55 a tonne after 1 July 1992. The other commitment that was given was that the tariff levels would then be the subject of an Industry Commission inquiry. Unilaterally, without any consultation with the industry, the Government moved for the reduction in tariffs.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for Senator Button to wax eloquently and say that farmers do not need protection and that, under the present Government, exports have expanded, but maybe Senator Button can answer this question: how does he expect the Australian sugar growers to compete on the world market when every other sugar cane growing country in the world has a domestic price? For the Economic Community it is $551 a tonne; Thailand, $447 a tonne; and the United States of America, $357 a tonne. Yet, Senator Button came in here some months ago and said that Australian sugar growers had excess protection under world tariffs.

That is simply not true. It opens up the question of how Australian rural producers can maintain productivity when the rest of the world is so heavily subsidising commodities that the world price is reduced, by corruption, and that world price then becomes the Australian domestic price.

Senator Button is asking Australian producers to accept the world price of $230 a tonne with a 21 per cent subsidy, when the rest of the world has subsidies of over 100 per cent in some cases. It is just not practical to expect our farmers to stay in there, when all the other sugar growing countries are subsidising their farmers through various means, whether they be export subsidies or production subsidies. The price on the world market is falling and has fallen to $230 a tonne and yet our industries are expected to take that price while the rest of the world has a domestic price. The sugar cane growers are prepared to accept that. Reluctantly, they were prepared to accept the terms and conditions of the parliamentary inquiry and then take their arguments and concerns to the Industry Commission inquiry.

That was the commitment that Senator Button gave-in fact, it was given by everyone in the Parliament when the legislation was passed. It was a commitment that Mr Kerin gave on behalf of the Government. When Mr Kerin was the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy he gave that commitment to the sugar cane growers, and yet Senator Button comes in here today and pulls the rug right out from under them. On the world scene the price has fallen from 14c a pound to 8c a pound, mainly due to the corruption of world prices. Yet the Minister expects canegrowers to be able to compete against the rest of the world, when the rest of the world is subsidising their sugar cane growers. I do not believe that we have any alternative other than to support the Democrats amendment, because it relates to a commitment that was given by this Parliament and by every party in the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that I had said all that I possibly could about sugar, but there are a couple of other points which I would like to make. Senator Boswell has to work out where his argument carries him. He says that everybody gave commitments here. What happened? He knows the truth about what happened. Members of the National Party of Australia pulled members of the Liberal Party of Australia by the nose on this issue, as they have always done and will do again. It pulled them by the nose into this arrangement a few years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell is not fair dinkum. If, as he says, the assistance level offered to the sugar industry is 21 per cent in Australia, and it is 100 per cent in the rest of the world, he has not been doing his job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two hundred per cent; 214 per cent in the EEC.

—If it is 200 per cent, Senator Boswell has not been doing his job; he has fallen down 179 per cent on his job. It is no good coming in here and arguing for a retention of existing levels of assistance in an international market which is subsidised to the extent that he claims when those levels fall far short of the levels in the rest of the world. The logic of his argument is that the level of assistance for the Australian sugar industry should be going up-not staying where it is now-to follow the rest of the world. That is the logic of Senator Boswell's argument.
—Well said!

—The bleeding hearts of the Australian Democrats! Senator Kernot tells us about 6,000 canegrowers in Queensland. These people come in here to `keep the bastards honest'; they are the conscience of the soul of the Australian community. What word has been uttered by the Australian Democrats about an urban industry which they ought to know about-the textile, clothing and footwear industry-that employs 100,000 people? There has not been a bleat from any of the Democrats about the changes in the tariff regime for the textile, clothing and footwear industry. We have not heard a word from them. They come in here talking about sugar farmers. For goodness sake; I have never heard such humbug from these people.
—I hope you will withdraw that tomorrow when you see Hansard.

—No, no-the passion with which Senator Kernot spoke about this issue, yet she did not see it in this setting. I also have to say to Senator Boswell that tariffs are about protecting a domestic industry. He agrees with that, I am sure. Export subsidies and production subsidies are essentially about export industries, which I concede can be damaging to Australian industry in the world market scene; there is no doubt about that. However, he has to consider what the mechanisms ought to be if he wants to achieve the result which he claims he wants to achieve. You say that the sugar industry is a great export industry. What you are arguing for is protection of a domestic industry, which is not the best way to go, if I might be so polite to say. It is not for me to devise arguments for the National Party; I have enough trouble doing what I am doing now.
—Senator Button, do not resist the temptation to address your remarks through the Chair from time to time, if you do not mind.
—I understand your status and the importance which you attach to it, the dignity of the Chair and the way you carry it out; I will do that in future.
—You disguise that very well, Senator Button.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must rise to defend Senator Boswell in this unsolicited attack.
—He is not that desperate; sit down!

—No, he is not desperate at all; but the canegrowers are, in the light of what is being offered here. I thought that somebody who is as interested in the sugar industry as Senator Button would have known that it is the efficiency, the productive capacity and the good performance of Australia's canegrowers which has made them competitive at the tariff level of 21 per cent and not the need for the sorts of subsidies that are needed internationally. I thought that Senator Button would have been the first to congratulate our efficient producers in that regard. They do not need the tariff levels that Senator Button was suggesting they might be insulted by. The subsidies that are needed are those which applied before the industry statement. That is all that is being asked for; that is what would satisfy the canegrowers and that is what they are capable of competing with internationally.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the slight that the Australian Democrats had not made any contribution on behalf of any of the other domestic producers, I would have thought that somebody who was interested in this area-the Minister-would have been interested enough to pay attention to the contribution by Senator Bourne in this place. He will find in her contribution considerable reference to another example, the textile, clothing and footwear industry. That is not something which has gained the Democrats' interest only recently. In fact, an examination of our policies would reveal to Senator Button that we are prepared to support any Australian domestic industry with tariffs and subsidies or whatever else to enable those industries which are environmentally sound, sustainable and useful to Australian society-in a number of definitions-to compete with any other industries which are either subsidised or able to compete with our industries internationally.

One thing that should not have escaped Senator Button's attention is the reference that the Democrats have made over the past several months to the sorts of exploitative practices which are engaged in overseas. These practices bring to the shores of this country products which have been produced by exploited workers, people who do not work for award wages, and products which do not provide fair competition. They may provide what Senator Button calls a level playing field, but they do not provide a fair playing field of competition. I stress to honourable senators such as Senator Macdonald that our policy and our actions in this place support those who contribute to Australia's welfare and Australia's future. I see the canegrowers as playing a very important part in Australia's future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I was not listening to the second reading debate. I happened to be attending a meeting in which we discussed the European Economic Community's common agricultural policy, which of course is one of our problems. I understand from what I have been told that the debate has not always been sweetness and light on this question of assistance to the sugar industry.
—It is going to be artificial sweeteners.

—I will acknowledge that interjection by Senator Kernot. It has been put to me rather forcefully that this Parliament had made it perfectly clear that the subsidy arrangements would apply until 1992. The contributions of Senator Kernot, Senator Boswell and Senator Bell have been influencing me to vote for this amendment. But I ask the Minister: what has motivated the Government to undo this arrangement, this commitment, a year earlier? Why not deal with this question in 1992? The canegrowers understood that they would be safe with subsidies until 1992. Why do it in 1991? Why not attack the problem in 1992, by which time the Industry Commission would have made its recommendations? Thus the Government would have honoured the undertaking given by this Parliament, as Senator Boswell said. Why now and not 1992?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I echo Senator Harradine's question. It also puzzles me why the Government has decided to make these changes ahead of the scheduled time-ahead of the date on which the Industry Commission is to make its report. I query what value there is in it. Senator Button always talks about people on this side being action-men and he-men. I suppose Senator Button must be the he-man doll of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button made certain comments about Senator Boswell. He said that Senator Boswell failed by 179 per cent. It is not Senator Boswell who fails by 179 per cent. It is, of course, Senator Button's colleagues who fail by 179 per cent. Senator Button and his colleagues have had eight years to do something about reducing the world level of subsidy and tariff protection. If anybody can do it in the Government, I am sure that Senator Button can, but it is a little absurd to expect Senator Boswell who sits on the Opposition benches to be able to reduce the tariffs. The real question is why Senator Button's side of the chamber has not done something about the level of international tariffs. That is the crux of the matter, not what Senator Boswell has done.

In his second reading speech Senator Button said that it was appropriate that we do something about the cost of processing industries. But when will Senator Button, as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, do something about the really hard issues? When will he get stuck into the hard issue of industrial relations reform? He dismisses the matter as an SPC magic wand, but Senator Button has yet to grab the magic wand in his hand and give it a try. He likes waving the magic words around, but let us see him try to grab the magic wand and run with it for a little while.

This Government cannot make any comment about improving industry while it fails to attack the key area of industrial relations reform. My point is that we will be quite happy to see some reductions in tariffs at the same time that Senator Button attacks the area of biggest inefficiency in Australian industry at the moment, namely, its shoddy, poor, lackadaisical industrial relations policy. I and many other senators on this side of the Committee would expect Senator Button, as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, to have some sort of input. I am sure Senator Button would not tell me that he has no input. We value his contributions to the Government much more highly than that. But we want to know why nothing has been done about that area either.
Question put:
That the request (Senator Kernot's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move that the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:

We also acknowledge that, as the amendment relates to the motor vehicle industry, the Industry Commission has put a point of view in that regard. We take the view that it would be too disruptive to dismantle the import credit scheme or precipitation scheme as it relates to the motor vehicle industry. In this instance, we do not believe it is appropriate, hence the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Schedule, page 3, proposed amendments of the Bounty and Capitalisation Grants (Textile Yarns) Act 1981, omit proposed subsection 5(5A).
2. Schedule, page 4, proposed amendments of the Bounty (Bed Sheeting) Act 1977, omit proposed subsection 5(3A).

Once again, I canvassed at length in the second reading debate the reasons why we would be moving these amendments in the Committee of the Whole. Given the hour, I will not canvass those in detail except to say once again that we believe the measures proposed by the Government discriminate against small business operators. We do not believe that is an appropriate, fair or reasonable position. We believe that everyone in the marketplace ought to be treated fairly and equitably and that we should not have a provision that discriminates against small operators and manufacturers in this country. Principally, that is the reason for the amendments being moved. As I said, in the second reading debate I canvassed in detail the reasons and rationale behind the amendments being proposed this day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say on behalf of the Australian Democrats that we will be supporting these amendments for the reasons that I delineated in my second reading contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay honourable senators about these amendments. The Australian Democrats and the Opposition are united on them. However, there are two observations I would make about them. First of all, the administrative arrangements are costly in terms of paying small amounts of bounty to a whole number of recipients. I have been in places where people who are not serious operators have almost complained about getting a form from Customs saying that they are eligible for a bounty and that they should fill it in and send it back.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened here was that members of the book industry made some complaints about this bounty threshold issue. They were quite justified in their complaints and the Government accepted their view. But it is another matter to take that view and apply it to a whole lot of industries such as the machine tool industry. The argument is essentially about new entrants to an industry. I understand that; it is a sensible enough argument. We do not want to choke off new entrants. But if any of these industries which have a level of technological sophistication and capital equipment requirements and so on are to do anything successfully, a $200,000 threshold, as would apply here, is not serious because we are talking about small milk bar proportions.

They are the Government's arguments. I do not want to delay the Committee because these amendments will be carried. We have lived without bounty thresholds of this kind for a long time and we can live without them again. In an administrative sense they are difficult and wasteful of the time of people who might otherwise be employed in more productive efforts.
