DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991THERAPEUTIC GOODS (CHARGES) AMENDMENT BILL 1991HEALTH LEGISLATION (PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it absolutely outrageous that we are about to debate a Bill and there is no Minister, no member of the Government, no Whip-nobody here in this chamber when I am about to speak. (Quorum formed)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 June, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.
Motion (by Senator McMullan)-by leave-agreed to:

That the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill 1991 and the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991 may be taken together for their remaining stages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first Bill in this allied debate is the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. This Bill amends the Health Insurance Act, the National Health Act, the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act and the Therapeutic Goods Act. The amendments to the Health Insurance Act and the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act seek to make more information about nursing homes publicly available.

SPEECH.PARA: Three further categories of information will be released directly to the public. First, there are plans submitted by proprietors of actions to be taken to satisfy standards. The majority of nursing homes have no problem with this provision because quality care is, and always has been, their objective. However, it is unfortunate that the structure of funding has placed undue stress on nursing home proprietors and staff.

The other categories of information to be released include the basic descriptive information concerning each nursing home, such as its name, address, number of beds, fees charged and the action taken or intended to be taken to suspend or revoke the approval of a nursing home, vary the conditions of its approval, cease benefits for new admissions or remove its exempt status. I seek assurance from the Government that appropriate appeal mechanisms are available, in the first instance, to a proprietor who is not satisfied with the information supplied about the nursing home and, in the second case, prior to the publication of other information about ministerial action and other information about the nursing home.

The coalition supports the technical amendments made to the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act. There are a number of minor amendments to the Health Insurance Act, and the coalition supports these. One of the amendments closes a loophole which has recently been exploited by some medical practitioners. Accounts and Medicare benefits will only be claimable for a service where a physical attendance on a patient occurs and a clinically relevant service takes place. The Bill will also require the proprietor of a pathology laboratory, the approval for which has been revoked, to take a number of steps to advertise that fact.

Part 5 of the Bill makes a number of amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. One of the noteworthy amendments is to the administration of the individual patient usage (IPU) scheme. This scheme has been in operation for 10 years and covers situations where drugs which may be beneficial to a patient but which are not marketed in Australia are to be used following approval under the IPU scheme. The legislation will decentralise the process and allow individual medical officers to undertake the same decisions as the current therapeutic goods administration officer in Canberra. This should mean a speedier process for all involved.

Although the coalition supports this proposal, it does not believe it reaches the heart of the problem-and that is the Government's inability to restructure adequately our drug approval process. Given the number of reports undertaken over the years, we can only hope that the Baume inquiry is fruitful and that some action is taken. The coalition supports the other changes to the Therapeutic Goods Act, which will lead to an overall decrease in bureaucracy associated with the procedures.

The second Bill we are debating is the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill. The amendments to this Bill relate mainly to reservations expressed by the coalition and the Australian Democrats at the time of the passage of the Therapeutic Goods Act. The Minister responsible for the legislation might remember-if he were here, that is-the concerns that were expressed. Basically, they relate to the grouping of therapeutic goods together where they share common characteristics or where they share both common characteristics and a common manufacturer. I conclude my remarks on this Bill, given the time constraint, and just indicate that the coalition supports it.

The Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill seeks to make three major changes to the administration of the pharmaceutical benefits program. First, it seeks to restrict eligibility for drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits program to Australian residents. Secondly, it seeks to implement a pseudo voluntary pharmaceutical eligibility checking mechanism by installing an on-line dedicated computer link between the Health Insurance Commission and pharmacies. Thirdly, it seeks to make it compulsory for pharmacists to make their claims for payment under the pharmaceutical benefits program through the computerised claims transmission system, which is already used by approximately 80 per cent of pharmacists.

I will speak about each of these initiatives in turn, but I will concentrate on the eligibility checking mechanisms because of their intrusive and universal nature as well as the considerable doubt that exists about the savings the Government envisages will be derived from them. Firstly, I speak with respect to restricting the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) to Australian residents. The coalition supports the Government's proposal to restrict eligibility for the pharmaceutical benefits program to Australian residents. It brings the program into line with the Medicare program, and it quite rightly prevents illegal migrants and visitors from receiving concessionary pharmaceuticals.

The Government considers that $6m will be saved by restricting concessionary access to Australian residents. When questioned in the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, the Health Insurance Commission claimed that this estimate was based on an assumption that there are about 200,000 non-residents in the country at a given time and that these non-residents are half as likely as residents to access the pharmaceutical benefits program.

As was stated in the minority report of the coalition senators, which was tabled in the Senate yesterday, we consider financial estimates which are based on assumptions like these to be entirely inappropriate. The importance of this matter should not be understated because all Australian residents can be asked to provide identification to their pharmacists in order to prevent the system from being rorted by non-residents.

Another major concern the coalition had, relating to this part of the Bill as well as to the pharmaceutical eligibility checking proposal, was the Government's attempt to try to force pharmacists to charge a Commonwealth price when dispensing pharmaceuticals to non-residents and any other people who are not entitled to concessions under the pharmaceutical benefits program-that is, people who cannot get their identity confirmed by the Commission.

We are pleased that the Government has foreshadowed an amendment that acknowledges that this is a private transaction between the pharmacist and the client and that it should not be determined by the Government. The coalition will be supporting the Government's amendment, which eliminates the price control implications of this section of the Bill.

With respect to pharmaceutical eligibility checking, the Government announced in November 1989 its black box proposal whereby each pharmacist's computer would be used to check pharmaceutical entitlement by way of a computerised link with the Health Insurance Commission. The then Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Blewett, rejected the proposal during the election campaign as a result of criticisms from the Privacy Commissioner and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia.

This proposal is an amended version of the black box proposal. The major differences are: first, the latest initiative entails a dedicated computer facility which will be kept separate from the pharmacist's computer-that is, if the pharmacist decides so; there is a possibility that the pharmacist may link it with the special facility. Secondly, guidelines will be issued by the Privacy Commissioner governing the conduct of pharmacists and the Health Insurance Commission.

In terms of alleviating the privacy concerns, these are marked improvements to the original failed proposal. However, this is a highly intrusive and universal system. Potentially, every Australian will be subjected to an identity check every time he or she makes a claim on a pharmaceutical benefits program. In the case of social security and veterans affairs recipients, this will entail the pharmacist receiving a confirmation of their concessionary entitlement from the Health Insurance Commission. The Commission will receive up-to-date benefit information from these departments which it will use during the confirmation process. In the case of all other Australians, their identity will be checked with information held by the Health Insurance Commission. Although the Government claims that the system is voluntary, pharmacists run the risk of not having a claim honoured by the Commission unless the client's identity has been confirmed by the Commission when the script is dispensed by the pharmacist.

With such an intrusive system being applied to all Australians, it is imperative to have guidelines which protect the rights of individual users. The Government has recognised this, and pharmaceutical benefits guidelines have been drafted by the Privacy Commissioner. However, the Government has not gone far enough. Every Australian will be affected by this proposal. All Australians will run the risk of having their PBS entitlement rejected if they cannot provide adequate information. All pharmacists risk having claims for payment rejected if they do not obtain confirmation of identity. Pensioners, the unemployed, invalids, the poor and the sick risk having to pay the full price of pharmaceuticals if they cannot provide adequate identification to their pharmacist.

When a system places responsibilities of this nature on individuals and pharmacists, the users must have every confidence that they can seek redress if they feel that they have been unfairly treated by the system. It is not sufficient to simply hope and trust that no-one will be unfairly disadvantaged by the system. The guidelines must have legal status. They must also be subject to proper scrutiny by the Parliament which represents the 16 million-odd Australians who will be affected by the Government's initiative.

The Government claims that it will not implement the eligibility checking proposals until the Privacy Commissioner's guidelines have been finalised, and nor should it. However, the coalition will be moving an amendment to ensure that this does not happen. Rather than a Minister asking the Privacy Commissioner to devise guidelines, we will make it a legal requirement to have such guidelines. We will seek to make these guidelines disallowable instruments, thus ensuring that they are subjected to the proper scrutiny that such a far-reaching proposal deserves.

We will also ensure that any breach of the guidelines is considered to be a breach of the Privacy Act. This means that the Privacy Commissioner will have the power to investigate any complaints he receives about an action that is in breach of the guidelines. Without all these amendments, the guidelines would be largely ineffective in upholding the rights of individual Australians.

The coalition's other major concern about the pharmaceutical eligibility checking proposal relates to the Government's failure to provide an accurate breakdown of the savings that will be derived from this initiative. In the minority report, coalition senators concluded:
In light of the evidence presented to the Committee, it is impossible to assess the cost and/or the benefits of the Government's pharmaceutical eligibility checking initiative.
Further on, the report states:
The Opposition members of the Committee are confident that the net financial initiative from the Bill will be considerably smaller than that estimated by the Government.

The Government has cited two surveys, one by the Auditor-General and one by the Health Insurance Commission, as evidence of the need to introduce computerised eligibility checking. One of these surveys claimed that the non-entitlement rate was 5.22 per cent, whilst the other claimed that it was between 2.5 per cent and 4.5 per cent. Those who have expressed doubts about the accuracy of these surveys include the Health Insurance Commission, the Auditor-General, the Pharmacy Guild as well as the coalition parties. The Government has simply taken 4.5 per cent as a happy medium between these two surveys and calculated that this non-entitlement rate will result in $40m in gross savings.

The doubt about the accuracy of the costings and the amount of untested assumptions contained within them may be best summed up by the Minister's representative in the Senate when addressing the Committee this week. He stated:

As to the exact order of these, you would need to have a look at them in a more sophisticated way than simply saying `$40m'. I think that is what this Committee has done. Nevertheless, there are savings available and, for that reason, the Government believes the system is justified.

Unfortunately for us, but maybe fortunately for the Government, it will probably be impossible to check the accuracy of the Government's savings estimates. But that is to be examined because these savings will be subsumed in general savings in the cost of administering the pharmaceutical benefits program as a result of the range of changes announced in the last Budget, including the $2.50 price indicator.

Presently, 80 per cent of pharmacists make their claims upon the Health Insurance Commission by way of a computerised link which is known as the claims transmission system (CTS). This Bill seeks to make it compulsory for all pharmacists to submit their payment claims through the CTS. However, the Secretary will be given the power to exempt pharmacists such as those serving isolated areas from submitting their claims through the CTS. In the explanatory memorandum it is stated that the move to compulsory CTS will result in savings of $6m.

During prior questioning in the Senate Estimates committee hearings, the Health Insurance Commission claimed that $6m would be saved by all pharmacists making their claims through the CTS. As 80 per cent have complied voluntarily, it is misleading for the Government to claim that $6m will be saved from introducing a compulsory CTS. It is far closer to the truth that the 20 per cent remaining non-complying pharmacists will realise savings in the order of $1.2m for the Government.

The coalition has no qualms with the computerised system per se. However, we are concerned that the rules governing the conduct of the CTS are properly scrutinised, and that there are appropriate avenues of review and appeals for pharmacists. Until the introduction of this Bill, rules governing the CTS were laid down by a delegated representative of the Minister in a determination under section 98C (1) (b) of the National Health Act. Unfettered powers contained in this determination include being able to disqualify a person from using the CTS indefinitely without reason and without any avenue of appeal. Independent in-house legal opinion expressed grave concern about these unfettered powers and, in addition, external legal opinion also expressed doubt about these powers being included in a determination that did not require tabling or disallowance.

I have expressed these concerns a number of times in the Senate. I am pleased to say that the Government has taken heed of these expressions of concern and has introduced new sections 99AAA to 99AAC into the National Health Act. Under these new sections, the Minister will make the rules governing the conduct of the CTS. These rules will be disallowable instruments, and there will be avenues of appeal for pharmacists. However, the unfettered powers contained in section 98C (1) (b) remain. Even though the Government has given a commitment to use section 99 to make rules governing the CTS, there is nothing to stop the Minister or a delegate of the Minister from still relying on section 98C (1) (b).

The offending section cannot be removed from the Act as it is also used for other quite legitimate purposes. However, to prevent any future unscrutinised use of section 98C (1) (b), the coalition will move an amendment which will make determinations made under this section disallowable instruments.

As I have stated throughout this speech-and as was expressed in the minority report of the Finance and Public Administration Committee-the coalition is concerned about the lack of adequate information that has been provided to allow a properly informed debate about these proposals. We will support the Bill because we believe it goes some way towards preventing people who are not eligible under the pharmaceutical benefits program from rorting the system. However, we are not at all convinced that no other methods could have been used to achieve similar, if not better, results. On behalf of the coalition, I move the following second reading amendment:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate expresses its concern that the Government has failed to provide adequate figures to allow an informed assessment of the costs incurred and the benefits derived from:
(a) the restriction of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Program entitlement to Australian residents;
(b) the introduction of an on-line pharmaceutical eligibility checking proposal; and
(c) the implementation of a compulsory Claims Transmission System''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill 1991 and the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991. I begin by looking at the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. This Bill has a number of purposes and amends a number of Acts. It is supported by the Australian Democrats. Therefore, I will not go through it in great detail. However, I want to look at the main changes.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to Medicare clarify a requirement that medical practitioners cannot claim under Medicare where they merely physically attend a patient but provide no clinically relevant service, such as a medical examination or a diagnostic test. There will also be a requirement for the proprietor of a pathology laboratory to take all reasonable steps to inform the providing practitioner and the patient that Medicare will not be payable where the approval of the laboratory has been revoked by the National Pathology Accreditation Advisory Commission. Failure to make such a disclosure will be an offence. We support these provisions.

The Bill also makes a number of amendments to legislation covering nursing homes. The main amendments include the overriding of secrecy provisions in the National Health Act to enable the Minister to release information to the public about nursing homes. This information will include nursing homes' action plans which apply to homes which do not meet prescribed standards of care; basic facts such as the number of beds, the fees charged and general descriptive information about the nursing homes; and information about any action that is to be taken to suspend or revoke a nursing home's approval or to vary the conditions of the home's approval. Proprietors will have 30 days in which to request a review of the decision to release information unless, of course, release is urgently required to protect the welfare of residents.

I know that some concern has been expressed about the breadth of these provisions, but it is desirable that potential residents and their families are well aware of the home which they may look at moving into and that, therefore, they have access to this type of information. Despite the efforts of the Government and of the vast majority of nursing homes, unfortunately we cannot hide the fact that there are still a few homes where serious problems arise. The public has the right to be aware of these problems.

The Bill also provides for an additional sanction to be used when a nursing home has breached one or more conditions of its approval. Currently, the only available sanctions are suspension or revoking of approval. The amendments will enable the Commonwealth to stop paying benefits for new admissions to the nursing home after the making of the determination that conditions have been breached. These measures are part of a number of steps to improve the quality of nursing home care and to ensure that the rights of residents are paramount.

This is one area where the Government, particularly Minister Staples, deserves credit for instituting welcome and long overdue changes that will ultimately enhance the quality of life of the residents of nursing homes. The Democrats have supported the Government's actions and its approach. We will not be moving any amendments to these matters.

The Bill also involves some changes to the Therapeutic Goods Act and makes some progress towards greater flexibility in the administration of this Act. I speak particularly about the individual patient usage or IPU scheme. Until now, IPU approvals have been given centrally. Typically, where a doctor feels that his or her patient requires a particular drug that is not available in Australia, the doctor has to approach a medical officer in the therapeutic goods administration who then assesses each individual request. However, requests for approvals have increased dramatically: 17,979 in 1989-90 and 9,409 in the six months ending 31 December 1990.

This centralised system is quite unwieldy and has resulted in even greater delays. This Bill will authorise regulations which will permit IPU approvals to be given to doctors outside the public service and to medical officers in specified hospitals. We welcome this move and the improved flexibility in the IPU system; it certainly is long overdue. However, there are still some enormous problems with the IPU scheme. For example, the IPU scheme requires the failure of accepted, conventional treatment before approval is granted for access to an unapproved drug. Even then, use is subject to the willingness of the company involved in Australia to supply the drug and mutually acceptable arrangements being put in place regarding protocols, reporting requirements, costs and so on.
The President of the Australian Federation of AIDS Organisations, Bill Whittaker, recently commented that the IPU and personal invitation schemes:

. . . cannot deliver drugs already approved overseas quickly and equitably to people with life threatening illnesses. Increasingly they are imposing heavy costs on consumers, both financially and in terms of effort. They place the onus on consumers to seek out their own treatments when it is the system that should be providing vital drugs to those in need.

It is true that the push for change in this area has gained substantial momentum since the advent of AIDS, but it is clear that the present system fails to properly address the needs and rights of people suffering from other life threatening illnesses such as cancer. It is also clear that there are significant problems in Australia's system of marketing approval for pharmaceuticals and I look forward to the report of Professor Peter Baume's review of our drug regulation system. I am hopeful that this will be the signal for some decisive action from the Government resulting in something more substantial than mere tinkering with the system, which is what we argue this Bill does.

The second Bill is the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill 1991. This Bill also makes several amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act. The amendments deal with the grouping of therapeutic goods which have common characteristics and a common manufacturer. Basically, the amendments mean that such goods will be charged for registration or listing as a group rather than incurring a separate charge for each individual item. We support this Bill and we will not be moving any amendments.

Finally, in looking at the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991, this Bill amends the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 and the National Health Act 1953 to implement reforms to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) which were announced in the 1990 Budget. The changes to the administration of the scheme involve the introduction of a checking system whereby pharmacists will be connected on-line to the Health Insurance Commission's computer to enable verification of a patient's entitlement. As Senator Patterson pointed out, that is for concessional benefits or the general benefit.

Honourable senators will recall that an earlier version of such a scheme, the so-called `black box' proposal, was dropped by the Government because of pharmacists' opposition and very real concerns expressed by the Privacy Commissioner. I acknowledge that the proposal that is now before us is very different from the earlier proposal where a fully interactive system involved two-way transmission of data and uncertainties about whether data from the Medicare and PBS programs would be kept separate. There was also a lack of precision about the information to be provided to pharmacists. The Democrats do not oppose justifiable measures aimed at reducing fraud on the public purse under the PBS or, indeed, any other government scheme.

Having said that, however, we do have a number of problems with this Bill. Our starting point, our first concern, in assessing measures of this kind is the need to strike a balance between the protection of individual privacy and the protection of the public purse from fraud and rorting. In this situation, the debate is always about these competing principles, as the Privacy Commissioner has observed on a number of occasions. The judgment which must be made, then, is the extent to which intrusions into privacy are justified on the basis of the competing principle of protection of the public purse. On that basis, I will now canvass and weigh up the competing claims made in relation to the proposal before us.

The Government itself claims that eligibility testing is estimated to save in the vicinity of $12m in 1991-92, $34m in 1992-93 and $40m in each year thereafter. The announced expenditure will amount to some $12.7m, $14.8m, $13.7m and $14.2m respectively in those years. The Government claims that the extension of the claims transaction system to all pharmacists will save it a further $6m in a full year and the restriction of entitlements to the pharmaceutical benefits program to Australian residents only will save another $6m annually. But it is most interesting to read how it actually arrived at the $6m. I commend to honourable senators the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

The savings of $40m are gross savings. When we break them down and try to work out exactly how the Government arrived at this figure, we need to go back and look at exactly what the Government is talking about in terms of fraud. One would imagine that that would be deliberate fraud. But that is not the case. When we look more carefully we find that at least half of the 3 1/2 per cent fraud that the Government has been claiming is made up in fact of mistakes-in other words, forms that have been wrongly numbered, forms that contain incorrect dates, et cetera. Although an old card may have been used, the person concerned still had an entitlement. That brings us down to 1.7 per cent fraud, assuming that the full rate applies. This means that the savings will be considerably less than $40m-in fact a maximum of $20m. If we then take off the $14m a year that the system is actually going to cost, we are left with a saving of some $6m at most. We question whether that $6m is in fact accurate.
We can look at the report on this Bill of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration that Senator Patterson mentioned previously. The report stated:
The Committee's review of the cost-benefit analysis was complicated by the Government's failure to provide any detailed costings for this initiative.
Senator Patterson has a second reading attachment that I will have a close look at because I understand that it tackles this problem. At paragraph 3 the Committee went on to say:
A further major ground for concern about the cost-benefit analysis is the significant variations in the estimates of the percentage of PBS claims which are invalid.
As I have already highlighted, there is a major problem in terms of exactly what we are talking about when we are dealing with fraud and whether a particular prescription is valid.
Paragraph 4 talks about the fact that we are going to have great difficulty in assessing the eventual benefits of this whole proposal. Paragraph 4 states:

The Committee learned that the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) will not be able to ascertain how much of the total savings in the cost of administering the PBS has been derived from each of its cost cutting mechanisms.
It goes on to say:

. . . the HIC needs to be able to identify: how much has been saved by restricting PBS entitlement to Australian residents; how much through checking PBS eligibility by way of a dedicated computer facility; and how much as a result of introducing the $2.50 price indicator . . .
Which was done some months ago. So this leaves a very big question. As this question remains unanswered, the Democrats in turn will not be supporting this Bill.

I now wish to deal with my second concern. I want to look at the failure of the Government to consider the alternatives that would be much cheaper, much easier on the system, particularly on the pharmacists and, we argue, of much greater benefit to the consumers who should be our major concern. Paragraph 1 of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration states:
It is clear that the Government had not considered alternate methods of preventing unauthorised claims on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). Possible alternatives would be:
a) improving the Health Insurance Commission's (HIC) internal auditing procedures;
b) improving the integrity of social security fringe benefits cards (as suggested by the Privacy Commissioner) and demanding the immediate return of all expired cards;
c) checking eligibility at the time that the prescription is written by the medical practitioner;
d) ensuring that the pharmacists check the expiry date of concession cards; or
e) taking legal action against people who seek pharmaceutical benefits to which they are not entitled.

I would stress here, too, that nobody is claiming, Government or otherwise, the existence of massive fraud but rather the existence of a range of possible mistakes in relation to concessional entitlements. It is rather ironical then that one clear example of fraud, where one person can use the card of another person, is not going to be resolved by this scheme at all. In this connection, one can refer to the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

In the time left I want to mention briefly our concerns relating to privacy. It is true that the Privacy Commissioner has worked on guidelines and I certainly welcome that. He has professed himself satisfied with the situation as it now stands. Unfortunately, the Australian Privacy Foundation remains profoundly concerned and I draw the Senate's attention to evidence given earlier this week by its representatives to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I want to quote from the Hansard record what was said by a witness who had a number of concerns. Mr Davies said:
Firstly, we are concerned that this system brings into too close a proximity medical records-medical consultation histories-and pharmacy use histories.
He went on to say:
The second point is that this system does create for the first time a link between the three major numbering systems-the TFN, the DSS number and the Medicare number.
He also said:

The third point is that there is no privacy protection whatever in the Bill. I understand that in other Bills there may be limited provision, but we contend that this Bill must have very strict guidelines on privacy and procedures. Ministerial instrument simply is not satisfactory . . .
I welcome some amendments that I understand will be moved tonight. Mr Davies continued:
The fourth point is that there is a real-time locater function in this system.
He made a couple of other comments that I would like to read. He said:

I think you all understand the term function creep which basically means that when a system is established by mysterious means and devious means the process is enlarged . . . The tax file number is a perfect example of function creep . . . We believe that just as the Medicare card is now used for two purposes, it may be used for more.
He went on to say:

The final point is the card itself. Although the Privacy Foundation has no problems with the card, or even the magnetic strip, we do have problems with a card and a strip that are not adequately oversighted in legislation, are not adequately protected.

Not only does the Privacy Foundation have some problems but the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills also expressed concern. Those concerns cannot be lightly dismissed, particularly when the announced justification for intruding on privacy is itself open to question.

I turn now to the people who will be responsible for administering this scheme if it comes into operation-the pharmacists. They share many of the concerns that I have already outlined but there is an additional very important reason for their opposition. On page 4 of their submission they state:
In general the overall cost effectiveness of the proposal should be such that the benefits must outweigh any disadvantages not simply in dollar terms. There must be:
tangible benefits to patients;
tangible benefits to pharmacists;
reduction in fraud (note that the system will not prevent persons fraudulently using other persons Medicare cards);
no significant increase in clerical work for the pharmacist.

One should look at the very considerable extra burden that is going to be placed on pharmacists. If pharmacists do make a claim for additional payments for scripts, we will find that just a 5c increase in scripts will mean a $5m cost to the public purse and there goes any savings, if there were any, that this Bill may have meant.

As they note themselves, the primary role of pharmacists is to dispense prescriptions. The safety and well-being of their patients must not be put at risk by the imposition of administrative burdens of this type. They are already attempting to come to terms with considerable changes.

Many elderly people still do not understand that they must always pay their $2.50. This can take considerable time-I have personal experience of that-with queues in pharmacies growing. Also, under the new system, they must be issued with generic drugs if they are cheaper than the ones that have been prescribed. Again, this imposes extra burdens on the pharmacists and takes up more of the time of the customers getting their prescriptions filled. Even if one accepts-and I do not-that the Government is entitled to transfer costs from the Health Insurance Commission to the private sector, to the pharmacists, the potential for interfering with the pharmacists' dispensing function in doing so is quite unacceptable.

I return to my original question: has an appropriate balance been struck between the protection of privacy and the protection of the public purse? The answer is: definitely not. I note that the Liberals are to move a number of amendments. I have not seen the final draft; but if they do answer any of the concerns that have been raised by the various people I have mentioned, the Democrats will certainly be supporting them.

I will go through the reasons that the Democrats will not be supporting this Bill. The claimed figures in justification for the scheme are rubbery, to say the least; alternative, less intrusive methods of addressing the problems that exist-I acknowledge that problems do exist-are available. Privacy protection remains an outstanding concern and patient well-being and safety are put at potential risk. We welcome attempts to improve this legislation. As I said, the Opposition is to move a number of amendments. We will not be moving amendments because, even with them, we believe this Bill will not be worth supporting. We will be voting against it at the second reading stage. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating three Bills: the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill 1991, and the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991. The first Bill has been dealt with thoroughly by my colleague Senator Patterson. While she also dealt thoroughly with the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill, I would like to address that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to ensure that only those people entitled to receive benefits under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme can claim this entitlement. The explanatory memorandum that the Government has put out reads:

The Bill makes it clear that the benefits of the Scheme are only to be available to Australian residents and those few other persons who under the Health Insurance Act 1973 are declared to be eligible persons. This amendment will preclude the benefits being obtained by visitors to Australia.
It goes on:
The Bill further tightens the eligibility testing on those persons who claim concessional benefits under the Scheme but in fact are not entitled to those benefits.

The Government claims that there have been rorts and that it has been losing a lot of money by people making various claims. We know that presently-the Government acknowledges this-there are about 300,000 extra Medicare cards floating around. The Government, very understandably, wants this cleared up, but it has chosen the most elaborate and high-cost method one could possibly imagine.

The legislation not only has great privacy concerns, as Senator Patterson said, but also it imposes many additional costs on pharmacists. I believe that pharmacists should be subsidised for the cost of their time, staff and inconvenience. The pharmacist has to deal with patients coming in with a prescription and having to be identified as being entitled to supplementary benefits when they are not on the register. He is then left to deal with these angry, confused people. Because of our concerns we will be moving quite substantial amendments.

Clause 11 was sent to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and clause 7 was sent to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for examination. Those two committees duly met. I intend to quote from the minority report put out by Opposition members of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. That report, I believe, was not only able to set a standard for all other Senate committees to follow but also is of such high quality that I will be referring to it quite considerably during my speech.

Clause 7 deals with the interpretation of the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill. The Committee called before it Senator Michael Tate, representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples), and Mr Kevin Hazell, the Assistant General Manager of the Health Benefits Division of the Health Insurance Commission, assisted the Minister. Members of the Opposition who put in the minority report were led by Senator John Watson, the Deputy Chairman, Senator Rod Kemp and Senator Ian Campbell. The report is something we should all read, mark, learn and inwardly digest. Government members made no comment, even after all the criticisms levelled at the legislation during the inquiry. However, Opposition members did comment and I intend to quote from their report later in my speech.
The whole purpose of this Bill is to save the Government costs. The financial impact statement that the Government has included in the explanatory memorandum reads:
Eligibility testing is estimated to save $12 million in 1991/92, $23 million in the 1992/93 and $40 million each year thereafter.

If we are looking at those figures as a saving they are not quite accurate because I understand that they reflect the gross saving. The cost of implementing the savings comes to $14.2m, so the savings are really only $25.8m-if that original gross figure is accurate. It is not clear and it is not correct to say that the savings are $40m each year because the costs must, of course, be taken from it. We must look at the situation in two ways: first, at the accuracy of the figures that the Government has given us on its estimates and, secondly, at how it should be corrected. The Government, in the explanatory memorandum, stated how it came to its financial impact statement:
It has been estimated that the restriction of payment of Pharmaceutical Benefits to Australian residents-
and that small handful of other eligible people in that line-
will save $6 million of Commonwealth outlays in a full year.
That was limiting the entitlement to Australian citizens only. The Committee's report states:

The estimate is based on an untested and highly questionable assumption that there are about 200,000 non-residents who are half as likely as Australian residents to utilise the PBS. The need to check every Australian resident's entitlement to prevent non-residents from rorting the system is arguable on the basis of this flimsy evidence.

How can the Government make the odd guess that 200,000 non-residents are half as likely as Australian residents to utilise the pharmaceutical benefits scheme? It seems to me that that first estimate is right off the top of the head and has no credibility at all. The Committee goes on:

The Government has not incorporated this saving into its costings, presumably because it believes it is negligible. Even if one in six non-residents seeking pharmaceuticals makes a fraudulent claim on the PBS, the total saving would be $1 million. Considering many visitors bring their pharmaceuticals with them and/or take out health insurance in their home country, a figure of this magnitude is unlikely. It is arguable whether it necessitates upwards of 10 million non-concessionary Australian residents having their Medicare Cards swiped by pharmacists every time they make a PBS claim.

In other words, very rightly, the Committee is saying that the Government is making 10 million Australians go to their pharmacists with their Medicare card and have the card swiped by the pharmacist just because it believes, off the top of its head, that 200,000 non-residents who are half as likely as Australian residents to utilise the claim might be rorting the system. The mind boggles. What a debacle. Of course, the Government does not mention the fact that there is nothing to stop me lending a visitor my Medicare card. That visitor could then go to a pharmacy and have it swiped. There is nothing at all to prove that the visitor who is using my card is not me. So for the Government to make the grand estimate of a saving of $6m seems to me to be quite incredible.
The Government was unable to provide any detailed costings, so these were not dissected into the various groupings. The Committee states that these:

. . . have not been dissected into those derived from people whose expired concession cards have not been checked by pharmacists and those derived from people who have become ineligible for benefits before their concession cards have expired. This is a crucial distinction in assessing the likely benefits of the proposed scheme, as opposed to benefits that could be obtained by other, less costly and less intrusive means.

The report goes on to refer to conflicting assessments made of the percentage of invalid PBS claims. The Auditor-General says it is 5.22 per cent while the Health Insurance Commission says it is about 3.5 per cent. As each percentage point amounts to a saving of nearly $10m, it is crucial that we have accurate figures.

Although the Committee was told that the Health Insurance Commission's survey was more comprehensive, I would like to quote from a letter by Mr Turk, the manager of the pharmaceutical benefits branch of the Health Insurance Commission, to the Department of Community Services and Health, as it then was. It reads:

The exercise was carried out in all State offices and proved to be both time and resource consuming. One of the major problems encountered was the lack of currency of data maintained on the DSS data base which was used for verification purposes.

These figures are a lot less than the 40% level of inaccuracy for pensioner and concessional entitlement numbers quoted in the Auditor-General's report referred in the `Strategy Proposal' document. Internal analysis and review of entitlement numbers also quoted in the `Strategy Proposal' document put the invalid entitlement figure at approximately 3-4%. These figures should be compared with the results of the latest review which estimates a cost of invalid entitlements at $20 million in a full year.
The difficulty in obtaining these figures and the significant variations shown on a State by State basis still casts some doubt upon their accuracy.

We had the Auditor-General saying 5.22 per cent and the Health Insurance Commission saying 3.5 per cent. What figure did the Government use? It accepted 4.5 per cent, which is somewhere between 5.22 per cent and 3.5 per cent. But, when one percentage point equals nearly $10m, one can understand the concerns of both the Committee members and the Opposition. We know that 90 per cent of Department of Social Security Department of Veterans' Affairs beneficiaries have a permanent eligibility and that about 10 per cent move in and out of eligibility at quite a rate. I again quote from the Committee's report:
In October 1990 the HIC introduced a check digit routine into all pharmacy computers. This routine seeks to ensure that entitlement numbers recorded in pharmacies, and thus sent to the HIC by CTS-
the claims transmission system-
have a higher degree of accuracy. This action will have already reduced the number of inaccurate entitlement numbers forwarded to the HIC since the Auditor-General's original report.
It goes on:
The system is therefore being introduced to identify only that small number of people who are using benefit numbers for which they are no longer entitled as well as all non-residents.

The Government is proposing to introduce a scheme that will use a sledge-hammer to crack a nut. We have this very costly scheme and we believe that the savings will be nowhere near the assessment that the Government has made, of $25.8m. The comment that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) made, having listened to the various Departments trying to explain how they came to their figures, was a very telling one. He said:
As to the exact order of these, you would have to look at them in a more sophisticated way than simply saying $40m.

I think that that is what the Committee has done. Nevertheless, savings are available and for that reason the Government believes that the system is justified. Yet Senator Tate has acknowledged that the way the estimates had been done by the Government really could not be verified. The Opposition members of the Committee pointed out very clearly that the estimates that the Government had come to were far from accurate and were cause for concern. The Opposition is also greatly concerned about this.

Leaving aside the financial aspects of the legislation, I turn now to the question of alternative methods. I believe that some of the alternative methods suggested by the Opposition members of the Committee would have to be looked at by the Government before anyone could possibly say that this legislation was the best method of attempting to save these costs. I again quote from this very excellent report. It says:
It was clear that the Government had not considered alternative methods of preventing un authorised claims on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). Possible alternatives would be:
(a) improving the Health Insurance Commission's (HIC) internal auditing procedures;
(b) improving the integrity of social security fringe benefits cards (as suggested by the Privacy Commissioner) and demanding the immediate return of all expired cards;
(c) checking eligibility at the time that the prescription is written by the medical practitioner;
(d) ensuring that pharmacists check the expiry date of concession cards; or
(e) taking legal action against people who seek pharmaceutical benefits to which they are not entitled.

None of those alternatives has been gone into by the Government. The committee members believed that this would be a far cheaper method for cost savings by the Government and for the pharmacists who have to implement this very complicated and costly procedure. If the Opposition were able to come up with so many simple and cost effective alternatives, why has the Government not looked at some alternative method? Why has it not at least looked at demanding that, when a new card is commenced, pharmacists simply check the expiry date of the card? If they were able to take legal action against people who seek pharmaceutical benefits to which they are not entitled, that may well scare people into not abusing the system. Perhaps they could demand the immediate return of all expired cards, just for starters.

If the Government implemented just those simple measures for perhaps 12 months, to see whether they worked and to see what savings came from implementing them, at least that would be a start and additional costs to the taxpayer and the stresses and pressures of costs to the individual pharmacist would be avoided. The Government has set about trying to stop an abuse. We do not know the extent of it. We have no idea what the cost savings will be. We have no idea whether it will amount to the $25.8m or whether it will be $2m. The Government must give us more accurate figures before we reach the committee stage of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before addressing my remarks to the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991, I must declare an interest through a very influential and persuasive wife who is a qualified salaried pharmacist. It is not that any of the savings in costs will accrue to our family, but my wife, Jocelyn, is very conscious of the need to save the maximum amount of money, possibly through the elimination of payment for ineligible scrips. On the other hand, she wants to ensure that there is a very efficient, cost effective and less intrusive system for both pharmacists and clients. I thank her for her contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: At a time when there is an urgent need for micro-economic reform, this Government is imposing a costly system on pharmacies, and indeed on all Australians who use pharmaceutical scrip products. This Bill has all the ingredients of a socialistic, inefficient Health Insurance Commission (HIC). It is clear that the Government has not adequately considered the alternative methods of preventing un- authorised claims on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS).

We are very conscious of the inadequate internal auditing procedures. We believe alternative methods could include the possibility of improving the integrity of the social security fringe benefits card, as suggested by the Privacy Commissioner, the immediate return of all cards, the ascertaining of eligibility at the time when the prescription is written by the medical practitioner, ensuring that the pharmacist checks the expiry date and the return of the cards on the expiry date or, better still, of the expiry date of a card being automatically fed into the chemist's computer. Also, legal action could be taken against those people who receive pharmaceutical benefits to which they are not entitled. There are quite a number of other possibilities, with which you, Madam Acting Deputy President, as a doctor, would be quite familiar.

Senator Tate was honest enough to admit, in relation to the $40m in gross savings on invalid prescriptions and the $6m alleged savings on overseas visitors, that the exact amounts were not known. We therefore have an admission from the Federal Government that it is not really sure how much taxpayers' money could be saved by forcing pharmacists to use this on-line computer system. Senator Tate, in his usual frank way, said that the Government would have to look at the costings in a more sophisticated way than it had done previously. Now that the Minister has had the opportunity to look at the Opposition's amendments, I trust that he will agree with the approach that we have taken of calling on the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance for a joint report for alternative systems. Mr Hazell, on the other hand, from the Health Insurance Commission (HIC), said:
The $6m saving by paying for medicines for overseas visitors and illegal migrants was based on the untested assumption that the group would only use about half the medicines of ordinary Australians.

The methods are quite unsatisfactory and arbitrary and they just cannot stand up. I must, of course, draw attention to comments made by the Director of the Privacy Commission, Simon Davies, who is concerned about the guesswork in relation to the savings aspect. He also drew attention to the secret agenda-not that I want to be linked with that-of introducing a checking mechanism that could possibly link the HIC data with Department of Social Security data and then the tax file number. Even Privacy Commissioner, Kevin O'Connor, indicated that there was no exact bridge by which health insurance, social security and tax file data could be linked. Nevertheless, he did warn that perhaps there could be lingering doubts in the minds of many people that a de facto identity card would not go away.

Furthermore, Mr Hazel admitted that the practice of borrowing cards would not necessarily reduce illegal payments where patients adopted this new technique and could continue to obtain scripts at lower costs. The Government seems to be obsessed with the view that by reducing the number of pharmacies and putting added burdens, costs and difficulties on to pharmacists, a lot of money can be saved. But in circumstances where a doctor writes 400 scripts a week, does it really matter a great deal cost-wise whether the patients with those 400 scripts go to one pharmacy or go to three pharmacies? The Government should concentrate on those measures to discourage doctors from writing so many scripts.

If we take this argument a further step back, preventative health care is much cheaper than hospitalisation. I think we have lost the focus of our vision by concentrating on the pharmacists' end of the spectrum. I am reminded of the old simple adage that a stitch in time saves nine; I think that is appropriate in any discussions on health care costs. Unfortunately, we tend to focus on the pharmacy end of the spectrum.

I was disgusted by the response to one of the questions as to why it was the pharmacist rather than others, including the doctors, who had to act as the policeman. It was stated that perhaps doctors had the means to fight such a proposal more strongly than the pharmacists. In other words, there was an admission that doctors had more clout, whether for constitutional or other reasons. I do not wish to suggest that, but maybe I led people into making that statement.

The computerised claim system will mean that not only will the Health Insurance Commission hold all Medicare claim records on file but also all patient drug history. If linked together, this could form some sort of data base containing a person's intimate medical and pharmaceutical history.

In closing, I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that there have been 16 major impacts in recent years on the pharmaceutical profession. I am deliberately truncating my contribution tonight, but I think this is important. Those 16 include the decision in November 1989 to reduce pharmacists' remuneration for dispensing pharmaceutical benefit prescription, and to abolish the mark-up component that took effect; reducing the pharmacists' remuneration by $1.05 per scrip on 20 December 1989; in August 1990, the introduction of a charge for pensioners-additional work for pharmacies; and, in January 1991, the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority.

There is an unacceptable attack by this Government on a very recognised and reputable profession. I hope that the Government will respond in a very positive way to the amendments that have been proposed by the coalition by ensuring that there is a further proper evaluation to ensure that this system does not go ahead without a more satisfactory system of costing and a less intrusive approach. I thank the Minister for his nod of approval.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators who have contributed to the discussion on these very important allied Bills that are being debated in the Senate chamber on the last sitting night for this autumn session. The first is the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. As honourable senators will be aware, it covers many matters. As the legislation currently stands-and you will be very well aware of this, Madam Acting Deputy President-a medical practitioner could itemise an account and claim Medicare benefits for a service where a physical attendance on the patient occurs, but during which no clinically relevant service takes place.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendment requires that a professional service be related to a medical examination, treatment, diagnosis or test that is necessary for the appropriate treatment of the patient. I would have thought that that would be a very elementary but very necessary clarification of what is required in the undertaking of a professional service to a patient. Clearly, it must be related to a clinically relevant service.

There is a clause in this Bill to require the proprietor of a pathology laboratory, the approval for which has been revoked, to take all reasonable steps to inform the providing practitioner and the patient that a Medicare benefit would not be payable in respect of the pathology service and to require the Minister to advertise such a decision. We have found some cases recently where pathology laboratories have failed to reach an acceptable standard of operation, the approval has been revoked and the Department of Community Services and Health has become aware that the operators of some of these revoked premises have continued to perform pathology services without informing either the referring practitioners or the patients. I think that that is an obvious matter that needed to be dealt with.

The Bill also contains a measure to facilitate the release of information about nursing homes to the public. I understand that the Opposition has raised some questions about the release of information on nursing homes. I understand that the Opposition sought an assurance from the Minister for Community Services and Health that departmental officers and geriatric assessment teams would be instructed not to favour one home or another in giving out the information. In response, the departmental officers who become delegates of the Secretary for the purpose of this section of the Act will be instructed to ensure the accuracy of information to be released and not to favour one home or another in giving out requested information.

Geriatric assessment teams will not, as a general rule, receive delegation under this section. The type of information to be released is not information that assessment teams would collect as part of their functions under the National Health Act. In the rare cases that delegation for this purpose is given to assessment teams, they will receive the same instruction as departmental officers.

The Opposition also sought assurances from the Minister that an appeals mechanism would be available prior to the publication of all information about nursing homes. In response, may I say that there are three categories of information to be released under this provision. First, information under section 45da of the National Health Act 1953 comprises action plans prepared by a nursing home proprietor on how standards in the home will be improved. Since these plans are drawn up by the proprietor, an appeal mechanism relating to the release of the plans is not necessary.

Secondly, proposed clause 45db concerns basic descriptive information that will be provided to the public on request. Appeal prior to release is inappropriate here. The decision to release is subject to ministerial review and Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) appeal, but there is no required waiting period between the decision and release.

Information under proposed clause 45dc concerns actions the Minister has taken or intends to take to withdraw, suspend or vary the approval of a home. A decision to release this information is subject to ministerial review, AAT appeal and a statutory 30-day delay between decision and release when representations can be made to the Secretary. A 30-day delay does not apply when there is an urgent need to protect the welfare or interests of residents. I hope that that gives some of the assurances that I understand were sought by the Opposition in relation to the releasing of certain information concerning nursing homes.

As I understand it, this particular Bill is not the subject of any amendments to be moved in the chamber. I do not think that I need to canvass any of the other matters that were dealt with, and I think I have responded to the concerns that were expressed.

As to the allied Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill 1991 which we are also debating, that is a rather technical Bill to do with grouped goods. The policy intention is that grouped goods should continue to attract only a single annual charge, rather than an annual charge for each product included in a group of goods that is separately registered or listed. Amendments to the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Act were necessary to achieve that result and to match the changes made by the portfolio Bill. I understand that that is not the subject of any great contest in the chamber either.

The major legislation of interest to honourable senators has been the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991. I am grateful for the contribution of those honourable senators who have spoken, although it took Senator Watson-that indomitable Tasmanian-to raise the rhetorical stakes in this particular debate when he spoke of the inefficient, socialised Health Insurance Commission and its schemes in this instance. I think that that was going a little over the top. As I say, it is the final night of the autumn sitting and I think Senator Watson would agree that he was just displaying a little bit of rhetorical flourish. In fact, the Health Insurance Commission is recognised as being extremely efficient, and I think it beats any of the private health insurance bodies in Australia hands down as far as efficiency is concerned.

I do believe that making changes to the administration of the scheme to involve the introduction of a checking system whereby pharmacists will be connected on line to the Health Insurance Commission's computer-more correctly, the Commission's eligibility file-will allow immediate verification of the patient's entitlement to free pharmaceutical benefits, concessional benefits or general benefits, and is a very sensible change to the way in which this particular scheme of pharmaceutical benefits is to be administered.

I am glad that most honourable senators dealt with the matter in a calm and rational way, looking for the efficiency gains that might be obtained as opposed to the regime that is being sought to be imposed by this Bill. I appreciated that tone. It was certainly different from that put forward by some of the witnesses at the committee meeting on Friday in relation to this matter. I think that we have to go back a little in history. When the Government took the decision to transfer the administration of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) to the Health Insurance Commission, it was against a background in which the Australian Audit Office had found that there was no effective checking of entitlements under the program and that the data provided was insufficient to properly manage the program.

The scheme which has been devised and which I have just described is the only way in which we believe all the problems could be comprehensively dealt with. Therefore, it deals with serious problems which the Australian Audit Office and others have identified. Clearly, parts of the problems which have been overcome by this scheme could have been overcome by some other method. But as a comprehensive total response to all the problems, this is the only scheme which can deal with everything that was revealed to be leading to the ineffective checking of entitlements in this program. For example, the suggestion for improving the integrity of Department of Social Security (DSS) cards was looked at, but the problem is not one of the integrity of the card. It is that a person's entitlement may change due to changed financial circumstances prior to the expiry date of the card issued to the person. That will always be the case and can only be addressed by a process in which the pharmacist is able to check the person's entitlement at the time of dispensing.

Senator Watson suggested in the committee stage that it might be realistic to ask a medical practitioner to do the checking rather than the chemist. I think that we refuted that very well in Committee. Certainly such a person has no financial involvement in the supply of the medication. I am sure that was the reason why we thought it inappropriate to suggest that the medical practitioner undertake that task; it was nothing to do with political clout or the Australian Medical Association union or any other such expression as may have fallen from Senator Watson's lips in an intemperate moment.

I turn to the question of anticipated savings. I think that this is a valid question for the Senate to have raised. I acknowledge that, and I understand that Senator Patterson has moved a second reading amendment which expresses some concern in that regard. I understand that the Committee Secretariat was provided with a couple of pages in response to the request by the Committee for further information in relation to the savings that were estimated to arise from improved eligibility checking. It was based on certain assumptions coming from the studies which were undertaken to check the entitlement of pharmacists' claims against data supplied by the DSS. In August 1989 the Commission had undertaken such a study, and it found that where a valid number was quoted, approximately 3.5 per cent of the services were found to have no current pensioner or concessional entitlement. Where an invalid number was quoted, no check was made against DSS entitlement records, but it was assumed that, once corrected, the level of error could be expected to be similar to that where a valid number was checked.

In its audit of the PBS for 1989-90, the Australian Audit Office did a more extensive study based on a limited but representative sample of 1,550 scripts which were checked against DSS entitlements. That study showed that in 5.22 per cent of scrips the person's entitlement had lapsed. As those studies were different in their methodology, and as the Australian Audit Office study was wider in scope and conducted on a smaller sample of claims, a conservative estimate of 4.5 per cent of pensioner and concessional scrips was used in the calculation of expected savings of $40m for the first anticipated full year of interactive processing, which is 1993-94. As senators will have been advised on the sheets that were provided to the Committee Secretariat, the savings were calculated on the basis of 4.5 per cent of an expected 72 million scripts at an expected saving of some $12.50 per scrip. That has been explained.

I have admitted that there are methods of post-payment checking which could cover some of the ineligibilities which no doubt could be picked up in that way. Admittedly, that would be a sum of some millions. In trying to estimate this comprehensive scheme in regard to the figure of $40m, this regime which is meant to cover all instances of cases where otherwise payment could be made to a person ineligible to receive it has been arrived at in a fair way, even though it will be the case that it is only when the scheme is in operation that we will be able to see whether the exact figures are borne out in the reality of experience. I think that it is a fair way to try to estimate savings arising from the improved eligibility checking. It is for that reason that the Government wishes that the scheme should proceed and that it should have the support of the Senate. It is also the reason why the Government cannot accept the second reading amendment moved by Senator Patterson.

In regard to the major matter of interest during the discussions in the Senate Committee, certainly in consideration of the Bill by the Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, that is the question of the operation of the privacy guidelines, the Government has indicated to Senator Patterson that we will be accepting all the amendments that she moved in this regard to ensure that the privacy guidelines are in operation in a way which satisfies the Parliament before the relevant sections of the Bill come into effect. We can deal with that more specifically in the committee stage. But I want to indicate at this second reading stage to Senator Lees that most of the amendments moved by Senator Patterson to deal with matters raised during the meeting of the Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs will be accepted by the Government. I commend the three Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 15, page 10, at end of clause, add the following paragraph:
``; (i) by inserting after subsection (3) the following subsections:
(a) the Commonwealth is liable under section 87a to pay an amount to an eligible person in relation to the supply by an approved supplier of a pharmaceutical benefit to the eligible person; and

(b) the amount (in this subsection called the ``purchase price'') paid by the eligible person to the approved supplier in respect of the supply of the pharmaceutical benefit is higher than the Commonwealth price of the pharmaceutical benefit;

the Secretary may, by notice in writing to the approved supplier require the supplier to pay to the Commonwealth an amount equal to the difference between the purchase price, and the Commonwealth price, of the pharmaceutical benefit.

`(3B) The Commonwealth may, by action in a court of competent jurisdiction, recover any amount specified in a notice given to an approved supplier under subsection (3A) as a debt due to the Commonwealth by the supplier.' ''.

This amendment will amend the existing clause 15. Under the provisions of clause 12, a person who has not been able to prove eligibility for pharmaceutical benefits at the time of supply but who subsequently demonstrates that eligibility to the Secretary is entitled to receive from the Commonwealth a refund of the difference between the amount which the person paid and the amount which would have been payable if eligibility had been established at the time of supply. As a result of the amendment of clause 10 (2), the charge made by the approved supplier in these circumstances might be at the private price, which is usually higher than the Commonwealth price, and thus the refund under clause 12 would be correspondingly greater.

New paragraph 15 (i) adds provisions to section 99aa of the principal Act so that, where such a refund is made by the Commonwealth to a person who subsequently proves eligibility, the Commonwealth will be entitled to recover from the approved supplier the amount, if any, by which the price charged exceeds the Commonwealth price. Normally this will be done by means of the existing subsection 99aa (4) of the principal Act, which allows such an amount to be deducted from any other amount which is payable to the approved supplier. This amendment ensures that in such cases the approved supplier ultimately receives only the Commonwealth price, which is the amount which the supplier would have received had eligibility been proved at the time of supply.
Amendment agreed to.

In the second reading debate I spoke at length about the reason for the inclusion of amendment No. 3. In that determination were certain discretions which resulted in the possibility of pharmacists having their livelihoods affected if the claims transmission process, or the equipment they were using, was deemed to be not adequate by the manager of the Health Insurance Commission. There was no right of appeal. A number of other concerns were raised.

In response to this, the Minister has put into the National Health Act the implementation of the claims transmission system as it now will stand under section 99aaa, which is an instrument that requires to be tabled and is disallowable. However, on advice that I have received, it would still be possible for other methods or systems to be brought in under section 98c (1) (b) in order to preclude that and to ensure that parliament is able to scrutinise the legislation adequately, especially the implementation of any similar system. Proposed new clause 18.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. After clause 17, page 11, add the following clause.
``18. After section 135a of the Principal Act, the following sections are inserted:
Issue of privacy guidelines for the conduct of the Medicare and Pharmaceutical Benefit Program
`135aa. (1) The Privacy Commissioner must,by notice in writing, issue guidelines for the conduct of the Medicare and Pharmaceutical Benefits Programs.

`(2) Guidelines under subsection (l) must be issued before 1 April 1992. Thereafter, the Privacy Commissioner may, from time to time, issue further guidelines to replace or vary any existing guidelines.
`(3) The Privacy Commissioner must report to the Parliament any failure to issue guidelines in accordance with subsection (2) within 15 sitting days of 1 April 1992.
`(4) Any guidelines issued under this section are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.
`(5) Section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 applies to guidelines issued under this section as if the following paragraph were inserted after paragraph (1) (a) of that section:
(aa) section 48 applies as if paragraph 48 (1) (b) were omitted and the following paragraph substituted:
(i) the first day on which the guidelines are no longer liable to be disallowed; or
(ii) if the guidelines make provision for their commencement after that day-in accordance with that provision.
`(6) Any guidelines issued under this section shall include an outline of the procedures that must be followed to ensure:

(a) the security of information transferred between the Commission and pharmacists or medical practitioners for the purpose of checking individuals' eligibility for the Pharmaceutical Benefits Program;
(b) the separation of information relating to claims upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits Program from information relating to claims upon the Medicare Benefits Program;

(c) that all information relating to claims upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits or Medicare Benefits Programs is de-identified within five years of its receipt by the Commission, unless such information relates to a current action that is pending in relation to an individual;
(d) that the Commission uses the most up-to-date, available information when checking the eligibility of concessionary beneficiaries to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Program.

`(7) Before issuing guidelines under this section, the Privacy Commissioner shall take all reasonable steps to consult with all relevant organisations, including the Commission and representatives of the pharmacy and medical professions.

`(8) In this section, ``Medicare Benefit Program'' means the provision of a medicare benefit under Part II of the Health Insurance Act 1973 and ``Pharmaceutical Benefits Program'' means the supply of a pharmaceutical benefit under Part VII of this Act.
Breaches of the privacy guidelines

``135ab. (1) A breach of the guidelines issued under section 135AA constitutes an act or practice involving interference with the privacy of an individual for the purposes of section 13 of the Privacy Act 1988.

`(2) An individual may complain to the Privacy Commissioner about an act or practice in relation to the operation of guidelines issued under section 135AA of this Act which may be an interference with the privacy of an individual.

`(3) In the event of a complaint being made by an individual, it shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of Part V of the Privacy Act 1988, which shall apply with such modifications as the circumstances require to the guidelines issued under section 135aa of this Act.'.''.

This amendment introduces the requirement of the issuing of privacy guidelines for the conduct of Medicare and the pharmaceutical benefits program, guidelines as provided by the Privacy Commissioner. It also provides for consultation regarding these guidelines to take place and enables those guidelines to be reviewed by Parliament. We were given assurances by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs that these guidelines would be in place, but as I said in the second reading debate, the implication of this legislation is that there is the potential for all Australian citizens to be required to produce evidence that they are eligible for a pharmaceutical benefit, whether it be a benefit as an Australian citizen or because they hold a beneficiary card that gives them a special benefit.

As a result, we thought it was imperative to include these privacy guidelines in the Act and also to enable the Privacy Act itself to be used if there were breaches of those privacy guidelines.
