It is an important amendment to this Bill and is something that really should have been addressed, rather than being left as a promise by the Minister. This acts to redress that and to make it able to be scrutinised by the Parliament. It assures the Australian public that this system will not come into place until the guidelines are firmly there and have been both scrutinised and approved by this Parliament, which is absolutely appropriate, and deemed to be adequate in our view to protect people's rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment. Considering the ramifications of this Bill, it is really amazing that the Government has not taken seriously the need for such guidelines. I fully support this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause agreed to.
Proposed new clause 19.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 17, page 11, add the following clause:
``19. After section 139a of the Principal Act, the following section is inserted:
Evaluation of pharmaceutical eligibility checking systems

`139aa. Those parts of the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991 which relate to the operation of dedicated computer facilities shall not come into effect until a joint inquiry of the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General has reported to the Senate that in its assessment the relevant estimated savings, as claimed in the financial impact statement of the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991, are realistic and that there is no other less personally intrusive system eligibility checking that could achieve equivalent savings.'.''.

The purpose of proposed new clause 19 is to overcome concerns about methods of checking eligibility. The coalition was not convinced by the evidence put forward by the Health Insurance Commission that there was no alternative method of checking eligibility. In fact, in one of the two committees that inquired into this matter, evidence was given that pharmacists do not always check the eligibility of their customers. They put onto their computer the customer's benefit number and, when the customer comes into the shop, they use that rather than checking the customer's card.

In addressing this issue, the Privacy Commissioner queried the possibility of whether social security cards could have a higher integrity and be updated more quickly so that these measures might improve the situation thus ensuring that people were not given benefits to which they were not entitled. Other suggestions put forward involved improving the Health Insurance Commission's internal auditing procedures and improving the integrity of the social security fringe benefits cards. Another suggestion put forward in one of the committees was that the Department of Social Security demand the immediate return of all expired cards, and that there may be a possibility of checking eligibility at the time the prescription was written by the medical practitioner.

There was also a possibility that an insistence ought to be made that pharmacists ought to check the expiry date of concession cards rather than just relying on their computers, and that there be an ability to take legal action against people who sought pharmaceutical benefits to which they were not entitled. Another possibility would be to give an incentive payment to pharmacists for undertaking those duties-a percentage per annum or some other estimate of the scripts of only those people who were entitled to benefits. This would encourage pharmacists to check people's entitlement benefits, given the fact that a certain percentage of people would have out of date cards.

I do not believe that every alternative was explored. I believe that this idea came into someone's head in 1989 when we saw it in the form of the black box and, rather than looking at alternative means, people have been fairly determined to set in place a dedicated system for which the easiest way was followed. Often, it seems that the easiest way is taken because people say that the technology is in place, but in fact it may not necessarily be the best way always, and there may be other ways that are much less intrusive. We want to be convinced of that before we actually concede to this Bill. We think it is absolutely appropriate that a joint inquiry of the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General report to the Senate and, in its assessment, show that the relevant estimated savings as claimed in the financial impact statement of the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill are realistic and that there is no other less personally intrusive system of eligibility checking that would achieve equivalent savings.

We were not convinced of that fact in the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. It was quite evident from the minority report that those honourable senators were not assured by the Health Insurance Commission's answers to the questions, and we believe that this is an appropriate way of dealing with this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this amendment, I go back to look at the original list of problems that I gave-the reasons why the Australian Democrats opposed this Bill at the second reading stage. We do believe that the figures are rubbery. Alternative schemes have not been explored. Privacy protection was inadequate, although I do note that the amendments moved by the Opposition tonight will go some way towards addressing that. The ultimate test, that is, patient well-being, certainly had not been given the green light. We believe that this amendment will certainly go some way towards at least looking at the possibility of there being other options or methods of achieving the same end with less personal intrusion on privacy. We welcome this amendment and will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the examination by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, and as a result of subsequent data given to the Committee, considerable doubt has now been acknowledged by the Minister, departmental officials and others about the exact accuracy of the savings and costings. Therefore, the Opposition's amendment, as moved by my colleague Senator Patterson, provides a further mechanism to satisfy the Parliament that those savings can be achieved, whether by this scheme or an alternative less personally intrusive scheme as a result of a review to be conducted jointly by the Australian National Audit Office and the Department of Finance.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that this scheme is, I suppose, modelled on certain schemes operating in Canada, and the cost per script in such schemes there is well over 60c, so it is not a cheap operation. However, it is interesting that they are tending to walk away from those schemes. At the very time we are introducing a scheme of this nature, those in the Canadian provinces are tending to walk away from what we are now intending to put in place.

I point out that it will cause a significant additional work load burden for pharmacists who will be carrying out detailed work for the Health Insurance Commission without reward. Under the Government's proposal, pharmacists will have less time for patient counselling. I remind honourable senators that much of that counselling results in cheaper costs in that people do not subsequently go to doctors on routine matters which would bring about far higher costs for the Government if they did.

While the Government claims that pharmacy users may not notice any change, this claim does not acknowledge down-time on the dedicated line-a problem not unfamiliar to those who use computer electronic transmission systems. Nor does this claim acknowledge the failure to regularly update the files of the Health Insurance Commission with input from the Department of Social Security, the Department of Veterans Affairs or other departments.

I think it is abominable that pharmacists, without reward, are being forced into the roles of policemen where they could face the embarrassment and wrath of customers who allege that they are entitled to the level of subsidy they seek, simply because part of the system has broken down. I think the Government should be very conscious of that embarrassment as a result of its inefficiency and problems in the line. They are not necessarily problems within the Health Insurance Commission-they could be within the Department of Social Security. The end result will be a problem for the pharmacist. I believe that there are alternative methods that should at least be evaluated.

This review by the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance will provide the level of satisfaction that I believe is necessary, given the unsatisfactory state of the costings that were presented to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I believe that this is a proper role for the Senate and a proper request for the Senate to make.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been indicated by Opposition senators in all of their speeches, there is considerable concern about the accuracy of the Government's figures contained in its financial impact statement. It is because of that that we have moved this amendment, as Senator Patterson has indicated. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Those parts of the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991 which relate to the operation of dedicated computer facilities shall not come into effect until a joint inquiry of the Department of Finance and the Auditor General has reported to the Senate that in its assessment the relevant estimated savings, as claimed in the financial impact statement of the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991, are realistic and that there is no other less personally intrusive system of eligibility checking that could achieve equivalent savings.

As is understood, the Senate will be looking forward to the report of the joint inquiry by the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General. I believe that this should have been done at an earlier stage-before the legislation was put to us-but as it has been put to us and as there has been an admission by the departments that this has not been done, we believe that the legislation should not come into effect until it has been undertaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot agree to this amendment which has only just been circulated in the chamber but which I am finding a little difficult to come to grips with. Just on a technical level, it purports to amend parts of the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill. Normally, an amendment would be cast in terms of amending an Act or adding clauses to an Act. Presumably, if this Bill is given a second reading, it will become an Act. On a technical level I find it very hard to admit the validity of the drafting of this particular amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: It refers to `those parts'-which parts? This legislation is to be passed by the Parliament of the Commonwealth, and the Senate is now looking at amendments which do not refer to clauses of a Bill or to sections of an Act, but just those parts of a Bill which relate to the operation of certain dedicated computer facilities.

If one tries to identify those parts, they may be referring to clause 11 or clause 12-I am not sure. If they are the parts to which the honourable senator is referring-and I see that her advisers are as puzzled as I am-then I refer to the first amendment proposed by Senator Patterson in the Committee of the Whole which was accepted by the Committee. It provides that sections 11 and 12 are to commence on 1 July 1992 or the day after guidelines issued under section 135aa of the National Health Act have been approved in the same form by both Houses of Parliament, whichever is the later. Either the first amendment which was accepted in this Committee stands, or this particular provision stands but, if passed, they cannot stand together.

I would further say that, in effect, this amendment undoes the previous vote by the Senate to affirm the second reading of the Bill. The second reading debate dealt with this matter of the estimated savings to be gained by the devising and operation of this particular regime. Indeed, a second reading amendment agreed to in the chamber expressed misgivings about some of those costings and estimated savings, but the second reading was granted by the Senate. This amendment, which is a very peculiar one, seems to be trying to undo the second reading of the Bill.

Finally, as to the departments that are asked to undertake a joint inquiry, the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General are being asked to make an assessment as to whether the relevant estimated savings are realistic and whether there is no other less personally intrusive system of eligibility checking which could achieve equivalent savings. If I was in a generous frame of mind, I might agree that the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General might make an assessment of the financial impact statement as to the relevant estimated savings. That is, perhaps, where their expertise might lie.

But those departments have no particular expertise to make a judgment-which the Government and the relevant portfolio Minister have made-concerning whether a less personally intrusive system of eligibility checking might achieve equivalent savings. That is a real policy question for the portfolio Minister on the advice of the Department, the Health Insurance Commission and others and, of course, on the advice of and after consultation with the Privacy Commissioner. That particular leg of what is being asked of the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General is quite outside the scope of their true abilities and expertise. I think it would be unfair of the Senate, if it were minded to pass this particular amendment, to require that sort of policy judgement by those two departments. It is just not appropriate.

For all sorts of reasons I find that this purported amendment to the Bill is totally unsatisfactory in its drafting and in what it is trying to achieve, particularly in relation to Senator Patterson's amendment No. 1 which has been accepted already by this Committee.

Certainly, I do not think one leg of the task being asked of the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General is an appropriate task. I would ask that further consideration be given to this matter in the Committee. Senator Patterson may wish to respond while I walk around, talk to a few people and work out what it is about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the Minister's argument holds that this amendment is at variance with our agreement to give the Bill a second reading. The Bill also contains a clause requiring that guidelines be provided. The amendment requires that a joint inquiry be carried out within 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that this matter has dragged on now for some time. I am to be convinced by anyone in the Department that urgency is involved. The issue of the first black box was raised in 1989. We were told in the Budget that it was supposed to be implemented in 1990. We were then told that the next start-up date would be June 1991. I discovered on Monday during the examination of this legislation by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs-this was a revelation to me-that the start-up date would now be July 1992. So this has been going on from November 1989 and the start up date is now to be July 1992.

Therefore, I need to be convinced that there is a need for great haste. I do not agree either that there is going to be a financial element in respect of this amendment. The amendment requires only that the Senate be convinced. A group of senators on the Committee were not convinced that the data was adequate.

I suggest to the Minister that one possibility might be to adjourn the debate at this point to see whether we can come to terms with some technical changes to the amendment. I have been informed by a person who is much more experienced than I am that the words `Those parts' is a form that is used. As an aside, Senator Hill has informed me that he has written more legislation than I have. I have to concede that that is the case. He tells me that the term `Those parts' is used.

I believe that we have not had adequate independent information. The Minister almost convinced me that the Department of Social Security ought to be involved. He suggested that Department might improve its card in order to ensure that the checking of eligibility is more reliable.

I stand to be convinced that the amendment cannot stand as it is presently drafted. It may be appropriate to adjourn this debate until a later hour this day so as this matter can be negotiated outside the chamber. I note that the Minister and I will be in the chamber discussing two or three other Bills. But that may be a solution to the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly think we ought to report progress in order to enable officers to look at the actual drafting of this amendment. I make this suggestion on the basis of an indication from the Australian Democrats that they support in principle what the Opposition is attempting to do with this amendment. Rather than send the Bill down to the House of Representatives for a better clause drafted by the Government or the Opposition to be inserted, I guess it would be better to make that change in this place tonight. We should try to get the legislation to the House of Representatives in a form that represents the will of the majority in the Senate. It can then be considered by the Minister in its final form.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 May, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Debate on the National Health Amendment Bill 1991 is restricted not by guillotine but by the lateness of the hour. It almost always tends to be that legislation in the health area, especially legislation that relates to nursing homes, is pushed through in the last week of sittings. We have seen this happen over and over again. Education, nursing homes and hostel legislation gets shoved to the end of the list and we always deal with it at a very late hour.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, a whole host of legislation has had to be passed this session for it to be implemented on time. In the hurry to have this legislation passed, it has not been drafted as carefully as it could have been-not because the parliamentary draftspeople are not paying attention to what they are doing but simply because they do not have the time to spend on legislation.

Clause 5 of this Bill inserts new section 4aaa in the principal Act. This section classifies as adjusted fee government nursing homes those homes listed in schedule 3 of the principal Act and those that the Government may later prescribe for this purpose. The section also allows homes to be removed from the schedule by regulations. This is necessary in case any home wishes to cease to be an `adjusted fee government nursing home'.

Well, that is all very fine but the problem is that someone forgot about existing section 4aaa. I have been advised that it would not matter if the two sections existed side by side, although there would be some confusion when there was reference to either section. One might ask, `What was the section that was forgotten?'.

Existing section 4aaa provides for benefits to be continued to be supplied to certain classes of pensioners for six months after they cease being defined as a pensioner due to changed circumstances-for example, if they get a job. Poor drafting, as I said, most probably due to time constraints, could have put these benefits at risk.

This Bill makes a number of amendments to the National Health Act concerning nursing homes. The first one is associated with benefit arrangements for government nursing homes or adjusted fee nursing homes. These changes set up a small number of recently established State government nursing homes on the same funding basis for the care aggregate module (CAM) as all the non-government nursing homes. The standard aggregate module (SAM) component is lower than for the non-government nursing homes, presumably to take into account the return on investment factor included in non-government homes SAM.

Commonwealth nursing home benefits paid in respect of the residents of government nursing homes have been frozen at November 1984 levels. As a Victorian, I am particularly concerned. Victoria has the largest number of residents in government nursing homes. I think there are something like 5,000 residents in Victorian government nursing homes and the next State has 2,500. I have kept a very keen eye on and I have a great interest in proposed changes to State government nursing homes. It seems that Victoria differs in every way from all the other States in terms of the number of people in nursing homes verses hostels. Out of 118 small rural nursing homes in Australia, 48 are in Victoria. Victoria also differs in respect of the number of residents in government nursing homes. Also, Victoria has more types of nursing homes than any other State.

Historically, Victoria has differed. I am always keen to look very closely, not only because of my position as a shadow Parliamentary Secretary but because of my role as a Victorian senator, at any changes the Government brings in. Inevitably, they always affect Victoria in a very particular way. Let me go back: the nursing homes to become adjusted fee government nursing homes are listed in this Bill. This list will become a schedule to the Act. The benefit will apply from 1 January 1991 retrospectively.

There is a story behind this change. There has been a long and bitter battle between the Federal and State departments over appropriate rates to be paid. The Victorian Government refused to open 11 facilities until an adjustment was made to the rates being proposed. The depleted Victorian Treasury-I do not need to talk about that; Mrs Kirner has admitted how bad it is-as well as pressure from some of the more militant industrial unionists involved in Victoria has meant that the case of these nursing homes has attracted a great deal of attention.

I cannot complain, being a Victorian, but I wonder what deal has been done to have these Victorian homes opened. I would be interested to hear an explanation from the Minister as to why only Victorian homes have been included in the schedule and there are none from any other State. I note that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills indicated in its report that under section 4AAA (b) the Governor-General could add to the list of nursing homes provided in schedule 3. In addition, pursuant to proposed new section 4AAA (2), the Governor-General could also omit nursing homes from schedule 3 by way of regulation. This is what is known, to all of us who are familiar with the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, as a Henry VIII clause; that is, primary legislation can be amended by subordinate legislation. The Committee expressed its concern that the legislation could be amended in this way and considered it a possible breach of one of the Committee's principles.

I also noted in the Scrutiny of Bills report that various provisions of the Bill were to have commenced on 1 January 1991; that is, they have an element of retrospectivity. The explanatory memorandum states that this is to comply with a commitment given by the Government and ensures that these homes do not lose the benefit of the higher funding due to the time taken to amend the legislation. This is yet another example of legislation by press release. I do not understand why the necessary amendments to the Act could not have been made earlier.

At the beginning of this session, I remember that we were scratching around, looking for legislation. Looking at the background of exempt home charges, the exempt bed nursing homes provide a higher level of service than other homes and charge higher fees. A lower Commonwealth benefit is paid in respect of exempt homes. These homes are not numerous. In the first year of operation of the exempt homes provision, approximately one per cent of nursing home beds were exempt; that is, 838 exempt beds only. When we debated this issue, the Government put forward the proposal at the beginning that there would be exempt beds within ordinary nursing homes. This would have enabled people in rural areas to have access to exempt beds but, as it is now, it is almost impossible for a person in a rural area to have access to an exempt bed unless he is in a large rural centre. Many nursing homes are the only ones in the township and they would not apply for exempt bed status. This has precluded many of the citizens of that town going into a nursing home.

The bureaucrats and the Government decided that one way to solve this situation would be to have exempt bed nursing homes in toto. The Government set a target of 6 per cent of nursing home beds. When the exempt homes provision was introduced it was decided that, unless the residents elected otherwise, they could maintain their non-exempt status for a period of two years after the bed became an exempt bed. Where a resident elected to become an exempt patient, the bed became exempt, and the resident was required to contribute a greater amount. As always, when legislation is not thought through in detail, we always strike problems somewhere down the track.

This Bill will allow people who are resident in a home, when its beds are granted exempt status, to remain there permanently without paying any additional contribution if they choose. Currently, the choice to become an exempt resident must be made within six months of the beds being granted exempt status. The Bill will allow people to again exercise this choice after the home's beds have been exempt for two years.

Ever since the inception of the exempt homes provisions, there have been problems. As I said, when the original proposal went through Parliament, the coalition allowed it to go through but we believed, and I think we indicated, that there were a number of problems which needed to be sorted out along the way. Some of these problems do not seem to have been fixed. Applications for exempt homes have not been forthcoming. Basically, this is because proprietors are unsure about it. As we have seen, there are some changes that would make them even less sure. Also, when the applications are made, there seems to be some unnecessary delay in getting it onto the books.

A number of organisations have a number of major reservations with the change being made to the exempt homes provisions. Our consultations with the industry suggest that there has been a lack of consultation by the department with these people. That is why we suggested that the Bill be examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. The outcome of the Committee was that the Bill stand as printed. This was not before serious reservations were expressed by the industry that the current exempt home provisions were not adequate and that the changes in the Bill will not make it more attractive for nursing home proprietors to make an application for exempt home status.

The industry groups have said that the proposal enabling existing residents of nursing homes granted exempt home status to remain in that nursing home without paying the additional fee if they choose not to means that a facility will be forced to operate indefinitely with an unknown financial liability as part of the financial arrangement. The open-ended proposal will make it difficult for nursing home proprietors to plan financially. The effect of this proposal is that after two years of receiving exempt status, a nursing home-and I must admit in an extreme case-could end up with every resident in a nursing home saying that he or she does not wish to pay the higher fee.

The Government has claimed that, in reality, there is only a small percentage of residents who would still be resident in a nursing home after two years and who may not elect to become exempt residents. However, figures supplied by the industry show that 33 per cent of residents stay for more than two years. Therefore, the point about the difficulty of planning is quite valid. The whole argument ought to centre around the fact that an elderly person should be able to enter into a nursing home and pay an extra fee for an extra benefit. Some people are quite happy to pay the extra fee for extra services and provision should be made to facilitate their wishes.

As I mentioned before, I have concern about the number of exempt beds and lack of beds in rural areas. As I have said, there is a problem associated with this particular concept in rural areas. Because a nursing home cannot be granted exempt status if it is the only nursing home in an area, there is no opportunity for people to enter an exempt bed nursing home unless they move out of that area. This restriction is unfair on those in rural areas.

I can understand the argument that a nursing home in a rural area cannot become exempt as it could restrict, as I said before, the freedom of people to move into nursing homes. But surely there must be a creative solution to this problem. The Government should be able to come up with a flexible solution so that those who have the ability to pay and choose to are able to do so and remain residents in their own local area.

The other proposal regarding exempt beds in this Bill is a situation in which an exempt home status is allowed to lapse. Residents who entered on the basis of the nursing home being exempt will be permitted to remain as exempt residents. The only problem with this proposal is that it may be impractical to provide additional services to the one-off resident. It is understood that residents have rights; but proprietors of nursing homes also have rights. It is beholden upon the Government and the industry to devise a solution which protects the rights of the resident, but gives the proprietor some surety in financial planning.

The Bill also makes an amendment in regard to the role of the community visitor. This remedies an error in the wording of the original proposal where the community visitor was given authority to check on the care being delivered within the home. The provision will be replaced so that community visitors may enter nursing homes to meet with patients. The Opposition supports this amendment.

The Bill also allows the Minister to take action against nursing homes which are not complying with standards of care. The standards do not present difficulties to the professional nurses in achieving quality care. Strengthening the Commonwealth's hand in ensuring that only quality care is acceptable, is an amendment acceptable to the Opposition. There are reasonable safeguards in the review and appeal processes that have been negotiated with the Commonwealth to ensure that proper professional standards and definitions will apply in the event of any disputes of judgment and application arising.

The Bill also continues to provide additional funding to assist nursing homes to employ a registered nurse at all times. Only the smaller homes need this assistance. The funding formula is such that only these smaller homes receive it. Some small nursing homes are also receiving additional funding to assist them to achieve financial viability. The Bill retains the existing arrangements for determining eligibility and level of additional funding. It also allows this funding to be provided without the need to change the home's fees every month. The proposal relieves the administration of this measure and the Opposition supports both of them.

One other issue I wish to raise is the issue of capital funding of hostels. Hostels which had signed an agreement have had their funding arrangement continued at the agreed level and according to the funding formula of 60 : 30 : 10. In the Estimates Committee, I raised the issue of the Department in Victoria attempting to vary the terms of these signed agreements and this issue seems to have been resolved. However, those hostels that have not signed an agreement will not receive their funding in the proportions that they had expected.

I give the example of Bright Hospital. Bright Hospital was approached by the Department to set up a hostel. I know individual citizens in the community who gave considerable donations that many of them had struggled to put together to ensure that they had aged care in their own community. The hospital contacted me and said that it was hoping to be able to go ahead on the understanding that it was to get the funding in the ratio 60 : 30 : 10. The hospital has actually purchased the land. I do not know whether the first sod has actually been turned, but it has advised me that it is now re-evaluating its financial situation. As of about two days ago, the hospital said that it was not sure whether the project was financially viable. The hospital had entered into the project on the understanding that when the agreement was signed the basis of the funding would be 60 : 30 : 10. But because it has not signed the agreement it will be caught between two stools, so to speak.

The funding arrangements have been varied because of a shortfall of funds for hostels. There has been an uptake of hostel funding. In the depressed economic climate, which has obviously impacted on the building industry, there has been a larger take-up of hostel building applications. This has placed strain on the Department's resources and the result has been the variation to funding conditions.

The Opposition is keen to seek the Minister's assurances that the funding arrangements will revert back to the original arrangements, especially for those hostels where negotiations have commenced with the Department. I do not know the non-sexist word for a gentleman's agreement, but it seems to me that when an organisation has commenced to negotiate with the Department there is a problem in varying the way in which it will get its funding. We hope that the funding will revert back to the original arrangements; that the variation will only apply to this financial year; and that the Minister will address the particular problems of those organisations which had commenced in good faith to take up the hospital beds that were offered on the basis that funding would be received in the ratio of 60 : 30 : 10. The varied arrangements are affecting the building of hostels and, in some instances, causing their deferment. As I said, the old arrangements would allow the hostels to plan again with some degree of confidence. I ask that the hostel at Bright be given special attention, because I know that it is in jeopardy as a result of this change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main purpose of the National Health Amendment Bill 1991 is to allow an increased Commonwealth nursing home benefit to be paid to a category of nursing home called `adjusted fee government nursing homes'. The Australian Democrats do not have any problems with these provisions. However, we do have a problem with the arrangements relating to exempt nursing homes. For the benefit of those honourable senators listening, I explain that exempt nursing homes provide a higher standard of care than does the normal nursing home. For example, exempt nursing homes often provide individual rooms with en suite facilities, perhaps a glass of wine with a meal, frequently air-conditioning, extra excursions and other benefits. I guess one could call them the luxury end of the market or the five star nursing homes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government granted a number of nursing homes exempt status effective from February 1990. This involved about 840 beds. However, a difficulty has arisen where there are residents who are already in a nursing home when that nursing home upgrades around them-that is, when that nursing home becomes exempt. These people did not choose to enter an exempt home and pay the higher fee; they simply find themselves now living in the home when it is granted exempt status.

Under existing legislation they can stay in the home for two years after status is granted, but then they must either pay the higher fee or move out. In February 1992, residents who are unable or unwilling to pay the higher fee in those homes which were granted exempt status last year will be relocated at the proprietor's expense. This has caused some distress to those residents who could not afford the higher fee and have had to move out of the nursing home. This Bill changes the legislation and provides that in future when homes are granted exempt status people already resident in the home can stay there permanently without paying the higher contribution. This is a very sensible move and the Democrats welcome it.

I can understand the concerns of the nursing home industry. It is not fair to force a resident to move when they did not choose to enter an exempt home in the first place. After all, we are talking about very elderly people; people who are often bedridden or perhaps disabled; and people who have become considerably attached to that bed and that room which has become their home. There is a shortage of nursing home beds, so it is entirely possible that residents who find themselves in this situation would have to move to a home a considerable distance away from the area that they already live in, the area they know and the area where there is ready access for friends and relatives.

We therefore support the amendments which will give substantial benefits to future residents in exempt homes. But I stress the word `future' because it does nothing to assist those residents who are in exempt nursing homes now and who will have to move out at the end of the two-year period if they cannot afford or are unwilling to pay the higher contribution. It is very difficult, as the Standing Committee on Community Affairs found, to ascertain the exact numbers involved. The Standing Committee on Community Affairs which looked at this Bill was advised by the Department that about 223 residents were presently in exempt homes still paying the standard fee. It appears, however, that some arrangements have been entered into for approximately half of these residents. The proprietor has said that they can stay on without paying the higher fee. We certainly congratulate those proprietors who have made a most humane decision.

However, this still leaves some 111 or 112 residents, as of today, who are facing the choice of paying the higher fee or of moving out in February. The Accommodation Rights Service (TARS) submitted to the Senate Standing Committee examples of such residents. One of the residents, aged 91, had been in the home for nearly 10 years and the other, aged 86, for eight years. As TARS observed, the average length of stay in a nursing home of between 21 and 23 months does not apply to all residents. This point was emphasised by Senator Patterson. The Accommodation Rights Service went on to say:

. . . with such length occupancy the residents no doubt would have built up quite a deal of attachment to these homes. The trauma of frail elderly people having to leave their nursing homes is well documented and it is something that we are concerned about should these residents have to confront a move.
I specifically quote from the Hansard of 7 June of the proceedings of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs:

One client talks of the huge upheaval it would be to her father-in-law's life should he have to move. She feels that his inclination to illness in recent times could be psychologically based, in that he deduces that this might prevent the home moving him . . .

The same relatives also tells me of another very old frail resident in the home who gave her a note last August to the effect that the resident felt that within 18 months she will have to make sure she is dead. Our client thinks this is because of the worry that the resident will have no choice of staying at the nursing home because she couldn't afford to pay the higher fee.

The same nursing home has 143 of the 454 beds in its area. Our client queries how the existing residents are going to be relocated given that there are relatively so many of them and especially since it's a working class area.

Of course, we must remember that there is certainly some justification in the proprietor's concern, as Senator Patterson has outlined. But these residents have lived in these particular homes for many years, without any expectation, and certainly without any desire, that higher fees would need to be paid or that they would be able to pay them. They certainly had no knowledge of the fact that eventually they would have to make the choice of paying up or moving out.

Basically, what has happened is that the Government did not really consider the ramifications of the legislation when it introduced the exempt home provisions. It has now got it right for future granting of exempt status but it is leaving the existing residents out on a limb. I have raised this issue with the Minister and his staff at length. We proposed this amendment and it was discussed in great detail. As the Minister rejected it, we then discussed another amendment which would have effectively put hardship provisions into this legislation. Unfortunately, that also was rejected, for similar reasons. I will go through the reasons which, unfortunately, we have to reject.

Firstly, changing the ground rules retrospectively is unfair to proprietors. There is an injustice here and I do have some sympathy for their position. But the original legislation meant a change in the ground rules that would be unfair to the residents. It will be at a cost to proprietors, but I suggest that a much greater cost will be borne by the residents concerned, who will have to leave their homes and adjust to others, and there is also the burden to be borne by their families, which will have to cope with all the traumas involved. It is also worth noting, as I mentioned earlier, that 100 or so residents are being permitted to remain in their exempt homes without paying higher fees. Obviously, some proprietors are willing to bear the additional cost, for what will mainly be, I imagine, a relatively short time.

Secondly, the Minister argued that any amendment would be unfair on those residents who have already moved out or agreed to pay the higher fee. Again, this is true. Those residents could certainly argue that they had been disadvantaged, but the Minister himself said that the existing legislation has caused distress, and Senator Tate noted that the current situation had caused very considerable anguish. Why not take this opportunity to ensure that it does not cause any further distress or anguish?

Thirdly, the Government has said that it is not prepared to meet the costs of the proposal. We argue that these costs will be minimal. The Minister claims that the projected savings from the lower benefits that the Commonwealth pays for exempt residents have already been built into the financial estimates. I argue that that is a quite feeble excuse. We are not talking about a great sum of money-probably in the vicinity of $400,000 in the coming financial year-and, of course, we are talking about a very limited number of people. There will be no new or unexpected costs. There will be no other people able to join into this scheme. Obviously the numbers will not remain very high for years and years to come.

I cannot accept the Minister's reasons for declining to support our amendment. I do not think they stand up. I am disappointed that the Government could not see its way to preventing further distress to these residents and their families. However, I am pleased to note that the Minister has agreed to put in place an additional measure to help these residents. I quote from a letter of 9 June 1991 from the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples):

The Government has sought to address consumer concerns by amending the existing legislation. In addition I will ensure that the Department of Community Services and Health makes qualified staff available in January 1992, to assist any resident who is moving from an exempt home as a result of the legislation. The Department will be able to ensure that any move undertaken by a resident who has not already been placed will be as comfortable for the resident as possible, and that all residents are placed in new homes that will meet their wishes and needs.

It has always been understood that it is the exempt nursing home's responsibility to find alternative care for these residents, and this understanding will remain. However, I understand the concerns expressed by you and trust that this additional arrangement will go a long way to address your concerns.
It does go a long way to addressing the Democrats' concerns, but we argue that it does not go far enough. Therefore, we will be moving an amendment in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is anxious that the National Health Amendment Bill 1991 be given passage through the Senate this evening. As honourable senators have already pointed out, the Bill gives effect to a number of Government initiatives relating to nursing homes and to the domiciliary nursing care benefit. The particular matter which has attracted the attention and concern and the comment of honourable senators is those amendments which have as their purpose the payment of increased Commonwealth nursing home benefits to a special category of government nursing homes, to be referred to as `adjusted fee government nursing homes'. As honourable senators have remarked, under the existing legislation a resident in a nursing home at the time that it is given exempt bed status can remain in the home for two years after that date without paying an additional contribution. Beyond that period they are automatically classified as exempt and so must pay the additional contribution or leave the home. Of course, that creates great trauma and difficulty.

SPEECH.PARA: This provision has caused distress to many of the residents of the homes that were given exempt status last year and to their relatives. The Bill proposes changes to the legislation to allow residents of homes given exempt bed status in the future to stay permanently, without paying the additional exempt bed resident contribution. Obviously, that is a very welcome amendment to the Act.

There are some other provisions in the Bill which are important. I refer in particular to the strengthening of the legal power of the Government to take action against nursing homes with poor standards of care. In a very small number of cases, nursing home proprietors have not provided the quality of life and care expected by the Government and, as taxpayers subsidise each resident in a nursing home an average $23,000 per year, it is essential that the Commonwealth be in a position to ensure accountability for the funds it makes available and, of course, to protect the rights and expectations of those particularly powerless members of our community who live in these homes. There are some other minor amendments that I need not dwell on.

Senator Lees has indicated a concern in relation to those residents in existing nursing homes. I understand that she will be moving an amendment to deal with that matter in the committee stage and I will comment on her amendment then. I commend the second reading of the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 3, page 2, line 6, omit ``sections 8 and 10'', substitute ``section 8''.

As I outlined in the second reading debate, the effect of this amendment would mean that existing residents in exempt nursing homes would be able to stay. It would mean that the Government would pay part of that cost. It would still mean that there would be negotiation with the homes, because there would be the balance to be picked up by the proprietors. I recommend this to the Committee. I believe that it is the most humane way to cater for those 100 or so residents who are caught in a very difficult position and will have to make some very difficult decisions in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the concerns which have animated this amendment from the Democrats, but the Government cannot accept it because it would change the ground rules for exempt nursing homes retrospectively. This would make it very difficult for existing exempt nursing homes to generate sufficient income to meet the additional cost of upgrading their premises and services. It could also discourage other nursing homes from applying for exempt status if they feel that the rules will be changed retrospectively.

SPEECH.PARA: It may also be said that the change would be unfair to the many residents who have already moved to another nursing home. Such residents may well claim justifiably that they have been misled by the Government in being told that their only choice was to pay or to leave. It is clear from the consideration of this matter by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs that the Government has demonstrated its willingness to listen to consumer concerns by introducing the amendments for new exempt homes as contained in the Bill. Some regard must be had, however, for the nursing homes industry's real concerns over the changes, and thus the Government does not believe it can go the whole way and make the changes retrospective. Nevertheless, I understand the concerns that have been expressed. I know that departmental staff will be made available to assist those remaining residents who may be required to find alternative accommodation. However, the Government cannot accept Senator Lees's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —With some reluctance I have to say that the coalition will not be accepting the Australian Democrats' amendment. I can see merit in their argument, but I also see merit in the Government's argument that there is an element of retrospectivity. My sadness is that this was not thought through before. It is all very well in the rarefied atmosphere of Canberra and the rarefied atmosphere of the bureaucracy of Canberra to think up a wonderful scheme, but as I have said a number of times in this place, we tend to forget that there are real live people at the end of the process. When we were discussing this last week, there were 111 elderly residents of nursing homes-there may be 110 or 109 now- who will have to move as a result of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had confirmation; the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, Mr Staples, has written to Senator Lees, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, saying that additional resources will be put in place to assist those residents who will be moving. We welcome that. There will be additional counselling, additional resources and staff to ensure that the transition of those residents into an appropriate nursing home is as smooth as possible.

I can see the argument that those people who have already moved could say, for example-which is a suggestion I put forward in the committee-that since there were 111 people involved, perhaps the Government might look to addressing the issue of meeting the difference in the cost between the Government subsidy and the additional money that is charged by the exempt bed nursing home, which can be up to $10 a day. I can see the argument that if the Government were to do that-and it really would cost very little compared with some of the costs in the administrative services of this place-it would be wrong and a disadvantage for those people who move, in that had they known that that may be the case, they may have stayed on in the exempt bed nursing home, receiving the benefit of being in an exempt bed nursing home.

With hindsight, we can always be wise, but I guess it is a lesson and it ought to be heeded by all of us in this place, that when legislation is rushed through, we sometimes lose sight of the implications for individuals. The bureaucrats sometimes lose sight of the implications for individuals, and this case is a perfect example of that. The Minister has gone some way in addressing our concerns, as I said, by providing additional people to assist the transition. I hope that if we hear from the industry that those transitions are impossible or very difficult-especially if there are problems with being able to find a nursing home within reasonable distance of the original nursing home-the Minister may in fact be able to use some discretion or bring the issue back to the Senate before the end of the specified time.

Given all those concerns, I will not support the amendment but I call on the Minister to honour the promise that he made and to ensure that the Department uses all the resources it has to ensure that those 111 people are transferred to another nursing home with all the respect and dignity that they deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to answer one comment made by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate). Yes, there are certainly injustices. It is not fair to ask the proprietors to pick up additional amounts of money that they had not budgeted for. It is not fair on those who have decided to move and on those who have to pay the extra amount. It is not fair on either of those groups, but I think by far the greatest injustice now is on those who are caught.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the amendment we were discussing at length with regard to hardship provisions would have catered for many of the concerns that Senator Patterson has and would have given this Parliament the ability to put into place a procedure whereby, if the counsellors found that there was a major problem and hardship could be established-in other words, the elderly residents genuinely had no assets, no property that could be sold or no other means by which they could raise the money to stay-then the Minister could have allowed for them to stay and the cost to be met. I stress that the costs are very, very low when one looks at the overall health budget. I wonder what the costs are now going to be for the additional staff. Perhaps those moneys could have been better spent keeping the residents in the home.
Amendment negatived.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the case that Senator Patterson raised about the Bright District Hospital, I give an undertaking to examine that case and a response will be made available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a marathon, Madam Acting Deputy President. The National Food Authority Bill 1991, which we are debating this evening, has been introduced by the Government to implement an important series of reforms in the food regulatory system that were recommended at the Australian health Ministers conference in June last year and agreed to at the Special Premiers Conference in Brisbane in October 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: The major reforms agreed to at the Special Premiers Conference were that uniform food standards would apply across the nation and be regulated by a National Food Authority (NFA). This is instead of the current mishmash of Federal and State legislation that has resulted in standards differing across Australia. All one needs to do to get an idea of the bureaucratic nightmare that currently exists is to examine one of the charts showing the consultative process for making changes to the food standards code. I have one here that comes from the Australian Rural Times of 12 September 1990 and we see here a plethora of groups: the National Health and Medical Research Council; the National Food Standards Council; the Commonwealth and State government departments which include the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs; and the Department of Community Services and Health. I will not go on because it is getting late, but we had a plethora of groups that required consultation and agreement for a process for change to the food standards code.

The objective of these reforms is to achieve the substantial efficiencies in food production and distribution gained from uniform food standards throughout Australia. In addition it is also important for our export markets. Public health and safety remain the primary objectives in setting food standards. However, the National Food Authority will have regard to the promotion of consistency with standards applied to food in international trade, as I just mentioned. The aim of this objective is to seek the benefits to be gained from greater international harmonisation of food standards.

Some of the complaints that have been levelled at the present system include: a lack of uniform national standards; a lack of clear objectives; excessively complex and rigid standards; too long a period of time taken to vary standards; a lack of consistency in decisions; inability of the public to make submissions; administrative inefficiencies; and barriers to reducing inefficiencies which are an impediment to the development of our food export industry. These complaints were echoed by the Commonwealth Business Regulation Review Unit (BRRU) in its 1988 report on the effect of food industry regulations.

The food industry is a major component of a manufacturing sector comprising about one-fifth of manufacturing production. It is a major source of exports. Both exports and imports of processed foods are valued at about $1 billion, accounting for about 3 per cent of total trade. Exports comprise about 7 per cent of the processed food sector's turnover. The report stated that it would appear that Australia's share of the world market for processed foods is small and has been declining in recent years. The BRRU report said:

. . . there is a lack of definition of the objectives of food regulation. This, together with an apparent predisposition against allowing increased scope for market forces, contributes to complexity and duplication . . . Some regulations can be identified as having been designed to inhibit competition. More important are those regulations which . . . have the effect of protecting some foods from competition. These interventions needlessly add costs to the food industry, raise prices and tend to direct rivalry towards traditional rather than innovatory products.

Many of these concerns were also noted in the Industries Assistance Commission's 1989 report on the food processing and beverages industries. The following examples illustrate the problems that have plagued our food regulatory system.

The first relates to jam. It seems amazing to me that in this job one has to know about SAM, CAM-and now jam. The firm concerned decided that it wanted to make jam with more fruit and less sugar. But, according to Australia's food regulations, there is no such thing as high fruit, low sugar jam. The regulation sets out in great detail what jam is, and only products that meet that standard can be called jam. So if one makes something with more fruit and less sugar, that is up to those concerned, but they cannot call it jam. This would put them at some disadvantage in the market. Then if they ask for the standard to be reviewed, it takes a minimum of 15 months. In the meantime one's competitors will have prepared their defences.

Another product is orange juice. A new form of technology allowed the extraction of juice from the skin of an orange. The problem was that orange juice was defined in the food standards as coming from the inside of the orange. Therefore, orange juice extracted by the new, cheaper method could not be sold as orange juice. There was fear among Australian orange juice manufacturers that their market share would be lost to imports made by the new method. There are many other examples, and I will not bore the Senate with them tonight, but they include margarine, crumbed fish fillets, ice cream and bread.

These changes to the food regulatory system should ensure that these inadequacies will be removed from the system. The Bill sets up an independent statutory authority, the National Food Authority (NFA), and sets out its functions, powers and objectives. The coalition would normally oppose the establishment of another statutory authority, but in this instance we believe there are significant benefits to be gained through the setting up of an authority that will develop and set standards on a national basis.

An agreement between the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments will ensure the adoption of food standards that are recommended by the NFA and agreed to by a majority decision of the National Foods Standards Council. I understand that there will be provision in the agreement for a deviation from a standard by a State or Territory where exceptional environmental conditions apply in that State. Negotiations are under way for the inclusion of an additional clause allowing for the deviation in public health emergencies.

The objectives of the NFA in developing and varying standards are set out in the Bill. The NFA must have regard to the following objectives in descending priority order. These are the protection of public health and safety; the provision of adequate information relating to food to enable consumers to make informed choices; the promotion of fair trading in food; the promotion of trade in commerce in the food industry; and the promotion of consistency with standards applied to food in international trade.

The particular objective causing some concern, which was subject to a great deal of discussion in the Senate Community Affairs Committee hearing, is that of the promotion of consistency with standards applied to food in international trade. I have acknowledged the advantages that would accrue to Australia, if there were a greater level of consistency between Australian and international standards, but the concern is that Australian standards may fall.

With the possibility of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade being formalised in the future, Australia may have to fall in behind international standards, which may be lower. GATT has said it will adopt Codex standards, which are set by Codex Alimentarius Commission, a joint body of the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations and the World Health Organisation. There have been some differences between Codex standards and Australian standards, most notably in the area of pesticide residues. It is in this area that some groups are concerned that Codex standards will be adopted in Australia and that Australian standards may fall.

The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, Mr Staples, has given an assurance that Australian standards and quality will not fall. In the Committee hearing the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, also sought to give his assurance that Australian standards would not be lowered. He said that if our standards are higher than international standards:

. . . they must be observed by anybody trying to compete with our food producers in Australia. Any food consumed in the Australian market has to meet our standards, not the Codex standards . . . Our standards will not be varied simply to meet a Codex standard.

An important point to note is that the NFA has been set up to work primarily towards the harmonisation of domestic standards between Australian States and Territories. There are significant advantages to Australian food exporters in reaching a greater degree of consistency in international food standards. However, there is some uncertainty and concern that Australia's food standards may fall.

The Opposition accepts the Minister's assurances, but foreshadows that it will support an amendment to be moved by the Australian Democrats that will allow for the promotion of consistency with international standards and will ensure that Australian standards are not lowered.

This Bill includes matters that may be included in standards and in variations in the standards. New and varied standards may relate to any of the following: the composition of food; the production of food; packaging, storage and handling; labelling or advertising; the interpretation of other standards; and other public health matters relating to food.

I would be interested to hear from the Minister why the matter of the maximum or minimum amounts of additives that must or may be used in the preparation of food is singled out and included in the production of food. I would be concerned if the effect was to limit matters that could be considered in the production of food.

I wish to raise the matter of labelling. The Opposition believes it is important that the NFA consider the issue of country-of-origin labelling. The Opposition accepts an assurance from the Minister that he will direct the NFA to ensure the Authority maintains country-of-origin labelling provisions and that, as part of the review of standards, the provisions will be made consistent throughout the Food Standards Code.

The NFA is to be a body comprising five persons who are required to have experience or expertise in relevant fields, such as public health, food science, the food industry and consumer advocacy. They will be appointed by the Minister after he has consulted with the Australian Food Standards Committee.

The Bill sets a 12-month time limit for the NFA to make recommendations on new or varied standards. There is the ability to fast-track in certain circumstances and to grant additional time to the NFA to consider a new or varied standard. The coalition supports the time limits, particularly given the wholesale delays previously experienced in the food regulatory system. However, we question why the NFA is given 24 months to consider draft standards currently in the system instead of the 12 months for new applications. This seems to be unfair to applicants who have had their applications in for some time. I would be interested to hear from the Minister why there is this difference in the time limits, and would also seek an assurance from him that priority will be given to applications already in the system.

I was somewhat bemused when I was told that, although there was provision in the Bill to charge fees relating to the performance of the NFA's functions, there was no intention to do so. I would be interested to hear from the Minister why this provision exists if the intention to charge fees is not present.

I wish to raise the matter of the integration of food policy administration. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) comes under the control of the Department of Primary Industry and Energy. I understand that the role of the inspection of food imports will remain with AQIS, and AQIS will ensure that imported foods comply with the standards set by the NFA.

The National Health and Medical Research Council will continue to set standards for maximum residue limits for agricultural and veterinary chemicals in food, and these standards will be recommended to the NFA for consideration. The coalition hopes that the different departments and authorities can work efficiently together to ensure that the objectives of the proposal are met and that we do not end up with a problem because of the lack of communication. The legislation is trying to reduce the problem we have had because of a lack of communication between different groups and we have to ensure that it does not, through a creeping effect, occur again.

On behalf of the coalition, I will be moving an amendment to remove the provision that restricts the age of the Chairman of the National Food Authority to 65 years. The coalition believes that it is inappropriate to be excluded or removed from a position purely on the basis of age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Food Authority Bill 1991 establishes an Authority which will set and administer uniform food standards for all Australian States and Territories. It is to be an independent statutory body consisting of five people, including a full time Chair. Following agreements at the 1990 Premiers Conference, uniform food standards are to be achieved by the National Food Authority (NFA) presenting draft standards to the National Food Standards Council consisting of State, Territory and Commonwealth Ministers responsible for food standards. The majority decision will then be adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction of uniform standards is applauded and will be most beneficial to everyone involved in the food industry for the elimination of present complexity and duplication. However, some broad issues in this Bill give certain commodity groups some concern. The Bill requires the National Food Authority to pursue the objectives set out in the Bill. At the outset it needs to be said that Australia has always had a very high food standard. Our food products are also of very high quality. It is because of this high quality that Australian products command a premium price in world markets. It is also well known that the international quality market is an expanding market and Australia is well placed to retain its reputation in this market because of high quality products.

One of the new Authority's objectives will be to promote consistency with standards applied to food in international trade. International standards are based on the Codex Alimentarius Commission, a body of the United Nations. Therefore, these are the standards that the Authority will be aiming to coordinate with. Negotiations in the current Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) are also aimed at these Codex standards being adopted as the basis of national standards.

The issue of the harmonisation of national and international standards has been subject to much public debate in the United States of America (USA), with consumers and environmentalists being concerned that lower standards, particularly in relation to pesticides, will lead to lower quality food and increased environmental damage. In Australia, the Australian Consumers Association, meat inspectors and the Victorian Farmers Federation have joined forces over the common concern of lower standards as a result of this express Authority objective.

There is concern that the Government, in rushing through this legislation, is imposing harmonisation and consequent lower standards on the Australian producer and consumer. Lower quality does mean lower cost for imported food products. Australian farmers and producers are losing large amounts of the market share from imported foodstuffs, which amounted to $2.134 billion last year. There are definite examples of Australian standards being lowered to allow trade to occur, such as with Chinese peanuts and chemical levels in seaweed. Furthermore, there is the ever present unfair trading situation with subsidised imports from the European Community (EC), the US and Thailand which is a continual burden for primary producers.

The trend with Australian farming has been to reduce the use of pesticides, yet compared to the Australian standards set by the National Health and Medical Research Council, Codex standards for the maximum residue limits for pesticide residues are lower in the majority of cases. For example, the Codex standard for 2,4,5,T for apricots and sugar is 25 times higher than the Australian standards. Fenthion in pigs and sheep is 10 times higher than the Australian standards. If standards were harmonised, imported goods would also be allowed in with these levels. This area of lower standards is where there is most concern at the Government's action in this Bill.

The objective given to the new Authority is criticised because the Government has introduced harmonisation into the Australian standards by giving it to this Authority without the opportunity for public debate. The Government has given away another bargaining tool at the GATT Round by accepting the adoption of international standards when, overall, EC export subsidies remain unresolved and dreadfully damaging to our farmers. Any lowering of quality creates an unfair trading situation between lower quality imports and our high quality products. If we were to lower our quality, untold damage would be done to our products-both to the consumer and to the export customer-and it would allow a further flood of imported products.

The Bill has been considered by a Senate committee and this exact question on harmonisation was put to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate. The Minister has pointed out that harmonisation is on a descending list of objectives that the Authority has to be guided by. Nevertheless, it is in the Bill and therefore the National Food Authority has to consider this requirement.

Whilst the argument is put that it is good for our export trade to comply with international standards, Australia already has exceedingly high standards and wins market share because of these high standards. The main problem lies with the damage done to our food production by cheaper imports and the fact that the Australian consumer will have to accept lower quality food. The Minister has said that the function of the National Food Authority is to determine standards for the consumption of all food in Australia. The Minister gave assurances to both the House of Representatives and a Senate committee that the National Food Authority standards would apply to all food consumed in Australia and that, despite the harmonisation objectives, Australian standards would not be lowered.

It seems that the Minister is trying to have two bob each way-we either have an NFA standard or a Codex standard; we cannot have a little bit of both. The Minister's assurances are appreciated-I know that Senator Tate is a man of integrity-but if assurances are to be given there seems to be no reason why these exact points could not have been incorporated in the Bill. Following the Minister's assurances, it is comforting that all high Australian standards set by the National Food Authority will be applied to imported food also. That is very important because we cannot have Australian processors, who are manufacturing at a very high standard which costs more money, and then allow imported food to come in under Codex standards. We would be playing on a very unlevel playing field if we allowed that to happen. I hope the Minister will pick up on that point in his response to the second reading debate.

If Australian standards are also applied to imported food, this will mean that all of the factors that the National Food Authority has to consider in setting standards will also apply to imported foods. These include maximum amounts of contaminants, residues, amounts of additives, storage, handling, labelling requirements, and any other health matters prescribed. The Minister has further assured us that no Australian standard will be lowered because of harmonisation. The Australian farmer is always trying to improve on quality and reduce the use of pesticides. Therefore, competing against lower quality products is becoming an increasingly real threat to the survival of many vegetable growers. Today I had occasion to tell the Senate about the increasing level of imported foodstuffs coming into Australia and how Edgell in Brisbane was forced to drop its price to Queensland pea growers by 12 per cent because of competition from subsidised imports.

Consumers, producers and industry workers have further concerns about other aspects of the Bill and I make mention of them now. There is a concern that the promotion of food quality is not part of the Authority's role and that there should be a demonstrated technological need before any new food component, process or additive is introduced onto the Australian market. There is also concern that public hearings will be held only at the discretion of the Authority and that this may restrict certain information on public health and safety being revealed to the public.

Another very important area for the National Food Authority is that it may make standards for the labelling of food. We were told at a Senate committee hearing that under this Bill the Authority may decide in some instances to include country of origin on the label if it feels it is consistent with its objectives, but in other areas it might decide that it is not a relevant issue and will not include that in the labelling of a particular food. That certainly rings warning bells to me.

I understand that at present all imported food must be labelled with the country of origin. To lessen any of those standards would be 100 per cent in opposition to what Senator Tate has said on a number of occasions in this Senate. He has told us that consumers deserve to have the right to know what product they are buying and in what country it is sourced. I note that Senator Tate nods his heads in affirmation. We are also told that the situation under present legislation is that food has to be labelled, and I have covered that.

Country of origin labelling affects the amount of imported food sold. In fact, it is my estimation that, if we had reasonable country of origin labelling, we would decrease imports by around 20 per cent. Most people will buy Australian products if they can see that they are processed in Australia. Labelling on imported food is important information to give to the consumer.

I point out that the possibility that Australian standards may be lowered because of harmonisation is a concern, a fact that may in turn affect the quality of Australia's high quality food products and high quality exports. In conclusion, I believe that the setting up of a National Food Authority to set uniform standards, which is the main purpose of this Bill, is welcomed in that it will provide many overall benefits for all aspects of the food industry. It is to be hoped that the Minister's assurance on the Australian standards will always form part of the operations of the Authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —By comparison with the rest of the world, Australian consumers enjoy a wide variety of very high quality food.
