A national food authority which will develop and implement a uniform set of food standards across the country can only benefit Australian consumers by ensuring that our food and any imported food meet the highest possible standards. A national body to overhaul and administer food standards is long overdue. A coordinated national approach is more sensible and efficient than eight States and Territories going their own separate ways on food regulations, and I congratulate the States for ceding some of their powers in this area. The current process of developing standards is lengthy and complex, and any moves to streamline this procedure are welcome. The opportunity for public input into the setting of standards is also welcomed. However, the Australian Democrats are not convinced that the National Food Authority Bill in its present form will satisfy the high expectations that have been set for it.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian consumers, and indeed consumers worldwide, are becoming increasingly sophisticated. We demand to know, and have a right to know, a lot more about the food we eat, including how many additives it contains, whether there is a need for these additives and preservatives, the levels of pesticides or contaminants, and whether our food comes from Australian producers or foreign ones. We need to ensure that our high standards are not compromised or lowered by pressures from our trading partners, and we need to ensure that Australia does not become a dumping ground for inferior imported products.

Research in January this year by the Pratt research group in Sydney found that Australian consumers were noticeably less critical of the quality of most Australian products than they had been a few years previously. In some categories, such as primary produce, consumers often regarded Australian products as being superior. The survey also found that consumer support for many domestic primary produce industries had strengthened, particularly when these industries were adversely affected by competitive imports, such as the difficulties we saw facing citrus growers in competing with imported juice concentrates.

The study concluded that along with the renewed interest in buying Australian made products has come a greater tendency for the consumer to read product packaging to determine country of origin. This raises two vital issues that the National Food Authority Bill 1991 appears to ignore: first, the need for adequate country of origin labelling that will apply across the board to all food and, secondly, the often poorer quality of imported food.

The Democrats will be moving amendments to widen the powers of the Authority and give it clear objectives in relation to imported food. The Minister in the other place stressed the importance of the food industry to Australia. It is a major contributor to our health and well-being by providing us with safe and nutritious food and it employs nearly 200,000 people. It accounts for $30 billion a year in manufacturing turnover and exports amount to $8 1/2 billion a year-over 20 per cent of total Australian exports. Yet foreign dumping of foods is costing the Australian industry millions of dollars and threatening thousands of jobs, as alluded to by previous speakers.

One of Australia's most efficient manufacturers, the canned fruit industry, has already lost 15 per cent of its retail market to cheaper dumped imports. Imports of canned peaches rose by more than 200 per cent last year. These products, often of inferior quality, are heavily subsidised and sold here at ridiculously low prices against which Australian manufacturers cannot even hope to compete. This not only leads to a loss of profits to Australian companies but also hits manufacturing workers and primary producers hard. We have heard a great deal about this over the last year that I have been in the Senate.

Only recently I read of yet another pineapple farmer in Queensland who has been forced to stop growing pineapples because he cannot compete with the cheaper imported products. This farmer pointed out that it is very hard to be efficient when he is paying decent wages at $9 per hour but overseas labour costs are less than $1 per hour. We have all heard the stories, I am sure, about imported Chinese peanuts and Japanese seaweed, which both contain high levels of chemical contamination and are not fit to be sold in many countries, yet which are accepted by Australia.

What is perhaps worse is that, when Australian consumers buy items such as these peanuts, they do not know they are buying the Chinese variety, as they may have been packed in Australia and therefore qualify as being `made in Australia'. The same goes for orange juice. Because it has Australian water in it, it is deemed to be a product of Australia. I think it is appalling that Australian consumers, who have already demonstrated a willingness to buy Australian-made products because of their superiority quality, and often as a protest against foreign dumping, do not know or are not able to tell whether they are getting the real thing because of inadequate labelling requirements. It is also appalling that Australian consumers do not know whether they are buying products that may not meet Australian standards and may contain high levels of pesticide or known carcinogens, and it is irresponsible of the Government to let this situation continue.

Despite many promises that we will get proper country of origin labelling, the action we have seen has resulted in the legislation before us tonight. The Democrats accept the written assurance of the Minister that he will direct the National Food Authority to ensure that it maintains country of origin labelling provisions. We were going to move an amendment to incorporate this as one of the Authority's functions.

It is claimed that the National Food Authority will help the Australian food industry achieve its full export potential by promoting consistency between domestic and international food standards. Australian producers are encouraged to meet standards that are consistent with overseas requirements. As I mentioned at the outset of my speech, Australia has very high food standards compared with many other countries; it is a feature of our international marketing. Quality is high on the international consumer agenda. This Bill as it is currently worded implies that our high standards could be compromised or lowered to meet the standards of our trading partners.

The proposals considered under the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade suggest that international standards are being promoted as the universal standard and that countries such as Australia may be prevented from implementing higher standards under threat of sanctions which might be applied under GATT. The rights of consumers in matters of public health and safety should not be compromised because of commercial considerations.

There is the very real danger, as other speakers have said this evening, that Australian standards will be watered down to meet lower international standards. We have seen already evidence of this happening, and I refer again to the example of Japanese seaweed. This import was at first rejected because of high levels of arsenic. However, following pressure from certain quarters, a new standard was set and the seaweed was allowed entry. This watering down of our standards would not only be disastrous for Australian consumers, farmers, producers and manufacturers, but it would also undermine our export potential, the very thing the Government is trying to improve with the establishment of the National Food Authority.

The Australian Democrats will be moving amendments to ensure that Australia's high standards will not be compromised or bartered for an increase in trade. The National Food Authority will develop policies in relation to imported food, yet the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service will implement these policies, and other Government departments will test imported food. Ideally, if we are to have uniform national food standards for both domestic and imported food, all these functions should eventually come under the control of the National Food Authority.

There are other aspects of this Bill that the Australian Democrats believe will lead to a watering down of standards and a loss of consumer protection. The Bill sets out a series of objectives that the National Food Authority is to follow when setting or developing standards. These objectives, when compared with the objectives of current standard setting bodies, such as the National Health and Medical Research Council, appear to have been considerably weakened. The promotion of food quality is not one of the Authority's objectives. In fact, food is defined in the Bill as `any substance whether or not it is fit for human consumption'.

In its long history of food regulation, beginning with the pure food Act back in 1907, Australia has always had the primary objective of keeping our food pure. This means that there has had to be a technological need for any additives or preservatives before they were allowed to be included in a product. Australia differs from other countries, such as America, in that their food can have anything in it as long as it is not prohibited. It is this basic difference that I believe has allowed us to enjoy and export high quality food without unnecessary additives and chemical treatments that may have caused public concern overseas.

In its present form, the National Food Authority will not have this requirement to demonstrate a technological need, yet in February this year at a world food conference in Rome Australia gave a public commitment that technological need had to be a food standard requirement. Australia's official position on this appears to have changed, and perhaps the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) in his comments could tell me why. Technological need is also a requirement under the international standard body, Codex Alimentaris Commission, the very body with which Australia is keen to harmonise its standards.

The Authority has also dropped objectives designed to promote food quality and to prevent deception and fraud. Without these objectives, I believe that our food could end up containing a whole new range of artificial colours, sweeteners and preservatives that, while benefiting the big manufacturers, will certainly not benefit consumers who are looking for less of these in their foods. These cheaper additives could be used purely for cosmetic purposes, to jazz up the appearance, taste or texture of a product without any concern for the technical need or health effects on a population that could be exposed to more and more substances in a wider range of products.

The use of additives for cosmetic purposes could also increase the possibility of deception or fraud. Prevention of this is a vital objective in terms of consumer protection and the rights of consumers to know exactly what they are getting in a product. Artificial colours are used extensively in food production, and these foods are labelled accordingly so that a consumer can check whether that product is artificially coloured.

It is generally agreed that it is undesirable to artificially colour primary produce, and not many consumers would suspect fresh food of being artificially coloured, but consumers are being deceived. South Australian prawns are artificially coloured to look like eastern prawns. As prawns are not easy things to stick a label on, consumers often are not aware of this deceptive practice, and I am sure that producers and retailers would like to keep it that way. If consumers were aware, some of them probably would not buy these prawns. Surely at the very least, consumers with this sort of interest have a right to know that this product does contain artificial colour.

There are many other examples. Wine companies using oak chip essence to counterfeit the qualities of wine matured in oak casks is just one of them. So, consumers are concerned about the long term effects of those additives on their health. While something might have been found safe in the 1980s, it might be proven or suspected of causing health problems in the 1990s or beyond.

Consumers are also concerned about adverse health effects from combinations of these additives. More and more of the additives previously considered safe are being found to cause health problems such as asthma, allergic reactions and hyperactivity. It is no wonder that a growing number of community groups, such as Parents For Safe Food, are forming to try to educate the community and provide the information that many manufacturers refuse to supply under the guise that this information is commercially confidential. The pressures of competition combined with rapidly advancing technology can easily persuade manufacturers that there are cheaper and easier ways to make a product. That is why it is of utmost importance that objectives relating to technological need, the promotion of food quality and the prevention of deception and fraud be spelt out in this legislation.

The Australian Democrats have a number of other concerns in relation to the fast tracking of standards and the lack of consumer representation within the structure of the Authority. Although it is an admirable ideal to try to get standards set up within 12 months, as there have been quite valid concerns from some manufacturers who have spent more than three years trying to get a product on the market, there are also dangers with this sort of time deadline. A prescribed time limit fails to take into account the varying complexity of food standards and there is no guarantee that the National Food Authority will always have the resources to adequately complete the evaluation within the time deadline. There is also the danger that public servants will be working primarily to meet a deadline rather than to meet the primary objectives of safety and consumer protection. The Bill allows for the time deadline to be reduced even further by regulation. I think that one way around this possible danger would be to ensure that one permanent member of the National Food Authority comes from a background of consumer rights and policy. We will be moving an amendment to that effect. That way at least, one person at the top of the hierarchy would be looking out for the consumers' interests.

It is a possibility that the National Food Authority, knowingly or not, could be stacked with people from backgrounds in public administration and food science. These people often are not even aware of the consumers' viewpoint. The food irradiation debate is a good example of this. The food processing industry and the scientists considered irradiation safe, and I do not think it ever occurred to them that consumers would object to the process. But we all know what happened when consumers did find out about this proposal, and we know that consumer pressure won out on this issue.

The National Food Authority's ability to hold public hearings is to be commended, as it will give consumers and interested parties direct input into the setting of standards; however, the Democrats are concerned about the restrictions on the publication of evidence given at these hearings and of public access to the hearings.

Closed hearings should be the exception and not the norm, and restrictions on disclosure need to be limited to truly commercially confidential information. Information relating to matters of public health and safety should not be kept from the public. Current industry practice classifies public health and safety information, such as amounts of pesticides and other toxicological data, as commercially confidential. This data, which is part of the standard setting process, is of legitimate scientific and public interest and should not, we believe, be kept secret.

We have the opportunity to end this practice and the Democrats will move amendments to deal with this matter. With this Bill we have the opportunity to bring about a number of reforms in the way our standards are formulated and the way that those standards will apply not just to all food across Australia but to all imported food as well. Because the good supply of quality food is one of our basic needs and rights, and because we are a lot more fortunate than many other people in this respect, it is vitally important that the National Food Authority be given clear objectives, functions and powers to ensure this. Consumers need to be protected from the large multi-national companies that want to put anything and everything in our food and want to replace natural ingredients with cheaper artificial counterparts.

I would like to conclude with an example of what could happen to a food that is close to some of our hearts-chocolate. It may not be a particularly nutritious food-although some advertisers would claim the opposite-but we still expect a certain level of quality in the product. Some countries sell chocolate that does not even contain cocoa or cocoa butter. Because these countries have virtually no food standards, their chocolate is made from artificial colouring, artificial chocolate flavouring and sugar substitutes, yet it is allowed to be sold as the real thing. Consumers have no way of telling the artificial product from the real one-until, I presume, they taste it.

If we water down our standards-and there are many aspects of the Bill before us that do this-we open the way not only for a flood of cheap imports but also for a dramatic fall in the quality of Australian products as reputable manufacturers are forced to use cheaper artificial ingredients. While large corporations that control food both in Australia and on the international market may welcome this weakening of standards, I do not believe that Australian consumers want to head down that road-they are much more sophisticated than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the National Food Authority Bill 1991. As senators have said, Australia has a very long and proud record in relation to food legislation. In fact, it was probably the first country in the world to enact pure-food legislation. So, the Senate is certainly standing with a very long and proud tradition in that regard while considering this Bill tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been emphasised by various senators, there is no doubt that the food processing industry, in particular, is very important to Australians. Of course, it is not only a major contributor to our health and well-being through the production of safe and nutritious food, it also employs many Australians. It represents the largest sector of our manufacturing industries-the food processing and beverage industries-and accounts for approximately 20 per cent, or in excess of $30 billion per year, of manufacturing turnover and employs some 173,000 people.

Senators will know that, as a major exporter of food, Australia exports $8.5 billion worth of food a year, which is over 20 per cent of total Australian exports. Many of those are low value added products. Of course, we need to process our food and put it onto the international market to obtain more revenue for Australia, and that ought to be undertaken. There is great potential, certainly in the Asian region, and we ought to pursue most vigorously those markets for value added and processed food.

The basic principles of the reforms that are being proposed tonight are to consolidate responsibility for domestic food standards development with the minimum number of decision making layers; to ensure uniformity between jurisdictions; to establish objectives for food standards; to promote coordination of domestic and international food standards; to ensure an open and publicly accountable arrangement which would allow input by interested parties and provide for public hearings, where appropriate; and, importantly, to retain the involvement of the States and Territories in standards development and administration.

The formal agreement between all heads of government in relation to the principles of this Bill to be adopted by the Commonwealth States and Territories, will be a most important step in the obtaining and retaining of the involvement of the States and Territories in this important matter. As is known to honourable senators, under the revised agreement presently being considered by the States and Territories, they will adopt food standards that have been recommended by the National Food Authority and agreed to by the National Food Standards Council by a majority decision. Anyway, that is the general principle on which we will be operating.

Several matters have been raised by honourable senators in the course of the second reading debate, and I suppose the international harmonisation question is the one that has attracted most interest here and in Friday's committee consideration. I simply repeat what I said at that committee and in Question Time in the Senate that, when one looks at the Bill, one sees that there are five objectives to which the National Food Authority has to have regard in setting its food standards.

They are: protection of public health and safety; provision of adequate information to enable consumers to make informed choices; promotion of fair trading in food; promotion of trade and commerce in the food industry; and, finally-and this is in descending order of priority-promotion of consistency with international food standards. It is the lowest priority matter to be taken into consideration by the National Food Authority when setting a standard. That means very clearly that there will be no harmonisation if such action would create a public health or safety risk.

Senator Kernot expressed a plea that the standard of public health and safety should not be compromised in the interests of international commercial interests-or an expression to that effect. Of course, that is precisely the way in which this particular clause in the Bill is structured-that public health and safety is the absolutely dominant concern. It has the first and overriding paramount priority in relation to the various criteria which the National Food Authority has to take into account.

If consistency with an international standard would do damage to the public health and safety criteria, as applied to particular food, then the international harmonisation has to be rejected in favour of the more stringent Australian standard securing greater public health and safety. For that matter, of course, if harmonisation would in some way detract from the promotion of fair trading in food, or the provision of adequate information to enable consumers to make informed choices, once again that harmonisation principle would have to be jettisoned in favour of the criterion which has a higher priority.

The main international body which develops food standards is the Codex Alimentarius Commission, a joint World Health Organisation-Food and Agriculture Organisation body in which Australia plays an active role. It is true that Australia currently adopts many Codex standards, as in most developed and even developing countries. But there are also many Codex provisions which Australia does not adopt. It is true-and I conceded and discussed this in the Friday committee-that under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), there will be more pressure to harmonise with Codex standards. But once again, within GATT, as within this Bill, any departure by Australia from the Codex standard which might be challenged by a country exporting to Australia, could be met with a defence if Australia could point to proper scientific reasons for the more stringent standard. Once again, as I say, within the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade process, as within this Bill, it is recognised that health and safety have absolutely paramount priority.

Senator Boswell was concerned about the application of the National Food Authority Bill to imported food. I know that he has requested that I make a statement on this matter, and I would like to do so. He required an explanation as to the absence of any specific reference to imported foods in the National Food Authority Bill. As I said to the committee on Friday, and have repeated, all food to be consumed in Australia-whether grown or processed here in the marketplace from Australian farmers, orchardists, fisher persons or others, or imported into Australia-has to conform to the National Food Authority standard. The words in the Bill's long title are:
A BILL FOR An Act to establish a National Food Authority with functions relating to the development of food standards, and for related purposes.

It needs to be clearly understood that the food standards developed by the National Food Authority are not given any legal effect by the Bill. It merely provides a legislative control procedure whereby food standards can be recommended to a council of Ministers representing all the Crown jurisdictions in Australia.

Food standards are given legal effect under State and Territory food legislation. Uniformity of food standards is dependent on State and Territory agreement to enact, whether by reference or otherwise, all decisions on food standards made by that ministerial council. I have already referred to the agreement that is being constructed to do that.

State and Territory food Acts apply to all food for sale, and as such all food for sale, including all imported food, is caught by the requirements of the food standards. There is thus no need for the Bill itself to specifically refer to imported foods, for the standards nevertheless apply to such food for sale in Australia. I just wish to put that on the record to assist Senator Boswell in dealing with his question in that regard.

I believe that I can deal with most other matters as they come up in the committee stage. The purpose of clause 71-that is, the 24 months clause-is to ensure that the entire backlog of food standards work is cleared within two years. I believe Senator Patterson raised this. That does not mean that all new applications will be given priority over matters already in the system. The Authority will be reviewing all applications before it, including those inherited from the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) and will allocate its priorities according to its judgment of the relative importance of all the applications.

Persons with an interest in a matter submitted to the NHMRC could always approach the Authority seeking priority consideration. Should they not be satisfied with the result, it will be open to them to withdraw the application and resubmit it to the Authority under the new scheme, thereby attracting the shorter timeframe. As I have said, I believe I can deal with other matters during the course of the committee stage consideration of this Bill, and I commend the second reading to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has asked me to read a statement. I would like to do it before 12.00 midnight, otherwise the words `today' and `yesterday' will not have the same meaning.

INTERJECT.PARA: After Question Time today Senator Parer raised a matter regarding the Hansard report of yesterday's proceedings. Senator Parer pointed out that Hansard had not reproduced correctly a document which he incorporated yesterday, in which lines had been drawn through certain words.

The President has been informed by the Secretary to the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff that when the document was being prepared for incorporation it was wrongly assumed that the words ruled out were to be omitted. This mistake should have been detected during subsequent editorial and checking processes but was not.
The correct version of the incorporation will appear as an erratum at the beginning of the Hansard of today's proceedings. The correct version will appear in the Weekly Hansard.

The President would like to take this opportunity to remind honourable senators that the Daily Hansard is a proof copy in which mistakes will occasionally occur, despite the dedicated efforts of the reporting and production staff and the rigorous and continuing checking processes in place in Hansard. The official report of proceedings is, of course, the Weekly Hansard.

Honourable senators would be aware that the Daily Hansard is produced under considerable time pressures. As an example of the service given to the Parliament, the Senate on Tuesday this week sat until 3.03 Wednesday morning. Hansard was available shortly after 9 o'clock the same morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 3, page 2, line 22, definition of `confidential commercial information', omit the definition, insert the following definition: `` `confidential commercial information', in relation to food, means a trade secret relating to food;''.
The Australian Democrats in this amendment are seeking to delete the definition of `confidential commercial information' in clause 3 of this National Food Authority Bill 1991, which states:
(b) any other information relating to food that has a commercial value that would be, or could reasonably be expected to be, destroyed or diminished if the information were disclosed.

We think it is too broad a definition because it could cover virtually anything, including public health and safety information. Current industry practice classifies public health and safety information, such as amounts of pesticides and other toxicological data, as commercially confidential.

As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, this data, which is part of the standard-setting process, is of legitimate scientific and public interest and should not be kept secret. Deleting this clause gives us an opportunity to end this practice. Companies applying for variations of standards should be required to make public the safety information on which they wish the public to accept that their products or processes are safe.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept this amendment. I put it very strongly that the amendment would confine to trade secrets the protection given in the Act to confidential commercial information. In order to carry out its work, the National Food Authority will need access to information such as market surveys carried out by companies which, while not trade secrets, clearly have commercial value. Senator Patterson, I am trying to persuade you here.
—I am listening.

—Good. Companies would be reluctant to provide such information if confidentiality cannot be guaranteed. That is the reason why the clause is drafted in the way it is. We simply feel that the Authority needs access to more than trade secrets which are nevertheless matters of commercial value.
—Can I ask the Minister: why are pesticide levels confidential?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In that simple form, I am advised that that is not a correct way to put the situation. I am told that the standard is obviously a public matter. The formulation of the product is confidential to the processor, the manufacturer, but the safety assessments made by what will now be the National Food Authority-previously the National Health and Medical Research Council-are available under the Freedom of Information Act.
—So consumers have to go to a considerable amount of trouble to find it out, but they can find it out eventually?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am giving an assurance that what is now available under the Freedom of Information Act will still be available under the Act in relation to the operations of the National Food Authority. As I say, that is a process which the Parliament has thought an appropriate way to have access to such information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister called on me to listen to what he had to say. I was of the opinion, or I was led to believe, that the Government would be supporting this amendment. The Opposition's initial inclination was not to support the amendment. Given the fact that we were advised that the Government was going to support it, we presumed that there was good reason for that. I think the Minister's argument has been sufficient for me to say that it was not the Opposition's original intention to do so, and we originally advised the Australian Democrats of that. On the suggestion that the Government was going to agree to the amendment, we had in fact indicated to the Democrats that we were going to support it but, as the information has either changed or is different, the Opposition will not be supporting that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Friday, 21 June 1991

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Kernot be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be proceeding with amendment No. 2 standing in our name because of the written assurance that the Minister has given us that he will give a direction to the National Food Authority to ensure that the Authority maintains country of origin labelling provisions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the assurance given by the Minister, the Government does not see any point in supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated that I was not moving the amendment. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Clause 9, page 6, paragraph (d), line 32, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:
``(d) any information about food including labelling, promotion and advertising;''.

We feel that the current definition in the Bill, which relates only to labelling and advertising, is too restrictive, and although there is a fine line between promotion and advertising we think that they are still two separate issues and should both be included.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform the Committee that the Government can accept this particular amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports this amendment, which includes matters related to the setting of new or varied standards, a reference to the promotion of food.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. Clause 10, page 6, line 42, after ``informed choices'', add ``and prevent fraud and deception''.

A lot has been said about retaining original objectives and not lowering consumer protection. The Australian Democrats think that a number of the current objectives used when assessing a food standard have not been included in the National Food Authority Bill, and by this amendment and our amendment No. 5 we are seeking to put some of those objectives back in.

The first one is the prevention of deception and fraud, which is a criterion under the requirements of the present State food Acts. I have a copy of the New South Wales food Act here. The Democrats think that this criterion should be included in the National Food Authority's objectives. In my speech in the second reading debate I referred by way of example to the colouring of prawns. The Government has argued previously that prevention of deception and fraud is covered by other areas of the legislation. I accept that, but I do not think it is enough. If it is the Government's aim to prevent deception and fraud, I do not think it should have a problem with stating this outright as one of the Authority's objectives. This amendment will let the Authority determine whether a standard or a product could be considered deceptive before it is released rather than having the current situation where the consumer has to apply to the Authority or to the Trade Practices Commission to investigate whether it is deceptive.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government can accept this amendment, though I must say that I find it surplus. If one is to promote fair trading in food, quite clearly, fair trading cannot permit any practices that amount to fraud and deception. I believe that the amendment is probably unnecessary but, rather than having a lengthy argument, the Government can accept this addition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports this amendment as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5. Clause 10, page 7, paragraph (e), line 3, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:
``(e) the promotion of consistency between domestic and international food standards where these are at variance, providing it does not lower the Australian standard.''

This is the most important amendment, I think, to ensure that Australia does not end up lowering its high food standards in return for an increase in trade in certain commodities. We think that the onus should be on importers to live up to our already high standards and that we should not be pressured into lowering our standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept this amendment. I understand that it was put to the Australian Democrats that they might care to redraft it, to make it clear that harmonisation should not occur where to introduce it would lower Australian standards in respect of public health and safety. That would give us a very clear and definitive criterion against which to work and it would be the issue, I believe, of major concern to all Senators and indeed to the general Australian community. I see that Senator Boswell is back in the chamber. I know that it is his primary concern that nothing should be done by way of harmonisation that would incorporate into the Australian marketplace a standard which could lead to a lesser health and safety standard being observed.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Kernot is not prepared to accept that further reference to that criterion, I am afraid that the Government will have to reject this amendment, simply because it is too vague and very difficult to put down in the Bill. As I say, I believe that public health and safety is the absolutely paramount and overriding concern. If the Senate wished to emphasise its belief that that should never be put in jeopardy, the Government could accept such an amendment. However, as it is presently drafted, it is just too broad and vague.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the amendment. We have had a number of assurances in the committee discussions on this Bill that the institution of this legislation will not lower the Australian standards, and I think this provision just puts into legislation that assurance.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Kernot) agreed to:
6. Clause 36, page 17, subclause (1), line 29, after ``Gazette'', insert ``and in a newspaper circulating in each State or Territory''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 7. Clause 40, page 21, paragraphs (c) and (d), line 1, omit the paragraphs, substitute the following paragraphs:

(d) 2 other members; and
(e) such other members, if any, as are appointed for a special purpose.''.

— I would just like to thank the Government for accepting our inclusion of a consumer representative as a permanent representative of the Authority. We appreciate that, and I think Australian consumers will as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

TALK.START.PARA: —I have succumbed yet again.

—I think it is very important that we record that we now have a second occasion on which the Minister has succumbed to my ageless charms. Hopefully, the Minister and I together will systematically amend the legislation and remove ages clauses from it. Since we are about the same age, one day when we are over 65, hopefully, we might be able to serve on some of these committees.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON COMMUNITY STANDARDS RELEVANT TO THE SUPPLY OF SERVICES UTILISING TELECOMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGIES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies, be appointed to inquire into and report on the following matters:

(a) whether a code of conduct reflecting community standards should be observed by providers and carriers of commercial recorded, information or entertainment services utilising telecommunications technologies and if so, its content, monitoring and enforcement;

(b) whether it is appropriate to control the provision of certain commercial recorded, information or entertainment services via networks utilising telecommunications technologies, or to control access to such services, or both, and, if so, how control would best be achieved;
(c) the suitability of the continued provision of certain commercial recorded, information or entertainment services carried by Telecom Australia including 0055 and Discovery Services; and
(d) whether the content of pay TV, were such a service to be introduced, should include material classified under the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations in the `R' or `X' categories,

I and the Committee consider the existing regulatory arrangements, at both State and Commonwealth levels, used to regulate all film, video, literature and other publications, and to determine whether similar arrangements are applicable to regulating the provision of commercial recorded, information or entertainment services via networks utilising telecommunications technologies.
(2) That the committee consist of eight Senators, as follows:
(e) four to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(f) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(g) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats; and
(h) one independent Senator.
(3) That the committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.

(4) That the chairman be appointed by and from the members of the committee, and that the deputy chairman be appointed in a similar manner from the non-government members of the committee, and that the deputy chairman so appointed act as chairman of the committee at any time when there is no chairman or the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee.

(5) That the committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(6) That the committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(7) That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the President.
(8) That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(9) That the committee report to the Senate on or before the first sitting day in October 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Committee reported progress on this Bill, it was considering an amendment which had been brought forward by Senator Patterson in Committee of the Whole and which had the effect of requiring a report from the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General to be made to both Houses of Parliament on the estimated savings contained in the financial impact statement in the explanatory memorandum to the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991. It asked that in that report there should be not only an estimate of the savings but also an evaluation of whether a less intrusive proposal for eligibility checking might be devised which could achieve the same sorts of savings.

SPEECH.PARA: I regarded that particular clause as then drafted as being inadequate for what was sought to be achieved. Even if it had been adequate, as it probably now is, as it is drafted a little more stringently, I find the proposal a peculiar one, given that there had already been amendments accepted in the Committee of the Whole in relation to the commencement date of this legislation which was put in terms of a particular calendar date or the day after which privacy guidelines issued by the Privacy Commissioner had been approved by both Houses of Parliament, whichever was the later.

I see now that a redraft of that particular clause has occurred and put in relation to amendment 1 moved by the Opposition. I would be interested to hear if it is now circulated throughout the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw the amendment to clause 2 which was standing in my name prior to the adjournment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 2, page 2, omit subclause (6), substitute the following subclause:
``(6) Paragraph 7(a), subsections 10(2) and (3), sections 11 and 12 and paragraphs 15(c) and (i) come into effect on:
(a) 1 July 1992; or
(b) the day after guidelines issued under section 135AA of the National Health Act 1953 have been approved in the same form by both Houses of Parliament; or

(c) the day after a joint inquiry of the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General has reported to both Houses of Parliament that the estimated savings contained in the financial impact statement in the explanatory memorandum to the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991 are realistic estimates and that equivalent savings could not be obtained through the use of alternative eligibility checking systems which are no more intrusive than the eligibility checking proposal contained in the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Act 1991;
whichever is the later.''.

If the Department has carried out a thorough analysis of preparation for the implementation of this legislation, this process should be able to be undertaken with relative speed. We have not been convinced by the evidence-and I think the Minister even hinted that he had some doubt, that the $40m gross savings was a bit sloppy and a bit rubbery. If that research has been done appropriately, it should not take long to convince either the Auditor-General or the Department of Finance that this is a cost efficient way and the best way of carrying out this process.

I put on public record tonight that I do not really think that the way to operate is by saying to people, `If you have this amendment, then this is what will happen. If you go ahead and put forward this amendment, we will tell the pharmacists that it is your fault that there will be the introduction of eligibility checking immediately based on your suggestion'.

Let me make it very clear to the Minister, to the advisers to Senator Staples and to the Health Insurance Commission that I have not suggested that eligibility checking should be used, using the current social security card. Those cards do not have integrity. A person can hold a current social security card and not be a current concessionary beneficiary. I have not suggested that. If people suggest that they will tell the pharmacists that they are now going to get them to check social security cards because that is what Senator Patterson suggested, the threats fell not on deaf ears-because I listened-but I will not be threatened. I will not have people tell me or my staff that the Health Insurance Commission will now march out.

Yes, one of the Minister's advisers might look a little puzzled. The Minister commented about a puzzled look on the face of one of my advisers. It was not by the person who is looking puzzled, but my staff were told by two people that this is what would happen. I will not accept that that is a legitimate and proper way to go about doing business. I will not accept that my staff should be treated in that way. I do not think it is the way that people should conduct themselves.

I put on the public record that what I said-and I will say it clearly-was that there may be alternative methods. One of them might be to use an improved social security card. That is not just a suggestion I have made; it is a suggestion that has been made by the Privacy Commissioner. The Pharmacy Guild, itself, said that there could be better ways of getting pharmacists to check eligibility. It is not some idea that I dreamed up in my head, and it is not an idea that can be implemented tomorrow.

If the Department tells pharmacists that they are going to have to check eligibility and that if they make a mistake they will not get their payment, I think that is appalling and I will say so now. I believe that those people in the Health Insurance Commission with integrity, and those people in the Department who have been negotiating with me, will not do that. But that is what I have been told.

I put on the record so that the public and the pharmacists know, that that is not what I was saying. I am saying, given the intrusive nature of this procedure, that this amendment is justified completely by the Government, and the members of this Senate can see that it is justified. As I said, the minority report to the Finance Committee was not satisfied and that is my justification for this amendment. I will not tolerate being told that if this amendment goes through then the Health Insurance Commission would use eligibility checking and not pay pharmacists. It is an unfair impost on pharmacists. I do not accept that if it happens it is my fault, because I have never suggested it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the committee does not press the requests for amendments made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

We have come to a sobering moment in the history of this legislation. We have come to a point at which, if the Committee does not support the motion I have just moved, a money Bill that has been before it will have been rejected twice. That is not a light matter. I therefore ask that the Committee support this motion at this time.

The Government decided that the wool tax rate for 1991-92 should be set at 15 per cent, with 11 per cent going to debt reduction, 3.5 per cent to promotion and other purposes, and 0.5 per cent to research and development. The Government understands the difficulties in the rural sector at this time. However, it had to take a responsible decision on the rate of wool tax which balanced the need to maintain a viable woolgrowing industry while at the same time protecting the interests of all taxpayers by ensuring that the Commonwealth's contingent liability for the $2.57 billion debt of the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) was not caught up. As the Government has explained repeatedly, the tax rate was but one part of an overall strategy for getting rid of the wool stockpile and the AWC debt. Any change to one part of the strategy places considerable pressure on all other components.

The House has referred the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1991 back to the Senate, having rejected the Senate's request that it amend the wool tax rate to 10 per cent. For its part, the Wool Council of Australia has made available analyses undertaken on its behalf by ACIL Australia Pty Ltd that propose a wool tax of 12 per cent. There seems to be some confusion about the nature of the Government's commitment to facilitate a $200m commercial loan by the Wool Realisation Commission as an advance on the sale of its non-wool assets. I should make it clear that these funds are to be available for drawdown only in that context and not to retire debt, as was made clear in the media release of 30 April 1991 by the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

Furthermore, this loan facility needs to be set in the context of the overriding Government requirement that the Commission will be required to manage the debt so as to reduce the liabilities outstanding at the end of each year by at least the amount required by the announced debt reduction schedule. This too, along with the debt reduction schedule, is set out in the 30 April media release. It is because of the way the $200m loan is included in the calculations prepared by ACIL on behalf of the Wool Council of Australia that it is able to derive a lower estimate of the wool tax required to meet the debt schedule than is suggested by the figures available to me.

The 10 per cent proposed by the Opposition is, in this context, even further removed from reality. The so-called balance sheet document tabled by the Opposition and on which it relies in arguing that that 10 per cent is manageable makes the same mistake as ACIL in the way it treats the Realisation Commission loan. It reflects the unrealistic view that it will be possible to sell $120m of non-wool assets in 1991-92, ignoring the very depressed state of the commercial property market and the best estimates of the current AWC, which owns and manages the properties now, that it does not expect to be able to sell more than $40m to $50m of property in that time.

The figures available to me are based on $50m in non-wool asset sales. As well, the Opposition sees stock sales generating $74m. But the Government's strategy is based on minimal stock sales in 1991-92. To do otherwise will only serve to further depress woolgrowers' incomes. The Government has analysed and re-analysed the best data available. I acknowledge that since the 15 per cent rate was announced on 30 April some factors in the market have changed, such as higher than anticipated prices, lower production estimates for 1991-92 and lower expected AWC debt at 30 June. However, any decision to lower the 15 per cent rate from 1 July 1991 is based on some very big ifs: if prices are better than the expected 475c per kilogram next year; if production forecasts are accurate; if the economies of our major customer countries perform as we anticipate; and if, as was expected, the AWC can sell a certain amount of its woolstore assets in a depressed property market.

For every one per cent reduction in the wool tax rate in 1991-92 it is necessary to sell more wool to meet the debt reduction schedule. But selling more wool from the stockpile depresses the price. The combination of reducing the tax rate and selling more wool means that the Realisation Commission has less income available to meet its commitments. The more wool that is sold from the stockpile, the more prices are reduced, and this impacts on grower incomes. There is, therefore, a trade-off in terms of grower incomes between the level of wool tax and the depressing effects on the price of stockpile sales. Analysis has shown that farm cash income in the short term is lower under a low tax and high stock release strategy compared with a higher tax and lower stock release strategy.

I come back to the competing objectives which I mentioned earlier: that is, keeping a viable industry but also protecting the Commonwealth contingent liability for debt. The more wool that has to be sold from the stockpile if the tax is too low, the more the viability of the industry is affected. The balance between the objectives is therefore upset, which is in no-one's interest. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, my colleague Mr Simon Crean, attempted to negotiate a sensible and prudent operative level of wool tax to apply in 1991-92, somewhat below the 15 per cent maximum rate set in the legislation, on the basis that the operative rate to apply from 1 July would be fixed by regulation. It would be easy for the Government to agree to a 10 per cent or 12 per cent wool tax now in the interests of getting the wool package through the Parliament. But that would be irresponsible and not in the best interests of the woolgrowing industry because it has attached to it a high probability that a higher wool tax would be needed next year, possibly back to 15 per cent or even greater. The Government is simply not prepared to play games with the livelihood of woolgrowers in this way. That is why the House of Representatives has rejected the Senate's request for a 10 per cent wool tax.

I hope that it is recognised in this chamber that, if the Senate persists with its current attitude and fails to pass the package of wool industry Bills it has before it, the Government will have no option but to have the industry continue to operate under the Wool Marketing Act 1987 with the reserve price scheme in suspension under the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Act passed by the Parliament earlier this year. The Parliament needs to realise that in such circumstances 25 per cent remains the operative rate of wool tax. I commend my motion to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this evening those of us who were following this debate had the opportunity to listen to what was probably the first major speech by the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, in the House of Representatives. He contended that he had spent the last 48 hours rehearsing and getting briefed for his brief speech on this issue in the House of Representatives. Unfortunately, he has already proved to be an obstinate and unsympathetic Primary Industries Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: We have just heard from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), representing Mr Crean in this place, and he obviously spent some 48 minutes this evening rehearsing and getting briefed for his seven-minute speech on this issue. This evening Mr Crean levelled certain accusations at the stance taken by the Opposition on this matter. He accused us of trying to create a new scheme that was unworkable, unrealistic, unsustainable and irresponsible. Let me address each of the tenets that Mr Crean put.

As far as being unworkable, I contend-and I am sure that I am supported by all honourable senators on this side of the chamber, including the Australian Democrats-that there are achievable proposals at far less than the 15 per cent level proposed by the Government. We know that there is a better market situation than when the Government put its original estimates down, claiming some 914 million kilos production. The figure has now been downgraded to 881 million kilos. If we add to that our proposed 25 million kilo sale from the stockpile, that makes the 906 million kilos, which is eight million kilos less than the original estimate by the Government and which makes a mockery of its arguments about the figures and the proposals that it is looking at and the proposed impact of the sales from the stockpile.

With regard to being unrealistic, let me turn to the assets sales that have been called into question. The fundamental issue is: whose assets should be sold-the unproductive assets of the Australian Wool Corporation or the assets of the thousands of small growers throughout Australia? The Minister talked about a depressed real estate market. Let me ask the question: in a depressed market, who do we look after? Do we look after people? Labor looks after its big mates in any industry. Big mates again seem to have preoccupied the attention of the Government, and Labor ignores and overlooks the thousands of small growers throughout Australia.

The Minister, Senator Cook, this evening had a preoccupation with contingent liability. What a pity that this Labor Government, the Western Australian Labor Government, the Victorian Labor Government and the South Australian Labor Government for the last few years have never looked at contingent liability. The way in which the Government is looking at the industry is heartless and does not have any affinity with the real issues.

With regard to unsustainability, let me quote the words that immediately followed that accusation by Mr Crean. He said that our arguments were unsustainable `in the process of restructuring the industry'. Let me stress that. He said, `in the process of restructuring the industry'. What is Labor's hidden agenda? Is it `perestroika-ing' Australia, restructuring Australia? We do not want a Russian economy focused on Australia or the wool industry. Simon Crean's first act as a Minister, after his elevation through the trade union movement, into Parliament and now to the primary industries portfolio, was to reverse all his principles of looking after people first. How quickly he has turned; he can now see things only as a bureaucratic Jim Hacker from Yes, Minister.

With regard to irresponsibility, it was contended that our proposals were not in the best interests of the industry. What rubbish! We have seen the recent actions of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government, using the bula spirituality methodology to kill off Australia's major resource projects, so it is now surprising that the Prime Minister and the Australian Labor Party have not discovered another dreamtime creation spirit that espouses extra ties on primary industry. Perhaps the Prime Minister can ask the Resource Assessment Commission to act as his mystic on this occasion.

Senator Cook's threat of a 25 per cent tax needs to be thrown out the window. That can be changed tomorrow by way of regulation, and the Minister knows it. If he dares to go above the 15 per cent that he is proposing in the Government's Bills currently, he will stand condemned for absolute hypocrisy.

What about the flow on consequences of any of these actions and the effects on the hundreds and thousands of small supporting towns and communities throughout Australia? We have responded; we have looked at that issue; we have taken into account not only the financial figures that we can sustain but also the sociological, the personal, and all of those immediate matters that have to be addressed on behalf of remote and rural Australia.

The Government contends that our figures are wrong and yet it has not tabled in either the previous debate or this one any substantive schedules, tables, facts or calculations. It has come in and shot down anyone else's submissions or proposals but it has not put anything else on the table to look at. With regard to the $200m interest free loan, we need also to look at what is now being said and compare that with what Minister Kerin said previously. Back in April of this year, in a press statement dated 30 April, Minister Kerin said:
The Commonwealth will facilitate a $200m interest free loan over two years as an advance on the sale of the property assets. This will enable the industry to maximise the return from property sales.

Where is the reference to what Senator Cook has referred to tonight as `draw down only' facility? There is no reference to short term bridging finance. What was the hidden agenda? These figures impact on any calculation. A couple of days ago in the debate in this chamber I tabled figures that included the $200m in our calculations. We have now taken that $200m out of the table and recalculated the figures. The bottom line is still showing figures of 9.7 per cent, 9.2 per cent, and 8.7 per cent-under the 10 per cent proposed by the Opposition. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. There is pressure throughout the rural community. But, very importantly, the Minister has not addressed all of the components that properly apply. We need to continue to understand that the wool industry will not collapse tomorrow if the Government does not get its way. The wool industry is vibrant. The people who are involved in it have been there for as long as the history of Australia and they will continue to be there. What they need is our support, dedication and interest, not this playing of games for mates, with monopoly money running around the table, that Labor so often carries on with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have reached a depressing situation here where the Parliament of Australia is unable to resolve a problem which confronts the great industry of Australia-the great industry which has a history spanning almost the entire period that our civilisation has been on this continent. Yet we are sitting here tonight throwing insults across the chamber, unable to come to a position which will assure the future of the great industry itself. It is bigger than any of us. It will remain despite our machinations and inability to solve this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: It will remain because Australia is uniquely qualified to grow wool. Australia has a comparative advantage over every other country on this planet in the growing of wool. It has the history, the expertise, the climate and the topography. With those things, here we sit doing our best to muck it up. I was hoping that this Government would stop fiddling about with the figures, would stop sitting in a prima donna fashion on one particular figure and could recognise that there have been many other figures which have applied in the history of the wool industry.

Throughout the history of our wool industry, there have been production levels and price levels which contradict the assertions made by the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean). When trying to explain the position to me, the new Minister seemed to be particularly hung up on the idea that, if more production was released onto the market, there would be necessarily a reduction in the price received. That may be so in a number of economists' calculations and their clean, precise and neat supply and demand graphs.

The wool industry itself, however, is not neat and clean. It is a farm industry, and farm industry has a lot of movement in it. It is described in economists' terms as an industry that has a high elasticity of demand. It is also an industry that spans the globe. It is an international industry with impinging factors from all aspects of the international scene. It is a special industry that does not equate well to the neatness of economists' graphs. It is an industry in which there is often more emphasis on fashion emotion, trends and the weather than there is on what the latest figures in the economists' graphs show. That is why, when I was hoping that this Government would recognise that, I was expecting a little more than another set of graphs which could easily be disproved by the history of the industry itself.

The wool industry is an industry which at times has had much greater production than it has now and, at the same time, a higher price level than it has now. That brings the nonsense to our new Minister's claim that, if more wool is released onto the market, the price necessarily falls. The huge number of other impinging factors should illustrate to anybody who knows our wool industry that that is so much nonsense.

What did I expect to see from this Government rather than the magic 15 per cent, 12 per cent, 10 per cent, et cetera? I did not want to pick a box. I did not want to pick a number. I did not want to see a used car market, which is how I thought the Minister described it earlier tonight in the lower House. If that is what he thinks this industry is, that illustrates perfectly his inadequate understanding of our greatest industry.

We were told in the contribution of Senator Cook, the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in this chamber, that the Government does not have any other option. The Government does have options. If there had been imagination, creativity and a few basic recognitions brought to this problem, we would have seen more options. If we could have seen a recognition that the wool industry is not a used car market where the great negotiators meet and ask each other for their best offers, and meet somewhere in the middle, if we had seen a recognition that the wool industry responds not simply to manipulation of figures but to the things I described earlier such as fashion image, emotion and the weather, and if we had seen a recognition that this is a very special industry, perhaps we would have seen the creativity necessary from this Government.

Instead, we saw confusion. That confusion has been described here. We picked on a figure of $200m. The Minister in this chamber introduced this argument about the $200m. What concerns me about that is there was some sort of confusion over what this $200m interest free loan facility was all about. I suggest that, if there is confusion, that confusion is directly the fault of the Government. If the Government is incapable of presenting to the people who have a vested interest in this industry, who are responsible for the future of the industry, an interpretation which is comprehensible to those people, that is as a result of the Government's inabilities. The growers' representative bodies and the coalition were unsure of what that $200m was all about. I thought I understood it after I asked the Minister's advisers, but to make certain, I asked for it in writing.

Senator Tambling read the plain statement by Minister Kerin, and it seemed plain enough to me. But when I asked the Minister's office to translate that plain statement so that I could see where it belonged in the calculations, I received this response in writing:
Senator Bell,
The $200m is not $200m off the debt up front.
The purpose of the loan is to give the AWC some interest free money to smooth their cash flows as and when needed-
I repeat that, `as and when needed'-
through the first two years.
As this money has to be paid back by the WRC, borrowing it all on 1 July 1991 would result in $200m debt to pay off and $200m new debt-or no change in total debt.
Do honourable senators understand this?

Without discussing the issue in depth with whoever the General Manager of WRC will be, I imagine that the $200m will be borrowed in bits and pieces to smooth the cash flows of wool tax and receipts from sales in and interest and capital repayments out. The logical way to go would be to borrow only what was needed as and when needed, because each borrowing creates new debt.

There would also be some cost involved in changing the nature of the debt package, eg getting a more advantageous mix of terms and currencies, and this interest free loan could be used to give the funds needed to do that in the first place. Borrowing to do something like that could in fact result in no further debt actually arising in the longer term.

There is another sentence in that document, but it is irrelevant to the sense of it-if that makes sense to those who are listening. As far as I was concerned, I was just a little lost, and I am not at all surprised that there was some confusion about the purpose of the $200m. I prefer the statement attributed to Minister Kerin which was read earlier by Senator Tambling. Tonight, an interpretation was given to us which I am absolutely certain is not in accordance with the explanation I just read.

The confusion is further increased by the multitude of lists of tables and figures which were presented. When asked for, they were finally presented for the people who are supposed to be making a decision to take into account. It is not only the confusion over the major component of the $200m debt. There are other figures which have been presented to us to assist in our decision making. Quite often, the figures have emanated from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE). In pursuing that group and asking repeatedly for the sorts of figures that I thought were necessary to enable calculations to be made, I have consistently received changing figures. In discussions with the people with whom I have been asked to negotiate I have called them a series of `shifting sands'. It is upon those shifting sands that I have refused to accept that a firm 15 per cent is the only answer possible.

Take, for example, the ABARE figures which have attempted to indicate the best possible price to be achieved for clean wool per kilogram as sold on the open market internationally. Apart from the fact that I am absolutely certain that I heard a representative of that group give a figure around the 300c level at a Wool Council of Australia meeting some months ago, the recent set of figures started at a level of 435c, followed some time later by a figure of 450c, followed very recently by a figure of 475c and, just yesterday, a figure of 485c was introduced into the calculations.

The question I have for anyone who wants to try to make sense of this is: why is it we are asked to accept a fixed figure of 15 per cent in these shifting sands and amongst this confusion? I contend that while these figures are shifting there is the opportunity to bring about a different solution-a figure which was not fixed at 15 per cent but which was fixed to the future of the industry; a figure which recognised the history of the industry; and a figure which was not fixed but which was totally ignorant of the wool industry itself and of any special qualities that this great industry has. While I am confronted with those things, I am continually reminded that what this Government is unable to do is to reveal its understanding of our rural industries and of what is in fact best for them. A bureaucratic flavour runs through these things which does not reveal the capacity to deliver what the industry wants.

I must explain the dilemma in which the Democrats find themselves. It is a dilemma which I do not think should be envied by anyone in this country. I know that our dilemma is not as immediate and painful as many of the dilemmas in which our woolgrowers find themselves, but when we have to make a decision relative to them it causes considerable pain. That pain is not limited to intellectual pain or pain that gives one a headache because one has been here so long; it is a pain which is actually heartfelt. It is a pain that is delivered to us because, although I think there is every reason to be able to justify a figure of about 12 per cent and a combination of measures that were very similar to those that were recommended by the Vines Committee of inquiry into wool marketing, which paid a great deal more attention than 48 hours to the industry and which came up with recommendations that were endorsed at the time, we have been unable to convince sufficient people to have that passed through this place.

In the absence of any sort of creative package from the Government to endorse that or to help it along in any way, we are left with no other option. The Government says that it does not have any options. We do not have any-that is our invidious position-and in the absence of options we have to stay exactly where we are.
