SPEECH.PARA: Then there is the point which Mr Crean made in the other place tonight, and which Senator Cook has also made, that if wool from the stockpile goes on the market the price will drop. But something that the Minister in this chamber has failed to point out is that, because prices have come down since we did away with the reserve floor price, demand has grown. After all, wool once had a 5 per cent share of the world's fibre market, then with the high prices we had it went down to 3 per cent. That was the whole trouble. The stockpile built up, but as the prices have eased the flow is much faster. He forgot to mention that.

As to the selling of assets, let me once again strengthen the argument. As Senator Walters has already said, if we have solid assets returning 14 per cent they will be readily saleable. One of the advisers is smiling. Mr Crean said tonight: why sell on a depressed market? Mr Chairman, can you tell me what the market will be next year? I reckon that under this Government the property market will be greatly reduced in 12 months time from what it is now. That 14 per cent return provides a good chance to get out. That is where the best premium will come from, as it is a higher return. I have said in here before that when an organisation goes into a property that is already tenanted it could normally expect only a 6 or 7 per cent return and the rest would be picked up on the first renewal of the lease, but in this case we are starting with 14 per cent. Senator Cook knows nothing about property development, except from when he was running his unions and causing strikes. He knows that about it. I do not think Mr Crean knows much better.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are embarrassing all your colleagues, Senator. Please sit down.

—I am forecasting a drop in the second half of next year, and property prices will go with it. The woolgrowers are behind the coalition and the Democrats. In the short time since the last debate I have faxed all the shires in Western Australia to alert them to what is going on and advised them to send faxes to the Government. The Democrats have been faxed enough; they have been targeted enough. I know that around 3,000 signatures came out of my effort, and Senator Crane would have generated just as many or more. That indicates the number of people who are behind us.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook also knows that, as the Act now stands, the marketing system can continue till 1 July 1992. He has failed to tell us. He has threatened us, just as Mr Crean has threatened us, with a rate of 25 per cent. He knows, and Mr Crean should know, that 30 per cent, plus a 10 per cent levy, is the maximum. That figure can be set at any level up to 30 per cent. That is in the Act. The Government can do what it likes. It cannot threaten us by saying that, if we hold up the passage of this legislation, we will not have a marketing system or that the figure will be set at 25 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Throw out this package and what is there now will apply.

—The Government does not have to set the figure at 25 per cent. It can set it anywhere between nought and 30 per cent. He fails to tell us that. If Senator Cook reckons the Government is going to set it at 25 per cent, he can go ahead and see what happens in the bush. Then, of course, we have the case of the $200m loan. The Government has changed the rules since Mr Kerin delivered the second reading speech. It has completely changed the rules, but that has already been handled by Senator Bell.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I will tell the Government what I told it the other night: that the eyes and ears of Australia are on us to see what sort of--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is an embarrassment. No wonder his colleagues are shaking their heads.
—Senator Faulkner would know a lot about wool! He probably has not been beyond the Blue Mountains to find out. He would know nought about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that the woolgrowers of Australia are relying on us to make a suitable decision, the right decision to keep them in place. As has already been pointed out time and time again, the Government has to make up its mind whether it is going to sell the woolgrowers' assets in Melbourne or in the south of France, or wherever. It is better to sell these assets than sell up farmers in the bush, because they are the woolgrowers' assets and no-one else's assets.

The Minister, Mr Crean, in the other place, has not told us about the big package of redundancy he may have for employees of the Wool Corporation. Is the Government keeping the tax up to make a bigger package to sell the employees out? No-one has asked that question yet, but I request the Minister to answer it now. In conclusion, I urge the Government to think again before it turns down the request made on behalf of the growers that we get back to 10 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the occasion of what is a fairly significant debate for the wool industry, I wish to make a number of very brief observations in relation to the speech made by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). First, I note the Minister's somewhat penny-pinching attitude in relation to the wool industry, which strikes me as rather peculiar given that the Minister comes from a government which has recently spent, for example, $1.6 billion baling out its mates in Victoria as a result of their failed State Bank of Victoria. The Government has also given the Victorians over $200m in a special tax package and has recently approved a $300m increase in borrowings through the Australian Loan Council. Of course, there is a difference because there they were baling out friends and here they are baling out a productive Australian export industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems entirely hypocritical of this Government and of this Minister to come before the Committee today and say, `We cannot afford to give the wool industry a chance because we are going to watch where the pennies go'. It is not really the Government's pennies at all. What we are talking about is an industry which has made a long term contribution to Australia's economic strength and an industry which, given the right circumstances and the right opportunities, will continue to do so.

There was one aspect of the Minister's speech which I found particularly disturbing and that was his assertion-it was nothing more than an assertion-that it would be possible for only $50m of assets to be sold out of the Australian Wool Corporation because there is a depressed commercial property market. Maybe the Minister does not understand this, but there is a very depressed rural property market. The depression in prices of rural properties far exceeds the drop in prices of commercial properties in the city.

This has a number of very significant consequences. The first of those is that the value of the properties has gone down and therefore the availability of credit and finance to woolgrowers has necessarily contracted, because the amount of money that a bank is willing to lend to the woolgrower on security is based upon the valuation of the asset. As prices drop, the value of the assets drops and therefore the credit limit available to the woolgrower contracts as well. This has a particular significance when one notes that this year woolgrowers are looking at a negative net cash operating surplus. In other words, the average woolgrower is going to have to borrow just to keep the farm operating-not to put the food on the table or any of the other things that are necessary to maintain a family and to maintain dependants. However, money will not be available to those woolgrowers because, as a result of the policies of this Government, rural farm prices have dropped.

This drives the woolgrowers to the second desperate option, which is that, with no money available for them to borrow, they must sell. As we see in a very depressed rural property market, the equity that those wool growing families have built up-in some cases over generations-will be lost entirely. Therefore, we come to the very simple choice: do we ask the woolgrowers to go cap in hand to the banks, only to be turned away and forced to sell their properties, forced to give up the equity that their families have worked generations to produce; or do we say that the Corporation must sell its non-core assets?

There is no logic in the argument from the Minister that there will be only $50m of sales and no more. The estimates of the sales of the non-core assets of the Corporation which have been made by honourable senators on this side of the chamber and by the Opposition in the other place are entirely realistic and are based upon the fact that the commercial property market has declined. We have taken that into consideration and we have come up with a very reasonable figure of some $120m.

The Minister should not attempt finally to say to this Committee that unless we do what he wants, we will have to live with 25 per cent tax. As Senator Panizza has so eloquently said, there is no need for a 25 per cent tax. A 25 per cent tax forced on the wool industry when this Government could, by regulation, bring the tax down lower, is just an act of pure thuggery. It shows the Government's contempt for the wool industry. It shows its contempt for the deliberations of the Committee, and that is why we on this side of the chamber, the coalition and the Australian Democrats, will not stand for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a lot in the debate so far tonight about graphs and forecasts for the sale of the existing stockpile and also about the property market and its fluctuations. What we have not heard much about is the plight of the woolgrowers themselves. Senator O'Chee just mentioned that to some degree. I have been listening to the farmers on this subject for a few weeks now. What I have heard over and over again is that farmers have said that they cannot possibly pay more than the 10 per cent. Thousands will be forced to leave their farms. The banks will foreclose on them. They will have to leave and sell out at very reduced prices, as Senator O'Chee just pointed out.

SPEECH.PARA: The worst thing that we can allow to happen to rural Australia is for the farmers to leave their farms. Rural Australia is in crisis, and I think some people in this place have not really got that message yet. There have already been huge problems in the wheat industry. Many of those same farmers who have had problems with the wheat industry are also woolgrowers. Environmentally and socially we cannot afford to allow Australia's farmers to be forced from their farms. Environmentally it is a disaster. The land degradation which has already been a huge problem in this country will only be worsened by woolgrowers and farmers being forced off their land. They must stay there. The best that we can possibly do is to encourage farmers to stay on their land and to look after it as they are increasingly doing. They are very aware of the fact that they have got to look after their land for future generations and that it cannot be degraded further. It will be degraded if farmers have to walk off their land in large numbers, and a tax greater than 10 per cent will ensure that that happens.

What about the social cost to farmers and their families? What about the costs to the country towns which depend upon the rural industry? I do not think the Government has really thought very much about the extra costs that will be incurred on the social welfare system by the break up of families, about the emotional stress and the social dislocation that will occur not only for woolgrowers but also for the country towns which revolve around the wool industry. We have not heard any kind of compassion expressed as far as that is concerned from the Government. The 15 per cent wool tax has been rejected by the Senate in favour of a 10 per cent tax, and the fact that the Government now comes back and says, `Okay. If you are not going to agree to the 15 per cent, you will cop the whole 25 per cent.', means that it does not understand that woolgrowers will be forced off the land.

This will force the woolgrowers who are able to remain on the land to refuse to pay, in solidarity with those who are forced off. I have heard this from a number of woolgrowers. They will not pay. So the Government has not got that message either: that it will be faced with what amounts to a massive riot from the rural community in Australia if it is not sensible and if it does not listen to reason in this debate.

We have heard a lot about the facts and the figures. All kinds of figures have been produced. Of course, it is a bit like the Bible. It can be used to prove anything. Statistics can be used to prove anything too, but I think in this situation what we have got to listen to is the voice of the farmers. They have told us over and over again that they cannot afford to pay more than 10 per cent. They will not be able to stay on their farms. They will not be able to continue as woolgrowers.

I am speaking particularly about the small woolgrowers here, the mixed farmers. I think that we have a duty to rural Australia-a duty to the land which we cannot allow to degrade any further and a duty to the people who have been the backbone of the nation for so many generations to ensure that they do not have to leave their farms, which would cause massive social dislocation as well as further environmental degradation. I beg the Government not to be so pig-headed as to come back in here and say, `Okay. If you are not going to cop the 15 per cent, we will land you with the 25 per cent'. It is just not acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first observation that one must make concerns the presentation tonight in the House of Representatives on the occasion of the first foray of the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) into an agriculture debate. I found it arrogant, I found it harsh and I found it cruel. It showed little understanding of the situation that exists. It was just a knockdown exercise, not an exercise in understanding. One is forced to comment in the strongest possible terms about the threat that was inherent in what was said tonight, and it was also repeated by Senator Cook. They know full well that the 25 per cent figure is set by regulation. To threaten this Senate and to threaten the woolgrowers of this country is an absolute disgrace. It may be that there are still some unions in this country that can do it; but I am damn sure of one thing-I will not be intimidated by that sort of talk, and I am quite sure that that comment applies to all honourable senators on this side of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider for a moment what was said tonight in relation to redundancies. What a different story that is from what we hear about the waterfront or the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) inspectors in Victoria. There was this special allocation that was slipped through from the Federal Government to the Victorian Government last week. The Government adopts a series of double standards, which is an absolute disgrace.

I want to emphasise what my colleagues and others have said here tonight about asset sales. As far as I am concerned, not one farm should be sold until such time as a proper assets sale program is put in place. After all, who owns those assets?

We also heard tonight in the comments made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy reference to the AWC-I was not too certain about whether he was talking about the Australian Wool Council or the Australian Wool Corporation. However, it does not really matter. Who has led this industry of ours into this mess, alongside Minister Kerin? Who has put the $1.8m of growers' funds that were supposed to devolve back to them at risk? Who were the managers of that? It was a combination of the Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Wool Council. In these terms, that is what we are really talking about. That is where the advice is coming from and I cannot give much credibility to it.

Unfortunately, this is a debate about figures, although I recognise the social implications that Senator Vallentine and others have talked about tonight, and they are very important. But it is worth looking at the figures. The Government will not give us any figures. It must have something to hide. It will not put them on the table. We have put ours on the table and the ACIL Australia figures are on the table. Why can we not see a full package? Let us consider what was said in the House of Representatives tonight. Minister Crean said that a figure of 14 per cent would raise $342m. From that, one can work out very easily that the total income from 881 million kilos next year would be of the order of $2.442 billion to $2.443 billion. Using those figures, that works out at a price of 277c a kilo greasy or 415c clean. That is an incredibly low figure to pick considering, first, what has occurred, secondly, the ABARE predictions and, thirdly, the situation that exists with the futures market. I will not read out all the figures and I seek leave to have some figures on the wool futures market incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. I just point out that the selling price from June 1991 to October 1992 ranges from 662c to 620c, and that is a very good indication of the fact that the world has confidence in the Australian wool industry. We should have confidence in the Australian wool industry and so should the Government, because that is what this exercise is about.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one other set of figures which I think needs emphasising here. They were quoted by Senator Tambling tonight in terms of the picture that was painted by the Minister of depressing the market by the proposal of the coalition for sales of wool from the stockpile. I want to say that that 25 million kilos of wool we put in there to raise $74m, at 450c clean, is equal to 2.7 per cent of the total estimated production for this year. If one looks at the fact that the 914 million kilos has been taken down or readjusted backwards to 881 million kilos, that is a drop of 3.6 million kilos. The Vines Committee reports were predicated and put together on the basis of 914 million kilos. That still leaves a situation one per cent better off than when those figures were put together.

I finish my comments by saying that it is absolutely crucial to the future of this industry that the tax level which is put in place is realistic and sustainable. The coalition has put figures on the table which are sustainable. The knocking down of those figures has been based on emotion and unrealistic figures. I end by saying that there is no way in this place that we can be intimidated, as I said before, by the threat, `We will put a 25 per cent tax on you if you don't toe our line'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not come as any surprise to my colleagues in this chamber to hear me say that I do not go along with some of the inferences which have been drawn during this debate reflecting on the abilities of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, or indeed the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, simply because they have been members or officials of trade unions. I was a bit concerned, however, when I heard the phrase `restructuring of this industry'. As I understand it, that was the phrase used by the Minister in the other place. I am a bit concerned about this because I know that people within this industry have been restructuring to such an extent that the industry is a very efficient industry.

SPEECH.PARA: From what I have heard and from what has been said-I think Senator Walters said it during the debate tonight and it has been said elsewhere-I am concerned that some of the very large corporations or firms in this industry would not mind seeing an exodus of the smaller growers who, by the way, are very efficient. I would be very concerned about that because, as Senator Bell said, this is not an industry to which is to be applied with ease certain economic axioms, because there are all sorts of variables in this industry which are not present in some other industries with which we may be familiar.

I will not keep the Committee at this hour of the morning. I must say that I have not heard anything in this debate tonight-or this morning-which can influence me to change the way I voted 48 hours ago. I intend to vote against the motion which has been moved by the Minister.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Cook's) be agreed to.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 21 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) For the financial year 1989-90, what was the total number of war widow pension recipients.
(2) What was the cost to the department of such pensions in the financial year 1989-90.
(3) For the financial year 1989-90, how many war widow pensioners had remarried since first becoming eligible for the pension.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The number of war widows increased during the financial year 1989-90. At the beginning of the 1989-90 financial year there were 74,743 war widow pension recipients and this had increased to 76,471 by the end of the 1989-90 financial year.
(2) The total cost to the Department for war widow pensions in the 1989-90 financial year was $573 million. This includes the domestic allowance.

(3) All widows who remarry or were remarried after 29 May 1984 retain their war widow pensions. There is no requirement for widows to inform the Department when they remarry and therefore no records are kept.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 21 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: For each of the Repatriation General Hospitals, what percentage of the average cost per occupied bed day, and the average cost per adjusted occupied bed day, is accounted for by: (a) salaries, wages and related payments; (b) administration; (c) services; (d) supplies; and (e) other; please specify.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: COMPONENT COSTS OF AN OCCUPIED BED DAY-REPATRIATION GENERAL HOSPITALS
Average cost of occupied bed days ...
Average cost of adjusted occupied bed days ...

1. Repatriation General Hospitals, in common with other hospitals in Australia and elsewhere do not have systems available which would permit the detailed costing of occupied bed days and outpatient occasions of service. Occupied bed day costs are an average of inpatient costs over the whole hospital. To give a truer indication of overall treatment costs a conversion used in the health industry is to equate 5.75 occasions of service as the cost equivalent of an occupied bed day. The converted outpatient occasions of service are added to inpatient bed days to give the adjusted occupied bed days.
2. Given their derivation the percentages sought are identical for both occupied bed days and adjusted occupied bed days.
3. The percentages given are based on the total running costs of each Hospital for 1989/90.
4. Terms such as administration, services, supplies have widely differing meanings. Those chosen are as follows:
Salaries: include salaries, wages, overtime, superannuation, payments to visiting medical officers and Comcare.
Administrative salaries, including estimates for overtime, superannuation and Comcare have been outlined separately to help in estimating administrative costs.
fuel, light, power, vehicles, post and telephones
central procurement, medical consumables, provisions, stores
repairs and maintenance, furniture, other expenditure.
5. Expenditure on capital equipment is not included.

6. Generally there are fewer privately insured patients or compensation cases in Repatriation Institutions than in other similar acute care public hospitals. As a result more patients are provided treatment by hospital-salaried medical staff.
